fields.headline: Coaches in a corner of some foreign field
fields.trailText: We may have Sven at the helm, but Swedish football still reveres a Yorkshireman and former national manager called George.
fields.body:
Mea culpas, sure, and xenophobia most certainly but, however many prostrate confessions are wrung from this corner, it still makes the blood boil that Britain's cupboard is allegedly so bare that it cannot find a native coach to take charge of its national teams. Then again, what's new - and, to be sure, what's sauce for the goose ...

Britons have been presuming to teach the rest of the world since organised sports began. England's football team may now be under the stewardship of a Swede called Sven. In Sweden their football still reveres a Yorkshireman called George.

George Raynor was born a miner's son in 1907. Football was the boy's passion and by 20 he was a professional, playing for Sheffield United, Mansfield, Bury and Rotherham. During the war he made a name for himself as an enlightened and inventive football coach but on demob no League directors were interested in hiring a has-been journeyman. So, horizons broad, in 1946 he took a job with a club in Sweden.

Within two years he was the national coach and his first return to his homeland was when Sweden won the 1948 Olympic Games gold medal at Wembley, sweeping aside the favourites Denmark and Czechoslovakia on the way. Raynor's maxim was "control the ball, then let it do the work for you like a dance - slow, slow, quick-quick, slow".

In the 1950 World Cup in Brazil, Raynor's Swedes made the final pool, finishing third. They also won the bronze medal in the 1952 Helsinki Olympics and in 1958, on home soil, they lost a vividly compelling World Cup final to the wondrous Brazil of Pele and Vava - after which the King of Sweden knighted his country's revered Yorkie.

The prophet without honour then merrily organised a 3-2 defeat of England in 1959, only their third at Wembley. He had club success with Juventus and Lazio in Italy and with the earnings bought himself a retirement house in Skegness. After a short brief as assistant to Jesse Carver, another manager of European repute, at then Third Division (South) Coventry City, and a year at Doncaster, probably England's most successful international manager took a job as a storeman at Butlin's holiday camp and saw out his footballing days as "honorary manager" of Skegness Town.

For most of last century the introverted British game and its public were oblivious to the achievements of their coaches overseas - enlightened missionaries like Carver, Leslie Lievesley and Ted Crawford in Italy, the Johns, Madden and Dick, in Prague, Glasgow's JT Robertson in Vienna and Budapest.

In those two cities the rheumy eyes of footballing greybeards still glisten at the mention of Jimmy Hogan. The tiny Lancastrian had been inspired to the point of glorious obsession in his teens by Lancashire's Scottish "imports" to the local League clubs, to whom ball control and short passing seemed inborn.

Again, with no heady name as a player, by 1910 he had taken his passion to coach in Holland. By 1912 he had been "snapped up" by the father of Austrian football, Hugo Meisl. Together they made Austria a force throughout Europe. Then Hogan did the same for Hungary, laying the basis for their resplendence in the 40s and 50s. When Hungary tore England to shreds at Wembley in 1953, wee Jimmy from Nelson was honoured guest in the royal box, grinning.

In the 1930s Hogan was in charge at Aston Villa. Brian Glanville recalled Hogan telling him: "The chairman told me he had no time for my theories about football. 'Just get the ball in the bloody net, that's what I want.' Hogan had to go to hospital and the Brummie burgher sacked him.

Bill Garbutt was just as much a pioneer. Nor could the Arsenal, Blackburn and England winger get a coaching post at home when he finished playing. He went to Genoa in 1912 and steered them to the Italian title. Then he joined the British army until 1918. More success followed at Roma and Napoli.

He took Bilbao to the Spanish title, was extradited penniless during the Spanish civil war and took over AC Milan. In 1940 he lost his wife and family in allied bombing, grew a beard, went "underground" and ran the local resistance. In 1946 he rejoined Genoa as coach, in which seaport a few ancients will still smile widely and remember fondly "magnifico Mee-ster Gar-butt".

fields.headline: O'Neill's Celtic boost for Collymore
fields.trailText: Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill has admitted he is interested in Stan Collymore, transfer-listed by Bradford City and looking for his latest club.
fields.body:
Celtic's manager Martin O'Neill has admitted he is interested in Stan Collymore, transfer-listed by Bradford City and looking for his latest club.

Although O'Neill, who last season took the striker to Leicester, has rejected a proposed swap deal involving Celtic's Tommy Johnson, he does see Collymore as a possible recruit.

"There are certain people who come into a short-term category," he said, "and I know Stan has said he'd love to join me.

"Handling players is my job; it's not a major concern. If I felt a short-term deal was the answer, I'd do it. I might want to fill a couple of spots until the end of the season."

O'Neill also confirmed that the Brazilian defender Rafael Scheidt, who was bought for £5m in John Barnes's time as head coach, has no future at Celtic. "Coming here was a massive culture shock for him," said the manager. "I think he really wanted to go home."

Tore Andre Flo is confident he will recover quickly from an injury which is less serious than first thought. Rangers' £12m striker worried the manager Dick Advocaat after suffering an ankle knock against Uruguay Soccer Club in Florida in midweek. Advocaat already has Billy Dodds and Michael Mols out, both injured.

Flo said: "I twisted my ankle but I've tried it out in training and it's not too bad."

The former Old Firm managers Walter Smith and Billy McNeill have backed plans to turn yesterday's meeting of Celtic and Rangers Over-35s into a regular event.

An Ibrox crowd of 50,002 - the second-highest British football attendance of the weekend - watched Smith's Rangers side beat McNeill's Celtic 4-1 with Ally McCoist scoring a hat-trick.

Celtic took an early lead through Alan McInally's header but Ray Wilkins cancelled that out and then McCoist scored his three.

Shaka Hislop will be back in West Ham's goal at Charlton tonight after being forced out at half-time with a knee injury against Sunderland nine days ago.

He will find a different three-man defence in front of him after a busy week in the transfer market for his manager Harry Redknapp. The trio who played the season's opening game were Javier Margas, Stuart Pearce and Igor Stimac. But Margas has retired after knee trouble, Pearce is banned and Stimac is still injured.

Christian Dailly will make his debut and Redknapp has added two other defenders, the Frenchman Sebastien Schemmel and Norwegian Raggy Soma, to his squad. In midfield, West Ham hope to have Michael Carrick back after a hamstring injury.

fields.headline: Nationwide  round-up
fields.trailText: Gillingham gave Alan Smith's Crystal Palace something to think about before Wednesday's Worthington Cup semi-final second leg at Liverpool, taking a two-goal lead at Selhurst Park before the hosts recovered to snatch a late point.
fields.body:
Gillingham gave Alan Smith's Crystal Palace something to think about before Wednesday's Worthington Cup semi-final second leg at Liverpool, taking a two-goal lead at Selhurst Park before the hosts recovered to snatch a late point.

Mark Saunders scored both Gills goals and the margin looked sufficient until Dougie Freedman and Mikael Forssell saved the day. "It's almost impossible to be on top form all of the time but I'm happy with the point," said Smith.

Norwich City's manager Nigel Worthington gained his first win since being confirmed in the post as Zema Abbey, a £350,000 signing from Cambridge, got the only goal against visiting QPR, still second from bottom.

Mid-table Portsmouth recorded their first win in seven league and cup matches, 2-1 against visiting Wimbledon, all the goals coming in the first half. Lee Bradbury opened the scoring from the spot, Jason Euell equalised but Nigel Quashie hit the winner from 25 yards.

A mistake from Stockport's goalkeeper Lee Jones allowed Kevin Donovan to snatch a draw for Grimsby with almost the last kick of the game. "Lee should have dealt with the situation," said Andy Kilner, Stockport's manager. "But it's only two defeats in 13 games now; three months ago we might have lost that one." Jarkko Wiss got County's goal in the first half.

In the Second Division Wigan and Walsall both won to keep the pressure on the leaders Millwall, whose match at Colchester was postponed. Wigan beat Oldham 3-1 with their substitute Neil Roberts, a £450,000 signing from Wrexham, scoring twice in the second half. John Sheridan opened the scoring for the visitors, who had gone eight games unbeaten, but Lee Ashcroft levelled just before the interval.

Two goals apiece from Brett Angell and Paul Hall and one from George Leitao gave Walsall their 5-1 win against Swansea, who have won only one of their last 15. "We have to carry on from this in Tuesday's game with Rotherham and in the match at Cambridge on Saturday," said Ray Graydon, Walsall's manager.

In the Third Division Chesterfield's 3-0 win at Darlington eased them nine points clear of Brighton, whose game with Barnet was postponed.

At the bottom Carlisle's 2-2 draw at Hartlepool moved them within two points of Exeter, who lost an ill-tempered game at Torquay 2-1. City had their captain Chris Curran, a former Torquay player, sent off in the sixth minute, conceded a penalty which Mark Ford converted and then saw Kevin Parker come off the bench to hit the last-minute winner.

fields.headline: Website prosecutions 'would not work'
fields.trailText: The government's intention may be good, but the news that the Department of Health has told internet providers they could be prosecuted for relaying information that breaks British adoption rules was last night greeted with scepticism and cynicism.
fields.body:
The government's intention may be good, but the news that the Department of Health has told internet providers they could be prosecuted for relaying information that breaks British adoption rules was last night greeted with scepticism and cynicism.

Leading industry figures and experts believe that the nature and scale of the internet, as well as the status of those who provide access to the web, will make it impossible to enforce the rule.

They also point to a European directive, expected to come into force in Britain in the next two years, which defines internet service providers (ISPs) merely as conduits for information who cannot be responsible for content. This rule would seem to contradict the warning.

The Department of Health also came under fire for failing to consult the industry properly before sounding its warning and it is bound to be heavily criticised by civil liberties campaigners who will see the development as another attack on free speech.

ISPs have three main functions. They provide access to the web, so theoretically they could stop particular sites being reached. But they say that would not be feasible as it would require almost unlimited resources. And banning a site would give it notoriety prompting many more people to look at it. The British government also cannot try to shut down a foreign website at source because it would have no jurisdiction to do so.

The second main function of the ISPs is to provide "hosted web space" for websites. ISPs do have more control here, but even a small website may have 20 pages. So if an ISP hosted just 100 websites, it would have 2,000 pages to monitor.

Third, the ISPs provide news groups, or bulletin boards where articles can be posted. An article posted with an ISP's news group - for example, on adoption - will be picked up by linked news groups run by other ISPs worldwide. Checking everything on the news groups would be impossible.

What will particularly annoy the ISPs about the government's warning is that they are considered world leaders in self-regulation. ISPs are not licensed and do not have to register anywhere. But about 130 internet firms in the UK are members of the Internet Services Providers Association, which has been at great pains to provide a code of practice aimed at addressing the problem of illegal material. Formed in 1996, the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF) also works with the internet companies, the police and government, to tackle problems such as child pornography sites.

There appears to have been little consultation between the Department of Health and the industry. The IWF heard about what was afoot only when officials from other government departments began ringing it late last week.

Both the IWF and ISPA believe that the Department of Health's approach is flawed.

David Kerr, IWF's chief executive, said: "I think it's been generally accepted by ministers and the police that internet service providers don't and can't be expected to know what's on their servers. The department seems to be ignoring this basic point. This tactic is very unlikely to work and will put the department in conflict with the industry in the UK and in the rest of the world."

Mr Kerr said the industry had tried to stop material appearing on the web which would be illegal to publish in other forms in the UK - for example, child and extreme adult pornography. Although ISPs cannot monitor all the material passing through, once they are told about such material, they can remove it.

But another huge complication is the status of the ISPs. Many argue that they are not publishers but facilitators. The possible counter-argument, that they are indeed publishers because they own the servers carrying the material, has not been explored in the courts.

There are few precedents. Last year a New York lawyer sued the net firm Prodigy after an impostor sent obscene messages purporting to come from his 15-year-old son. The state's highest court threw out the claim, arguing that "an ISP, like a telephone company, is merely a conduit", and was backed by the supreme court.

Here, however, Mr Justice Morland decided in the high court that the internet company Demon Internet was liable for defamatory comments published about the physicist Laurence Godfrey - whose argument was that the ISP had become a publisher when it did not remove the comments.

Campaigners for free speech point out that some British ISPs now remove a comment, however fair and legitimate, as soon as they get a complaint rather than risk being sued.

Speaking after the Godfrey case, Mark Stephens, a media lawyer and vice-chair of the IWF, anticipated a flurry of litigation unless the laws were clarified. "In America ISPs have immunity over the content they provide access to and that must be the situation here. Otherwise, you'll have a legal free-for-all with libel writs flying left, right and centre."

He was right. A radical gay magazine's website, an anti-censorship site and one which highlighted miscarriages of justice, have all fallen victim to the uncertainty. Some have moved sites to the US rather than risk prosecution here.

One leading industry figure said: "It sounds as if the Department of Health has leapt into this without thinking the thing through. A lot of people in the industry are going to be puzzled and angry."

fields.headline: Things get worse for 'bizarre' Kilshaws
fields.trailText: If Judith and Alan Kilshaw thought the worst was over, they were wrong. Tania Branigan reports
fields.body:
If Judith and Alan Kilshaw thought the worst was over, they were wrong. Not only have their adopted babies been removed by social services, but every day brings fresh revelations about their unconventional lives from former colleagues, neighbours and relatives.

Bizarre allegations of magic rituals and amateur artificial insemination in their front room were splashed across yesterday's papers, fuelling concern about their appropriateness as parents - to their sons Rupert and James, as well as the twin sisters.

The couple are preparing to fight social services in court on Tuesday for custody of the twins, Kimberley and Belinda, who they adopted over the internet from an American single mother. Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services at Flintshire council, said: "We are aware of reports which are beginning to focus on the situation of the boys... we are monitoring the well being of all the children."

Tabloids yesterday claimed that Mrs Kilshaw, 47, had threatened to use magic to get the twins back, although she denied the claim. Former business partners and tenants said she had issued death threats following rows.

Her daughter Louisa from her first marriage, claimed the couple had begged her to act as a surrogate mother. When Louisa said she was already pregnant, her mother apparently told her to get an abortion and charged her £50 a week to live in an unheated caravan. Mrs Kilshaw said yesterday that she would never speak to her daughter again.

With her instinct for making a bad situation worse, she told a reporter that she had had argued with her husband. "We nearly came to blows. I was saying to Alan that he hadn't defended me enough."

In another statement likely to invoke the local authority's wrath, she said: "I will not be sending my two sons to school tomorrow because I'm afraid they'll be bullied."

Yesterday's stories would seem incredible if any other family were involved. But the new claims seem run-of-the-mill for the couple. Alan Kilshaw, a 45-year-old solicitor, is as eccentric as his wife. He was the home affairs spokesman for the hard-right Democratic party. He happily confirmed that he was encouraging Hollywood to turn their story into a film and is allegedly trying to recoup some of the £24,000 spent getting the girls out of the US.

The couple's former childminder said their farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, was "covered with dog muck", but the couple said the only problem was that it was haunted. They allegedly called in paranormal investigators.

Their self-belief seems to have blinded them to the impression they are creating. Mrs Kilshaw herself told a paper that she had impregnated a female friend using Mr Kilshaw's sperm. Little wonder that, as she complained this weekend, she says, "I am going to have to live with this for the rest of my life".

Former business partners and tenants said she had issued death threats following rows. Her daughter Louisa from her first marriage, claimed the couple had begged her to act as a surrogate mother. When Louisa said she was already pregnant, her mother apparently told her to get an abortion and charged her £50 a week to live in an unheated caravan. Mrs Kilshaw said yesterday that she would never speak to her daughter again. With her instinct for making a bad situation worse, she told a reporter that she had had argued with her husband. "We nearly came to blows. I was saying to Alan that he hadn't defended me enough." In another statement likely to invoke the local authority's wrath, she said: "I will not be sending my two sons to school tomorrow because I'm afraid they'll be bullied." Yesterday's stories would seem incredible if any other family were involved. But the new claims seem run-of-the-mill for the couple. Alan Kilshaw, a 45-year-old solicitor, is as eccentric as his wife. He was the home affairs spokesman for the hard-right Democratic party. He happily confirmed that he was encouraging Hollywood to turn their story into a film and is allegedly trying to recoup some of the £24,000 spent getting the girls out of the US. The couple's former childminder said their farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, was "covered with dog muck", but the couple said the only problem was that it was haunted. They allegedly called in paranormal investigators. Their self-belief seems to have blinded them to the impression they are creating. Mrs Kilshaw herself told a paper that she had impregnated a female friend using Mr Kilshaw's sperm. Little wonder that, as she complained this weekend, she says, "I am going to have to live with this for the rest of my life".

webTitle: Row over crackdown on adoption websites

fields.headline: Row over crackdown on adoption websites
fields.trailText: The government is to clamp down on adoption over the internet by warning British-based service providers that they face criminal prosecution for relaying material which infringes British adoption law, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Steven Morris and Tania Branigan
fields.body:
The government is to clamp down on adoption over the internet by warning British-based service providers that they face criminal prosecution for relaying material which infringes British adoption law, it emerged yesterday.

The extraordinary move by the Department of Health, which came as the controversy concerning the case of the couple who adopted twins on the net continued to gather pace, was immediately attacked as unworkable.

Industry leaders argued that the nature and scale of the internet meant that it was impossible for ISPs to check all material being accessed by their customers. There was also concern that the warning from the health minister John Hutton seemed to go against the spirit of a European directive on e-commerce. Moreover, it would put a great strain on the authorities who would have to try to police the ISPs.

The government, however, is keen to be seen acting strongly following the case of Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who bought baby twins Beverley and Kim berley from a Californian adoption broker they found on the internet. Even before Mr Hutton's initiative emerged, the government had announced that parents who adopted from abroad without undergoing the proper checks would face up to three months in prison and a fine of £600.

Regulations on inter-country adoptions had already been under discussion following a private member's bill passed in 1999 but it understood that they were not going to come into force until January next year. They will now be introduced in April.

The developments coincide with increasingly lurid allegations about the Kilshaws. One newspaper alleged yesterday that Mrs Kilshaw had said she would use witchcraft to regain the twins, who were taken into care on Thursday, though she denied making such a threat.

Mr Hutton, the minister responsible for child protection, believes his move against the ISPs could provide a lead for the EU and G8 to crack down on child-broker websites.

Government lawyers have advised that the adoption internet sites are a clear in fringement of the 1976 Adoption Act. Although they are powerless to close down sites based outside British jurisdiction, they have advised ministers that ISPs offering a route for the material to be accessed by people in Britain are open to prosecution.

The 1976 act makes it an offence for any advertisement to be published indicating that a parent or guardian wants their child to be adopted, or that a person wants to adopt a child, or that any person other than a local social services authority or voluntary adoption agency approved by the secretary of state is willing to make arrangements for the adoption of a child.

Mr Hutton wrote late on Friday to Ispa, the UK Internet Service Providers Association, which represents 130 companies and organisations, and the Internet Watchdog Foundation, which works with the police and the government to crack down on illegal material on the internet, pointing out it would be an offence for such material to remain available to British subscribers.

A senior Department of Health source said: "We have a good relationship with Ispa and we will be working with them to get this issue resolved so that UK internet service providers do not end up getting prosecuted."

But Nicholas Lansman, of Ispa, said a European directive spelling out that ISPs should be regarded as "mere conduits" for information until it is shown that they are carrying illegal or defamatory material was expected to become British law within a couple of years. He said: "This does not sound like joined-up government."

webTitle: Letter from John Hutton to internet service providers

fields.headline: Letter from John Hutton to internet service providers
fields.standfirst: Health minister John Hutton warns the internet service providers association over internet adoption responsibilities
fields.trailText: Health minister John Hutton warns the internet service providers association over internet adoption responsibilities
fields.body:
ADVERTISING FOR ADOPTION ON THE INTERNET ADOPTION ACT 1976

You will be aware of the considerable press and public interest in children being advertised for adoption on the internet. I am writing to alert you that I have received legal advice that if a UK based Internet Service Provider has actual knowledge that they are storing any material which breaches Section 58(1), they must remove it. If they do not do so they are committing an offence and may face prosecution.

Section 58(1) of the Adoption Act 1976 provides that it is unlawful for any advertisement to be published indicating -

(a) that the parent or guardian of a child desires to cause a child to be adopted;

(b) that a person desires to adopt a child; or

(c) that any person (not being a local authority or voluntary adoption society approved by the Secretary of State) is willing to make arrangements for the adoption of a child.

"Making arrangements for the adoption of a child" is defined in section 72(3) of the Adoption Act 1976 as amended by section 13 of Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999.

Section 58(2) provides that any person who causes to be published or knowingly publishes an advertisement in contravention of section 58(1) is guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale.

The law applies equally to the internet as it does to any other medium.

Yours faithfully

JOHN HUTTON

fields.headline: Battling Bradford dim the lights at Sunderland
fields.trailText: Sunderland 0 - 0 Bradford
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
A record crowd swarmed to Wearmouth, flicking through their fanzine Champions League pull-outs and buzzing at the prospect of a spanking of the bottom club. By the end, after this dose of stark reality, the Sunderland fans trudged home in chilled frustration.

Sunderland have not lost at the Stadium of Light since Bradford City won here in April. Fifteen teams have come and gone since but City, who had not conceded on three previous visits to this stadium, should have ended that sequence yesterday. Early in the second half Dean Windass, unmarked at the far post, speared Robbie Blake's low cross wide of an open goal. With Windass's cheeks still burning, Thomas Sorensen was forced to tip Blake's vicious shot over seconds later.

"I think Dean was reading the headlines before he put it in," said the Bradford manager Jim Jefferies ruefully. "We could have sneaked it, but it was a good solid performance. They gave us a real pasting at our place on Boxing Day and we changed things around after that. This was a benchmark of how much we have improved."

Sunderland, still two points ahead of Arsenal in second place, have mounted their unlikely European challenge by instilling resilience and an unflappable work ethic throughout a talented, if underrated, squad. Jefferies is attempting much the same at City, so it was hardly surprising that the sides cancelled each other out in a match of huff and puff but little attacking zing.

The home side's forward play was far too convoluted to throw off a resilient Bantams' back line. The outstanding Robert Molenaar nullified Niall Quinn; Andy O'Brien stuck to Kevin Phillips - whose three goals in the 4-1 Christmas rout are as many as Bradford's leading scorers have managed all season - leaving Peter Atherton to mop up the dregs.

Phillips, watched by Sven-Goran Eriksson, had three vague shots in the first half but was denied a clearcut opportunity and, when Quinn escaped his Dutch minder, he headed wide or shot straight at Gary Walsh. Don Hutchison blazed over, and Alex Rae's effort was diverted by Walsh. Eriksson was left to renew acquaintance with the only Englishman he has ever signed, although the former Sampdoria striker Danny Dichio's impact was also negligible.

"We didn't have enough craft or guile," admitted Peter Reid. "But I always felt it was going to be difficult and I'm happy with a point. I've never said we are the greatest side in the league - we're nowhere near the finished article - but I know we are honest and that's what I got today."

It could so easily have been honest defeat. On the rare occasions they stayed onside, Blake and Dean Saunders fluffed first-half chances and ultimately the Premiership had its fourth goalless damp squib of the weekend.

Even with the farewells of Benito Carbone and Stan Collymore still hovering around Valley Parade, hope springs eternal in west Yorkshire. "We've made certain decisions people have found strange but I think you can see the benefit of some of them now," added Jefferies. "We're still in with a chance."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Strachan loses the backing of supporters
fields.standfirst: Abject collapse puts Coventry manager under fire
fields.trailText:
Coventry 1 - 3 Everton
Strachan loses the backing of supporters.
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan remains defiant that he is the manager to save Coventry from the prospect of relegation but it is his biggest challenge since he replaced Ron Atkinson more than four years ago.

Coventry's perilous position, second bottom and three points adrift of safety, is not an unfamiliar one but Strachan has, for the moment, lost the support of the fans and faces a monumental task in lifting his side after a display that he admitted was the worst he had seen in his time in charge.

Geoffrey Robinson MP, Coventry's president, gave Strachan his backing afterwards and urged the supporters to follow suit. Judging by the number of fans who joined in the chants of "We want Strachan out" during and after the humiliation, and by the anger of a group who attempted to accost Strachan as he left the pitch, this seems unlikely.

Should Coventry rise to the challenge all will be forgiven. It is not, however, easy to see where the 18 points or so that City will need to stay up are going to come from. Among their last 14 games they must travel to Leeds, Manchester United, Leicester and Ipswich and will be visited by Arsenal, Chelsea, Sunderland and Liverpool.

On Saturday they were taken apart by a side who were missing 13 players through injury and suspension and who lost another two, Niclas Alexandersson and Alec Cleland, before half-time.

Everton, who had not scored at Highfield Road since 1995, were 3-0 up in 31 minutes. Their captain Kevin Campbell said afterwards that: "At times we made it look pretty easy". Coventry, in contrast, played as if the basic principles of the game were a mystery to them.

The only City player who seemed to have the will and ability to trouble Everton was David Thompson. The former Liverpool midfielder hoped that his side's inept display was a one-off.

"You get them days when you're stinking and the other team's playing quite well and exploits it," he said. "That's what Everton did. We were all over the place. We got hit by two early goals and it destroys your confidence, especially when you're down there because it's tough mentally.

"You're frightened to try things in case it doesn't work and it leads to a goal. You're frightened to make a mistake and it does get to you. We need to pull together as a team because individuals won't get us out of this situation."

Strachan had no alternative solutions. "That performance will stick in our memories for a long time," he said. "The whole thing was an embarrassment to the club and that includes myself, the coaching staff and the players. Even the ones that weren't playing should be embarrassed because they have to say to themselves 'if I'm not good enough to get picked for that ...' "

City's malaise distracted attention from a vital win for Everton, their first in eight league games. Bill Kenwright, who will have owned the club for a year come Thursday, will today unveil Everton's plans for a 55,000-seat stadium at the King's Dock in Liverpool city centre. It is vital that they stay in the Premiership should the bid succeed and, if opponents allow them as much space as Coventry did, survival should be a formality.

After eight minutes Danny Cadamarteri seized on the home side's inability to clear and fed Scot Gemmill, who calmly scored. Seven minutes later Alexandersson found Cadamarteri unmarked six yards out for the second and, with only a third of the game gone, Campbell was allowed two attempts to put the ball in for the third.

Lee Carsley scored a late penalty but it did not quell Coventry's fans. Strachan needs a response from his side and quickly. Otherwise their 34-year stay in the top flight will come to a painful end.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Poyet dares to dream of Europe again
fields.standfirst: Premiership
fields.trailText:
Chelsea 4 - 1 Ipswich
Poyet dares to dream of Europe again.
fields.body:
Ken Bates must have gone to bed with a grin wider than the gap that separates Manchester United from their so-called championship rivals. Chelsea won comfortably, Dennis Wise scored to keep the tea ladies happy, and the statistics are beginning to look impressive.

Only United have taken more points from their past five matches than Claudio Ranieri's side. And although the patient is not yet back to full health, talk of Europe is starting to mean more than a prescribed summer break in the Algarve.

Even before those great over-achievers from Suffolk had been swept aside, Ranieri reiterated his ambition of reaching at least the Uefa Cup. Afterwards Gus Poyet, scorer of two Chelsea goals, dared contemplate the C-word that must make the ears of Bates's piggy bank prick up.

"If we believe in the possibility of finishing in the top three maybe we can do it and qualify for the Champions League. If we don't believe it there's no chance," he said.

Given that Wise seriously considered turning out for Blackburn at Grimsby and Stockport, anything is believable in these parts. Chelsea lie seven points behind third-placed Arsenal with a game in hand having lost once in eight matches, although for fantasy to become reality a little more consistency is still required.

Two points dropped at home under Ranieri compares with three picked up away and, as at Arsenal last week, their second-half showing was as excellent as patches of the first had been rotten. Then again, the inconsistency starts at the top.

That Ranieri began with four in defence and switched to a more effective system at half-time, featuring a back three, showed again that the Italian is either impressively flexible or clueless as to which formation suits what opponents. The certainty is that there is quality in the raw materials.

The pace, power and movement of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink were prominent features, and it is no wonder Chelsea want to keep Gianfranco Zola for a further year after his contract expires in the summer of 2002, even though he will be 36. "He's playing better than ever," said the managing director Colin Hutchinson, "and we hope he will stay."

Wise proved the value of his decision to stick around and the sense of using him in central midfield, Poyet showed his nose for goal by taking his total to seven from his past 10 starts, and Jesper Gronkjaer did enough to suggest he will offer the width Chelsea need in attack. Two other youngsters, John Terry and Sam Dalla Bona, have already settled.

Yet what may have pleased Ranieri above all was the fighting spirit he felt was lacking when he arrived. Between his opening game at Old Trafford and the draw at Highbury, Chelsea fell behind in eight matches and lost seven of them. Now they have recovered from a goal down to take points in successive games.

That they found themselves behind was a testament to how well George Burley's team started. Rushing around like foxhounds looking for possible new employment, Ipswich seized the initiative and prevented Chelsea from settling.

Marcus Stewart's 17th goal of the season, clipped bravely over the onrushing Carlo Cudicini, was deserved. Poyet's scrambled equaliser in first-half injury-time was crucial. "It gave them a lift," Burley said.

The second half was one-sided. Helped by the width their wing-backs provided until Gronkjaer's arrival, Chelsea made this a rare occasion on which Ipswich have been overwhelmed in the top flight.

After Wise headed in Hasselbaink's cross, an error by Fabian Wilnis allowed Hasselbaink to set up Poyet for No3. The fourth, though controversial, was academic. Wilnis won the ball cleanly from Dalla Bona but Andy d'Urso awarded a penalty, which Hasselbaink scored after John McGreal was sent off for foul and abusive language which he assures Burley he did not use.

Ipswich will hope this, like the 4-1 defeat at Sunderland, was a blip. Chelsea are praying it was proof that Ranieri's revolution will soon threaten Europe.

fields.headline: Payton's placement
fields.trailText:
Burnley 2 - 1 Barnsley
Payton's placement settles it.
fields.body:
Burnley finally rediscovered the winning touch after a worrying slump of seven games without victory had pushed Stan Ternent's side out of the play-off places.

Unsurprisingly Saturday's win was secured by the predatory instincts of Andy Payton who is clearly desperate to make up for lost time at his beloved Turf Moor.

The 33-year-old was shown the door by his hometown team as a schoolboy and started his career at Hull. He marked time at Celtic, Middlesbrough, Barnsley and Huddersfield before finally wearing claret and blue three years ago. Successful scorers thrive on quests for personal targets and Payton, who now has 220 career goals, is no exception.

"There are only nine players who have ever scored 100 goals for this club," he said, "and I've now got 75 in three years. I've just signed a new contract and fully intend to add my name to that list."

Payton's scrappy close range effort added to Lenny Johnrose's first-half header and came just three minutes after the Barnsley defender Chris Morgan was dismissed for denying Ian Moore's clear run on goal.

Having been reduced to 10 men, Barnsley came close to claiming an unlikely point after Steve Hayward scored on his debut with a stunning 25-yard drive. Isaiah Rankin, another midweek signing by the new Barnsley manager Nigel Spackman, then spurned a chance close to the end.

Ultimately though, it was perhaps fitting that nothing should be allowed to deny Payton his fully deserved moment in the spotlight.

fields.headline: Lost Owls seek players' wisdom
fields.trailText:
Sheff Wed 0 - 3 Bolton
Lost Owls seek players' wisdom.
fields.body:
The fourth round of the FA Cup comes up next weekend and whereas in-form Bolton are regarding their game with Burnley or Scunthorpe as an unfortunate distraction from the league programme, Sheffield Wednesday are looking upon their trip to Southampton as respite from the business of continually dropping points.

"In a normal season we would be top of the league now," said Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce after steering his team to a 10th win in 12 league games, "but when you are on top of your form you could do with cup games being league games."

He has written off any hope of catching the leaders Fulham and is convinced Bolton will need to break Middlesbrough's second-place record of 91 points to secure the other automatic promotion spot.

Wednesday's manager Paul Jewell is looking only as far as reaching fourth bottom, and was still locked in the dressing room with his players an hour after the whistle. It fell to his assistant Peter Shreeves to issue the official line. "We need at least seven wins to get out of trouble," he said. "We've preached that to the players; whether they can cope with that pressure or not is the conundrum."

Given that Wednesday have managed only seven wins in 29 league games it is a tall order, and once Bolton's substitute Ian Marshall had all but emptied three sides of the ground by hooking a shot between Marlon Beresford and his near post, it was time for some home truths.

"We've taken note of what the players said," Shreeves added. "It might not necessarily be what we feel we need, but let's try everything."

Lack of effort was not their problem here, more a shortage of confidence and experience, but with Des Walker sidelined with flu, Andy Hinchcliffe out for the season with an achilles problem and Wim Jonk at least two weeks away from a return, the financially stricken club have little option but to persevere with what they have.

Bolton began like the home team, moving the ball around with purpose, always looking to give themselves options and with Colin Hendry, on loan from Coventry, in commanding form.

They soon went ahead with a smartly taken goal from Ricardo Gardner, who fastened on to a Michael Ricketts header, beat a defender and steered a low shot into Beresford's bottom left-hand corner. Ricketts scored his 15th in the league this season when he latched on to an astute pass from Bo Hansen and finished neatly.

Wednesday had their moments in the second half, the best of them when Alan Quinn's header from Matt Hamshaw's cross was well held and then Gerald Sibon's 25-yard shot from a tapped free-kick hit the bar. But after Marshall had the last word on the pitch it was time for them to pipe up in the dressing room and contemplate a fortnight without a dropped point.

fields.headline: Kinks recalled by Fulham's latest hit
fields.trailText:
Watford 1 - 3 Fulham
Kinks recalled by Fulham's latest hit.
fields.body:
Another day, another hurdle cleared for Fulham, who now have as many points from 27 games as they managed in 46 last season. The men with Demon on their shirts are a team possessed, and the lure of the Premiership makes them irresistible.

In fact, a quasi-Premiership feel buzzed around Vicarage Road all afternoon. Sky had ac corded the game a high-noon billing, the gathering of 18,333 was Watford's biggest league crowd since they were in the top flight, and the game itself warmed up and bubbled over into a thrilling spectacle.

For an hour the sides traded blows equally until Luis Boa Morte overturned a miserable first half, in which he spurned several chances and was booked and booed for handling, by twice shooting past Alec Chamberlain. First he pounced on a loose ball to the left of goal; then, eight minutes later, Lee Clark neatly fed him in the same position.

Watford pulled one back when the on-rushing Heidar Helguson scored his first goal since mid-September, though replays revealed generous use of his right hand, but the final blow was delivered by Louis Saha soon after when Bjarne Goldbaek surged in from the right and found him free to make it three.

"That was a throwback to when we were in the Premiership last season," said Taylor. "You can match a team for an hour but then the quality of the opposition forwards is that much higher and they can score from one attack."

It is 33 years since Fulham were last in the top flight. They started their sporadic descent and ascent through the divisions just four years after the Kinks sang Louie, Louie, and it is high time for a reprise. This year's Luis, Louis act has a combined tally of 38 goals for the season while Barry Hayles, absent with an ankle injury, has snaffled another 17.

"They have so much pace and strength that if a game is tight and 0-0 you know they have the ability to finish off our passes," said a satisfied Clark.

Taylor simply opined that Fulham are "a class above the rest of us" - their aggregate win over Watford in two matches this season is 8-1 - though he tried to take the sting out of the Hornets' defeat.

"It was harsh on us," he reflected. "If we play like we did today for our remaining 19 matches, then we'll win far more than we lose."

Chillingly Fulham still display the mind-set of a side hanging on by the skin of their teeth. "There is a long way to go," said Clark. "I just hope that by May 6 we are in one of the two automatic promotion places." When will the demons lose their spirit?

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hughes soars on hot air
fields.trailText:
WBA 2 - 1 Sheff Utd
Hughes soars on hot air.
fields.body:
After the week that was for Bruce Grobbelaar and the good name of English football, FA officials may take issue with Neil Warnock's assertion that he needs "a team of con-men" to succeed.

The Sheffield United manager directed his wrath at Lee Hughes, who scored his 17th goal of the season to condemn United to another away defeat.

He accused him of running 30 yards to encourage Michael Ryan to send off Rob Ullathorne after 32 minutes for a challenge on Ruel Fox - a second "bookable" offence - and added that Hughes should have been dismissed himself.

Warnock, who avoided a reprimand from the FA when he accused James Beattie of "conning" David Elleray after United's loss at Southampton a fortnight ago, said: "Cheats don't prosper they say. What a lie. Hughes has won the game and it absolutely stinks."

The game, however, was really won by West Brom's midfielders Michael Appleton and Fox, albeit against 10 men who allowed them space to shine and create in the second half.

Appleton, making his debut after signing from Preston, had kept his head in the first half while all around him hopeless football ensued. Later Fox, the captain, exploited his free role excellently before scoring his first goal for the club he joined last August.

Fox later defended Hughes from Warnock's accusations. "Lee is an honest player. The sending off may have been a bit harsh but their reaction was to see who they could get sent off," he said.

Fox added that he did not feel the "referee got a hold of the game" although this was understatement; rarely do home supporters boo a referee from the pitch after they have won a match and seen their opponents reduced to 10 men. Such was Ryan's failure to get a hold of the game.

Albion nearly lost points when the former Hawthorns favourite Paul Peschisolido, on loan at Sheffield from Fulham, scampered through the middle and scored from a rebound off the bar from his own strike. Gary Megson was rightly concerned about a fault-line down the middle of his otherwise solid side. Paul Thompson, West Brom's chairman who has spent £5m on players since last March, has told Megson he has another £500,000 left. A central defender is a likely investment.

Megson was pleased however with his side's integrity. "I have never questioned their honesty," he said. Warnock will beg to differ.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Houllier seeks answer to Owen's missing quality
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 0 - 0 Midlesbrough
Houllier seeks answer to Owen's missing quality.
fields.body:
It was with the dull, thudding pain engendered by another squandered opportunity that Gérard Houllier moved with rare swiftness to throw a protective arm around one of his favoured sons.

For once it was not the perpetually irritating Robbie Fowler but the golden boy Michael Owen, a youngster who is finding difficulty in negotiating safe passage through footballing puberty.

With the paternal affection which has come to represent one of the main planks of his Liverpool stewardship, Houllier rose to the challenge even before there was one.

It was a classic example of what could be described as a manager getting in his defence before there was time for any would-be detractors to find a way of couching, in seemingly harmless terms, the odd awkward question.

Houllier is an accomplished practitioner of what is a most delicate art - he effortlessly moves the point of discussion to relatively safe ground.

Having spent the first half shivering on the touchline, presumably ruing his manager's determination to introduce the Anfield faithful to the delights of a rotation system, Owen was thrown on after the interval and promptly missed three very acceptable chances in 12 minutes.

Had he scored even once, Liverpool would certainly have won a furiously contested game for, as goalkeeper Mark Schwarzer repeatedly dived athletically to his side's rescue, Middlesbrough's hugely impressive early football was but a fast-fading memory.

Having missed a shed-load of chances recently at Crystal Palace in the Worthington Cup, Owen was there to be shot at. So enter Houllier with rational explanations and perceptive observations.

"With Michael at the moment it is a matter of confidence," said Houllier. "Sometimes players - especially young strikers - look very confident but they aren't; they are unsure of themselves. He is not totally right at present.

"We are working on him and we hope to have him back to his best level soon, in three, maybe four, weeks. It is nothing major, just some niggles we have to get rid of.

Middlesbrough's coach Terry Venables was asked his opinion of Owen's stuttering performance but waved away the question, preferring instead to point out that one of his own forwards, the enormously gifted Alen Boksic, could also have provided the afternoon with a defining moment.

"If we had come here with just a little more self-belief, if we had believed we could have won, I think we might have done just that," said Venables.

Not once since succumbing to the lure of the Teesside shilling has Venables threatened to transform Middlesbrough into a fashionable, aesthetically appealing team.

Quite the contrary. Understandably all the talk was of collective units, of work ethic, of discipline both on and off the the field and, of course, of survival.

Since his arrival Boro are unbeaten in eight games and, even more significantly, have shipped only two goals - a penalty and an own-goal at that. " We have tried to get solid. We worked on the defence, now I'm moving through the team," said Venables.

A mean team is always hard to beat, so Middlesbrough's short-term future appears secure.

But, with Venables still enamoured of the studio lights, he may find greasepaint altogether more alluring than warpaint.

fields.headline: Graham caught in waiting game
fields.trailText:
Tottenham 0 - 0 Southampton
Graham caught in waiting game.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
The search for clues, like the search for goals, proved elusive: how long will George Graham be in his job once Enic take over Tottenham in three weeks' time?

After Saturday's game, which nearly saw Spurs slip to their first home defeat of the season, the man himself was of little help. "I've met their main chap twice briefly," said Graham. "But we talked about nothing in-depth. Hopefully we'll have a good meeting once the takeover is complete."

The main chap is Daniel Levy, mastermind of Enic's takeover, lifelong Spurs fan and someone with a lot of hard thinking to do about the manager's position. On the one hand, should he give Graham more time to get things right based on his past successes? On the other, should he take heed of a compelling list of counter-arguments?

The Scot's connections with Arsenal and non-Spurs-type football still rankles with Tottenham fans; Levy has a long-standing admiration for the prince regent of White Hart Lane, Glenn Hoddle; appointing the "king of White Hart Lane" would play well with the fans; and Graham has struggled to find his old magic touch.

Even he admitted it on Saturday: "I would have expected to be further along the success route than we are and some of that is my fault."

Part of Graham's problem has been his inability to build a decent side on the limited resources imposed by his old chairman. Indeed Graham recently said he would need £50m to bring the championship to White Hart Lane.

This could actually be the crucial point for Levy. For Enic's policy with the portfolio of clubs they already own has been one of careful husbandry rather than heavy spending.

So, while Spurs fans might like to think that Hoddle's possible return is all to do with recapturing the glory, glory days of swashbuckling football, it may be based on something far less romantic: the fact that at Swindon, Chelsea and Southampton Hoddle has impressed on limited budgets.

For Hoddle's part, it is an open secret that he would love to manage his old club and his Southampton contract is reported to contain a suitable get-out clause.

But, whoever is manager, his first call on Enic will be for transfer funds to strengthen a squad which Graham says lacks the depth to cope with the current plethora of injuries and Saturday's loss through suspension of Neil Sullivan and Tim Sherwood.

"In my time here we've got rid of 15 experienced first-team squad players but only brought in nine," he moaned, though one might ask: whose miscalculation is that?

Tottenham avoided defeat on Saturday only thanks to a series of glaring first-half misses by a well-organised Southampton side looking to atone for last season's 7-2 defeat. Kevin Davies was the player most guilty of profligacy. Twice he found himself one-on-one with Ian Walker but both times placed his shot too close to Spurs' reserve keeper.

In a more even second half Ledley King hit the top of the bar for Tottenham. But that did not prevent a chorus of boos ringing out on the final whistle. Perhaps this provided the biggest clue to George Graham's future.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Ferguson has drive but not drink
fields.standfirst: United are so focused on the title that they are 100-1 on
fields.trailText:
Man Utd 2 - 0 Aston Villa
Ferguson has drive but not drink.
fields.body:
In these broccoli-enhanced days it has become fashionable in some quarters to assume the modern footballer can no longer consider himself the real thing until he has been so brainwashed with dietetics it has reached the stage where he goes to bed thinking about his greens.

In many ways Sir Alex Ferguson twigged the benefits of a strict health regime long before most of his contemporaries although the Manchester United manager will also know from days gone by as a Govan publican that the occasional gargle of mother's ruin is not always a bad thing either.

Last Monday as the United squad sunned themselves on a mid-season break in Jerez he told his players that if they wanted a night out they could do so with his blessing.

While it was not carte blanche to get blotto, it was nevertheless the type of invitation that the average footballer might reasonably see as the green light for a pleasant evening sampling the local Sangria. United, of course, have few average footballers: the offer was politely declined and the players organised a quiz night among themselves before lights out at 11pm.

When the manager inquired to their reasons, he was told they did not want to run the risk, however minuscule it was, of detracting from what was a time for recharging batteries. "It just goes to show their professionalism, how strong their focus is," Ferguson said on Saturday, and he had every right to glow with satisfaction. "I thought they might want a beer but, to a man, they wanted to stay in the hotel."

That type of slavish dedication has helped take United a country mile clear at the Premiership's apex and for as long as Ferguson continues to scold those who say the title is theirs the fact remains he is not fooling anyone.

One bookmaker is offering 100-1 on - the shortest odds ever - for United to reel in their seventh title in nine years. Another firm paid out three weeks ago after declaring the championship won. Take United out of the equation and we would have a heck of a contest, but delving into hypothesis does not alter the fact that the league is becoming something of a snooze. Aston Villa have had lofty pretensions to United's throne and what was ultimately a humdrum result might have been different if their impudence had paid off at the start of the second half when they displayed something spookily reminiscent of an away team at Old Trafford playing with, that's right, self-belief. It remains a peculiarity that for all the time United spend in opposition territory their best player so far this season has been their goalkeeper. How the watching Sven-Goran Eriksson must have wished Fabien Barthez had been born in Leyland rather than Lavelanet after watching him pluck the ball off Lee Hendrie's toe in the midst of Villa's intrepid adventures.

Hendrie seemed certain to score but that chance gone, and a shot from Gareth Barry hoofed off the goalline by Jonathan Greening moments later, United stirred from their torpor while still remaining somewhere off their mesmeric best.

First Gary Neville diverted Roy Keane's free-kick inside the near post after a foul that only the referee Mike Riley seemed to see. Then David James patted Andy Cole's centre into Teddy Sheringham's path and once again Eriksson must have found himself gazing longingly towards Barthez. David Beckham and Mickael Silvestre were given the weekend off and United's resources are so bloated, their lead so awesome, that Ferguson can afford to rest others between now and the end of the season. Keane will be left out against Everton on Saturday week.

No such luxury for Villa, who will hope that their club-record £9.5m signing Juan Pablo Angel's inefficacious debut was merely due to beginner's nerves. Hendrie and Barry will both have impressed Eriksson, although the England coach declined to identify the individuals he had noted and it would have been of scant consolation to Villa's manager John Gregory anyway.

In football, as in all walks of life, there are talkers and doers. Unfortunately for Villa they do not belong to the latter category: 13th position is a shabby state of affairs for a famous old club that began the season pontificating about qualifying for the Champions League.

fields.headline: City fear of failure defies the law of averages
fields.trailText:
Derby 1 - 1 Man City
The law of below-averages prevails.
fields.body:
By the law of averages, or perhaps by mistake, 20 footballers in the strongest league in the world might be expected to string together two decent moves in 90 minutes. But with these sides the law of below-averages prevailed. They managed one. Happily it produced a goal. But no one learned.

Adam Murray, in front of the dug-outs, slid a thoughtful pass up to Malcolm Christie, who ran at the defence, played a swift give-and-go with Deon Burton and crossed flat for Darryl Powell to rush in. Before Derby could cast off their anxiety City equalised, Steve Howey powering home a header from a corner. Taribo West, in the words of the new criminal justice and police bill, was guilty of "watching and besetting" but not of marking.

There was a good deal of this in a match governed by fear. After half an hour Youl Mawéné and Paulo Wanchope were booked for persistent mutual molestation. The teams were frightened of losing, the players of making a fatal mistake.

The previous week the Aston Villa manager John Gregory talked of a "roll-up-your-sleeves situation" to explain his half-time substitution of David Ginola, who is better suited to a let-your-hair-down situation. From the outset this was an act-first-and-think-later situation, as exemplified by Danny Tiatto when, already booked, he studded Craig Burley's chest with a late challenge, then stayed down longer than his victim.

No doubt the managers will do some thinking now. Both sides came into the match on the back of 4-0 defeats. Both were devoid of playmakers, by mischance or mischoice. With 15 games to go they seemed to have decided to battle their way out of the jungle rather than get out the map and compass and look at the stars. The trouble is that most of the stars belong to the opposition - except, of course, on Saturday.

Joe Royle admitted his team were short of confidence and quality, hardly surprising after seven points from 14 games now in which he has tinkered in search of his best formation. "Today we defended properly," he said, having reverted to a back four which, for the most part, was more composed than Derby's. But their attacks fell foul of the franticness on which they were founded.

One by one the strugglers have rallied - first Derby, then Coventry a bit, now Middlesbrough. Derby, but not on this showing, might point the way. Colin Todd, whose arrival as Jim Smith's assistant initiated their recovery, admitted: "Bad habits have crept in again." The secret lies in defensive shape and discipline. They will need it at Blackburn in the Cup, when Powell, Burton and West are on international duty.

Christie's lively running gave him two half-chances to tie up the game in the last half-hour but after the goals it was a roll-over-and-go-back-to-sleep situation for the crowd, or just sit- uation vacant. The managers may soon be in the same boat.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Alex
fields.trailText: You really should try a safari on Fraser Island - the biggest sand island in the world. One piece of advice - only swim in the fresh water inland lakes, as there are tiger sharks in the sea which wait in the shallows waiting for a tourist to dip in their big toe.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

I was just returning from Australia about this time last year. I spent three amazing months on the east coast between Sydney and Cairns. I know you don't have that long in Australia, but here a a few things which I enjoyed.

In Sydney I stayed in the YHA by the central station - very nice, but as it's massive it's a bit on the impersonal side - unless you end up in a room with like-minded people. I did the most amazing five day 'learn to surf' trip with Aussie Surf Adventures run by Nat and Dan, up to Byron Bay. Five days of surfing, eating, surfing, drinking, surfing and a bit of partying thrown in. Highly recommended, even though surfing is a bit like being in a washing machine.

Byron Bay is a must - loads of hostels to choose from, but the best by far is Aquarius. There are loads of things to do in Byron Bay - I had to drag myself away - but one thing you have to try is sea kayaking with dolphins. Two other things that you really should try and do are a two or three day boat trip out to the Whitsunday Islands and a three day four-wheel-drive safari on Fraser Island - the biggest sand island in the world. One piece of advice - only swim in the fresh water inland lakes, as there are tiger sharks in the sea which wait in the shallows waiting for a tourist to dip in their big toe.

Take a boogie board to slid down the sand dunes - if you do you will boost your popularity ratings by far! You could give Cairns a miss - not much there - but it is an outpost to Cape Tribulation ' where the reef meets the rainforest'. Fantastic place to chill out and relax. Hope you have a good trip and enjoy it all.

Alex

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Si
fields.trailText: If you really want to enjoy Oz, give Sydney the old heave-ho and get yourself onto the train to Perth. You can watch the sunset into the Pacific for a start, but it also means you're halfway towards going to the Hammersley Gorges.
fields.body:
Milly,

Don't, whatever they do or say, go to New Zealand. It's pants! If you don't believe me, read what Sam's getting up to there - lots of rain and sheep and blathering on about caves and the like. Do you really want to spend every day hiking around countryside that looks like England? I firmly believe that the people who are suggesting you go are all paid members of the Kiwi Tourist Board - there's just no way it's worth your time and effort going.

Tell you what though, if you really want to enjoy Oz, give Sydney the old heave-ho and get yourself onto the train to Perth. You can watch the sunset into the Pacific for a start, but it also means you're halfway towards going to the Hammersley Gorges. Middle of bastard nowhere, bloody difficult to get to and from, possible risk from asbestos fibres on the way out but for my money the best fun it's possible to have with an inflated inner tube. You can also then get to Broome and Derby in the north, which is about as far from big cities as you'd want. I can also get you in touch with a cattle station up there if you want somewhere to stay and do some real work for a change...?

Hope the rest of the trip goes well, love Si

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Oliver
fields.trailText: When you get to Bali, try to get out of Kuta after a couple of days and get up to ubud (craft area) and a huge volcano called Mount Batur. You can stay in the caldera in a village with a hot spring right next to a big lake. In the early morning people climb the volcano to see the sun come up; it's wonderful.
fields.body:
Dear Milly,

Darling Harbour in Sydney is a nice place to hang out in your free time.

Some of the job centres in Sydney give out work very early in the morning; you have to be there at 5am and they hand out work. At this time of the year there are jobs in the grapefield up at Mildura where you pick sultanas; I did this a few years ago and lived in a tent for three months. It was really nice, quite quiet but lots of fun working with people, and getting to see lots of wildlife, too.

On the way up to Cairns there are lots of great places to go. One really beautiful place is Brampton Island; I think it's off Rockhampton or somewhere like that.

When you get to Bali, try to get out of Kuta after a couple of days and get up to ubud (craft area) and a huge volcano called Mount Batur. You can stay in the caldera in a village with a hot spring right next to a big lake. In the early morning people climb the volcano to see the sun come up; it's wonderful. On the other side of the lake is a village of the indigenous people of Bali - they put their dead in cages. I heard it's very exciting but didn't go.

Oliver Blackbourn

fields.headline: No sleep 'til El Salvador
fields.standfirst: Oxfam last week flew out £100,000 worth of water and sanitation equipment and shelter to earthquake-struck El Salvador. In the first of a series of exclusive diary entries, aid                             worker Rachel Stabb describes the team's journey to the quake zone
fields.trailText: Oxfam last week flew out £100,000 worth of water and sanitation equipment and shelter to earthquake-struck El Salvador. In the first of a series of exclusive diary entries, aid worker Rachel Stabb describes the team's journey to the quake zone
fields.body:
Earthquakes come without warning and need an instant response, while other types of emergency develop more slowly. With earthquakes, there's no time to lose.

So it was last week. I had four hours' notice before heading to Manston airport in Kent to pick up Oxfam's aid flight to El Salvador.

It sounds almost a normal way to go, but it certainly isn't. As a first experience, it held a certain curiosity. That wore off after we climbed into three cramped rows of seats bolted onto a metal palette in the tail of a DC-9. Ahead of us were 27 tonnes of emergency aid, carefully netted and stowed.

Galvanised steel water tanks in flat packs, large green pipes, tapstands and a neat stack of hundreds of Oxfam's trademark green buckets took up almost the entire plane. You could just squeeze along one side with difficulty.

George - our "flight attendant" - showed us the ropes. Literally. He reminded us the emergency chutes were actually ropes. So none of that shoes-off-and-slide-down-on-your-bottom routine. He handed over oxygen cylinders for two people and told us to grab the attached mask if we heard a loud bang and darkness! He then provided sleeping bags to keep us warm and sandwiches and soft drinks to while away the first leg of our flight.

I didn't know what to expect from our stopover five hours later in the Azores. It was just as well. Nine of us - a mixture of Oxfam water engineers and journalists bound for their next foreign assignment - emerged into the misty night and found very little. We ended up in a pristine but completely empty airport lounge.

A public relations officer appeared to take pity on us for having nothing to do as we sat out the hour-and-a-half refuelling time. Out of nowhere, he produced a stack of glossy brochures on holidaying in the Azores which, with nothing better on offer, we all leafed through with a surprising sense of interest.

Before long we were on our way to Bridgetown, Barbados, joking about opting for the beach rather than the earthquake zone in El Salvador.

On this five-hour stretch, sleep was seriously planned. A competitive search for any flat surface began. The lucky ones stretched on top of crates, almost touching the ceiling; others curled around a stack of buckets. I waited for the ingenious ones to bed down before spreading myself across their empty seats.

Bridgetown turned out to be not much better than the Azores, except for the hot cups of coffee which an airport worker made for us. By this time, backs were beginning to ache and sleep was elusive.

Eventually, we were on the final leg to El Salvador and the end was in sight. On arrival, we struggled wearily off the plane into the heat. From fleeces to T-shirts in one easy move. Our cargo was unloaded at great speed.

Miraculously, within an hour of ending our 20-hour flight, we were ready to get to work, revived by the sense that a full blown emergency required our services. And required them now ...

fields.headline: Warner Brothers in fresh battle over Harry Potter website
fields.standfirst:
Dec 22: Warner wins Potter rights
More internet news
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: Warner Brothers has demanded that a 15-year-old Singaporean girl surrender rights to her Harry Potter website, writes Amy Vickers.
Dec 22: Warner wins Potter rights
fields.body:
A fresh battle is looming over a Harry Potter domain name with Warner Brothers demanding that a 15-year-old Singaporean girl surrender the rights to her website, harrypotternetwork.net.

Christie Chan, who set up her website in October 1999, has been contacted by Warner Brothers's legal team demanding that she surrender the site's name.

In a defiant move against Warner Brothers - the company that owns film and merchandising rights to Harry Potter - Miss Chan is standing her ground.

So far, Warners has not threatened to take Miss Chan to court, as she had complied with some of their requests to credit images to the entertainment giant.

Nevertheless, Miss Chan has gone on record in the Asian press, voicing her concerns that one day she will be forced to close down "because other fairly well-established sites have shut down due to notices from Warner Brothers".

The latest domain name dispute is almost a carbon copy of a case in December when 15-year-old Brit Claire Field received a letter from Warner Brothers's London legal department asking her to hand over the name www.harrypotterguide.co.uk.

Like her dragon-defying idol, the British youth rebelled and gained the support of other Harry Potter fan sites around the world.

The publicity gained by Miss Field eventually led to Warner Brothers granting her permission to keep the website although she had to make a number of changes.

Her website now states on its opening page that it is an "unofficial Harry Potter site" with no connections to JK Rowling, Warner Brothers, or the books publishers.

Despite the seemingly heavy-handed tactics of Warner Brothers, the company has always tried to make it clear that it has never had any intention of shutting genuine fan sites down. Its justification for threatening teenage girls with legal action is that it is protecting the Harry Potter brand.

Useful link: www.potterwar.org.uk

So far, Warners has not threatened to take Miss Chan to court, as she had complied with some of their requests to credit images to the entertainment giant. Nevertheless, Miss Chan has gone on record in the Asian press, voicing her concerns that one day she will be forced to close down "because other fairly well-established sites have shut down due to notices from Warner Brothers". The latest domain name dispute is almost a carbon copy of a case in December when 15-year-old Brit Claire Field received a letter from Warner Brothers's London legal department asking her to hand over the name www.harrypotterguide.co.uk. Like her dragon-defying idol, the British youth rebelled and gained the support of other Harry Potter fan sites around the world. The publicity gained by Miss Field eventually led to Warner Brothers granting her permission to keep the website although she had to make a number of changes. Her website now states on its opening page that it is an "unofficial Harry Potter site" with no connections to JK Rowling, Warner Brothers, or the books publishers. Despite the seemingly heavy-handed tactics of Warner Brothers, the company has always tried to make it clear that it has never had any intention of shutting genuine fan sites down. Its justification for threatening teenage girls with legal action is that it is protecting the Harry Potter brand. Useful link: www.potterwar.org.uk

webTitle: In brief: Crowe and Spacey battle for Capra-esque role

fields.headline: Crowe and Spacey battle for Capra-esque role
fields.standfirst: Plus: Damon and Affleck to bring wife-swapping to the screen; Vinnie Jones falls for the charms of LA; documentary about Shane Macgowan given cinema release
fields.trailText: Plus: Damon and Affleck to bring wife-swapping to the screen; Vinnie Jones falls for the charms of LA; documentary about Shane Macgowan given cinema release
fields.body:
 Russell Crowe (pictured) and Kevin Spacey are both competing for the same role in a new Disney comedy drama, according to Ananova. Honest Abe follows the fortunes of a nice guy whose principles and beliefs are questioned when he is elected to run for state Governor. It is rumoured that the £30m (£20.48m) film will be in the style of Frank Capra's 1939 classic Mr Smith Goes to Washington. Sources close to Capra-fan Crowe claim that he has been looking for just such a script with a 'lighter touch" after his rough and ready role in Gladiator. The smart money, however, is on double Oscar winner Spacey, soon to be seen in Pay it Forward, as Disney executives believe he is "more suitable."

 Hollywood buddies Matt Damon and Ben Affleck are set to team up again for a new baseball film about a real-life wife-swapping scandal. According to reports, Damon has bought the rights to sportswriter Maury Allen's memoirs All Roads Lead to October which chronicles the highs and lows of the New York Yankees. However, Damon is planning to focus only on the chapter which recounts the exploits of team-mates Fritz Peterson and Mike Kekick. According to Allen: "They literally exchanged wives, kids, houses, furniture, dogs and cats. They hatched the swapping plan whilst they were at my house."

 Vinnie Jones has sworn that he will never live in Britain again, according to entertainment site PeopleNews.com.The Snatch star, who moved to Los Angeles in 1999 claims he loves the anonymity that living in America gives him. "I went to the movies a couple of days ago," he told the site, "and then to a restaurant and just sat there and had a burger. I couldn't do that in England because the place would come to a standstill." The former footballer lives in a $3m home in LA with his wife and stepdaughter. He is currently filming espionage drama, Swordfish, with John Travolta and Halle Berry.

 Ex-Pogues frontman Shane Macgowan is apparently delighted with a new film about his life. The maker of the still-untitled TV documentary-turned-movie, Sarah Share claims that the troubled singer thinks that he has been depicted accurately and fairly. "Shane himself is extremely pleased with the finished product. He thinks it's the most honest and true material that has ever been done about him." She told reporters: "Some of it is actually quite hard-hitting, but Shane has no problems with that. He is quite prepared to take it on the chin." The warts and all documentary was originally commissioned by the Irish-language station TG4, but has now been acquired by the Buena Vista movie company for distribution on the big screen.
