fields.headline: Council rapped over 25-year dispute
fields.trailText: Bickering councillors have taken more than 25 years to decide on how and where to build a new civic centre, in what is thought to be one of local government's longest running planning disputes.
fields.body:
Bickering councillors have taken more than 25 years to decide on whether to build a new civic centre, in what is thought to be one of local government's longest running planning disputes.

Councillors have been discussing the new centre since Mid Devon district council was formed in 1974, and still have not reached a final decision. Chief executive Mike Bull today defended the council's record, saying it had faced "very difficult site issues".

But a review of the council says this is just the most extreme case of the inability of its councillors to take decisions, which are "constantly deferred, contradicted or avoided", and a symptom of wider problems at the authority.

The review goes on to say that the authority faces the possibility of serious overspending and has a demoralised and "ground down" workforce.

It concludes that if Mid Devon is to improve: "Councillors will need to overcome their long history of independence, lack of collaboration and mistrust of each other and of officers. They need to agree the future direction of the council."

The review was organised by the Improvement and Development Agency (IDeA), a local government self-policing body usually known for pulling its punches. It was carried out by local government professionals and councillors, and aimed at helping to improve the way the council is run.

Despite this, it says Mid Devon suffers from "weak political leadership" and that this has led to the authority wasting resources and running the risk of severe financial difficulties.

The council spends about £1m over its annual government spending assessments, and is currently balancing its books using interest from its reserve funds, which could soon be eaten up by planned new building projects, including a leisure centre.

Mr Bull, the lowest paid chief executive in the country according to the report, accepted the review's findings, admitting: "There've been difficult local dynamics." Mr Bull is retiring, but insisted the move had nothing to do with IDeA's report.

His employees are said to suffer from low pay and a "blame culture fostered by members (that) has a negative effect on the morale and motivation of staff".

Michael Lee, leader of the council's Conservative group, said of the review: "It's positive in a sense. We've got to do something, we've got to make it right. Otherwise we shall carry on as we are, in chaos."

The IDeA review highlights a number of positive aspects of Mid Devon's work, including its progress in working with other local service providers and businesses, the commitment of its staff and its recognition of the need to support the area's struggling rural economy.

The council has a history of being run by independents, and they still outnumber the largest political group, the 16-strong Liberal Democrats, by one councillor on the 40-seat authority.

The Fabian Society conference, 'Transforming Britain: Prospects for a Second Term', is being held on Saturday January 27 2001 in the Peacock Theatre of the London School of Economics, Portugal Street (off Kingsway), London WC2.

fields.headline: Hamas claims Netzarim bomb attack
fields.trailText: The Islamic militant group Hamas has claimed responsibility for this morning's roadside bomb attack on an Israeli tank that wounded a soldier near the Jewish settlement of Netzarim in Gaza.
fields.body:
The Islamic militant group Hamas has claimed responsibility for this morning's roadside bomb attack on an Israeli tank that wounded a soldier near the Jewish settlement of Netzarim in Gaza.

The incident occurred as Israeli and Palestinian negotiators tried to hammer out a peace accord in Egypt. They hope to strike a deal before the Israeli elections on 6 February, which could replace the current Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, with hawkish Ariel Sharon.

"The atmosphere is not negative and the discussions on refugees and land, including Jerusalem, are taking place in a very serious and detailed manner," said Palestinian information minister Yasser Abed Rabbo.

"If such an atmosphere continues until the end of the week, maybe we will then have a pleasant surprise. This does not mean we have agreed on any of the issues, but the talks are being held in an in-depth and serious way," he said.

The bomb attack at Netzarim has not hindered the talks so far and did not reverse an Israeli decision to open its borders with the Gaza Strip and the West Bank to the 16,000 Palestinians granted Israeli work permits last month.

The attack is the latest incident of violence in 16 weeks of unrest in which at least 368 people have died, most of them Palestinians.

Palestinian officials also responded to the change of administration in the US, accusing former US president Bill Clinton of siding with Israel during seven years at the helm of Middle East peace talks and calling on George W Bush's newly inaugurated administration to take a new tack.

The Palestinian negotiating team made the comments in a memorandum summing up the Clinton administration's role in brokering talks with Israel since the 1993 Oslo peace accords were signed. The US is the main sponsor of Middle East talks.

Palestinian officials close to negotiations with Israel said the letter was intended to notify US President George W Bush of Palestinian dissatisfaction at the way Clinton mediated the peace talks and to urge him "to avoid making the same errors".

"Over the last seven years in particular, the US has become increasingly identified with Israeli ideological assumptions," they stated in the memorandum.

They accused Washington of not taking a tough enough stand against Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, the occupied lands that Israel captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 war and that Palestinians want for a future state.

webTitle: Roma slip up as title race gets tight

fields.headline: Roma slip up as title race gets tight
fields.trailText: There are lots of things British fans find hard to understand about Italian football. There's the caginess of the tactics for a start, while the willingness to spend millions of pounds on Karel Poborksy is another. But the most baffling thing of all must surely be this concept of a "title race". What exactly does it mean?
fields.body:
There are lots of things British fans find hard to understand about Italian football. There's the caginess of the tactics for a start, while the willingness to spend millions of pounds on Karel Poborksy is another. But the most baffling thing of all must surely be this concept of a "title race". What exactly does it mean?

Well, after poring over this morning's league table, things become slightly clearer. It appears that a title race is when you have more than one team that could win the league. Roma are at the top of Serie A, like Manchester United are top of the Premiership, but they only lead the table by three points, with Juventus, and Dino Zoff's Lazio, breathing down their necks.

Fans of competition have Alberto Zaccheroni's AC Milan to thank. The Rossoneri ran out 3-2 victors against Roma at the San Siro last night, with two goals from Andrei Shevchenko taking the Ukranian back to his traditional place at the top of the Serie A scoring charts.

Leonardo gave the home side the lead after just three minutes, curling a free-kick past Cristiano Lupatelli from 25 yards. 18 minutes later Shevchenko took advantage of a malfunctioning offside trap to latch on to Demetrio Albertini's through-ball before beating Lupatelli for their second.

This sparked Roma into life, and Fabio Capello's side enjoyed their best spell of the match. But, with Gabriel Batistuta strangely wasteful in front of goal, they could only claim one back, through Francesco Totti's deflected strike.

That was all the encouragement Shevchenko needed, and the Ukrainian duly scored his 13th goal of the season a minute before half-time. A Totti penalty, late in the second half, reduced the final deficit.

Capello remained upbeat after the match. "I'm happy," he claimed. "Not with the result, but with the way my team played, and not only in the second half."

Taking a leaf out of the Massimo Taibi handbook, Capello went on to blame his team's studs for their poor first-half showing. "We didn't have the right studs for the pitch," he said. "I saw Gabriel Batistuta miss a great chance to score with his head because he slipped as he jumped. During the second half we changed our attitude, but our studs as well."

By contrast, Milan boss Alberto Zaccheroni was all doom and gloom. "This win has changed nothing between Milan and me," said the man tipped for the exit door at Milan this summer. "The players didn't play for anybody but themselves, and they didn't play for Zaccheroni. They played for themselves, and, after two points from their last four matches, they had to win at all costs."

Juve keep up the hunt

Juventus took full advantage of Roma's slip (without or without the studs) with a 1-0 away win over Perugia. Filippo Inzaghi's finish from a inspired pass by Edgar Davids was enough to see off the team who deprived them of the Scudetto on the final day of last season, and extend their unbeaten run to 11 league matches.

Several great saves from Perugia keeper Andrea Mazzantini kept the score down, which is more than can be said for the contents of Paolo Montero's stomach. The giant Uruguayan defender delayed the start of the second half by spewing in the centre circle. Montero played on and completed the match (picking up a customary yellow card) but the number of sliding tackles in around the centre spot has yet to be confirmed.

Lazio are go

The Saturday evening match saw Lazio's post-Sven-Goran Eriksson bounce continue at the expense of Internazionale (no real surprise, surely). Choosing to pair Hernan Crespo with Marcelo Salas, Dino Zoff's selection paid off as early as the fifth minute. A cross from Pavel Nedved was flicked on by Salas and Crespo arrived to do what he does best, turning the ball past Sebastien Frey from 10 yards.

Lazio were in charge of the match from then on, and in a dominant second half had a number of chances. Most prominent in these attacking thrusts was the aforementioned Czech Express (or whatever they call him) Karel Poborsky, and his tumble in the box in the 78th minute was rewarded with a penalty which Salas stepped up to take. He duly converted and put the game beyond Marco Tardelli's side.

webTitle: Peers urged to block human cloning

fields.headline: Peers urged to block human cloning
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText:
Religious leaders urge House of Lords to fight government plans to rush through plans to legalise human cloning.
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.body:
Religious leaders today urged the House of Lords to fight government plans to rush through laws to which would allow human cloning.

The Archbishop of Canterbury has joined forces with the Roman Catholic archbishops of Glasgow and Westminster, the Chief Rabbi and the President of the Muslim College to protest at changes to the law which will allow testing on stem cells derived from the cloning of human embryos.

In an open letter which was sent to all peers, the religious leaders said the proposals deserved to be examined in more detail than than that allowed by a brief parliamentary debate.

The Archbishop of Westminster, the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, said that the research had disturbing implications.

"Firstly this is using human life as disposable organic matter, and it is certainly the Catholic church's view that the human embryo from the very beginning has unlimited respect and protection," he said.

"And it is unnecessary. There are other ways of achieving stem cells from other sources, from adults, which will achieve the same ends."

If passed, the government's plans would permit limited human cloning which, say its detractors, would lead to full cloning in the future. Human cloning is, at present, illegal across the world.

Conservative peer Baroness Blatch, who plans to vote in favour of an amendment calling for a select committee to scrutinise the order, said the government's attempt to force it through was a "constitutional outrage".

"The government is abusing parliamentary procedure here. This is secondary legislation on a fundamental principle, which cuts across all parties and religions," she said.

Lord Alton, the crossbencher who suggested the amendment, said he was confident his colleagues would support him. "Many peers are surprised that we are having a full scale parliamentary Bill on fox hunting - and yet the government is stampeding an order through with awesome consequences, that have not been properly discussed," he said.

fields.headline: Hindujas get nasty surprise in court
fields.standfirst: How a 24-hour visit to Delhi for Britain's wealthiest Asian family turned into a lengthy grilling by India's Central Bureau of Investigation - and it's not over yet. Luke Harding reports from New Delhi
fields.trailText: How a 24-hour visit to Delhi for Britain's wealthiest Asian family turned into a lengthy grilling by India's Central Bureau of Investigation - and it's not over yet. Luke Harding reports from New Delhi
fields.body:
These are tricky times for the Hindujas, Britain's wealthiest Asian family. Last Thursday, the brothers - Srichand, Gopichand and Prakesh - flew into India for the first time since Indian investigators accused them of taking huge bribes in the country's most notorious corruption scandal.

It was a bold move. By coming to Delhi voluntarily, before they faced possible extradition proceedings, the billionaire industrialists would be able to confound their critics who said they would never show their faces in an Indian court. But things did not turn out as the Hindujas had expected.

On Friday, Ajit Bharihoke, the special judge hearing their case, ruled that they should not be allowed to return to Britain without his permission.The move appeared to dumbfound the Hindujas' defence team, who gathered in an impromptu huddle in the well of the Delhi court. They had earlier requested that the brothers be allowed to leave for the US that evening.

Worse was to follow. On Saturday Mr Bharihoke, ordered the brothers to submit themselves for questioning before India's Central Bureau of Investigation. Srichand was grilled for three hours, returning yesterday for another five. His brothers are expected to appear this week.

Instead of spending only 24 hours in India, it now appears that the Hindujas could be stuck here for weeks, if not months. Srichand Hinduja, the group chairman, has responded to this setback with philosophical good humour.'Whether our application (to leave) is granted or not granted, with modern communications we can still operate,' he told the Guardian. 'We have nothing to hide.'

The industrialists are accused of accepting £7.1m in commission from the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors.The money was allegedly paid in 1986 after they used their influence with the late Indian prime minister Rajiv Gandhi to secure the firm a huge defence contract.The bribes were hidden in a series of secret Swiss banks accounts, codenamed Lotus, Mont Blanc and Tulip, it is claimed.

Indian investigators have been pursuing those they claim were involved in the scandal for 10 years. But they have acquired a dangerous momentum thanks to the Hindujas' close and substantial links with New Labour. They entertained Tony and Cherie Blair at their annual 'interfaith' party 14 months ago and gave £1m to sponsor the Dome's spirit zone.

The Hindujas have consistently denied the allegations.

The Observer revealed yesterday the brothers had asked Peter Mandelson to inquire whether an application for British citizenship by Srichand - known as SP - would be welcomed by the Home Office. SP's previous application had been rejected but in March 1999 it was approved, just as Swiss federal courts indicated they would release details of the Hindujas' private bank accounts.

Gopichand became a British citizen in November 1997, soon after Labour's election victory, while Prakesh acquired Swiss nationality in October 1999, in the same month that the Indian CBI first named the Hindujas in connection with the Bofors scandal. SP yesterday confirmed he had approached Mr Mandelson over his passport application but said he had only asked for procedural advice.

The fact that the Hindujas are no longer Indian citizens has left prosecutors 'apprehensive' as to whether they will turn up for the later stages of their trial. Between March 1991 and March 1999 the brothers came to India 78 times but then stopped coming when their Swiss bank accounts were finally disclosed to investigators.

Though they appear to have suffered a temporary setback the Hindujas can take consolation from the fact that Indian justice moves extremely slowly - and that they will probably be allowed back to Britain next month. Observers in Delhi agree it could be another 10 years before a verdict is pronounced on their case, if ever, by which time New Labour could be history.

fields.headline: Bears, Potatoes, and Flash cards
fields.trailText: KAN I BUILD IT (A SMALL HOUSE IN THE NORTH OF ENGLAND THAT IS)?
fields.body:
KAN I BUILD IT (A SMALL HOUSE IN THE NORTH OF ENGLAND THAT IS)?

If you're a bear or a tortoise and have been hibernating for the past few months, you may have missed Frederic Kanoute's goalscoring form for West Ham. In fact, if you are a bear then you should probably still be asleep, so apologies for any disturbance. The point is that Freddie K has been good - really good - for something approaching a third of a season. Which means he's fully justified in talking up a move away from the club he joined only last summer, isn't he?

"When you are in a big team like Arsenal or Manchester United the selectors see you all the time," Kanoute told the Mirror this morning (in an interview sponsored, for some reason, by a power company). "As soon as I get into that team, the selectors will look at me. Sometimes you have to move to get noticed."

Now, while it would obviously be the selectors' fault if Freddie left Upton Park, the 24-year-old still felt the need to issue a quick website-based statement this afternoon (sponsored by his official website) to assure Hammers fans that he's staying. Sort of. "It's nice to think that such big sides are interested in me - it's an honour. But I must forget about that," he said, as if he was Nigel Lythgoe thanking that fat Scottish singer for turning up.

So Freddie is staying at West Ham forever. Which must be some relief to him, because he's unlikely to survive if he ever ventures north of Watford. Explaining that the sort of big clubs he was interested in basically amounted to Arsenal and Manchester United, Kanoute observed: "I don't really like the north. It's always cold, it's always raining, and I don't like all those little houses." Which means he can't have looked around Upton Park recently. Or found Manchester on a map. But, apart from that, good work Fred.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HIS LAME IS RIO

Getting up and being active is never easy if you spend most of your life slumped in front of the television. For example, the Fiver's weekend consisted of draping ourselves over the sofa drinking fizzy pop (bad), smoking tabs (extremely bad) and eating kebabs (healthier than pizza), and as a result we're in no shape to play a full 90 minutes of football. Having said that, we could just about manage ten if we didn't leave the centre circle - and that's more than you'll get from telly addict Rio Ferdinand at the moment.

"It was freak accident and typical of this season," said David O'Leary O'Leeds this afternoon, as he patiently waited for his voice to be drowned out by chortles of varying pitch and volume. "Rio was watching television and had his foot up on the coffee table. He had it there in a certain position for a number of hours, then he gets up and he's strained a tendon behind his knee."

Before O'Leary could tell us that Rio is likely to miss the midweek game against Aston Villa but should be back for next Saturday's FA Cup tie with Liverpool, thoughts had drifted elsewhere. After all, wasn't it Rio's team-mate Robbie Keane who once ruptured knee ligaments upon bending down to pick up a remote? And didn't David Seaman, who must have played against Rio or Robbie at some point, break a bone in his foot performing a similar act? Why, it must be a curse! Ban this evil menace now!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm listening to my body. Something has to give and it has to be the internationals" - Tony Adams announces his retirement from international football. His body was unavailable for comment.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NOT MUCH ADO ABOUT SOMETHING

[Scene: A training field, somewhere near the Riverside stadium this morning. Standing in the field are two figures, one in a three-quarter-length leather jacket, the other in a big sheepskin coat and chatting on a mobile. Two more men arrive, both with silver hair, wearing glasses and sensible winter jackets. They are both smiling politely. The man in the sheepskin coat goes over to them and offers his hand as if to shake, before pulling it away at the last minute]

TEL (yes, that's right): Allo Sven. I'm Terry, but you can call me Terry. I used to manage England, got 'em to the semi-finals of Euro 96. English through and through me.

SVEN: That's very good, yes. And who is? [Sven points in the direction of the leather-jacketed man]

TEL: That's Robbo. Say 'ello Robbo.

ROBBO: 'ello Robbo.

SVEN: This is Tord. [Points to other well-dressed Scandinavian] Tel, I am here to be packing your brains about the big job. Do you have any tips?

TEL: Yeah, pick Incey, he's brilliant.

ROBBO: Pick Incey, he's brilliant.

TEL: And Ugo Ehiogu.

ROBBO: Ugo.

SVEN: Yes, that's very good. But do you not have anything you want to say about the job, the pressures of creating a tight-knit group of players in such a short space of time?

TEL: No, and if you don't sling your Swedish [another man appears in the field. He is a reporter for Middlesbrough's official website]

REPORTER: Mr Sven, Mr Sven, do you have anything to say to our readers that will be repeated first by other websites, then the TV, and then the next day by the papers?

SVEN: "I feel at home everywhere. It's perfect, wonderful. There are many good players and I will try now to see as many as possible and try to talk to as many managers as possible before the first friendly game we have in February. Terry is an extremely good manager. He has done the work before me and it's very important that I have a good relationship with him." Will that do?

REPORTER: Thank you Mr Sven, thank you.

SVEN: Terry, I must now be going. But please do keep in touch.

TEL: That'll be the day. But before you go, have you ever thought about investing in an internet business?

SVEN: I really must now go.

TEL: Well, I just happen to know this fella

[SVEN heads off to a helicopter parked nearby, while TORD can be seen explaining the finer points of catenaccio to ROBBO with a series of flash cards]

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Reports in France suggest that Liverpool are close to agreeing a £7m deal with Paris St Germain striker Christian.

Manchester United are looking at Henrik Larsson as a replacement for Teddy Sheringham.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

West Ham are close to signing Bulgarian forward Svetoslav Todorov from Lovech in a £500,000 deal which will rise to up to £2m depending on appearances.

Carl Asaba is set to complete a £750,000 move from Gillingham to Crystal Palace.

Newcastle midfielder Kieron Dyer has been given the all-clear to resume training after undergoing tests on what was believed to be a serious shin splints problem. "All tests have shown no serious problem at the present time," a club spokesman said today. He is expected to be fit to play next week."

Liverpool are facing a striking mini-crisis with both Michael Owen and Emile Heskey injured. Owen has had a precautionary scan on his right hamstring and could be ruled out for two weeks, while Heskey is likely to be out for a week with a thigh injury.

Everton midfielder Paul Gascoigne is out for another month after suffering a recurrence of the thigh muscle tear that has already ruled him out since November 5.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (1.30am)

[rustle, bang, clank]

Channel 5: Argentine Football (3.55am)

Ssh! Can you hear something stirring?

Sky Sports 1: Live Monday Night Football - Charlton v West Ham (7pm, 12midnight)

[loud braying, angular shuffling, general bedlam]

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 2am)

Why, it's McCaff!

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11.30pm SS1)

[snivel, sniff, whine]

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)

Hmm, he's fed up of being ignored and he's demanding some attention.

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)

[stamping of feet, holding of breath, angry twanging of braces]

Talksport: Football First with Steve Bower (7pm)

Stop that! Now, be patient and you may get a cuddle tomorrow.

webTitle: Derek Malcolm live on Film Unlimited

fields.headline: Derek Malcolm live on Film Unlimited
fields.standfirst: With the completion of his century of films, Derek Malcolm went online to discuss the 100 movies which he selected as the best of the last 100 years. During the conversation, Derek discovered that there was some disagreement about whether his choice was too esoteric or not esoteric enough!
fields.trailText: With the completion of his century of films, Derek Malcolm went online to discuss the 100 movies which he selected as the best of the last 100 years. During the conversation, Derek discovered that there was some disagreement about whether his choice was too esoteric or not esoteric enough!
fields.body:
gillianmar Excuse my ignorance if you have already done this, Derek, but have you ever considered directing your own feature?

Derek Malcolm Yes, I nearly made a film once... actually in Australia. Lucky I didn't, isn't it? I guess it would have been very moderate indeed. Might have had a good script, though.

gillianmar You have the dream job of most of the people on the site, I'm sure you realise that, but has watching films for a living ever become a chore?

Derek MalcolmYes, being a film critic is much better than work! But there are some crosses to bear, and they include many, many bad movies indeed. I see around 500 a year and guess how many of those are good. About 50 at the most. Yes, you do get bored and it does become a chore sometimes. But then you see a movie of worth and your enthusiasm is fired up again. I've never lost my love of movies. But I hate bad ones with a mortal hatred.

paul15 Very enjoyable as list-making can be - how would you answer the criticism raised by David Thomson, and I'm sure many others, that these exercises to identify the best-ever films of all time are evidence that "clearly, the medium is begining to die"? Are we poking around in the dust of a once-great but will-never-be-great-again medium or do you think, more hopefully, that such exercises suggest a maturity, a sense that film has both a treasurable history and a vital future?

Derek Malcolm You want to know whether the cinema or film is dying. I doubt it's so, but this is not a golden age, that's for sure. Maybe there'll be another one - even if commercial interests, which mean everyone has to make the same movie to be successful - make that difficult to envisage. Will there be another Bergman, Fellini, Tarkovsky, Ford, Hawks, etc, etc? I'm afraid that I doubt it. But the influence of these great artists will live on, and some may eventually equal them. Not in my lifetime however, the way things are going.

harrybackhouse This site is populated by film enthusiasts and yet the vast majority of the posters here have seen less than half of your list. How do you respond to the accusation that your list is too esoteric to be of any practical use?

Derek Malcolm Too esoteric? Not really. It's just that so many films of great stature are never seen these days that I wanted to remind people that they exist and should be revived. World cinema is alive and well but for the fact that so little of it gets out and about to the cinema-goers of the world. Should I only have included films that people can see? Well, it would have been a pretty moderate list!

shakermaker What's your favorite film of the last 5 years?

Derek Malcolm The best movie I've seen in the last five years? That's very difficult but it could be Breaking the Waves, it could be Edward Yang's Yi Yi, it could be one of Mike Leigh's. It sure doesn't come from Hollywood unfortunately. That lot are far too predicated on making movies for 17-25 year-olds. Only it's 45-year-olds who are making them!

frmerrin While I realise you have to be selective, I was very disappointed at the lack of any films by Sam Peckinpah, one of the masters of American cinema, or Brian De Palma, surely the most underrated American filmmaker since Robert Aldrich. Did you feel a conscious determination to steer away from commercial American film in your choices ?

Derek Malcolm You bemoan the absence of Peckinpah, De Palma and Aldrich - so do I, in a way, though they are not my favourite directors. They just didn't quite make the list, that's all. A lot of others who are worthy didn't either. No, I have no bias against the American commercial cinema, though it sure isn't very good now. It's just that I do have a bias towards world cinema, which is so badly ignored nowadays. There are well over 30 Hollywood movies on my list. Surely enough, and certainly more than from anywhere else. But there happen to be good movies from India, Africa, Latin America, et al too. Not many may have seen them outside their own countries, but they should have.

pickers I have seen only 3 of your list. Is there any hope for me?

Derek Malcolm Yes, there is hope, but you need medication... seriously, I understand. if you don't live in or near London or other big cities, and you don't watch TV much, you would be lucky to have seen one of my choices.

robmaj While I applaud your endeavour in fashioning a list of your hundred favourite films, I can't help thinking your choices a little populist. Don't you feel that you should have chosen a more individual list? Shouldn't the critic lead the public, rather that follow it slavishly? Come on Derek, let's have something a little more esoteric?

Derek Malcolm So you think my list isn't esoteric enough. I agree! I'm really upset by the fact that readers have actually seen some of these films. I was hoping I could maintain a clean sheet.

It's just that so many films of great stature are never seen these days that I wanted to remind people that they exist and should be revived. World cinema is alive and well but for the fact that so little of it gets out and about to the cinema-goers of the world. Should I only have included films that people can see? Well, it would have been a pretty moderate list! shakermaker What's your favorite film of the last 5 years? Derek Malcolm The best movie I've seen in the last five years? That's very difficult but it could be Breaking the Waves, it could be Edward Yang's Yi Yi, it could be one of Mike Leigh's. It sure doesn't come from Hollywood unfortunately. That lot are far too predicated on making movies for 17-25 year-olds. Only it's 45-year-olds who are making them! frmerrin While I realise you have to be selective, I was very disappointed at the lack of any films by Sam Peckinpah, one of the masters of American cinema, or Brian De Palma, surely the most underrated American filmmaker since Robert Aldrich. Did you feel a conscious determination to steer away from commercial American film in your choices ? Derek Malcolm You bemoan the absence of Peckinpah, De Palma and Aldrich - so do I, in a way, though they are not my favourite directors. They just didn't quite make the list, that's all. A lot of others who are worthy didn't either. No, I have no bias against the American commercial cinema, though it sure isn't very good now. It's just that I do have a bias towards world cinema, which is so badly ignored nowadays. There are well over 30 Hollywood movies on my list. Surely enough, and certainly more than from anywhere else. But there happen to be good movies from India, Africa, Latin America, et al too. Not many may have seen them outside their own countries, but they should have. pickers I have seen only 3 of your list. Is there any hope for me? Derek Malcolm Yes, there is hope, but you need medication... seriously, I understand. if you don't live in or near London or other big cities, and you don't watch TV much, you would be lucky to have seen one of my choices. robmaj While I applaud your endeavour in fashioning a list of your hundred favourite films, I can't help thinking your choices a little populist. Don't you feel that you should have chosen a more individual list? Shouldn't the critic lead the public, rather that follow it slavishly? Come on Derek, let's have something a little more esoteric? Derek Malcolm So you think my list isn't esoteric enough. I agree! I'm really upset by the fact that readers have actually seen some of these films. I was hoping I could maintain a clean sheet.

webTitle: Havas to take 100% control of Media Planning

fields.headline: Havas to take 100% control of Media Planning
fields.trailText: 5pm: French ad giant Havas is set to increase its 45% stake in Media Planning to 100%, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
French advertising giant Havas has unveiled plans to take full control of Media Planning, the global media buying network whose clients include Microsoft, UDV and the Central Office of Information.

Havas, the world's fourth-biggest advertising network, already holds a 45% stake in Media Planning. Havas will buy the remaining 55% share from its Spanish owners at an estimated cost of $550m in cash and stock.

The news follows reports at the weekend that Havas is in preliminary talks to buy rival advertising group True North.

According to the Financial Times Havas, which owns the advertising agencies Euro RSCG and WCRS in the UK, is considering a bid that would value True North at more than $2bn. Neither company would comment on the report.

fields.headline: Global warming: full steam ahead
fields.standfirst:
The change of power in Washington doesn't bode well for the future of the planet, writes environment correspondent Paul Brown

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The change of power in Washington doesn't bode well for the future of the planet, writes environment correspondent Paul Brown.
fields.body:
It seems ironic that on the day the world's scientists issue a report saying the problem is escalating, the new US president should say he is not sure whether global warming is a reality or a threat.

Man is having a serious effect on the climate, and temperature and sea level rises are going to be higher than was predicted in the last report five years ago, according to the latest research.

The ponderously named Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change is a collection of 3,000 of the world's best climate scientists who have studied every aspect of climate change and come to the conclusion that it is speeding up dramatically.

In the worst case, temperatures could rise 6C in the next century and sea levels by a metre. Add to that the regional differences - for example it gets much warmer in big landmasses like Europe and North America - and the changes are too fast for natural vegetation like trees to adapt. The result is potentially disastrous.

One of the ironies is that some of the best and most influential scientists who have come to these conclusions are American, yet they have a Texan oil man, President George W Bush, who is not convinced of their arguments.

Since the US emits 24% of the world's main greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide, an agreement to cut the world's emissions must include America. When the climate talks collapsed in December, the US was blamed for refusing to make enough effort to cut its domestic emissions.

America wanted to rely on planting forests and changing agricultural practices to claim credit for emitting less carbon dioxide than it would have done so otherwise. The EU rejected this as cheating.

Talks are due to resume in May, but already the US has asked for a postponement until July. The reasoning is that the new administration's team - which is not yet assembled - will need until then to brief itself on the complex issues involved.

US allies, which in this case including Russia, Japan, Canada, Ukraine and Australia, are backing this stance, and, despite the irritation of Europe and developing countries such as India and China, look likely to succeed.

So while the science moves on, the political progress is stalled. Currently, the world looks as if it is racing towards climate disaster.

fields.headline: 'Malicious racism' in youth prison
fields.standfirst:
'Overt race malice' at youth prison

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: A confidential prison service report following the murder of an Asian inmate by a white prisoner at Feltham, west London, has concluded that the youth jail is guilty of institutional racism, with ethnic minority staff and inmates enduring overt racist abuse by warders and failures by senior management.
fields.body:
A confidential prison service report following the murder of an Asian inmate by a white prisoner at Feltham, west London, has concluded that the youth jail is guilty of institutional racism, with ethnic minority staff and inmates enduring overt racist abuse by warders and failures by senior management.

The report, obtained by the Guardian, follows the beating to death of Zahid Mubarek by his cellmate Robert Stewart and is the most damning official indictment of racism within a British jail ever.

Martin Narey, director general of the prison service, commented: "There's no element of denial, I've been absolutely up front about the problems we have. It goes beyond institutional racism to blatant malicious pockets of racism."

But Mr Narey said no officer was facing disciplinary action over racism or allegations of intimidation because evidence had not been found identifying individuals as culpable.

The prison service commissioned an internal inquiry into the troubled young offenders' institution in September. Stewart was convicted of Mubarek's racist murder in November. Prison staff missed repeated signs that Stewart, a racist psychopath, would harm his cellmate.

The report by the senior investigating officer, Ted Butt, brands Feltham as "institutionally racist", and found a "damning indictment of how staff are failing in their duty of care towards prisoners".

It concludes: "There is evidence that racism exists at Feltham, both overtly and by more subtle methods. Minority ethnic staff should not have to tolerate the level of harassment that exists in order to feel accepted as part of the team. Similarly, prisoners should be able to live free from racist abuse by staff."

The first part of Mr Butt's report on Feltham, revealed by the Guardian in November, condemned poor management and a host of other failings that led to Stewart's racist and violent tendencies being missed.

The second part of the report focuses solely on racism. It has been with Mr Narey for weeks, having been completed in December - but no date for its publication has been set.

Last night Mr Mubarek's family demanded that the government set up a full public inquiry into his death. Their lawyer, Imran Khan, said Mr Narey should call in the police: "There's no doubt there's a degree of criminal culpability by prison officers who've abused their position."

Mr Butt's report says: "Evidence found by the team suggests that a small number of staff sustained and promoted overtly racist behaviour as well as more subtle methods and that there are issues surrounding both staff and prisoners.

"Staff from all ethnic groups told of an underlying culture that suggests the only way minority ethnic group staff can be accepted as part of the team of Feltham is by enduring racist comments and racist banter/jokes. Senior managers know what they should be doing but have not done it. This leads the inquiry team to form the conclusion that Feltham is institutionally racist."

The report, stamped as confidential on each of its 30 pages, found a "failure by staff at all levels to take complaints of racist incidents seriously". It said some of those responsible for race training believed racist jokes could be acceptable.

Half of Feltham's 717 inmates are from Asian or Afro-Caribbean backgrounds, as are 11% of its 654 staff. The senior management is entirely white.

The inquiry team even doubted whether records detailing which staff had received race relations training were genuine.

"The training department records show that 103 members of staff have received race relations training since November 1999. Sixteen members of staff surveyed are shown as having been trained, out of these only three stated they had been trained."

The report says it is apparent that the poor state of race relations at Feltham owes much to the lack of an effective race relations management team. The inquiry team felt the team was reactive rather than proactive.

The report says warders were twice as likely to use control and restraint force against black or Asian inmates than against a white prisoner.

It also found that inmates had no faith in the complaints system and heard allegations from the board of visitors that prisoners were intimidated into keeping silent.

Mr Butt calls for a further inquiry into a host of concerns and wrote: "The use of unacceptable language, intimidating prisoners into not complaining, failures to carry out investigations of racist incidents and evident deficiencies in the regime concerning food, paint a sorry picture of Feltham prison.

"Most alarmingly, though, families contacting the board of visitors rather than the managers at Feltham to complain about racist issues, is a damning indictment of the lack of trust between prisoners, their families and Feltham prison."

The report's conclusion says: "The procedures in place for reporting and recording racist incidents are poor, inconsistent and not communicated to those who may need to use them. Similarly, the procedures for investigating such incidents are haphazard, incomplete and again inconsistently applied."

It demands that improvements in race relations must be a management priority.

The report also says that a staff member is under investigation after "requesting a Muslim visitor to remove his headgear for searching".

Imtiaz Mubarek, uncle of Zahid, aged 19 when he was murdered in March 2000, said: "This is more reason for there to be a full public inquiry into Zahid's death. Feltham is a hotbed for racism. The lack of commitment for race issues among staff contributed to Zahid's death."

The commission for racial equality is due to investigate racism within British jails following the murder. The Metropolitan police is investigating whether prison service managers should face charges of corporate manslaughter for neglect.

Full text
Read excerpts of the secret report

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-one, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-one, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Blue Square's Patrick Murray with more examples of pathetic failure
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £154.49, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £39.40, Paul MacInnes = £28.15
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £154.49, Sean Ingle = £52.75, Football Unlimited punters collective = £39.40, Paul MacInnes = £28.15

Scott Murray: Tottenham v Southampton - Southampton to win £5 @ 4/1

He's at it again, opposing home sides with unbeaten home records. Last week it was Arsenal, this week it's Spurs, what does Mr M have against these North London clubs? I do hope these bets are being chosen on purely footballing grounds (though admittedly opposing 'popular' teams is often a good policy as their odds are liable to have been artificially shortened by the bookies).

Last week, I pointed Scott in the direction of the Asian handicap - unbeaten home teams, even those who look ripe for opposing, are surely far more likely to draw than lose - but did he listen? I fear not. Of course, the price is shorter when your team are getting a half or three-quarter goal start, but in a game such as this I would think the increased chance of winning gained by having the draw on your side more than makes up for this.

But, as I also said last week, who am I to advise the legend that is Scott Murray, who has accumulated his vast wealth through just such bets as this one?

Paul MacInnes: Risky £5 treble - Gillingham to beat Crystal Palace @ 5/2, Leeds to beat Newcastle @ 4/7, Man Utd to beat Aston Villa @ 1/3

In a way, I suppose it's a good job Mr MacInnes couldn't get a single on Gillingham because the sheer heartbreak of seeing a two-goal lead evaporate in the last ten minutes might have permanently scarred his already bruised psyche.

It's never a good sign when a punter is writing off his chances before the game has even begun, but we've all been there - we've all had these bad runs where it seems we could no more pick a winner than see than the point of Nicky Butt. But one must not give into despair: while there is life there is hope, luck will even out in the long run (that damn phrase again) and value bets will start to pay off.

One more thing, Mr M, although 'those Blue Square bloodsuckers' may have tried to stop you having a single on Gillingham (FA regulations, old chap, nothing to do with us), the good old British weather did in fact come to your aid with its traditional January decimation of the fixture list.

If you had included a couple of postponed matches in your treble, you could have got round the trebles-only rule. As it was, filling up your treble with a couple of short priced Premiership teams is just about the worst course of action in terms of value, though I appreciate that in this scenario winners, not value, are (wrongly) what you were looking for.

Thank the Lord, in a sense, for Leeds' ineptitude which blunted the pain of Palace's comeback. Ten-odd years ago, back in the days when trebles only was the rule for all football, I myself learnt the pain of losing a two-goal lead in the last ten minutes. In fact, it was the last two minutes in my case: Manchester City, inevitably, conspired to draw at home against the mighty Oldham, costing me over £200 quid (a lot of money for me back then).

But I survived, prospered even, and so can you, dear punter - if just keep your eye on the long run and stick to the value singles through thick and thin. It's the way forward, honest.

Tim Sainty of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Coventry v Everton - 0-1 goals @ 9/4

Ignoring for a moment the fact that this bet had already lost with less than 15 minutes of the match gone, it is hard to fault the logic behind it. Coventry are woeful in front of goal, Everton are ravaged by injury, the fact that the bet was a loser doesn't mean it wasn't value.

If the likes of Mr Sainty had been choosing the bets every week maybe the FUPC won't be in the predicament it now is. Or maybe it would - it's equally true that just because its value doesn't mean it will win in the short term and the long term can be very long indeed.

This is the third week back after our Christmas break and our intrepid punters have yet to pick a winner between them. It would try the patience of a saint but a saintly patience is what is required; as soon as desperation starts to set in, thoughts of value go out the window and, in the long run, it is only through value that a profit can be made.

Get well soon, Sean Ingle!

! indeed.

webTitle: Blair's constituency in support of regional government

fields.headline: Blair's constituency in support of regional government
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today faces fresh pressure to devolve more power to the English regions after a poll of voters in his Sedgefield constituency found overwhelming support for the move. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Tony Blair today faces fresh pressure to devolve more power to the English regions after a poll of voters in his Sedgefield constituency found overwhelming support for the move.

The survey, conducted by the campaign for a north-east assembly, found nearly three-quarters of the prime minister's constituents wanted a referendum within the next two years on whether their region should have its own elected assembly.

The prime minister is said to be unconvinced of the case for further devolution, worrying that there is little support for the move.

This latest poll will confound some of his objections by suggesting a mounting head of steam behind calls for more devolution in the prime minister's own backyard. A 1999 Mori poll for the Economist found around half of those in the north-east supported the idea of having a regional assembly, compared with today's 72% finding in Sedgefield.

Ian Mearns, the campaign's chairman and a Gateshead councillor, said: "We can see the power the Scottish parliament gives them at the bargaining table. We've had a fairly consistent demand, and that's for the development of a regional government with powers at least as strong as those of the Welsh assembly."

The poll is part of a concerted campaign by MPs and activists to persuade the prime minister to allow referendums on regional assemblies, and to kick-start the debate on regional devolution in the run-up to the general election.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is known to be strongly in favour, and northern Labour MPs Austin Mitchell and Jim Cousins have led backbench calls for action.

Mr Mitchell last week told MPs: "Devolution provides Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales with a powerful platform from which to argue for a better deal and attract new industries. We need that same platform."

Mr Blair also faces pressure for devolution from Labour's national policy forum, which has called on ministers to produce a green paper on regional government. This follows on from the party's 1997 election manifesto pledge to allow referendums on devolution "in time".

Mr Prescott told the commons last week that devolution in London, Scotland and Wales, and the creation of regional development agencies, were "a good step towards our commitment".

The campaign's phone poll took in 224 voters in the Sedgefield constituency, and was put together by volunteers under the guidance of Howard Elcock, professor of government at the University of Northumbria, who is backing the results.

"It's 95% certain at least that they'll have a representative sample. I don't think there's anything problematic about the way they've gone about it," said Mr Elcock.

We need that same platform." Mr Blair also faces pressure for devolution from Labour's national policy forum, which has called on ministers to produce a green paper on regional government. This follows on from the party's 1997 election manifesto pledge to allow referendums on devolution "in time". Mr Prescott told the commons last week that devolution in London, Scotland and Wales, and the creation of regional development agencies, were "a good step towards our commitment". The campaign's phone poll took in 224 voters in the Sedgefield constituency, and was put together by volunteers under the guidance of Howard Elcock, professor of government at the University of Northumbria, who is backing the results. "It's 95% certain at least that they'll have a representative sample. I don't think there's anything problematic about the way they've gone about it," said Mr Elcock.

fields.headline: Dell spooks markets with another profit warning
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: In another blow for the US tech sector, computer company Dell has posted its fifth profit warning in a year, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The punch-drunk US technology sector is reeling from another blow after computer company Dell posted its fifth profit warning in a year.

Dell said a slowdown in the global economy and a fall in demand for computer systems and services would push fourth quarter earnings below analysts' estimates.

A below-par Christmas trading period has produced similar warnings from the likes of Apple, Compaq and Hewlett-Packard, and accelerated the slump in the technology-based Nasdaq index in New York.

The plight of normally sturdy technology heavyweights such as Dell has exacerbated the downward spiral of telecoms, media and technology stocks over the past six months. The coming together of the internet, TV and telecoms as media distribution platforms, and the cross-sector alliances that have been formed by companies, have caused TMT stocks to be lumped together by panicking stock market investors.

Dell said fourth quarter revenues would be between £5.81bn and £5.87bn, below previous estimates of £5.94bn. In a strong hint at drastic cost-cutting measures, the company said it plans to "aggressively manage its cost structure" during the next year.

Dell announces its fourth quarter results on February 15.

webTitle: Pope acts to protect his legacy

fields.headline: Pope acts to protect his legacy
fields.standfirst: 37 new cardinals named in attempt to sway choice of successor
fields.trailText: 37 new cardinals named in attempt to sway choice of successor.
fields.byline: Stephen Bates, religious affairs correspondent and  Philip Willan  in Rome
fields.body:
The Pope yesterday sought to secure his conservative legacy in the Vatican by naming an unprecedented 37 new cardinals to join the college that will eventually choose his successor.

Speaking in a tired and slurred voice from the window of his study, the Pope, 80, who is known to have Parkinson's disease, named the new cardinals during his weekly address and blessing of pilgrims in St Peter's Square.

The move is being seen as his latest - and possibly last - attempt to ensure that the men who will choose his successor from among their number will elect someone in his image as a theologically and socially conservative leader.

Two churchmen are being appointed in pectore - in the breast. Their names are not being disclosed for fear they will be persecuted.

But the Pope lamented the fact that he could not find room for still more appointees "whose dedication to the service of God's people merits a promotion to the dignity of cardinal".

"I hope to have the opportunity in future to show also in this manner to them and to the countries from which they come my esteem and my affection," he added.

The rank of cardinal comes second only to that of pope. It is the cardinals - or at least those under the age of 80 - who are locked away in conclave after each pope's death to choose a successor, with a puff of white smoke from the chimney of the apostolic palace next to St Peter's traditionally showing that they have reached their decision.

The laborious voting - the successful candidate must achieve a two-thirds majority - is highly political, even though the cardinals are supposed to be secluded from outside pressure and guided only by God.

All popes try to point the cardinals towards a successor who will continue their legacy - but few have been as determined as John Paul II. Just as he has named more saints than any of his predecessors, he has also appointed more cardinals during his reign - 195, though not all survive, and some are over 80 and therefore ineligible to vote.

The list shows the changing global balance of the church: 11 new cardinals from Latin America and six more from Asia and Africa.

John Wilkins, editor of the Roman Catholic weekly the Tablet, said: "It is a much longer list than expected. I would have thought it is inconceivable that the Pope would not have scrutinised the names very carefully to ensure they are in sympathy with his thinking."

Also among those named is the leader of the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales, the Archbishop of Westminster, the Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, and the Most Rev Desmond Connell, Archbishop of Dublin.

Archbishop Murphy-O'Connor, who succeeded Cardinal Basil Hume at Westminster a year ago, said: "I see this as a great honour for the Catholic church in England and Wales and as a sign of the warmth that exists in the relationship between the Holy See and the Catholic community in these countries."

The announcement means that, for the first time certainly since the Reformation, there will be four cardinals from the British Isles, the latest appointments joining Scotland's Cardinal Thomas Winning and the former archbishop of Armagh, Cahal Daly.

The new cardinals will gather in Rome next month for the consistory - a ceremonial meeting of cardinals - at which the Pope will formally appoint them and give them the traditional scarlet hat and robes and ring to signify their office as princes of the church. The gathering is expected to take place on February 22, the Feast of the Chair of St Peter.

Cardinals, who are usually appointed from the rank of bishop or archbishop, are meant to be men "outstanding in doctrine, virtue, piety and prudence in practical matters".

Until the 16th century, popes could choose their relatives or favourites - even very young men or children - but the rules have been tightened up since then. With no obvious successor commanding wide enough support to gain the required majority, the race to be next pope is regarded as wide open.

Senior Catholics are already saying that the preferred candidate of the church's liberals, Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini of Milan, now has no chance of succeeding - although they are taking solace in the knowledge that previous conclaves have not always gone the way the popes who appointed them would have liked, appointing liberal candidates instead of reactionary ones and vice versa.

Of yesterday's nominees, Giovanni Battista Re, head of the Congregation of Bishops and former deputy secretary of state at the Vatican, can be expected to ally himself with other Vatican insiders in pushing for a conservative candidate. He is spoken of as a future pope, though probably not next time.

The Archbishop of Lima, Juan Luis Cipriani Thorne, is the first open member of the secretive and highly reactionary Opus Dei movement to be made a cardinal and he can be expected to wield strong influence with his fellow Latin Americans.

In the words of The Next Pope, a recent book on the papacy by the late Peter Hebblethwaite and his wife Margaret: "Whatever happens inside the conclave, no one is going to have more influence on its outcome than the one man who will not be there: John Paul II. He cannot himself choose his successor but he has chosen the people who will be the ones to choose his successor."

The main candidates

Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, 73 Archbishop of Milan. Not a progressive but regarded as head and shoulders above other Italian candidates in intellectual, administrative and pastoral ability. "Not flashy - on the contrary, rather a dry Martini - though with great stature," say the Hebblethwaites. A Jesuit; no Jesuit has ever become pope

Cardinal Giacomo Biffi, 71 Archbishop of Bologna. Theologically highly conservative and intransigent. Probably the choice of reactionary groups such as Opus Dei. Opposes feminism, pacifism, gay rights. Recently suggested non-Catholics (especially Muslims) should not be allowed to settle in Italy

Cardinal Diognigi Tettamanzi, 66 Archbishop of Genoa.
Possible compromise candidate. Able but dull. Famously described by the Archbishop of Edinburgh as "a wee fat guy". Could he ever live down his name, though? It means bull's tits

Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, 72 Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (formerly known as the Inquisition).
The ultimate Vatican insider. Highly able but theologically deeply conservative

Cardinal Christoph Schönborn, 54 Archbishop of Vienna.
The coming man, highly intelligent though theologically conservative, from an aristocratic family and appointed to deal with the mess when his predecessor had to resign in 1995 in a sex abuse scandal

Cardinal Francis Arinze, 67 Archbishop of Nigeria.
The first black pope? Outgoing, relaxed, genial, full of charm - but again conservative and no intellectual. A good communicator. His election would be a powerful symbol of the church's changing centre of gravity

fields.headline: Last Tuesday for net entrepreneurs
fields.standfirst: As dark clouds gather over the fate of dot.com matchmakers First Tuesday, deputy Online editor Neil Mcntosh looks back to its dazzling arrival and contemplates its imminent departure
fields.trailText: As dark clouds gather over the fate of dot.com matchmakers First Tuesday, deputy Online editor Neil McIntosh looks back to its dazzling arrival and contemplates its imminent departure
fields.body:
The fact that First Tuesday, the corporate matchmaking club, may have already held the last of its flagship monthly meetings is certainly something of a symbolic event in the brief, traumatic life of British e-commerce, if not a seismic one.

First Tuesday, like so much of the dot.com world, shone brightly at the height of net mania in 1999, with an incredible, buzzing atmosphere which made the onlooker feel like a little bit of Silicon Valley had been brought over to central London.

But First Tuesday quickly fell victim to the dot.com greed it helped to spawn. By this time last year venture capitalists (VCs) - the monied half of the First Tuesday equation - were beginning to complain that good ideas were thin on the ground at the monthly networking meetings. A regional network of meetings, after a bright start, failed to recreate the kind of buzz found at the London events. From its estimated peak value of £36m last summer, the company is now reportedly up for sale again, for £2m.

By that time word had spread the nation over that First Tuesday was the place to sweet talk some city whiz kid into handing over millions for your half baked dot.com idea. Likely lads descended; there were tales of people even pretending to be VCs, out to steal the latest hot dot.com ideas.

At the same time technology stocks were plunging, venture capitalists were taking fright, and the party fell flat, not helped by attempts by First Tuesday to grab a little bit of the money itself by charging a levy on VC payouts.

But we can safely ignore some comments from unnamed VCs that, as deep into net history as 18 months ago, they felt it was all a bit naff - that would place us in mid-1999, when First Tuesday was in its heyday. The first balmy Tuesday evening in August that year saw the event - held at Home House in London - thrice over-subscribed. The money men were flocking in, lured by the promise of a fast buck.

Perhaps the most attractive, most net-like aspect of the First Tuesday concept was its apparent democracy: the notion that any decent idea could be a goer, given a sharp enough line in sales patter and a bit of luck in meeting a willing VC. The mystery was being removed from venture funding, always more scarce in the UK than in the US.

The businesses those nights spawned, however, reads today a bit like a who's who of so what: ClickMango, which went bust last autumn after barely mustering the turnover of a corner shop, was one of the most obvious failures. Others - like music site peoplesound and ihavemoved.com - the site that tells your friends you've moved - have yet to prove they have anything to offer that will allow them to stand out. Moreover.com, the news aggregator, is perhaps the shining alum of First Tuesday - and it was started by the club's co-founder, Nick Denton.

In these austere days, with their multimillion pound judgements being proved wrong again and again, we should expect the VCs to feign casual indifference towards First Tuesday. But let's not forget they were looking pretty keen in 1999, in the middle of the feeding frenzy. Then, the plan was to get some funding, build that brand and then get to market - all within six months, and never mind the profits. Chaotic First Tuesday was the perfect breeding ground for such fast living start-ups.

If it is going belly up, we should salute it as a symbol of the remarkable times it helped create, and which it ultimately fell victim to. A bit like some look back with fondness to Glastonbury festivals of yore - we'll grow to love its memory, forgetting that it was a bit sweaty, many were ripped off, and that it was probably never as good as it was cracked up to be.

fields.headline: Oil spill Galapagos Islands' 'worst disaster'
fields.standfirst: Graphic: guide to the disaster
fields.trailText: Some of the world's rarest marine species are threatened with long-term damage from an oil spill just half a mile from the main port on Ecuador's Galapagos Islands.
fields.body:
Some of the world's rarest marine species are threatened with long-term damage from an oil spill just half a mile from the main port on Ecuador's Galapagos Islands.

"It may be one of Galapagos' worst disasters," the environment ministry spokesman, Mauro Cerbino, said yesterday.

The spill was caused by an Ecuadorean-registered tanker, the Jessica, which was carrying about 243,000 gallons (almost 1m litres) of diesel fuel. running aground last Tuesday on the archipelago's easternmost island of San Cristobal.

The vessel, listing heavily to its starboard side some 550 yards (500 meters) offshore, started leaking on Friday.

Ecuador's environmental minister, Rodolfo Rendon, said yesterday that new damage to the hull had increased the amount leaked to about 150,000 gallons (570,000 litres).

Mr Rendon said a team of US experts, including 10 members of the coast-guard's pollution response national strike force, had arrived late on Sunday, bringing specialised oil-spill equipment, such as inflatable oil-containment barges and high-capacity pumps to help remove remaining fuel from the ship.

Ecuador's President Gustavo Noboa yesterday demanded a "detailed report" about the cause of the accident, which officials had attributed to navigational error.

Police on San Cristobal said no charges had been filed against the ship's captain, Tarquino Arevalo, or against his company, Acotramar. But Mr Rendon said a request for a criminal investigation would be made today

The Galapagos Islands, 600 miles (about 1,000 kilometres) off the west coast of Ecuador in the southern Pacific Ocean, are famous for their giant tortoises and rare species of birds and plants. Charles Darwin developed his theory of evolution by studying wildlife on the islands.

Floating nets and barriers have been launched to control the spill, but officials said slicks had reached nearby beaches, affecting at least 11 sea-lions and some 20 birds, including blue-footed boobies, pelicans and albatrosses.

Galapagos National Park biologist Mauricio Velasquez said the long-term danger is that the fuel will sink to the ocean floor, destroying algae, a vital component of the food chain, threatening marine iguanas, blue-footed boobies, masked boobies and seagulls, as well as sharks and lobsters.

Mr Velasquez said the current was pushing the spill south, and that within days it could reach Spain Island, where large colonies of sea lions and other marine animals congregate.

fields.headline: Moustaches, hashes and brilliant flashes
fields.trailText: The Man in the Moustache is not a happy chappie ( just for a change). Real Madrid boss Vicente del Bosque has had enough of cheeky comments about his moustache and his impressive inability to smile. He told Marca columnist Julián Ruiz this week that he's "not a misery". And even though del Bosque "never complains" when people criticise him on football matters, he admitted that "comments about my moustache annoy me".
fields.body:
The Man in the Moustache is not a happy chappie ( just for a change). Real Madrid boss Vicente del Bosque has had enough of cheeky comments about his moustache and his impressive inability to smile. He told Marca columnist Julián Ruiz this week that he's "not a misery". And even though del Bosque "never complains" when people criticise him on football matters, he admitted that "comments about my moustache annoy me".

And The Not-at-all Miserable Man in the Entirely Unremarkable Moustache was even more unhappy this weekend when his side failed to win for the first time in nine games, drawing 2-2 at Real Valladolid.

Fernando Hierro was the man at fault for Valladolid's opener in the fourth minute. Waiting for the game's first corner, the Madrid captain decided to engage in a bit of play-fighting with his good mate, Valladolid midfielder José Caminero. One slap later, Caminero had stolen a yard and sent an excellent header over Iker Casillas and in off the bar. Whoops.

Real, missing the suspended Iván Helguera, were disappointing throughout but equalised on 48 minutes with a deflected Roberto Carlos free-kick. Valladolid were incensed - that wonder of technology, the electronic number-board, had only shown one minute of injury time. Madrid were 2-1 up early in the second half, Fernando Morientes scoring from close range from Luis Figo's clever free-kick.

Valladolid got the draw they probably deserved when referee Bueno Grimal gave an extremely harsh penalty for a "push" on Fernando by Albert Celades. It could have been worse, too - Iker Casillas saved the day when Jamie Kaviedes found himself clean through in the dying minutes.

Madrid, though, were incensed by the referee's performance: both Iker Casillas and Michel Salgado told the press that Fernando had admitted it wasn't a penalty, while Morientes moaned that Grimal had missed an "blatant" foul on Raúl at the other end.

Referee spotting

The good folk at Quiero TV must be laughing all the way to the bank. Of course, only a cynic would say it's anything other than a coincidence that referees wearing their logo for the first time captured the headlines this weekend. Well, of course - but the hijos de puta in their shiny new kits did brandish eight yellows and a red at the San Mamés when Athletic beat Racing Santander 3-1, another red during Real Sociedad's 1-1 draw at Osasuna, two reds during Barcelona's 1-0 win at the Mestalla, and ... well, you get the picture.

But while sports-daily AS described Grimal's performance as "disastrous", it would be a tad unfair to have a go at his colleague López Nieto - there wasn't much he could do to limit the cards on display at the Mestalla, where fans witnessed a bruising encounter between Barcelona and Valencia.

Barça scored the game's only goal after just 7 minutes, Frank De Boer's swerving long shot somehow beating Santi Cañizares from 30 yards. Giant Norw... erm plain old John Carew, currently on nine goals, stands to get a tasty salary increase when his tally reaches ten. But Carew and Valencia just couldn't find the equaliser they so badly craved, despite the first half-dismissal of Luis Enrique. Mind you, Héctor Cúper's side did have Italian hardman Amadeo Carboni sent off in the second half after yet another clash with Gareth Southgate look-alike (tragic but true) Simão.

Barça were nearly another player short for their visit to the Mestalla after police arrested a man "acting suspiciously" on Thursday afternoon. The suspect, whose business has been going down the pan, admitted planning to kidnap a Barcelona player to seek a king's ransom. Well, at least Comedy Keeper Richard Dutruel was safe. The suspect also admitted, though, that he wasn't sure which player to grab as he "doesn't know anything about football". Ah, maybe the Comedy Keeper wasn't safe, after all.

A police spokesman said that they found a hand-gun in the suspect's van, "and some other materials that could be used in a kidnapping". Some old newspaper headlines, a pair of scissors and a bottle of glue, then.

Deportivo bounce back

Deportivo La Coruña are back in the title race after they recovered from an early Dario Silva goal to beat Málaga 3-1. Super-sub Scaloni played yet another Solskjaer role, with two in the last seven minutes. But the real excitement's been off the field.

Brazilian Djalminha has threatened to take the Spanish FA to court for loss of earnings after they banned him for two games following his punch-up with team-mate Víctor last week. Depor's president Augusto César Lendoiro isn't happy about the ban - he claimed that it would never have happened to a "big club" - but he insisted that Djalminha's on his own with this one. "This", he said, "is a personal case, being brought by the player, not the club".

Djalminha's not the only one letting the side down. Real Sociedad striker Edgaras Jankauskas undid all John Benjamin's defensive work with an own goal, Oli missed a penalty as Oviedo drew 1-1 against Mallorca, and Rayo keeper Kasey Keller's dreadful clearance nearly KO'd the onrushing Pablo Lago, but the midfielder found his feet to score for Las Palmas, who drew 1-1 in Vallecas.

Elsewhere, Numancia won 2-0 at Alavés, who now haven't won for four games, and Celta dominated Zaragoza but could only manage a 1-1 draw.

Better than Becks

Meanwhile, there was lots of fun in Villarreal this week, with the arrival from Boca Juniors of striker Martín "El Loco" Palermo. Anything Becks can do, Martin can do better.

Posh's knickers? Pah! Sarongs? A mere flirtation with girls' clothes. This bloke - whose previous photo-shoots include full drag, complete with blonde wig, evening dress, feather boa and sparkling necklace (oh, and a 5 o'clock shadow) - makes the Ok! magazine star's dress sense look positively masculine. Palermo's arrival sent the fans wild this week, but it wasn't enough for Villarreal to avoid a 2-1 defeat at Espanyol. Not surprising, really - the Argentinian wasn't even playing

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: January 22
fields.trailText: January 22: David McMurtrie, UK managing director of new-media sales house Real Media, has quit without a job to go to.
fields.body:
David McMurtrie, UK managing director of new-media sales house Real Media, has quit without a job to go to.

Nova has poached Paula Cain from John Brown Publishing to be its first advertising director.

Procter & Gamble has locked horns with Channel 5 over ad rates. The fmcg giant is understood to have asked the channel for a lower rate for 2001.

Manning Gottlieb Media has poached Saatchi & Saatchi's group media director Ben Hayes to be its first strategic planning director.

William Reed, publisher of The Grocer, is to run a second series of Grocer TV on Sky Digital in September.

A style magazine named Cream is set to hit newsstands on March 7.

IPC Connect is to test a Chat spin-off, entitled It's Fate. The magazine will take a psychic slant on relationships, celebrity gossip, beauty and careers.

fields.headline: Hall pockets £1/4m for opera job
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Outgoing BBC News chief Tony Hall is thought to be joining the Royal Opera House for as much as £250,000, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The outgoing chief of BBC News, Tony Hall, is thought to be joining the Royal Opera House for as much as £250,000.

It means Mr Hall will not be taking a £100,000 pay cut, as previously believed, to move into the impoverished arts sector.

A Royal Opera House spokesman refused to confirm or deny the salary of Mr Hall, who joins in April.

But it is widely accepted that Mr Hall delayed his decision about quitting the BBC to join the Opera House because of disputes over money.

The deal, if confirmed in this year's annual report, will make the news chief one of the highest paid in the arts sector.

He will easily take home more money that the previous incumbent, Michael Kaiser, who is on a salary of around £140,000.

According the annual report, the highest paid executive at the Opera House is on a package of £240,000 a year. Although the recipient is not named, it is believed to be chairman Sir Colin Southgate.

The salary is likely to be controversial in the arts world, which has struggled to offer the sorts of salaries that pull in big commercial players.

It is thought that Mr Hall will have the highest salary in the UK arts world, beating that of South Bank Centre director Karsten Witt, who gets around £200,000.
