webTitle: The continuing saga of Express Newspapers

fields.headline: It's as if aliens have taken over three national newspapers
fields.standfirst:
Roy Greenslade on the continuing saga at Planet Desmond, also known as Express Newspapers.

Jan 17: Tea with Dirty Desmond
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on the continuing saga at Planet Desmond, also known as Express Newspapers.
fields.body:
Remember that slogan when Richard Desmond moved into Ludgate House in November? "It's OK! at the Express," it said. Well, if that was a belief-beggaring claim then, it certainly isn't remotely true now.

Two months on from his takeover, everything is far from OK on Planet Desmond. The surreal has become the norm. It's as if aliens have taken over three national newspapers and have no idea what they are doing.

In the past century of British press history there has never been a situation as weird as the one at the Daily and Sunday Express. Desmond has not spoken to his editor-in-chief, Rosie Boycott, since December 15.

There is no daily link between management and editorial. All those tedious, but necessary, meetings about marketing and promotion do not happen. There are no formal daily reports to the editor about sales, which is just as well since my sources suggest returns are running at record rates.

The editor and her journalistic staff are operating in limbo. It is known that Boycott was asked to make people redundant and rejected the idea by email, the only method she can use to communicate with Desmond.

Meanwhile, lawyers acting for Boycott and her deputy, Chris Blackhurst, are trying to negotiate exits for the pair with Desmond's team. So certain are their departures that statements about them "leaving by mutual consent" and other such humbug have already been prepared by Desmond's public relations advisers, ready for the moment the deal is settled.

Most newspaper offices are infected by an explosive mixture of rumour and paranoia at the best of times. So imagine what it's like for the reporters, subs and writers on the Express in these worst of times. There have been two journalists' union meetings to discuss supposed plans to introduce new contracts from next month. These contracts are expected to reduce holidays and even threaten pension entitlements.

It is assumed, although not confirmed, that 100 people will be made redundant. Some claim to know that there are plans afoot to create a pooled subs' desk which will serve both the Express and the Sunday Express, the Daily Star and even OK! magazine.

As if this isn't bad enough, I'm sorry, but not surprised, to hear that some of the staff, particularly the reporters, somehow blame Boycott and Blackhurst for what's going on.

Whatever arguments one may have about Boycott's stewardship of the paper in the past, and even about the fact that she fired staff early in her reign, to blame her for the current impasse is way off beam.

She has made a principled stand by refusing to sack anyone for Desmond and is demanding that, if he wants her to go, he should pay what her contract stipulates. Surely that's reasonable? As for the spin about her holding up an agreement by refusing to sign a confidentiality clause, that is utter nonsense. Like all senior executives in her position, she acknowledges that she will have to sign and has made no protest about doing so.

What is at issue, I understand, is that Desmond wants to pay her off in monthly instalments. She wishes to have a lump sum. Again, given the question marks over the liquidity of Desmond's company and the continuing squeeze on Express profits, that isn't an unreasonable demand.

Those journalists who are carping about Boycott would do better to think about their own uncertain future under Desmond. He is letting it be known that he has great plans to invest in the promotion of his papers, but why should his staff believe him?

In the euphoria of his first week, he announced that he would immediately increase the print run by more than 250,000 copies a day. That didn't happen. He also pledged to launch a £1m TV promotion campaign. He has not. He said he would release "big money" for book serialisations and buy-ups. No such money has been forthcoming.

He did recruit a Sun sports writer, Brian Woolnough, for £200,000. But none of the many staff who have left the Express - including Tony Bevins, Peter Hitchens, Stephen Pollard and Ros Wynne-Jones - have been replaced. There is a formal ban on recruitment by the editor.

Regular contributors tell me that their December payments were not paid on time. Attempts to carry out trivial cost-cutting measures, such as the ban on the use of couriers, have been frustrated so far, but they indicate a state of mind on Planet Desmond.

Could there be a reason for Desmond keeping Boycott so long? It is known that, at his Downing Street meeting with the prime minister within two days of his takeover, Tony Blair urged him to keep Boycott. It is known that Blair has since had talks with Boycott and his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, also met her two weeks ago.

It may be too far-fetched to suggest that she is being held hostage in order for Desmond to avoid a referral of the Express deal to the competition commission. Given the strict financial criteria, a referral is unlikely, but there could be a public interest reason to investigate whether he is a fit and proper owner. Blair may feel that it would be counterproductive to alienate a newspaper proprietor just before an election. He may also regard Desmond as not much worse than the rest of a bad bunch.

But, with the greatest of respect, this business of newspaper ownership is more important that a single election, and Desmond is a man apart from other press controllers. His wealth - and his access to the German bank loan - is based entirely on his profits from his pornographic businesses.

I am disgusted that two of my old friends - Jonathan Holborow, former Mail on Sunday editor, and Arthur Davidson QC, former Labour MP and veteran newspaper lawyer - should be acting as a figleaf for the pornographer by joining his panel of independent directors.

What do they think they are doing? Did they not read Francis Wheen's column in the Guardian on Wednesday which revealed why Desmond deserves to be called a pornographer? If anyone wants a definition of the difference between sauciness and filth, between fun and exploitation, then Wheen provided it.

In every way, Desmond proves that free-market forces provide no adequate safeguard for press ownership. His pornography is vile and exploitative. The two-month experience of his control suggests he lacks a grasp of what is involved in practical terms to run papers. He has made a set of promises he has failed to keep.

If the government lets this takeover through with a smile and a nod, it will be remembered by journalists as having connived in the downfall of the Daily and Sunday Express. It isn't too late to act. But is there the will?

fields.headline: Panorama's popularity plummets
fields.standfirst: TV ratings: January 19-21
fields.trailText:
4pm: Panorama last night pulled in its second smallest audience since the show moved to Sunday nights, writes Jason Deans.
TV ratings: January 19-21
fields.body:
Panorama has been dealt another ratings blow - last night it posted its second smallest audience since moving to Sunday nights.

According to unofficial ratings, Gavin Hewitt's profile of George W Bush was watched by only 2.7m - just 15 % of all viewers watching TV at the time.

It was the worst performing programme since another report on US politics, broadcast on October 22, when the show only pulled in 2.2m viewers - a 13% share of viewing.

That edition, about the underhand tactics used by both sides in the US presidential election, was the lowest rating Panorama since the BBC1 current affairs flagship moved to Sunday night on October 15.

Overall, Panorama has averaged 3.1m and an 18% share since the move.

This is 1m viewers down on what the show averaged in its last three Monday-night outings last year.

The low ratings will fuel fears that current affairs is been marginalised at the BBC.

Director-general Greg Dyke and director of television Mark Thompson have given assurances that Panorama will not be moved out of primetime.

However, many critics believe the series is being screened on the wrong day and too late in the evening.

Last week, Panorama reporter John Ware - who made the film exposing the Omagh bombing suspects - attacked TV executives for neglecting investigative journalism.

Sunday night's Panorama was up against ITV's Tarrant on TV, which had 8.5m viewers, and Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned, which gained 5.2m.

But the David Baddiel and Frank Skinner vehicle did less well on Friday, when it lost out to Channel 4's So Graham Norton on a grisly night for ITV late-evening comedy.

So Graham Norton attracted 3.3m viewers and a 21% share, battering Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned down to just 3m and an 18% share.

Channel 4's entertainment champion was up against ITV's comedy pretenders for the first half-hour of his show, which ran between 10.30pm and 11.20pm.

Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned also lost out to BBC1's Clive Anderson Now.

The satirical current affairs show gained 3.6m viewers between 10.35pm and 11.05pm.

Immediately before that, returning ITV comedy drama Big Bad World fared little better, losing out to BBC1's Ten O'Clock News.

The Ardal O'Hanlon vehicle had 4.1m - one in five viewers - from 10pm; while the BBC1 news bulletin notched up 5m and a 24% share.

BBC2's post-Comedy Zone Friday night schedule is shaping up well.

A Timewatch history documentary on Hitler's right-hand man Heinrich Himmler drew 3.2m viewers and a 13% share on Friday.

It beat a Channel 4 repeat of Friends, which had 2.2m from 9pm, and home-grown sketch show Armstrong and Miller, which drew 1.3m viewers from 9.30pm.

On Saturday night, Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? notched up 11.1m.

Viewers tuned in to watch Steve Devlin, who previously pulled out of the show because of nerves, fail in his bid to win £1m.

London's Burning returned strongly to ITV on Sunday night from 9-10pm.

The long-running drama gained 10.9m viewers and a 44% share, beating BBC1 drama Rebel Heart, which pulled in 3.2m.

Last night, the terrestrial premiere of Contact, starring Jodie Foster, from 9-11.50pm, was the high point of Channel 5's Sci-Five Weekend.

The film drew 2.5m viewers and a 14% share.

London's Burning returned strongly to ITV on Sunday night from 9-10pm. The long-running drama gained 10.9m viewers and a 44% share, beating BBC1 drama Rebel Heart, which pulled in 3.2m. Last night, the terrestrial premiere of Contact, starring Jodie Foster, from 9-11.50pm, was the high point of Channel 5's Sci-Five Weekend. The film drew 2.5m viewers and a 14% share.

fields.headline: The Galapagos Islands
fields.standfirst: The Galapagos Islands have been hit by a potentially devastating oil spill. Here is our guide to the best links on this unique ecological area.
fields.trailText: NetNotes: The Galapagos Islands have been hit by a potentially devastating oil spill. Here is our guide to the best links on this unique ecological area.
fields.body:
1. A unique South American wildlife sanctuary, the Galapagos Islands are now threatened by an oil spill that occurred off the coast of South America on January 16. The tanker Jessica ran aground near the Galapagos, spilling 240,000 gallons of oil into the Pacific.

2. Any oil spill is bad news, but the delicate ecosystem of the Galapagos plays host to some of the world's most unique species, including the giant tortoise and the Galapagos land iguana.

3. The islands were an inspiration for Charles Darwin who used his observations of the islands' isolated species to develop his theory of evolution.

4. After Darwin highlighted the significance of the species on the islands, other scientists have used the area to carry on Darwin's work.

5. The government of Ecuador, which controls the islands, has appealed for international help to prevent the spill from reaching the Galapagos and to rescue endangered wildlife.

6. According to the WWF (formerly the World Wide Fund for Nature), the spill could have a devastating and long-lasting impact on the islands. Environmentalists have called for an end to shipping in the area.

7. Aside from the environmental impact, any damage to the Galapagos could have disastrous financial consquences for Ecuador. The islands are a major source of tourist revenue, and tourists tend to avoid beaches covered in sticky black gunk.

8. The eventual damage dealt to the Galapagos will depend largely on the success of the cleanup effort. Scientists hope their past experiences of oil spills will make the operation more efficient.

9. As bad as the Galapagos spill looks, it is not the worst environmental disaster. Cleanup workers have spent 12 years monitoring the damage inflicted on the formerly pristine Prince William Sound in Alaska after the Exxon Valdez oil tanker spilled 11m gallons of oil there in 1989.

10. Despite the lessons learned after the Valdez spill, the threat of spills has not abated. As any tortoise on Galapagos can tell you.

fields.headline: Stepstone axes 40 UK staff
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Anglo-Norwegian recruitment website Stepstone is laying off 40 staff from its UK offices, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The dot.com pinch has finally hit the seemingly buoyant online recruitment market.

Anglo-Norwegian recruitment heavyweight Stepstone today announced it was laying off 40 staff from its UK offices.

The redundancies have been made in StepStone's production and sales departments.

Sixteen production staff have been axed with the roles now outsourced to StepStone's Indian operation in a bid to cut wage costs.

And 24 members of StepStone's 150-strong sales force have been given their P45s, while "temporary" offices in Birmingham and Milton Keynes have been shut down.

In a noble gesture, the company, which floated on Norway's stock exchange last March, said it would "work with staff and their representatives to explore options of assistance for the future".

A spokeswoman for StepStone said the cost-cutting move applied only to the UK office and was an inevitable side-product of launching into new territories.

"StepStone tends to overstaff on the sales front when looking to gain foothold in a new market, then once established it's necessary to cut back slightly," she said.

The company claims to be the biggest recruitment website in Europe with more than 1m users each week, operates in 16 European countries and has recently expanded into India.

fields.headline: Broers reappointed at Cambridge
fields.trailText: Sir Alec Broers is to be reappointed as vice-chancellor of Cambridge University. He is to serve for another two years after his initial five-year contract as university head ends in September 2001.
fields.body:
Sir Alec Broers is to be reappointed as vice-chancellor of Cambridge University. He is to serve for another two years after his initial five-year contract as university head ends in September 2001.

The reappointment, endorsed by the universityÕs council, means that Sir Alec will serve the maximum seven years allowed for the position.

He is likely to use his extension to continue with his modernising agenda at the 800-year-old institution. One of the few UK vice-chancellors with industrial as well as academic experience, he has led the university into an era of closer links with big business. A new £40m research lab funded by the Marconi company is just one of the new buildings rising on the universityÕs West Cambridge site and is symbolic of such links.

Sir Alec believes that the introduction of larger companies into the Cambridge region is the key ingredient needed to make Silicon Fen, the area's cluster of high-tech start-up companies, a real success.

He has also pushed through critical reforms allowing senior professors at the university higher wages - a step that will help retain the universityÕs allure for top academics across the world.

The former head of the universityÕs engineering department is also conscious of promoting the arts and humanities as well as the sciences at the university. A new centre for academics in the arts and humanities is being opened next month.

On the research front, Sir Alec is known for establishing a nanofabrication laboratory at Cambridge where the technology of miniaturisation was extended to the atomic scale.

Concerns and challenges for Sir Alec over the coming years will include this yearÕs research assessment exercise, the ongoing battles over the bureaucratic burden of teaching quality inspections, and the debate over top-up fees expected to open up after the general election.

fields.headline: Project Mayo will set us free
fields.trailText: After Napster, here comes something to threaten the film industry. David Docherty reports on the pirating of videos on the net.
fields.body:
There is a chilling moment in the movie Poltergeist, when the little girl turns away from the TV set and says in a small, mysterious voice: "They're here." Since the advent of MP3, Hollywood and the TV industry have been waiting in fear for a similar moment when the soldier ant hackers out there finally work out how to do a Napster on them. Well "They're Here!" - maybe. In the US, the merry boys and girls who dedicate their lives to using the web to screw up conventional media economics have been working on something called DiVX, a modified form of Microsoft's MPEG4. This produces at least VHS quality pictures that can be compressed and downloaded to a CD or held on a hard disk.

DiVX was created a few years ago by a French video engineer and a German hacker who took a piece of code Microsoft released for developers only and rewrote it for general use. Initially called DiVX;-), it cocked a snook at the now defunct DiVX, a DVD rental format that tried to reassure Hollywood by guarding against piracy. The smile at the end of the new format tells you all you need to know of the intentions of the new hackers on the block. Throughout last year the movement built and now the cutting-edge people, such as the guys at the mysterious Project Mayo, are preparing new and better versions of the software. "We are," they claim on their website, "a Big Deal." And they probably are.

Nonetheless, digital nirvana is currently horribly difficult and slow to deliver on 56k dial-up. But with the rise of broadband, DiVX and its successors will come into their own. When the next Star Wars comes out on DVD (or before if someone pirates a copy), you'll be able to download it to a CD within hours.

How are audio-visual content providers supposed to respond to this new force? Well, we could take the music industry's initial approach to Napster and run into the middle of the road, bury our heads in tarmac and shout: "Go away nasty truck," as the juggernaut hammers towards us. Or, we could get the legal and technical rottweillers on the case. In the US, Paramount and Time Warner are already suing some of the people in the movement, and the studios are putting pressure on the manufacturers of digital reception equipment to install obliteration codes that will seek out and destroy any illegal content - such as a DiVD download.

No doubt various combinations of these approaches will swirl around the industry in the next few years. There is a third option, however. Which is to try to harness DiVX and use it legitimately, rather than try to strangle it in the cradle. We wait to see where Bertelsmann's tie up with Napster goes, or whether new legal alternatives to Napster, such as Wippit.Com, which tags the download and asks the users to pay for their bytes of Britney, begin to make money. But they do show a way forward for the TV, movie and games industry faced with digital grand larceny. If the software might eat Hollywood, then Hollywood must eat the software.

Broadband as a technology is neutral in all of this. It will either host the pirates, because it will be incredibly difficult to block them, or it can help enable safe, legal alternatives. The challenge will be to control the windows. Currently, there is a very tightly defined set of rules and markets from the premiere of a piece of content to it turning up for a fifth rerun on the Turner Network, or in a remainder bin at Woolies. All this is under threat with these new DiVX-type developments. If the premiere of a movie, or for that matter a TV show, is de facto the moment at which it is available to broadband web, then how do you control your intellectual property and make money from it?

That's where digital rights management companies come in. These new outfits are developing encryption padlocks as fast as the hackers are unpicking the locks. In the end, though, the big companies will find a way of making the consumer pay for the digital transfer of movies and TV shows. They will because they must.

The good news in all of this is that as with MP3 where anyone with talent and access to a home PC and studio can put their music onto the www, now anyone who wants to make a show can also do it. And it will be seen in just the same way as anything George Lucas is shooting. These will be people of imagination finally taking advantage of a low-cost distribution medium to get their type of humour, interest, dramatic perception, aesthetic judgment out to like-minded people and have them pay for it. Broadband and DiVX are the real foundations for the streamed narrowcasting world we've been predicting these past few years. Broadcasting in the fullest sense of the word.

 David Docherty is managing director of broadband content at Telewest

fields.headline: Hatfield crash inquiry shelved
fields.standfirst:
Criminal prosecutions for manslaughter expected to be laid against named staff at Railtrack and Balfour Beatty.

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ministers have ruled out a public inquiry into the Hatfield rail disaster "because they have no stomach for it" and want to avoid a third embarrassing inquiry into a train crash in less than three years, sources close to the investigation revealed last night.
fields.body:
Ministers have ruled out a public inquiry into the Hatfield rail disaster "because they have no stomach for it" and want to avoid a third embarrassing inquiry into a train crash in less than three years, sources close to the investigation revealed last night.

The decision was taken by the transport minister, Lord Macdonald, after a meeting with health and safety officials and accident investigators.

Ministers are anxious to keep what is rapidly becoming a politically sensitive issue as low key as possible in the lead-up to the election.

They hope that the matter will be effectively dealt with and public disquiet satisfied if high-profile criminal prosecutions are taken against those directly involved in the crash in October, which killed four people.

The sources said that a public inquiry could last up to two years and would hold up any criminal action against Railtrack or Balfour Beatty, the maintenance contractor at the Hatfield crash site.

But this seems of secondary importance now because Lord Cullen, who chaired the joint inquiry into the Paddington and Southall rail disasters, has been asked to comment on the implications of Hatfield for the industry when he reports later this year.

The Department of Transport confirmed last night that there would be no public inquiry into Hatfield. It said the health and safety executive was carrying out a detailed examination of the tragedy with independent experts and transport police and would make its recommendations as soon as possible. "In the circumstances, the government does not think that a public inquiry is necessary."

James Melvin, the brother-in-law of pilot Steve Arthur, 46, one of the four men killed in the Hatfield crash, said he was shocked at the decision not to hold a public inquiry and believed the government was making a "huge mistake".

"It is a bolt out of the blue," he said. "I fully expected a public inquiry because it is only right and just that one should be held."

Criminal prosecutions for manslaughter are expected to be laid against up to six named staff at Railtrack and Balfour Beatty as a direct result of the Hatfield crash.

It has already been confirmed that Railtrack and Balfour Beatty were aware of the poor state of the track at the crash site at least 10 months before the tragedy and failed to act on warnings to put the problem right within six months.

A second report into the accident is due to be published by the HSE tomorrow. It will reveal that the Hatfield track was so bad at the point of the crash that it shattered into about 300 pieces, like a sheet of glass, and was therefore the direct cause of the accident.

The investigators will produce a piece of track, taken 50 metres (160ft) south of the crash-site track and in a similar condition, which shows severe wear. This discovery has caused investigators to question why both Railtrack and Balfour Beatty had failed to impose speed restrictions before the crash.

Investigators are also carrying out a thorough examination of the couplings on the train, and particularly on the buffet car, where all the deaths occurred. The car reared up off the track while the rest of the train remained upright.

The investigating team want to satisfy themselves that the coupling was not faulty. The train company, Great North Eastern Railway, says it has thoroughly inspected its fleet and that its couplings are all right.

The naming of company officials would be a new departure for the crown prosecution service. Such a measure was considered after the 1997 Southall rail disaster, but in the end individuals were not named although the company involved, Great Western Trains, was fined £1.5m.

The Hatfield disaster has exposed the deterioration of the network over the past few years and the increasing threat to the safety of the travelling public caused by the fragmentation of the industry.

Investigators say they are still concerned that Railtrack discovered 300 other "serious" site problems when it examined the rest of the network in the first few days after the accident. It immediately shut large parts of the system.

Railtrack is drawing up a plan to take more effective control over the activities of its contractors by bringing them into a more effective, centrally controlled partnership.

Balfour Beatty has been removed from the Hatfield contract, which Railtrack has awarded to another company, Jarvis. But Railtrack has compensated Balfour Beatty with a new contract in a different part of the network.

fields.headline: Globes of wisdom
fields.standfirst:
It's not hard to guess who will win this year's Oscars - so long as you know who won the Golden Globes, writes Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Comment: It's not hard to guess who will win this year's Oscars - so long as you know who won the Golden Globes, writes Film Unlimited editor Xan Brooks.
fields.body:
Pencils at the ready, punters, for the hottest Oscar tips in the business. Place your money behind Gladiator for best picture, Tom Hanks (in Cast Away) for best actor and Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich) for best actress. The best director award will go to Ang Lee (for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon) and Stephen Gaghan will win best original screenplay for Traffic. Just don't let on that we told you so. In the words of LA Confidential, these tips are strictly hush-hush.

Except they're not - not really. Instead, what we have here are the big results from last night's Golden Globes awards, a kind of Oscar precursor that invariably establishes the candidates who will be walking away with Academy statuettes come the end of March.

Last year's globes for film, director and screenplay, for instance, all went to American Beauty. Despite tossing in an extra best actor Oscar for Kevin Spacey, the subsequent Oscar ceremony merely rubber-stamped the globes' decision.

Chances are that it will be the same this year - because Oscar night is less of an explosive revelation, and more the predictable last stop on an awards road that begin last December. Over the past two months a string of ceremonies (from the American Federation of Film Critics to the New York Critics) have been quietly establishing who and what will walk away with this year's honours.

Think of these ceremonies as akin to the presidential primaries that build to the party conventions. This time last year, the media was whipping up counterfeit excitement over the challenges by Republican John McCain and Democrat Bill Bradley while never truly believing that Bush and Gore were in any real danger.

Hollywood, it is said, is politics for pretty people and politics is Hollywood for ugly ones. Both worlds share the same rigorously stage-managed process of decision-making.

The one rogue element in this year's Oscar runup remains the lack of a clear favourite. Gladiator, Traffic, Almost Famous, Erin Brockovich, Cast Away and Crouching Tiger have all established themselves in one poll or another as the Academy's big guns. None, however, have distanced themselves from the pack the way American Beauty did in 2000 (and Shakespeare in Love the year before that).

Traditionally Oscar likes to throw its weight behind one big winner; it doesn't like to divide its five main awards between five different contenders. This year, it may be forced to do just that. If that happens, we can thank the globes for breaking up the movie monopoly. Its disparate set of awards at least add a whiff of variety - dare one even say tension? - to the stock Oscar night script.

Chances are that it will be the same this year - because Oscar night is less of an explosive revelation, and more the predictable last stop on an awards road that begin last December. Over the past two months a string of ceremonies (from the American Federation of Film Critics to the New York Critics) have been quietly establishing who and what will walk away with this year's honours. Think of these ceremonies as akin to the presidential primaries that build to the party conventions. This time last year, the media was whipping up counterfeit excitement over the challenges by Republican John McCain and Democrat Bill Bradley while never truly believing that Bush and Gore were in any real danger. Hollywood, it is said, is politics for pretty people and politics is Hollywood for ugly ones. Both worlds share the same rigorously stage-managed process of decision-making. The one rogue element in this year's Oscar runup remains the lack of a clear favourite. Gladiator, Traffic, Almost Famous, Erin Brockovich, Cast Away and Crouching Tiger have all established themselves in one poll or another as the Academy's big guns. None, however, have distanced themselves from the pack the way American Beauty did in 2000 (and Shakespeare in Love the year before that). Traditionally Oscar likes to throw its weight behind one big winner; it doesn't like to divide its five main awards between five different contenders. This year, it may be forced to do just that. If that happens, we can thank the globes for breaking up the movie monopoly. Its disparate set of awards at least add a whiff of variety - dare one even say tension? - to the stock Oscar night script. fields.headline: Popstars proves big hit for ITV
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: ITV's Popstars boosted its audience by almost 1m on Saturday evening, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Popstars bandwagon has started to roll for ITV, with audiences swelling by almost 1m on Saturday evening.

The show pulled in 7.5m viewers, up 800,000 on the previous week's audience, according to unofficial overnights.

The third instalment of the show showed the number of pop hopefuls being cut down from 163 to just 30.

Over the past week, Popstars has caught the imagination of the media and Saturday night's episode added more grist to the mill.

Fifteen-stone Scot Claire Freeland - who had the voice but not the looks for the band, according to TV's latest "Mr Nasty", Nigel Lythgoe - did not make the final 30.

The show's audience share between 5.55pm and 6.55pm rose by six percentage points to reach 37%.

The share figure for 16 to 34-year-olds makes encouraging reading for ITV director of programmes David Liddiment.

Popstars climbed from a 39% to a 47% share in this demographic, week on week.

The Mole, Channel 5's big new reality entertainment series, was not such a success story on Friday evening.

The show, in which 10 contestants battle to complete tasks, while trying to work out the identity of the traitor in their midst, drew a 1.2m audience for its second episode.

This was 200,000 viewers down on its debut last week. Its audience share fell from 6% to 5%.

webTitle: Hatfield rail crash inquiry may name names

fields.headline: Hatfield rail crash inquiry may name names
fields.trailText: The official inquiry into the Hatfield rail disaster, which exposed the appalling state of rail's infrastructure, is moving towards naming the guilty parties.
fields.body:
The official inquiry into the Hatfield rail disaster, which exposed the appalling state of rail's infrastructure, is moving towards naming the guilty parties.

Railtrack and Balfour Beatty, its maintenance contractor, are facing charges of criminal manslaughter for the accident in which four people were killed in October last year.

Both companies have already conceded that 11 months before the crash they were aware of the cracked rail at the crash site.

They were given a six-month warning by site engineers to replace the rail, but failed to act.

The question arises as to whether the police will ask the Crown Prosecution Service to bring charges against named people.

The British Transport Police today confirms that charges are likely to be levelled at up to six senior managers from both companies some time next month.

If this happens, it will be the first time that individual managers have been asked to carry the can.

The CPS stopped short of corporate manslaughter over the Southall rail crash in 1997. Instead, Great Western Trains was fined £1.5m.

Two of the top men at Railtrack at the time of Hatfield were Gerald Corbett, its chief executive, and Nick Pollard, area director for the east coast main line.

Mr Corbett has since resigned and Mr Pollard has been moved to another job in the organisation.

The government is anxious for a quick fix so that somebody can take the rap.

It has decided, much to the astonishment of the Hatfield victims' families, not to press on with a public inquiry, arguing that it would get in the way of a criminal trial and hold up proceedings for up to two years.

The families argue that while a criminal trial is to be welcomed, its focus is narrow.

They say that a full inquiry would undoubtedly bring out crucial evidence about the background to the crash and the dangerous state of the industry, which the government might wish to hush up.

Tomorrow's interim report on Hatfield by the health and safety executive will be revealing. It will say that the rail on which the accident occurred was shattered into 300 pieces, like a piece of glass.

Investigators are also examining the coupling which broke on the buffet car, in which the four people died.

This caused the coach to rear up off the track while the other carriages remained upright.

Hatfield led to a widespread shutdown of the industry from which it is still recovering three months later.

Putting it into context, Railtrack found 300 other "serious'' rail cracks after Hatfield, all of which could have led to another accident.

fields.headline: Glad to be Che
fields.standfirst: Why is the artist Gavin Turk so obsessed with a dead revolutionary, asks  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: Why is the artist Gavin Turk so obsessed with a dead revolutionary, asks Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
Che Guevara was the Marilyn Monroe of Marxism, an empty receptacle for fantasy. The Argentine doctor and guerrilla leader was - as the former Guardian writer Richard Gott, who met him, recalled in a talk last week - beautiful. People were bowled over when he walked in the room. Women threw themselves at him, as, perhaps without quite knowing the source of their fervour, did young French and British male Marxists. He was possibly the only sex symbol in the history of Marxism. Not only that, he was a sex symbol when it mattered, in the 1960s, and it did wonders for far-left politics that, in the age of Jim Morrison, the most intensely erotic male icon of all turned out to be a communist leader.

This potent brew of sex, youth, hope and pop art didn't need to say anything important. He had a face. His admirers may profess horror at the way Che has become a massive commercial phenomenon, his image used in contexts a million miles from the third world guerrilla warfare he lived and died for, yet it's not surprising at all. There always was something vacant about the cult of Che. And if the artist Gavin Turk has achieved nothing else with his two-week teach-in The Che Gavara (sic) Story, still meandering along in London's Shoreditch, he has charted the furthest windy crevices of that vacancy.

Turk has already posed as the dead Che in a waxwork sculpture, lying Christ-like in his military fatigues on a reproduction of the washing block where Che was photographed in death by the Bolivian army - a work of transcendent stupidity. The Che Gavara Story is perhaps an improvement. Turk is certainly disarmingly honest - he admits he doesn't know much about Guevara. The German artist Joseph Beuys used to organise massive self-educative events a little like this, but he was a charismatic figure, able to inspire audiences with his crazy visions. I'll acknowledge the interest of Gott's talk on Che in Africa, but Turk's event is more like a Beuys action restaged by Andy Warhol's Factory: an aimless, inarticulate shambles. One day he reported on the movement's activities: the planned video of Citizen Smith wasn't available, so a Werner Herzog film about the Congo was shown instead. There's going to be a demonstration on Saturday, though last week Turk still didn't know what about.

Yet the real focus of irritation, as tinny Cuban music comes out of the CD player and we pass around a book of pictures of the revolutionary, is Che himself. There are worthier radical figures to celebrate, but the hunchbacked Antonio Gramsci, great theorist of an enlightened class struggle who died in an Italian prison, or the bespectacled Walter Benjamin, were both too bookish for this kind of crass, post-political idolatry. They said things that were complicated and difficult. You'd have to hang out at Turk's quite a long time to establish that Che ever said anything at all (as opposed to looking great). And, when you do encounter his views, it's a crushing disappointment. His masterpiece of revolutionary theory, La Guerra de Guerrillas (1961), outlines a strategy of jungle warfare that he himself discredited by his dismal failure in Bolivia in 1967.

Che is the perfect political hero for an apolitical age, because none of us is ever likely to be moved to any action by him. He inhabits a fantasy world of jungle shoot-outs, which his recently published diaries of motorbike journeys around Argentina and misadventure in the Congo make available to the armchair revolutionary: travel writing with a machine gun. Ultimately this is what Turk and the Hoxton Popular Front have drawn attention to - Che Guevara as a political symbol whose emptiness matches the times.

At the political strategy meeting, we talked about why Andy Warhol never did Che. Someone suggested it was too political for him - but he painted Mao, and the hammer-and-sickle. Turk talks a lot better about Andy than he does about Che. Later I remembered: Warhol did depict Che, and Fidel, in his 1965 film The Life of Juanita Castro. They are played by women and all kinds of gay goings-on in the Cuban government are implied. Everyone adored the idea that Raul, the real-life brother of Fidel, who was a defence minister or something like that, was a transvestite, said Warhol.

Later revelations about the persecution of homosexuals in Cuba and the film's allusion to the bizarre blend of machismo and desire that surrounds Che make it more telling than anything going on at the Foundry this week.

 The Che Gavara Story is at the Foundry (020-7379 6932), London EC2, until January 28.

fields.headline: Commonwealth Institute wins backing
fields.trailText: Following a root and branch review, the Institute of Commonwealth Studies, in London has secured vital funding and is looking for a new director.
fields.body:
Following a root and branch review, the Institute of Commonwealth Studies, in London has secured vital funding and is looking for a new director.

He or she will have £200,000 from London University to spend on development plans in an effort to enhance the academic reputation and activities of the institute founded in 1949.

A panel chaired by Sir Anthony Kenny, former master of Balliol College, Oxford, and warden of Rhodes House, reviewed the institute's role and future and has urged it to concentrate on the contemporary Commonwealth rather than imperial history.

The report praised some aspects of the institute's work - it received very high ratings (5s) for politics and history in the last research assessment exercise - but said it would "strengthen the intellectual future" of the institute to concentrate on on the contemporary Commonwealth as an institution and an example of trends in international politics and economic relations.

The institute in Russell Square, London, has a small staff but an important library of 160,000 items, particularly Caribbean, South African and Australian documents. It runs about 150 conferences and seminars a year.

A Masters degree in Commonwealth studies should be re-established alongside the present MA in Human Rights, recommended the panel. The previous director, Professor Pat Caplan, did not have her three-year contract renewed. The new director is to be appointed for five years. An appeal to endow a chair in honour of the former Commonwealth secretary general, Emeka Anyaoku, is to be launched with the Duke of Westminster as patron.

fields.headline: Atlantic Telecom cuts 350 jobs
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Atlantic Telecom has announced drastic job cuts as it strives to reach profitability, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Atlantic Telecom has announced drastic job cuts as it joins its rivals in striving to reach profitability ahead of schedule.

The British company said the 350 redundancies at its residential telecoms division will allow it to concentrate on providing high-speed internet services for small businesses.

"The restructure will fully align our cost structures with our business strategy and allow us to achieve cost savings of approximately £30m in the next financial year," said Atlantic executive chairman Graham Duncan.

He added that the job cuts will ensure the company achieves positive earnings earlier than analysts' predictions of 2004.

Redstone Telecom recently scaled back its investment plans as a change in market sentiment closed funding opportunities for small European telecoms companies.

Banks have effectively turned their backs on the sector, after companies built up massive debts to pay for next-generation mobile phone licences.

Atlantic will now concentrate on providing broadband internet services to businesses in the UK and Germany. It will install its equipment in 600 telecoms exchanges in the UK, and has already started the process in 331 German sites.

In a further boost to its broadband plans, Atlantic said it has reached an agreement to use the fibre-optic network owned by Carrier 1 in Germany.

fields.headline: Lord Prentice of Daventry
fields.standfirst: Labour minister whose defection to the Tories prefigured an era of leftwing infighting
fields.trailText: As plain Reg Prentice, Lord Prentice of Daventry, who has died aged 77, achieved political notoriety as the highest-ranking Labour figure ever to defect to the Conservative party.
fields.body:
As plain Reg Prentice, Lord Prentice of Daventry, who has died aged 77, achieved political notoriety as the highest-ranking Labour figure ever to defect to the Conservative party.

His dramatic switch in 1977, which followed his deselection in Newham North-East after a series of battles with leftwing constituency activists, prefigured a decade of destructive infighting within Labour's ranks, and was all the more shocking because of his background as a trade union official.

But his career was not without solid achievement on the ministerial benches - albeit in both major parties. After defecting, he managed not only to land a safe Tory seat at Daventry but to obtain office under Margaret Thatcher as a junior social security minister, from 1979 until ill health forced his retirement in 1981. Knighted in 1987, the year he stepped down as an MP, he popped up in the 1992 new year's honours list as a peer.

Probably there was something in his background and resilience, rather than in his pugnacious personality, that appealed to the then prime minister, John Major, himself another improbable south London survivor.

Educated at Whitgift school, Croydon, then as now a fee-paying school, Prentice went to the London School of Economics, worked as a temporary civil servant and emerged from military service in the Royal Artillery in the officer class, serving in Italy and Austria during the second world war.

After another spell at the LSE, he graduated and, in 1950, joined the staff of the Transport & General Workers Union (TGWU), then under its formidable leader, Ernie Bevin, Labour's foreign secretary. The union propelled Prentice into parliament as MP for East Ham North in 1957.

A conventional political career beckoned. When Labour finally won back power in 1964, after the internecine 50s, Harold Wilson made Prentice a minister of state, first at Education and Science (1964-66), then Public Buildings and Works (1966-67), and finally in charge of the still-new Ministry of Overseas Development (1967-69).

In opposition, after 1970, Prentice was a red-faced and genial colleague who had a knack of doing well in shadow cabinet elections, sometimes coming top, to the surprise of colleagues. In 1974, with Labour back in power, he entered the cabinet as education secretary, cheerfully helping to abolish direct grant status for leading grammar schools and driving them into the private sector - a problem that haunts Labour governments to this day.

By 1975 Wilson sent him back to Overseas Development. But by this time, troubles were brewing in his renamed constituency, Newham North-East, which he was accused of neglecting, usually an important feature of deselection battles in any party. The larger picture was one of growing economic strain under successive oil shocks, which fed through into rising unemployment and inflation, putting pressure on public services, including councils.

Leftwing militancy among unions was matched by infiltration - or "entryism" in the jargon of the time - by previously banned groups like the Militant Tendency. Prentice had his supporters in Newham, leading councillors included, but he was also opposed by the legitimate left.

What made his battle so memorable was that bedsit Trotskyism was matched in Newham by the arrival of alleged Labour moderates, notably a young Oxford graduate called Julian Lewis, to fight on the MP's behalf. Helped by funding from the Freedom Association (it later emerged), Lewis, now himself the Tory MP for New Forest East and on William Hague's right, briefly won control of the constituency party in late 1976. As befitted a turbulent decade, the language on both sides was extravagant.

When asked to resign, Prentice hit back at the "little gang" who ran the local party, accusing them of "going completely round the bend" and of indulging in a "transparent fiddle". He claimed that the crucial deselection resolution had been tabled without reference to him and that the situation had reached "low farce" and "pure communism".

At Labour's 1976 party conference - the one that saw chancellor Denis Healey recalled from an IMF meeting to face his furious critics in Blackpool - Prentice appealed from the rostrum to have the national executive committee endorsement of his deselection overturned. "Political cowardice as the price of political survival," he called it. The conference was unmoved.

When he joined the Tories, Labour allies, who had backed him, including Shirley Williams, herself to break with Labour four years later, were furious and embarrassed. Naturally, his Newham enemies were gleeful at their early, somewhat self-fullfilling detection of what ex-chief whip Bob Mellis (no leftwinger he) now dubbed "a nauseating traitor". Prentice said at the time that his defection was brought about by "a growing emphasis on class war and Marxist dogma" in the Labour party. Yet he remained loyal to comprehensive schools and to incomes policy even as he became a Thatcher convert.

As Tory-to-Labour defectors are now finding in their turn, new colleagues do not readily embrace a convert. With honourable exceptions, their old colleagues reserve a special venom for them. Like the gang of four who formed the SDP in 1981, and assorted politicians who defected or gave up during Labour's long rehabilitation, Prentice got little credit from those who stayed behind to fight - or from those leftwingers who had fought him, stayed behind and have slowly metamorphosed into Blairites.

Prentice would have chuckled at some of his old foes in sharp suits and sombre ties. In later years, he was president of the Conservative Association in Devizes, where Tory chairman, Michael Ancram is the MP. He lived in Marlborough and listed walking and golf among his recreations.

He is survived by his wife, Joan, and a daughter, Christine.

 Reginald Ernest Prentice, Baron Prentice of Daventry, politician, born July 16 1923; died January 18 2001

At Labour's 1976 party conference - the one that saw chancellor Denis Healey recalled from an IMF meeting to face his furious critics in Blackpool - Prentice appealed from the rostrum to have the national executive committee endorsement of his deselection overturned. "Political cowardice as the price of political survival," he called it. The conference was unmoved. When he joined the Tories, Labour allies, who had backed him, including Shirley Williams, herself to break with Labour four years later, were furious and embarrassed. Naturally, his Newham enemies were gleeful at their early, somewhat self-fullfilling detection of what ex-chief whip Bob Mellis (no leftwinger he) now dubbed "a nauseating traitor". Prentice said at the time that his defection was brought about by "a growing emphasis on class war and Marxist dogma" in the Labour party. Yet he remained loyal to comprehensive schools and to incomes policy even as he became a Thatcher convert. As Tory-to-Labour defectors are now finding in their turn, new colleagues do not readily embrace a convert. With honourable exceptions, their old colleagues reserve a special venom for them. Like the gang of four who formed the SDP in 1981, and assorted politicians who defected or gave up during Labour's long rehabilitation, Prentice got little credit from those who stayed behind to fight - or from those leftwingers who had fought him, stayed behind and have slowly metamorphosed into Blairites. Prentice would have chuckled at some of his old foes in sharp suits and sombre ties. In later years, he was president of the Conservative Association in Devizes, where Tory chairman, Michael Ancram is the MP. He lived in Marlborough and listed walking and golf among his recreations. He is survived by his wife, Joan, and a daughter, Christine.  Reginald Ernest Prentice, Baron Prentice of Daventry, politician, born July 16 1923; died January 18 2001

fields.headline: Tobacco body fights ban
fields.standfirst: Useful link: tobacco advertising bill
fields.trailText:
1pm: A tobacco trade body has warned that the proposed advertising ban will lead to a rise in consumption, reports Claire Cozens.
Useful link: tobacco advertising bill
fields.body:
A trade body that represents all the major tobacco companies is warning that far from reducing smoking, the proposed ban on tobacco advertising will lead to a rise in tobacco consumption.

In what is being seen as a veiled threat to the government, the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association is claiming a total ban on tobacco advertising would leave manufacturers with no choice but to lower prices to compete with each other, a move it says would lead to an increase in smoking.

"This bill goes way too far and extends unprecedented censorship of a product that is freely and legally available for sale to adults," said John Carlisle, director of public affairs at the TMA.

"The most likely outcome of this policy is that tobacco consumption will reach even higher levels, the opposite of what the government intends."

MPs will today debate the government's proposals to ban tobacco advertising and sponsorship, one of Labour's pre-election commitments.

Under the proposals, advertisers who flout a ban on tobacco advertising will face fines of up to £5,000 and even imprisonment.

But according to a report in Sunday's Observer newspaper, the Tories will try to scupper the ban by tabling an amendment to try to water it down.

Plans for a UK ban on tobacco advertising were unveiled in the Queen's Speech last December.

The government decided to introduce measures of its own after a surprise judgement two months ago by the European Court of Justice that a planned EU-wide ban on tobacco advertising was illegal.

The court ruled that the issue of whether to ban cigarette ads should instead be decided by individual member states.

fields.headline: Kanoute in 'big team' turnaround
fields.trailText: Frederic Kanoute today pledged his "100% commitment" to West Ham, despite hinting he may leave the club to further his international ambitions.
fields.body:
Frederic Kanoute today pledged his "100% commitment" to West Ham, despite hinting he may leave the club to further his international ambitions.

The French striker, who joined the club last summer in a £3.7m deal from French side Lyon, told the Mirror he believes he will only get a chance for Les Bleus if he plays for a "big team".

"When you are in a big team like Manchester United or Arsenal, the selectors will see you all the time," Kanoute told the Mirror this morning. "As soon as I get into that kind of team, the selectors will decide to look at me."

Both Manchester United and Liverpool have been linked with £15m bids for the player, but the 24-year-old stated he is unlikely to sign for a club in the north because there are too many "little houses" in the region.

"I don't really like the north," he said. "It's always raining, it's very cold and I don't like all those little houses. It's not for me. I couldn't see myself ever playing for someone like Middlesbrough or Everton."

But possibly after considering the reception he is likely to get upon his next visit to Upton Park - never mind whenever he plays north of Vicarage Road - Kanoute backtracked this morning, if only slightly.

"I'd like to comment once more on the rumours of contracts with Liverpool or Manchester United," he said on his website icons.com today.

"It's nice to think that such big sides are interested in me - it's an honour. But I must forget about that.

"In every game I must have the same approach: to give my best and be 100% committed as if it was my first game. It's the best way for me to keep my feet on the ground."

However, Hammers fans will remember comments made by Kanoute when he agreed to a new pay deal last month.

Ostensibly committing himself to the West Ham cause, he said: "Why would I want to leave Upton Park to go to Chelsea or Liverpool, where I'd play one game in three or sit on the substitutes' bench?

"One day I'd be happy to join the big names like Liverpool or Chelsea but I won't sign for them until I'll be sure to be a starter."

Kanoute has scored 10 goals for the Hammers and has impressed many with his skills.

fields.headline: BBC signs Ian Wright
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The BBC has clinched a £1m two-year deal with former England footballer and ITV presenter Ian Wright, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed the signing of former England footballer and ITV presenter Ian Wright to an two-year exclusive deal believed to be worth £1m.

As part of the deal, the star will take over from Ant and Dec as the main host of BBC1 Saturday evening entertainment show, Friends Like These.

The SM:TV Live pair are quitting their BBC1 show to develop an ITV peaktime entertainment format.

Mr Wright, who had his own chat show on ITV, has signed up to present a football programme on Radio 5 Live with former Crystal Palace team-mate Mark Bright.

He told BBC1 Breakfast News today that he chose television over football management because he felt he could be more successful in a TV career.

"I am never going to be England manager, so why should I stay in something where I cannot reach the top," said Mr Wright.

"Ian has great talent and charisma and he is one of life's enthusiasts," said BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey.

"He sums up what I am trying to do with BBC1 and the new spirit of the channel," she added.

The signing of Mr Wright is part of a concerted drive by the BBC to rebuild its on-screen talent line-up following a series of high-profile defections.

On Friday, the corporation announced it had signed Olympic boxing gold medallist Audley Harrison to an exclusive deal.

Jonathan Ross has also been signed to an exclusive contract.

Louis Theroux, presenter of BBC2's Weird Weekend series, has also signed a two-year deal with the corporation.

He will be developing a new series as well as having the opportunity to do more one-off programmes such as the highly acclaimed When Louis Met Jimmy.

"Louis and BBC2 have been a fantastic combination resulting in some of the most original television in recent years," said BBC2 controller Jane Root.

"The next two years will see Louis spreading his wings on BBC2 and bringing his inimitable style to some new and exciting formats," she added.

Theroux said: "I am very pleased. Whatever subject I've decided to cover, be it porn films or gangsta rap, the BBC has always given me total creative freedom."

fields.headline: Cloning: disaster or necessity?
fields.standfirst:
As peers threaten to block government plans to allow the cloning of embryos, science editor Tim Radford looks at a medical revolution

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText:
As peers threaten to block government plans to allow the cloning of embryos, science editor Tim Radford looks at a medical revolution.
Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.body:
DNA has been around for 3.8bn years, renewing itself with each life at conception. In humans, a length of adult DNA from a male enters an egg and unites with DNA from a female, turns back the clock, becomes the first infant cell, divides and starts a cascade of reactions that turns one fertilised egg into 1,000bn cells of more than 200 different kinds.

How it does this is a whole series of mysteries, but one key to these lies in first stem cells from which all bone, skin, blood and nerves subsequently stem. These appear in the first 14 days, before the cell implants in the womb.

For the last 10 years, British scientists have used embryos up to 14 days old to assist infertile couples to a pregnancy, and to study the puzzles of infertility.

Four years ago, Scottish scientists stunned the world by taking DNA from a dead sheep and growing Dolly. Then three years ago, US scientists working with private money managed to "immortalise" stem cells in a laboratory dish.

The combination of the two discoveries seemed to open a magic door: onto a horizon in which incurable, irreversible diseases such as multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease could be one day cured. "Personalised" stem cells could be grown in a dish, and implanted in a sufferer, to make new nerve cells grow. The paralysed Superman actor, Christopher Reeve, might walk again.

American federal law will not permit taxpayers' money to finance embryo research of any kind, but US private laboratories can do what they like.

In Britain, all such research is subject to the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act. A government committee considered the opening, and gave the green light to a very limited extension to permit research into embryos up to 14 days old for other diseases besides those of infertility.

Nervously, the government created another committee, which also gave the green light. Again nervously, the government then permitted a free vote in the House of Commons. It passed, by a huge majority.

Now, driven by some, but not all, religious groups, the House of Lords could kick the legislation into touch, or at least into the next parliament, by referring "therapeutic cloning" to a committee.

Dissidents argue that latest experiments with "adult" stem cells mean that embryos may need never to be used. There is a case: there could never be enough donated eggs to make the stem cells that doctors would ultimately need.

The hope is that ultimately stem cells from adults could be "reprogrammed" to cure diseases. But at present, the only way to get to that point is to study stem cells as they emerge in the first 14 days, using surplus embryos that would otherwise be destroyed.

The Roman Catholic church and other groups talk of embryo stem cell research as a "dehumanising" and disastrous step. That's not how Parkinson's disease and muscular dystrophy campaign groups see it, nor the British Medical Association, nor the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, nor Diabetes UK.

The issue explained

16.12.2000, leader: Stem cells offer hope

fields.headline: Mandelson 'helped' passport bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: A controversial Indian tycoon who with his brother gave £1m to the Millennium Dome has admitted he was assisted in his application for a British passport by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary.
fields.body:
A controversial Indian tycoon who with his brother gave £1m to the Millennium Dome has admitted he was assisted in his application for a British passport by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary.

But Mr Mandelson has denied that he lobbied the Home Office to give a passport to Srichand Hinduja, who is facing corruption charges in India.

Mr Hinduja made the inquiry with Mr Mandelson more than two years ago after his first application had been rejected. His second attempt in obtaining citizenship succeeded last autumn.

Sources close to the Hindu jas yesterday confirmed that they had asked Mr Mandelson how to go about getting a British passport. They were introduced to him by Michael Heseltine, a key advocate of the dome, in 1998.

The Hindujas asked Mr Mandelson whether an application by Srichand Hinduja would be welcomed by the Home Office. He came back to them and said the application would be "accepted and dealt with in the normal manner", the sources claimed.

There is no evidence that Mr Mandelson lobbied the Home Office in this matter.

"He did not get me a passport or influence anybody. It was purely a question of: 'What is the procedure?'" Srichand Hinduja said last night.

"He said that in the normal course of things it would be welcomed. Did I use his office for getting the passport? That is not true."

Mr Hinduja and his brother Gopichand donated £1m to pay for the dome's faith zone.

Labour party sources said Mr Mandelson made the inquiry through his private office to establish whether a second application would be welcome but insisted he had done nothing wrong. "At no time did he support or endorse an application for citizenship," a party spokesman said.

The disclosure of Mr Mandelson's involvement comes as three Hinduja brothers are facing charges in India for allegedly receiving £6bn kickbacks in a 1986 arms deal involving the Swedish manufacturer Bofors.

The Liberal Democrat MP Norman Baker called for an urgent investigation into Mr Mandelson's role in securing Srichand Hinduja's citizenship. "We have a rich businessman in the middle of a corruption scandal who gets a British passport in record time after donating £1m to the dome," he said.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said Mr Mandelson must provide a full explanation about his role in the affair.

But the Northern Ireland Office spokesman issued a further rebuttal, saying: "He did not support or endorse any passport application nor would he have done so."

fields.headline: Network of the World links up with Meanfiddler.com
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Online entertainment service Network of the World has signed a content deal with Meanfiddler.com, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
London-based interactive entertainment service Network of the World has signed a wide-ranging content deal with Meanfiddler.com.

Vince Power, Meanfiddler.com chairman, described the link-up as "a milestone deal".

It will lead to the distribution of webcasts for bands performing at Mean Fiddler's 12 venues across the country.

Meanfiddler.com will webcast 13 shows live over the next 26 weeks.

Each show will be recorded to enable NOW to produce music programmes as part of its MP3 TV brand and, in turn, broadcast to 130m homes via NOW's Asiasat3 network.

"This deal shows the potential for expanding the audience for our content via media partners such as NOW," said Mr Power.

NOW is a joint venture between Pacific Century CyberWorks (owned by Hong Kong media mogul Richard Li) and production company Trans World International.

It has not been immune to the prevalent dot.com woes.

In December, NOW was hit by cutbacks as its parent company scaled back investment and laid off staff.

fields.headline: Una monarquía consolidada
fields.standfirst: Twenty five years ago, Juan Carlos de Borbón was declared King of Spain. Eulàlia Furriol finds that although most young Spaniards like their royal family, few want a monarchy
fields.trailText: Hace veinticinco años Juan Carlos de Borbón fue proclamado Rey de España. Era el 22 de noviembre de 1975. Dos días antes había muerto el general Francisco Franco. Este militar había empezado y ganado la guerra civil española. Durante cuarenta años fue jefe de Estado, hasta que murió anciano en su palacio. Franco había nombrado al príncipe Juan Carlos como su sucesor. En 1975 el futuro de España y de la restauración de la monarquía era incierto.

Hace veinticinco años Juan Carlos de Borbón fue proclamado Rey de España. Era el 22 de noviembre de 1975. Dos días antes había muerto el general Francisco Franco. Este militar había empezado y ganado la guerra civil española. Durante cuarenta años fue jefe de Estado, hasta que murió anciano en su palacio. Franco había nombrado al príncipe Juan Carlos como su sucesor. En 1975 el futuro de España y de la restauración de la monarquía era incierto.

Hoy, veinticinco años más tarde, el ochenta y cinco por ciento de los españoles opina que la monarquía está consolidada. Tienen una imagen positiva de la familia real y creen que la monarquía debería continuar con el príncipe Felipe, hijo del rey Juan Carlos y de la reina Sofía.

Sin embargo, sólo un cuarenta y tres por ciento de los españoles se declara monárquico. Un dieciséis por ciento se declara republicano, y un cuarenta por ciento "no sabe/no contesta".

¿Qué opinión tienes de la familia real española? ¿Crees que hacen un buen trabajo?

Marta (19 años): Me gustan porque son gente muy normal. No parecen reyes. Son muy majos y hacen bien su trabajo. Me gusta también como tratan a la gente. Son encantadores. No tengo ninguna crítica de la familia real.

Adrià (16 años): Yo soy republicano. Sólo veo al Rey el día de Navidad en su discurso en televisión. Mi posición es de indiferencia. No me interesa la familia real.

Chencho (17 años): Me caen bien. Es una familia bastante simpática. Aunque no sigo con mucho interés lo que hacen. Su trabajo de representar a España ante otros países no lo hacen mal. Son también bastante serios con los temas de terrorismo y con las relaciones con Latinoamérica, por ejemplo. Están ahí y hacen un buen papel. Los veo como una familia más.

¿Crees que Juan Carlos de Borbón fue clave para la transición de la dictadura militar a la democracia en España?

Adrià: Sí, porque el cambio fue para mejorar. Ofreció esperanza. Pero, de todos modos, la democracia no estaba en peligro en España porque tarde o temprano habría llegado. Hace veinticinco años en Europa todo eran democracias. Las dictaduras ya se habían acabado. Es una cuestión de tendencias.

Chencho: Lo más importante es que eligió la democracia. Seguramente no fue una decisión fácil. Ello ayudó a acelerar los cambios para convocar elecciones, etc.

Marta: Creo que sí que fue decisivo. Franco lo nombró su sucesor para que siguiera con su régimen totalitario pero Juan Carlos prefirió la democracia. Fue muy hábil dialogando con todos, con los defensores del antiguo régimen, con el ejército y con los polticos a favor de la democracia.

¿Crees que el príncipe Felipe debería ser el próximo rey de España?

Adrià: Me gustaría que me lo preguntaran en un referéndum. Entonces tendría la posibilidad de votar a favor o en contra. En una república llega al poder la persona votada por el pueblo. En un sistema monárquico manda quien le toca por sucesión, sin que el pueblo pueda hacer nada. Si le toca al príncipe Felipe, pues que lo sea. Me da igual. Las monarquóas, la religión, todas estas cosas son de derechas y totalitarias. Son como una dictadura escondida.

Chencho: No me molesta pero tampoco me importa si no lo es. No tengo muy claro si soy republicano, pero tampoco me declaro monárquico. De momento el sistema monárquico va bien. Para mí el Rey es una persona importante que nos representa en numerosos actos.

Marta: S&#237, porque está muy preparado para ser rey.

¿Crees que la familia real tiene un coste económico alto, medio o bajo para el país?

Adrià: No lo sé, pero todas las familias reales viven muy bien. Tienen un chollo.

Chencho: Tiene un coste medio-alto. Pero de algo tendrán que vivir, aunque sea a costa nuestra. Tampoco podemos influir en esto.

Marta: Creo que es un coste medio, pero no me preocupa.

fields.headline: U-turn on adoption website crackdown
fields.standfirst: Text of minister's letter to ISPs
fields.trailText: Ministers have backed off from draconian measures to tackle illegal internet adoption websites, instead appealing to the public to report rogue sites so that they can be "switched off" by UK web providers. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
Ministers have backed off from draconian measures to tackle illegal internet adoption websites, instead appealing to the public to report rogue sites so that they can be "switched off" by UK web providers.

Health minister John Hutton today clarified overnight press reports that suggested internet service providers (ISPs) could face prosecution for carrying material that contravenes the 1976 adoption act.

He said that ISPs - companies such as AOL Europe and Freeserve that provide access for their subscribers to the world wide web - would have to remove illegal sites once they were made aware of them.

But he said they would not be forced to screen their own servers for illegal material, an admission that effectively recognises the difficulties in policing the internet.

The clarification could head off a row with internet industry leaders, who had argued that it would be impossible for them to check all the material being accessed by their customers.

The government has also confirmed it will push through legal regulations relating to a section of the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act 1999 that closes a loophole exploited in the recent net twins case.

It will introduce section 14 of the act by April. This will ensure that the adopters of children from abroad who are brought back to the UK to live will have to be assessed as to their suitability by accredited adoption workers.

In the case of the net twins, the adopters, Alan and Judith Kilshaw, evaded UK accredited home study assessment by claiming they had been subject to a study in the US, which allows couples to arrange private assessments. Parents who adopt from abroad without undergoing the proper checks will face up to three months in prison and a fine of £600.

The remaining sections of the Adoption (Intercountry Aspects) Act are expected to be introduced by the end of the year.

The next twist in the saga of the net twins will come tomorrow when the Kilshaws go to the high court to attempt to overturn a decision to allow Flintshire county council to take the six-month-old pair Kimberley and Belinda into care.

The council is expected to apply to make the children wards of court. Flintshire social workers took the children away on Thursday night last week after serving an emergency protection order on the couple.

Mr Hutton wrote to the UK's internet service providers' association (ISPA) at the weekend warning that they could be breaking the law if they had illegal adoption websites online.

Under UK law, only local authorities and voluntary adoption agencies approved by the health secretary are allowed to advertise children for adoption.

But he made it clear to today that internet providers could not be penalised for carrying illegal sites they did not know about.

He told BBC Radio 4's the World At One programme: "The recent high court litigation in this country has confirmed that when an internet service provider becomes aware of illegal material on their server they do need to take action to deal with that.

"That is all we are trying to alert them to. We are not saying to all the UK ISPs that they must go away now and check all the material on their servers, that would be completely unreasonable and we are not unreasonable.

He added: "If the Department of Health became directly aware of any website that we felt contravened the adoption act we would certainly bring it to the attention of a UK-based internet service provider, of course we would," he said.

"And of course, if any member of the public or local authority or any other source were to alert a UK internet service provider that they were carrying a website that contravened the Adoption Act we would of course expect the UK internet service provider to take action.

"I don't think that is unreasonable. We are simply saying to the UK internet service providers that this is the legislation, it does impose obligations on you as it does on newspapers, on radio, on TV and other broadcasters too."

fields.headline: Microsoft unveils $200m ad campaign
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Microsoft has unveiled a $200m corporate advertising campaign, reports Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Microsoft today unveiled a $200m corporate ad campaign which it hopes can help it offset the effects of a global slump in PC sales.

The TV and press campaign - with the strapline "Software for the agile business" - has been created by McCann Erickson.

Aimed at businesses rather than consumers, it will be the software company's biggest ever campaign.

It will kick off soon in the US and is expected to be rolled out globally this year.

The world's biggest company is beginning to feel the pinch of a slowdown in PC sales.

Figures released today by UK research firm Context showed the European PC market in 2000 suffered its worst fourth quarter for four years.

As the business and home PC markets approach saturation, Microsoft is unable to shift as much of its highly profitable PC-based software such as Office and Excel.

Instead it has recognised that growth comes from selling businesses whole solutions - what it calls enterprise software - such as strategies for e-commerce with customers.

"Through the magic of software we can help make smaller companies big, and make big companies fast," said Microsoft president and chief executive officer Steve Ballmer.

Mr Ballmer is also targeting other areas for growth including mobile phone operating systems and games consoles.

In the latter category, Microsoft is about to announce an agency to handle the launch of the Xbox games console, which goes on sale in the US and Japan this autumn.

The Xbox campaign is expected to be even bigger than today's 'software agility' campaign.

fields.headline: Medi@Invest's losses mount
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Internet investment firm Medi@Invest has plunged further into the red, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet investment firm Medi@Invest has plunged further into the red following a nightmare six months for one of its brightest hopes.

It has been forced to write off £6.4m against its KZN Media children's internet service provider, after advertising and access income tumbled in a competitive market.

"The ISP market is buggered and we have to take stock of that. We have yet to see an ISP take a decent advertising hit," said Medi@Invest director Robin Jones.

The AIM-listed company reported losses of £8.96m for the six months to September 2000, a massive increase from the deficit of £58,000 for the same period in 1999.

Some solace was provided by the performance of its computer games company the Creations Group, which had a number one hit with its FIFA 2001 game for the PlayStation. Its Andromeda Holdings publishing company is on track to reach its predicted profit level for the year.

"The games company has plenty of money in it, the publishing company is doing well, and neither of them are a drain on central resources," said Mr Jones.

However, the slump in fortunes at KZN has left the company with just £3.4m in the bank. Medi@Invest's shares fell 15% to 4p in early trading, far below its year highs of just under 100p.

Fellow internet investors NewMedia Spark and Durlacher have suffered similar falls from grace, as the value of their investments dried up and the stock market turned against dot.com start-ups.
