fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are still very much in love with Chris Evans
fields.trailText: Planet Football are citing "reports in France" which suggest that Liverpool are on the verge of signing Brazilian forward Christian from Paris St Germain in a £7m deal. Aston Villa, Leeds and Arsenal have all been linked with the 25-year-old, but none were prepared to meet PSG's valuation.
fields.body:
Planet Football are citing "reports in France" which suggest that Liverpool are on the verge of signing Brazilian forward Christian from Paris St Germain in a £7m deal. Aston Villa, Leeds and Arsenal have all been linked with the 25-year-old, but none were prepared to meet PSG's valuation.

The move will increase speculation that Robbie Fowler will be on his way from Anfield: Arsenal and Chelsea are the usual suspects.

Arsenal and Chelsea have also been alerted to the possibility of signing West Ham striker Frederic Kanoute, who is angling for a move to further his international ambitions. All is explained here.

Gilles Grimandi wants to leave Arsenal at the end of the season. The 30-year-old wants regular first-team football and would also like "a new challenge".

The inevitable arrival of Ruud Van Nistelrooy at Old Trafford could mean the end of Dwight Yorke's Manchester United career, claims the Daily Mail without actually suggesting where he'll go.

The Mail does, however, suggest Manchester United will sign Henrik Larsson from Celtic as a long-term replacement for the ageing Teddy Sheringham.

Marcel Desailly will consider leaving Chelsea if the club fail to win a place in next season's Champions League. "I want to play in the Champions League again, and I need to be in it," he said. "I will stop playing soon so I don't have a lot of time. I don't want to leave the club, my family is very happy living in London but much will depend on what happens in my football life."

webTitle: Gladiator wins, Soderbergh loses at Golden Globes

fields.headline: Gladiator wins, Soderbergh loses at Golden Globes
fields.standfirst: Gladiator was named best dramatic film and Ang Lee best director at a chaotic Golden Globes ceremony which further muddies the Oscar waters
fields.trailText: Gladiator was named best dramatic film and Ang Lee best director at a chaotic Golden Globes ceremony which further muddies the Oscar waters
fields.body:
Ridley Scott's Gladiator, Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous emerged as the winners of what appeared to be a split-decision Golden Globes in LA last night. Industry insiders will now be sifting the results of a chaotic ceremony which conspired to honour a variety of Oscar hopefuls without annointing one clear favourite.

All told the awards were a mixed-bag. Gladiator (pictured) seized the award for Best Film, Drama, while Ang Lee took the Best Director statue for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which also won the award for Best Foreign Film. The nod for the Best Film, Musical or Comedy, went to the coming-of-age rock outing Almost Famous. Tom Hanks was named Best Actor, Drama, for his role in Cast Away, while Julia Roberts took the Best Actress, Drama, gong for her turn in Erin Brockovich.

The real surprise of the night was the poor showing of Steven Soderbergh, heavily tipped for Oscar glory for either Traffic or Erin Brockovich. Despite receiving two nominations for Best Director and a nomination for Best Film, Drama (for Traffic), Soderbergh missed out on the main awards. As if to make amends, Roberts paid lavish tribute to the director in her own acceptance speech. "I'd have read the phone book for him if he'd asked me to," said the actress who will appear in Soderbergh's Ocean's Eleven with George Clooney and Brad Pitt.

The confusing signals given by the Globes was reflected in the ceremony as a whole, which teetered at times on the verge of farce. Actress Renee Zellweger found herself in the toilet when her name was called to receive an award for Nurse Betty ("I thought I had something in my teeth and I wanted to fix it," she later explained), while Elizabeth Taylor almost blundered by reading out the winner for Best Film, Drama, before she had gone through the rest of the nominations. Fortunately one guest kept his head beautifully. Accepting an award for his role in the TV show Ally McBeal, recently paroled Robert Downey Jr thanked his fellow actors for their support. "It's nice not to be under the table tonight," the newly sober star told the assembled throng.

 The 2001 Golden Globe winners

Best Picture, Drama: Gladiator

Best Picture, Musical or Comedy: Almost Famous

Best Actor, Drama: Tom Hanks (Cast Away)

Best Actress, Drama: Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich)

Best Actor, Musical or Comedy: George Clooney (O Brother, Where Art Thou)

Best Actress, Musical or Comedy: Renee Zellweger (Nurse Betty)

Best Supporting Actor: Benicio Del Toro (Traffic)

Best Supporting Actress: Kate Hudson (Almost Famous)

Best Director: Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon)

Screenplay: Stephen Gaghan (Traffic)

Original Score: Hans Zimmer & LIsa Gerrard (Gladiator)

Original Song: Things Have Changed, by Bob Dylan (Wonder Boys)

Foreign Language Film: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

fields.headline: Human cloning
fields.standfirst: The House of Lords is threatening to overrule government plans to allow the (therapeutic) cloning of human embryos. Angelique Chrisafis and Mark Tran explain the arguments over genetic engineering
fields.trailText: The House of Lords is threatening to overrule government plans to allow the cloning of human embryos. We explain the arguments over genetic engineering.
fields.body:
What is therapeutic cloning?
The creation of human embryos in a lab in order to remove special cells and grow them into body tissue, such as nerves, muscles, organs and bone.

Is therapeutic cloning legal?
No. The current law bans the research needed to develop therapeutic cloning. By law, scientists can only work with stem cells less than 14 days old to carry out research into understanding fertility, reproduction or congenital disorders. Using stem cells for any other purpose is not allowed. Human cloning is against the law for whatever purpose.

Is this about to change?
Possibly not. A government-appointed panel recommended that scientists should be permitted to create cloned embryos to study the creation of cells and tissues for transplant, but the House of Lords is threatening to reject the legislation. Peers accuse the government of attempting to railroad the plans through parliament and are demanding further research.

How does therapeutic cloning work?
In the same way that Dolly the sheep was created. Scientists take genetic material from a cell in an adult's body and fuse it with an empty egg cell. They trigger this to grow into an embryo. Inside the embryo are master cells with the potential to develop into any of the 216 cell types that make up the body, including nerve tissue, blood, heart muscle and brain cells. Since 1998, scientists have been able to isolate and culture these cells. Individual cells could be removed and implanted into our bodies to repair the damage caused by degenerative illnesses like heart disease.

What are the benefits of therapeutic cloning?
The new tissue could be used to treat disease. Transplant patients would no longer have to wait for someone else's tissue that their bodies might reject. They can have themselves cloned to produce perfect match tissue. This would do away with the powerful anti-rejection drugs needed to tame the immune systems of transplant patients. Some experts believe it may be possible one day to "grow" whole replacement organs in the laboratory. Likewise, "body repair kits" could be produced in which every newborn baby in the country has a supply of cloned cells in case a transplant is needed in later life.

What diseases could it cure?
Any degenerative disease where one cell type has gone wrong. This includes Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, Huntingdon's Chorea, diabetes and cancers. New muscle could also be produced to repair damaged hearts. Therapeutic cloning could eventually heal injuries such as burns. It would also end the long search for the right bone marrow donor in leukaemia cases, as perfect-match bone marrow could be created from a patient's own skin cells. Scientists estimate that 100m people could benefit worldwide.

What would happen to the cloned embryo?
The embryo would be destroyed. But scientists plan to remove cells before the embryos are 14 days old, stopping short of creating a cloned embryo that develops beyond a week. They hope this will circumvent ethical concerns about the creation of a cloned adult.

What do critics say?
The Catholic church objects to any research which involves the overproduction and then destruction of human embryos. It says any human embryo - including the small clump of cells produced for this research - is sacrosanct. Anti-abortion groups are suspicious that scientists want to develop therapeutic cloning for reproductive purposes. The pressure group, Life, has voiced fears that embryos would be cloned, implanted into a surrogate mother, allowed to develop for a full pregnancy, then killed for their hearts and other organs. Some argue that it is possible to remove so-called stem cells from adults and is therefore not necessary to produce cells from embryos. But although research has shown that adult bone marrow cells can be transformed into liver cells, scientists believe that only embryonic stem cells could produce a complete range of tissue types.

What is the current situation with human transplants?
Currently, victims of heart, liver and kidney failure need xenotransplantation - the transplant of tissue to a human being from a foreign source, such as another human or animal - to survive, but many are dying because there are too few human transplant donors. Groups in Britain and the US have been working to develop a line of genetically engineered pigs with human-compatible hearts to provide a supply of organs that would survive immediate rejection by the immune system but there is concern about spreading unknown pig viruses to the human population.

Special report: the ethics of genetics

webTitle: Three actors and a moment of mischief: the enigma solved

fields.headline: Three actors and a moment of mischief: the enigma solved
fields.trailText: The enigma of one of the rarest photographs in British theatrical history was solved yesterday by an eyewitness account of the mood in which it was taken nearly 21 years ago.
fields.body:
The enigma of one of the rarest photographs in British theatrical history was solved yesterday by an eyewitness account of the mood in which it was taken nearly 21 years ago.

The picture, to be auctioned for charity at Christie's in London tonight, is the only known image of Sir Ralph Richardson, Lord Olivier and Sir Alec Guinness in one frame.

The answer to the enigma, discussed by the Guardian when the photo's existence was revealed last week, is that the spirit behind their pose is "irrepressible" mischief rather than the infirmities of their old age.

This was partly because they felt naughty being photographed together without Sir John Gielgud, the fourth great theatrical knight of the late 20th century.

"Johnny would be annoyed if he knew about this," said Sir Ralph. So they asked the photographer, Terence Donovan, a close friend of Sir Ralph, to promise that the picture would be kept secret until they were all dead. It came to light only when Donovan's widow, Diana, gave it to the HIV charity London Lighthouse to raise funds for tonight's auction.

The photo session was in May 1980 at Holborn Studios, London, officially to take individual shots of the three for Vogue magazine. All had been film idols in their youth, but Richardson was then 79, Olivier 73 and Guinness 66.

Vince McCartney, now studio director, was at the session. "We had two girls of about 18 and 25 in reception, almost too young to have heard of the three of them. But when they walked in, doffed their caps with their canes in their hands and said good morning, they had such star presence that the girls almost passed out," he said.

"It was overwhelming. They were as frisky and nimble as boys playing truant from school. There was lots of fun."

Lord Olivier, who had been seriously ill with cancer and other conditions for several years, told Mr McCartney: "You know, my boy, I'm dying."

Sir Alec put in: "Yes, but you must remember that he has been saying that for at least 10 years."

fields.headline: Tobacco marketing
fields.standfirst: The government plans to ban tobacco advertising and  sponsorship. We explain how.
fields.trailText: The government plans to ban tobacco advertising and sponsorship. We explain how.
fields.body:
Why is tobacco marketing back in the news?
Legislation drastically curbing the promotion of cigarette sales is being debated by MPs.

Why is it controversial?
Labour was deeply embarrassed by the disclosure, soon after it took office, that Formula 1 chief Bernie Ecclestone had donated £1m to the party. Quite coincidentally, of course, the government had exempted motor racing from the advertising ban for three years.

What is the argument for favouring motor sport?
Britain has established a clear global lead in designing and building very very fast cars. The industry, which attracts huge sums of tobacco sponsorship, is worth tens of millions in exports. Bernie Ecclestone is also worth a king's ransom.

Are any other sports exempt from the proposed ban?
Yes. Snooker. The Embassy world championship and all that.

What does the EU want to do?
The European Commission, after vigorous lobbying by Downing Street, proposed extending the exemption for the two sports until 2006. Other sectors will be obliged to refuse tobacco sponsorship by 2003.

And the European Court of Justice?
It has ruled the Commission directive unlawful, on technical grounds connected with the fiendishly complex community rules on the single market. Health and safety issues were not considered.

Who else wants a ban?
The European Parliament is keen to toughen health warnings on cigarette packets. It is bitterly critical of the industry, which spends £100m a year on marketing.

How exactly do the Euro-MPs want to scare smokers?
They want 40% of the front and 50% of the back of packets to be devoted to health warnings, illustrated by pictures of diseased lungs, rotting teeth and so on.

How big are the health warnings now?
In Europe, they occupy 4% of the packaging. In the USA the proportion is 6%, and in Canada it is 50%.

Is anyone against curbs on tobacco promotion?
The tobacco industry, naturally, is dead set against them. The Treasury also has an interest in protecting its handsome revenues from tobacco taxes. And there is an argument that the curbs encourage cigarette smuggling, which drives down prices.

Isn't smuggling a small-scale affair?
It's a huge industry - and there are allegations that some of the major players in the trade, like British American Tobacco (BAT) are involved.

Key legislation
Tobacco advertising adn promotion bill

Are you an addict?

fields.headline: Woman's editor in with lads
fields.trailText: 5pm : Lads magazine Loaded is set to be relaunched after a new editor from a women's magazine, Keith Kendrick, was appointed, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
The appointment of the former Chat editor, Keith Kendrick, as the new editor of Loaded paves the way for a reinvention of the title.

Mike Soutar, the head of IPC's Music & Sport division, who joined last year to inject some fresh blood into IPC Music & Sport, said Loaded had been "guilty of not reinventing itself".

"I've seen it happen to quite a lot of magazines including Loaded, Q and Smash Hits.

"These ideas are created by a wayward genius, who then leaves and the people who are left spend a lot of time trying to recreate the format," he said.

He said Mr Kendrick, a former regional young journalist of the year, who has done stints on the Daily Mail and the Washington Post, would be "insurgent, rather than incumbent".

Despite surprise over the appointment at Mr Kendrick's lack of experience in men's magazines, he is said to be "an ideas man" who famously came up with the successful "Win a Divorce" competition for Chat.

Mr Soutar continued: "We need to get a grip on the product and make sure that the product has a feel for itself. If this means marketing it in a brand new way then that's what we'll do."

And he hinted that he might consider taking the title to an older age group. "A lot of people I talked to before I took this job had a low opinion of Loaded readers", he said.

"The age at which Loaded is targeted is one which has never been set in stone," he added.

The appointment of Mr Kendrick, who has not worked for a men's magazine will come as a surprise to the industry.

It is widely known that IPC spent almost a year agonising over who to appoint to the high profile job.

Among the contenders were Front editor Piers Hernu, who came to public notoriety during the documentary Trouble Between the Covers, and Maxim editor-at-large Bill Borrows.

Loaded acting editor, John Perry, was also in the running.

webTitle: Giles Smith on the Audi A3

fields.headline: Premium upgrade
fields.standfirst: Sporty and smooth, Audi's new A3 is a hatchback that feels like a saloon. Giles Smith gets a quietly superior feeling
fields.trailText: Sporty and smooth, Audi's new A3 is a hatchback that feels like a saloon. Giles Smith gets a quietly superior feeling.
fields.body:
It is not too difficult to make a hatchback share some of the poshness of a saloon. Car companies are doing it in the factory all the time, but you could almost do it yourself at home, with an afternoon on your hands and the right tools. You stick a little leatherette around the seats, wire in a CD player, electrify the windows or the sun-roof. Hey, presto.

To make a hatchback which is itself a premium grade vehicle and which feels like a saloon, rather than a wishful imitation of one, is something else. But Audi has done, with the A3.

The A3 came out in 1996. It was the first time Audi had bothered to design a hatchback since the 1970s, having had bigger fish to fry. The company had been too busy developing and establishing its crushingly cool saloons, the estimable A4 and its big and highly unaffordable sister, the A8, which is the price of a three-bed room house in most areas. With those two models alone, Audi had successfully outmanoeuvred the opposition, making Mercedes look tacky and BMW look like producers of automobiles by appointment to the world's wideboys.

Audi seemed to have looked at the most important, decision-shaping consumer desirables within the saloon-buying market - ostentation and the potential for crude one-upmanship - and then to have performed a neat shuffle by appearing to distance itself from all that. It wouldn't do gimmicks and flashiness; it wouldn't be so vulgar as to compete . It would proceed by a kind of understatement - and it would say smart things about you if you joined it in this quest.

In fact (and this was neat), there was no better way to get one-up than by driving an Audi. There was no more ostentatious way to be uninterested in ostentation. The company appealed, in the shape of its cars and, very compellingly, in its advertising, to the buyer's inverted snobbery, which is, of course, the most enjoyable kind of snobbery of all. No car has looked down its nose at snobbery quite so successfully as the Audi A4.

The A3, with its quietly dynamic look, continued this important family tradition - and still does so in its new version for this year. It's a classy motor, in many senses, but mostly in the sense of middle-class. (So smartly does Audi play the class game that it's difficult to believe it is not a British company. It is, of course, a German one: witness one of the colour choices for the A3, "Denim Blue". The denim in question appears to be stonewashed.)

It is commonly the way with car relaunches that what distinguishes the new model from the original is a bold mix of the barely discernible and the completely invisible - a slightly bigger badge here, a somewhat smaller accelerator pedal there and, under the bonnet, some fine-tuning which will probably only be perceptible at 147mph, and only then if you are Damon Hill.

For most companies, what goes by the name of a radical cosmetic make- over is actually the equivalent of having a skin-tuck in your underarm: very few people are going to notice. Whether you find the new A3 blisteringly different from the old model will depend at least in part on whether the following alterations raise any hair on your neck. Or indeed your underarm.

It's changed the grille; it's made the front Audi badge a bit thicker; it's put in new light mouldings; it's made available a new set of alloys (five different designs); some of the airbags stay puffed up for longer, just in case you're in for that always disappointing second impact; it's found a way to get a few more miles per gallon out of a 1.6 engine; it's come up with a slightly different steering wheel.

That's the main points covered, I think. Apart from the new, easy-touch boot catch, which slings the back door up almost when you breathe on it.

But who could blame Audi for not wishing to strip the car down and begin again from scratch? It was too good a mould to break.

Actually, the A3 shares a mould. VW is Audi's parent company and the A3 has been built, for reasons of economy, on the same base as the Golf. You might have imagined that this would force the cars to occupy much of the same territory, yet they could hardly be more sharply distinct from one another. The Golf is to the A3 what Little & Large are to Morecambe and Wise - merely a low-rent, end-of-the-pier imitation.

Inside are the Audi staples: plastic which doesn't look like plastic; elegant, clean controls; a densely insulated cabin which ignores road noise almost to the point of rudeness. If you never looked over your shoulder you could assume you were driving an A4 which had just come over all sporty on you.

Of course, not everybody wants a hatchback which performs like a saloon. Some people like their hatchback to act like a hatchback. After driving the A3, I found myself wondering: why?

The lowdown

Audi A3 1.8T

Price: from £14,605

Top speed: 217 km/h

Acceleration: 0-100 km/h in

8.2 seconds

Consumption: 7.8 l per 100 km

At the wheel: Graeme Le Saux

On the stereo: Moby

En route for: Hay-on-Wye

fields.headline: Into the night
fields.standfirst: Gaultier ditches jokey image
fields.trailText: Gaultier ditches jokey image.
fields.body:
The catwalk show everyone was talking about, as the fashion world assembled yesterday morning in Paris, was the one they were not allowed to see. At the Givenchy salon, canopies were being put up for a presentation of Alexander McQueen's collection. But press invitations were withdrawn giving leave to just the wealthy couture clients to be admitted.

As it turned out the day was anything but a washout. Jean Paul Gaultier proved that he has outgrown his role as fashion's court jester to become a sophisticated couturier, presenting a collection so strong and beautiful as to overshadow any disappointment over the Givenchy show.

The designer, who once cited his inspiration as "your funny, fat British girls with their black eye make-up and burgundy hair", believes that his role on the kitsch television series Eurotrash cost him the job of couturier at Christian Dior.

Three years ago, Gaultier founded his own couture house and showed himself to be more than up to the job.

He has even ditched his trademark French nautical striped T-shirts.

The show opened with a virtuoso display of inventive tailoring, including a double-breasted suit jacket sliced into two to make a bustier and a bolero.

But the highlight of the show was the sensational evening wear. Sophie Dahl looked like a sexed-up Degas dancer in a floor-length corset dress made from the pink ribbons used to tie ballet shoes. Delicate, fluid Galliano-esque gowns in tobacco and aubergine were exquisitely distressed and artistically darned; an "afternoon dress" in black crepe had peek-a-boo seams hinting at froths of nude-coloured chiffon; a rose-printed sheath dress had an outsize ruff of red at the hem, the silhouette emphasised by a full-length black net cape.

Gaultier has not lost his mischievous edge: his take on the traditional wedding dress finale involved a model carrying a baby under her long veil.

There is speculation that Bernard Arnault, boss of the fashion company LVMH, which owns Givenchy, is about to name Belgian designer Olivier Theyskens as the new couturier at the house of Givenchy.

webTitle: What does your wardrobe say about you?

fields.headline: Suits you
fields.standfirst:
In an age in which appearance is all, deciding what to wear to work can be a tricky task. So what does your wardrobe say about you, asks fashion editor Jess Cartner-Morley .

Four women tell Diane Taylor their dress codes
fields.trailText: In an age in which appearance is all, deciding what to wear to work can be a tricky task. So what does your wardrobe say about you, asks fashion editor  Jess Cartner-Morley  .
fields.body:
Women can rarely escape being judged on their appearance. A woman wearing a sober coloured suit is categorised immediately as career-oriented, serious, ambitious. A man, on the other hand, can simply wear a suit and not be defined by it. We are still hemmed in by our hemlines - and we know it, which is why, for women, the matter of dressing for work brings to the fore issues a little more complicated than whether there's a clean shirt ironed.

But all that early morning worry and effort is about issues a lot more subtle than wanting people in the office to fancy you. Rarely is it even about anything as simple as looking good for the sake of it. We don't get up on a Monday morning and think, I want to look drop-dead gorgeous for work today. But we can scarcely ignore attractiveness: in a culture that places a premium on appearance, some of the value afforded to beauty is inevitably carried over into the workplace and the job market.

Yet for women at work, appearance is also fraught with issues about looking appropriate, looking "the part". This complicates matters enormously and is the reason why, while getting dressed for an evening can be a fun activity, getting dressed for work is a chore, the first thing that furrows our brows of a morning.

In the 1980s, when the issue of women in the workplace was a "sexy" news item, the reference points were clunkily naive. The male office uniform of the two-piece suit was directly translated to fit women, the shoulder-heavy silhouette reproduced on the female form with foam shoulderpads. To this were added a few common-denominator signifiers of femininity: high heels, outsize pearl earrings, glossy red lipstick. It was unsophisticated marketing, the sartorial equivalent of the hefty paperback book covers embossed with gold lettering that flourished around the same time.

Over the past decade, however, as women's presence in the workplace and in public life has become normalised, and as work culture becomes increasingly fluid and informal, women's appearance in the workplace has shifted to become an extension of how women dress anyway, rather than a drag queen parody of men at work. There has been a shift towards "softer dressing": in many workplaces, cardigans stand in place of jackets, T-shirts or sweaters in place of shirts. A small industry has grown up out of a minor cult of jewel-coloured velvet and silk scarves, as worn by TV presenters and public figures to "soften" their look.

While this look is more overtly feminine than the previous power dressing aesthetic, it is perhaps less obviously sexual. Being more natural, it is somehow less eroticised. But it carries new problems, about whether the wearer is perceived as serious or, more specifically, as a person to be taken seriously. A too-keen interest in fashion is the 21st-century equivalent of novel-reading in the time of Jane Austen: an indicator of a slight intellect and flighty temperament. And somehow, a cardigan just doesn't convey the authority of a jacket.

Anyway, sex can never be erased from the equation where appearance is concerned.With clothes, it is almost impossible to disentangle sex from status: think of high heels, a signifier of wealth that has become a symbol of sex. Or of tailoring: once, close-fitting clothes were available only to those who could afford the seamstress's fees.

Sex and status, power and presence: all of these feature in the messages layered within our clothes and make-up. It's not easy, finding an outfit that would meet the approval of your boss, your best friend and Giorgio Armani, all before 8.30am. Sometimes it's hard to be a woman.

To this were added a few common-denominator signifiers of femininity: high heels, outsize pearl earrings, glossy red lipstick. It was unsophisticated marketing, the sartorial equivalent of the hefty paperback book covers embossed with gold lettering that flourished around the same time. Over the past decade, however, as women's presence in the workplace and in public life has become normalised, and as work culture becomes increasingly fluid and informal, women's appearance in the workplace has shifted to become an extension of how women dress anyway, rather than a drag queen parody of men at work. There has been a shift towards "softer dressing": in many workplaces, cardigans stand in place of jackets, T-shirts or sweaters in place of shirts. A small industry has grown up out of a minor cult of jewel-coloured velvet and silk scarves, as worn by TV presenters and public figures to "soften" their look. While this look is more overtly feminine than the previous power dressing aesthetic, it is perhaps less obviously sexual. Being more natural, it is somehow less eroticised. But it carries new problems, about whether the wearer is perceived as serious or, more specifically, as a person to be taken seriously. A too-keen interest in fashion is the 21st-century equivalent of novel-reading in the time of Jane Austen: an indicator of a slight intellect and flighty temperament. And somehow, a cardigan just doesn't convey the authority of a jacket. Anyway, sex can never be erased from the equation where appearance is concerned.With clothes, it is almost impossible to disentangle sex from status: think of high heels, a signifier of wealth that has become a symbol of sex. Or of tailoring: once, close-fitting clothes were available only to those who could afford the seamstress's fees. Sex and status, power and presence: all of these feature in the messages layered within our clothes and make-up. It's not easy, finding an outfit that would meet the approval of your boss, your best friend and Giorgio Armani, all before 8.30am. Sometimes it's hard to be a woman.

webTitle: In brief: Save the Last Dance stays on top in US

fields.headline: Save the Last Dance stays on top in US
fields.standfirst: Plus: David Duchovny too busy to star in Kevin Smith's latest film
fields.trailText: Plus: David Duchovny too busy to star in Kevin Smith's latest film
fields.body:
 Save the Last Dance (pictured) clung hold of the top spot at the US box office during a weekend of relative stasis within Hollywood. The unheralded feel-good youth flick starring Julia Stiles as a feisty ballet student was budgeted at just $13m (£8.87m) but made $16m (£10.92m) over the last three days, pushing its total takings to $47m (£32m) in only 10 days of release. Cast Away and Traffic also stuck firm at number two and three respectively, while the highest new entry was Guy Ritchie's Snatch which muscled in at number four after pocketing a cool $7.6m (£5.18m) in its opening weekend. Considering that Ritchie's previous flick, Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, made some $3m (£2m) in total during its release in the US, this counts as a major triumph for Britain's favourite mockney auteur.

 David Duchovny has exempted himself from a supporting role in Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back, the new film from writer/director/star Kevin Smith. The creator of Clerks and Dogma had offered the X Files star a role in the film, but a hectic work schedule has now intruded, according to a report on Hollywood.com. Duchovny is now due to co-star alongside Julianne Moore and William H. Macy in the sci-fi caper Evolution. Meanwhile, Smith is currently weighing up a replacement actor, although he says: "It's too early to say who it is."

webTitle: Will Channel 4's internet investment pay off?

fields.headline: Entertaining the interactive
fields.standfirst: Channel 4 is pumping millions of pounds into its websites and internet broadcasting, just when the dot.com bubble has burst for many others. Amy Vickers thinks it's a gamble that might pay off.
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is pumping millions of pounds into its sites and web broadcasting, just when the dot.com bubble has burst for many others. Amy Vickers thinks the gamble might pay off.
fields.body:
It's been said before, but now it could finally happen. The internet is about to become an entertainment medium. While most players are pulling out of internet broadcasting, it's a refreshing change to find Channel 4 pumping millions of pounds into developing a website for entertainment devotees.

But not only is the channel getting serious about developing an online entertainment destination to stand head and shoulders above the crowd, it is about to sprint way ahead of the broadcast competition when it reveals the potential of E4.com.

But the freshest breath of air is that Channel 4 is not screaming and shouting from the highest building about how wonderful E4.com is going to be. It seems it has learned the lesson of caution from the recent implosion of the dot.com market.

"The web is not yet proven as an entertainment medium," says Andy Anson, head of strategic planning and interactive at Channel 4. "We've still got to prove it can work within the current limitations and make sure we're not too far ahead of the game."

So rather than run before they can walk, the interactive team at Channel 4 are adamant that the present version of E4.com is in pre-launch mode. The official launch of the website will not happen until March, by which time Channel 4 will have completed part of its crucial learning phase and have a sense of what floats the boat of online entertainment seekers.

It's largely untrodden ground. The number of good online entertainment channels can be counted on one hand: Zeppotron.com, Z.com, AtomFilms.com, Icebox.com and Heavy.com are the ones that have gained something of a cult status among a hardcore fraternity of web users but the brands have yet to become household names.

E4.com should be able to change all that by its strategy of working with the best of the already established entertainment sites, such as Icebox.com and Heavy.com, and aggregating all the programming in one place. It has already commissioned Zeppotron's Office Romance, a series of 15 animations aimed at anyone who has loved and lost that will appear every Wednesday on E4.com.

It is also hoping to sign up Z.com's Dare for Dollars, a variation on The Hopefuls, the classic yuck TV item from Channel 4's The Word. "Contestants" email in their dares and how much money they would be willing to do it for. Dares are then posted on an auction forum where visitors are encouraged to challenge them or suggest a more extreme dare. The most extreme daredevil is chosen by the web producers who film the dare and broadcast it on the website.

Stevan Keane, head of interactive commissioning at Channel 4, says he has high hopes of taking a web show such as Dare for Dollars on to TV. "The strategic rationale is that E4.com will be an incubator for new talent and shows. We'll start things online and work them back into TV. We're already talking about what E4.com content can go on TV before the end of the year."

Anson adds: "It's not about crap TV on the web, it's about using the web in its best way and creating very good, compelling web entertainment."

The first example of an E4 cross-platform show is Banzai, a madcap Japanese gameshow which will be simulcast (broadcast simultaneously on TV and the web) on Sunday nights. Web viewers will be encouraged to play along by betting on which contestants will win and playing along with a Banzai online game.

In addition to building up the Banzai fanbase via the website, E4 has developed a Banzai Wap game and an enhanced TV product which it says will work in a similar way to Sky Sports Active, with viewers able to bet on the outcome of the show using their remote controls. At the moment, however, this service is only available on ONdigital, although Anson anticipates that a version will soon be available on Sky Digital.

"We're taking very small steps with interactive TV because it's expensive but we do want to be able to allow TV viewers to play along with the gameshows. Big Brother 2 will have a significant deal of interactive TV built around it," says Anson. The web plans for Big Brother 2 are being kept under wraps but given Channel 4's new remit to make everything cross-media, the web channel is going to be more involving this time around with games and more accessible webcams high on the agenda.

The cross-media strategy is also being funnelled into Channel 4's FilmFour website, FilmFour.com, which is gearing up for a relaunch in March and working towards screening pay-per-view films.

Another part of the strategy is to make investments in other websites where the objectives fit in with those of Channel 4. Its first was in Fingertips, a soon-to-launch personalised online entertainment tool two years in the making. Channel 4 is believed to have invested some £1.5m in Fingertips, which was set up by the former BMP interactive specialists Ross Sleight and Robert Fields. The plan is to tie Fingertips.co.uk very heavily into E4.com. "Fingertips was perfect for our needs," says Anson. "It's all about planning entertainment needs and social lives and because of the heavy emphasis on personalisation it will allow us to get very close to consumers."

Channel 4's other dot.com investment to date has been in Popworld, the music portal co-founded by the ex-Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller. As part of the Popworld deal, a Popworld-branded daily TV show is being screened on E4, and a 60-minute version is to be broadcast on Channel 4's Sunday morning teen show T4. The Channel 4/Popworld partnership also encompasses a co-branded microsite on E4.com that will be linked to the Popworld portal.

The clear message is that E4.com is not just going to be a support vehicle for the TV channel. "While we do want to support the channel, we want to do it in an innovative way. E4 is a multi-platform brand that we're taking on the internet in a way that mirrors the TV content but is uniquely focused on interactivity," says Anson. "We'll always have something new and fresh every day and when we start marketing the site around the full launch, we'll be encouraging people to come and visit us for 10 minutes every day - it's healthier than taking a fag break."

Between now and March, E4.com marketing will be confined to the URL appearing on trailers and at the end of shows but over time it will be mentioned in programming and promoted to the wider audience of Friday night Channel 4 viewers.

Can Channel 4 pull off a coup and change the way we use the internet? Zwillenberg thinks so: "E4.com has a chance to succeed where others have failed. It has distribution, marketing and a broadcast partner to go along with creation, production and sales - something no other attempt at broadband entertainment has had."

Considering Channel 4's reputation for cutting edge TV, the odds are stacked in E4.com's favour. With broadband slowly seeping into the UK, Channel 4 has dropped a firm anchor into the turbulent waters of new media that, all being well, should give it a market leading position whenever the storm calms.

fields.headline: Nuclear sub to leave Gibraltar
fields.trailText: Britain expects repairs on a nuclear-powered submarine docked in Gibraltar to be completed by the end of March and that the vessel will leave "soon thereafter", a Ministry of Defence spokeswoman, Sarah Haywood, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain expects repairs on a nuclear-powered submarine docked in Gibraltar to be completed by the end of March and that the vessel will leave "soon thereafter", a Ministry of Defence spokeswoman, Sarah Haywood, said yesterday.

The Spanish daily El Pais reported yesterday that Britain had secretly agreed with Spain that it will remove the HMS Tireless from Gibraltar by May 19.

The submarine docked there nine months ago after a crack was found in its cooling system, prompting widespread protests in the colony.

The Royal Navy plans to tow the submarine to Britain if it cannot be repaired by the May 19 deadline. However, Ms Haywood told El Pais that the navy is sure the submarine will be repaired by the end of March.

fields.headline: BBC to launch Bill and Ben magazine
fields.trailText: 10.45am: BBC Worldwide is to launch a spin-off magazine to accompany the return of Bill and Ben, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide is to launch a spin-off magazine to accompany the return of the popular children's TV series.

Bill and Ben magazine, which launches on February 19, will be aimed at three to five-year-olds.

The magazine is the latest in a line of magazine spin-offs from popular BBC television brands such as Teletubbies, Tweenies and Bob the Builder.

BBC Worldwide - the BBC's commercial arm - is expected to mine a rich seam with Bill and Ben merchandise.

Merchandising from successful properties such as Bob the Builder and the Tweenies has already helped the corporation to sales of £20m over Christmas.

Bill and Ben magazine will have an initial print run of 100,000, and will be priced at £1.35 per issue.

webTitle: Leaked Labour memo puts reporters in their place

fields.headline: Reporters put in their place
fields.standfirst:
Leaked memo gives Labour assessment of political writers

MediaGuardian.co.uk
See the original Labour memo here
fields.trailText:
A leaked memo gives Labour assessment of political writers, report Seumas Milne and Kevin Maguire.
The dossier on 28 of Fleet Street's political journalists
See the original Labour memo here
fields.body:
Leaked official documents are usually expected to embarrass ministers or civil servants, but now the journalists who write about them have themselves become the subject of a government leak.

A cabinet office memo detailing the supposed connections and political leanings of 28 political reporters and commentators, which has been passed to the Guardian, highlights the increasingly ambitious scope of Tony Blair's media management operation.

The government briefing paper - which also gives a sometimes waspish assessment of the journalists' prospects, influence and reliability - was drafted by Downing Street staff in political charge of the Cabinet Office-based media monitoring unit.

The unit, which was in effect transferred to the government from Labour's Millbank headquarters after the 1997 general election, provides round-the-clock briefings on the press and broadcast media to ministers, including Mr Blair.

The leaked memo on daily newspaper journalists is understood to have been drawn up by Carl Shoben and Chris McShane - who both worked at Millbank and are now No 10 political advisers attached to the unit - mainly to guide civil servants preparing daily media briefings.

Assessments in the memo vary from the unexceptionable to the questionable, with journalists' politics carefully graded from left to right.

Among those mentioned in the leaked briefing, Paul Routledge of the Daily Mirror is described as "influential in the sense that his columns appear in prominent placing in the Mirror each day" and "formerly close to Scargill, but now on the traditional Old Labour right".

The Guardian's Hugo Young is said to be "obsessed with Europe and freedom of information, but considered very influential among Labour-voting 'chattering classes'."

"Rightwing commentator" Simon Heffer of the Daily Mail should always be included in briefings because he is "taken more seriously than likes of Peter Hitchens".

fields.headline: Orange to float at £41bn
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Orange has scaled down the valuation of its share offering in the face of mounting market jitters, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange has scaled down the valuation of its share offering in the face of mounting market jitters about the health of the wireless sector.

The France Telecom-owned company made the move after fund managers said they would not pay top-whack for the stock, reflecting doubts over the welfare of indebted telecoms operators.

Orange will float with a price tag of up to £41bn, 20% below analysts' expectations and more than 50% below its previous valuation of £95bn.

Up to 15% of the company's shares will be offered to the market, priced between 732p and 860p.

France Telecom is hoping that the generous discount will be enough to tempt investors back into a battered telecoms sector that has lost 50% of its value in 10 months.

Even Orange's rivals are wishing the company well, as the likes of BT, Deutsche Telekom and Dutch operator KPN have similar offerings lined up.

They plan to float their wireless subsidiaries before the end of the year and are depending on Orange to soften up market sentiment.

However, investors will be aware that mobile phone operators must attempt stock market listings in order to raise the cash to finance the roll-out of their networks. This will allow them to have a far stronger say in the price of the flotations.

European telecoms companies are also desperate for cash to pay off debts built up through acquiring next-generation mobile phone licences.

Last year, the sector borrowed a mammoth £290bn from banks, with £167bn due for repayment over the next 12 months.

Orange operates in 19 countries with a customer base of around 30m, and will use the proceeds of the flotation to expand its geographical reach to 50 countries by 2005.

The UK is by far its most promising market with 9.8m customers.

France Telecom bought Orange from arch-rival Vodafone for £25bn last year and will list the company on the Paris and London stock exchanges.

webTitle: NHS to have its own Big Issue

fields.headline: NHS to have its own Big Issue
fields.trailText: Britain's hospitals are turning to Big Issue-style magazine-sellers to raise cash. Anthony Browne reports
fields.body:
Britain's hospitals are turning to Big Issue-style magazine-sellers to raise cash.

Volunteers will tour hospital wards and waiting areas to sell a new magazine to patients and visitors. A portion of the sale price will be ploughed back into the health service.

Feelgood Magazine will be launched this week in 200 hospitals across the country. For every £1 copy sold, 40 pence will go to the local hospital. It runs on the same principle as the Big Issue, which the homeless sell to earn money.

Sales of the first edition are expected to be 150,000, but its founding editor, Dr Liz Wilkinson, hopes it will rise to a million copies a month, generating around £5m a year for the NHS.

The magazine will contain "optimistic" health stories, ensuring it does not frighten patients or become a "hypochondriacs gazette". It is aimed at answering questions that patients may not have time to ask a doctor.

Dr Wilkinson, a surgeon at Moorfields Eye Hospital, denied it was a sign of desperation: "Fundraising is part of the way the NHS is run. If we can do as good a job as the Big Issue, we'll be very happy." The League of Friends - an umbrella group for hospital volunteers - already raises £30m for the NHS.

Dr Wilkinson insists that sick patients won't feel under pressure to buy the magazine. It won't be sold in intensive care wards.

A Department of Health spokeswoman insisted money raised would be in addition to government funding.

The magazine will contain "optimistic" health stories, ensuring it does not frighten patients or become a "hypochondriacs gazette". It is aimed at answering questions that patients may not have time to ask a doctor. Dr Wilkinson, a surgeon at Moorfields Eye Hospital, denied it was a sign of desperation: "Fundraising is part of the way the NHS is run. If we can do as good a job as the Big Issue, we'll be very happy." The League of Friends - an umbrella group for hospital volunteers - already raises £30m for the NHS. Dr Wilkinson insists that sick patients won't feel under pressure to buy the magazine. It won't be sold in intensive care wards. A Department of Health spokeswoman insisted money raised would be in addition to government funding.

webTitle: What are you like: Couch potatoes

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: Couch potatoes
fields.trailText: Couch potatoes, compiled by Alastair Ray.
fields.body:
There are just under 1.5m couch potatoes, a group of inactive Britons who watch at least four hours of TV a day, and they are thrilled by the prospect of more TV channels. They are likely to be aged between 35 and 54; 55% of them are women and they loathe housework.

What do they watch? Couch potatoes favour shows such as Trisha, Supermarket Sweep and This Morning. At night, soaps, gameshows and entertainment series such as You've Been Framed are picks of the day. Although 52% of them think ITV is better than it was last year, they're not taking any chances and have all signed up to satellite or cable.

Are they aware of their addiction? "I try not to watch too much TV but I just find myself getting into the different shows," confesses one TV addict.

Advertising: 42% of this group find the ads entertaining and in fact 61% of them would like the BBC to show ads so they would not have to pay the licence fee. They are often tempted by what they see advertised and think that TV advertising is interesting.

Other media? Unsurprisingly, the top read for this group is TV guides. Couch Potatoes are more likely to be tabloid than broadsheet readers with 35% of them taking the Sun.

Do they get out much? Not really, they rarely leave the local area and only go to the cinema once in a blue moon, preferring to wait for films to come out on video or multichannel TV.

Other ways to identify a couch potato: "We go to the same place in Spain every summer - it's got all the things we need" and "I just don't really have the time for technology" are classic couch potato sayings.

THE GUARDIAN

The Labour party has compiled an assessment of 28 political reporters and commentators. P1
The government may let religious sects own television broadcast licences. P7
Text messaging is destroying literacy, according to one academic. P7

MEDIA GUARDIAN
The Labour party's sensational dossier on political hacks reveals that Andrew Grice of The Independent is "perhaps a little on the wane now" and lists the influence, reliability and political leanings of 27 others. P2-3
BBC director-general Greg Dyke brushes off concerns over the News At Ten move: "Any change at the BBC brings you flak, it always has done." P4-5
Is Express owner Richard Desmond letting Rosie Boycott stay on as editor just to avoid the competition commission? P7

Although the iron curtain has been lifted, broadcasting freedom is still under threat in the ex-communist bloc. P10

Channel 4 slates Tory privatisation plans as "unthinking vandalism". P6
Online networking firm First Tuesday is on the verge of collapse. P8
Hollywood screenwriters hold last-minute talks to prevent strike. P13
Mobile phone operator Orange expected to scale down flotation price. P15
Nigel Lythgoe, head of comedy and entertainment at LWT, says Popstars will not take reality TV too far. Monday Review P1
First Tuesday founder Julie Meyer says she has learnt her lessons. P9

Opposition leaders William Hague and Charles Kennedy have signed up to an alternative, Blair-free, televised debate. P8
Matt Beaumont, a former advertising copywriter, has been nominated for the WH Smith Book Award. P9
Italian media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi takes the risk of aligning himself with the heirs of a disgraced former prime minister in his quest for political power. P15
Collectibles trading house Icollector.com teams up with online auctioneer eBay. P23
Richard Branson's V2 record label signs digital distribution deal with Tornado Group. P23

Guy Ritchie film Snatch is an unlikely hit in the US. P3
Lastminute.com founder Martha Lane Fox angrily denies that she was spotted buying plane tickets at a rival travel agent. P20
German media company EMTV could be sued after a deal involving shares in formula one's holding company went badly wrong. P25

FINANCIAL TIMES

Britain chosen as best European country to set up an e-business. P2
European dot.coms are taking a massive risk by ignoring legal risk management. P14
Microsoft to reveal $200m TV advertising campaign. P27
US media baron Ted Turner comes to rescue of Russian media giant Media-Most. P32

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

PC industry in Europe shows an alarming slump. P1
Interactive channel Two Way TV to cut workforce by 25%. P4
Court gives stay of execution to Letsbuyit. P4
Record industry bosses are concerned that a new EU copyright directive will legalise internet piracy. P27
Advert producer Regina Ebel works flat-out to ensure the Super Bowl adverts are ready before Sunday. P29
US regulators take first steps towards guidelines for interactive-television technologies. P29

DAILY MAIL

The UK couple in the internet twins controversy blame the world's media for all their problems. P7
The departed Auberon Waugh is described as "wiser and more humane" than Guardian writer and arch-critic Polly Toynbee. P15
The BBC is set to link up with pay-TV sports channel Premium TV. P83

DAILY EXPRESS

An Express editorial slates the advent of two News at Tens. P12
In the battle of the bongs, the Express examines whether ITN or BBC will come out on top in the clash of the News at Tens. P13
Matthew Price argues that children should be exposed to violent TV news because they should "understand the world we live in". P14
The building of mobile phone masts could be banned in the UK, due to safety fears. P29
Steve Martin has quit as PR head of sports giant Adidas. P79

THE SUN

Market trader Eddie Skinner and his daughter Kerry have been axed from EastEnders. P3
Peter Sissons and Sir Trevor McDonald are sized up in the News at Ten face-off. P6
The Sun prints praise rival papers for its libel appeal victory against Bruce Grobbelaar. P8
Doug Digby's final moments in the Grimleys are not for the faint hearted, after he gets on the wrong end of a javelin. P15
Telly ads for thrash metal dandies Limp Bizkit are banned before 7.30pm. P19 Louis Theroux signs £500,000 deal with the BBC. P22
Popstars reject Claire Freeland slates the show. P22-23

THE MIRROR

Coronation Street mum Susan Baldwin is to be killed off in a horror crash. P7
The winners of Popstars have been forced into hiding because the location of their safe house has been revealed. P11
The Mirror heralds the return of the News at Ten. P15
Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? winners describe how they spent their prize money. P22-23

DAILY STAR

Popstars contestant Susan Robinson slams Nigel Lythgoe for getting her thrown off the show. P5
Mike Baldwin and Ken Barlow will come to blows again at the funeral of Coronation Street mum Susan Baldwin. P13

AND FINALLY...

Has Chris Evans dumped Billie Piper? Or are they really back together again after a tumultuous weekend? Will we ever care? The Sun P11. The Mirror P19. DAILY STAR P10

webTitle: Broadcasting freedom is under threat in the ex-communist bloc

fields.headline: The state they're in
fields.standfirst: Broadcasting freedom is under threat in the ex-communist bloc, says Ian Traynor.
fields.trailText: Broadcasting freedom is under threat in the ex-communist bloc, says Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
From a luxury villa on the Costa Del Sol to the vast, cold expanse of Prague's Wenceslas Square, a vital battle is being joined for control of television and freedom of expression across the ex-communist bloc. In scenes reminiscent of the 1989 Velvet Revolution that toppled the communists, tens of thousands of Czechs have been marching and protesting for a month to save national television from the politicians they say have betrayed the hopes and the legacy of 1989.

By contrast, President Vladimir Putin of Russia has spent much of his first year in office trying to secure as much television power and influence as he can. He has just scored a coup with the submission of Boris Berezovsky, the exiled media magnate, to his will.

In a typically Russian insider deal, Berezovsky says he is to surrender his 49% stake in Russia's first television channel to the Kremlin via a billionaire middleman, Roman Abramovich, who by way of payback gets to tighten his grip on Russia's lucrative oil industry.

The contrast between Moscow and Prague is great, although the issues and liberties at stake are identical. Putin, who last week told Russian journalists that reports of the death of the free press in Russia are exaggerated, is steadily establishing control of all the key national television networks, whereas in Prague people power has put the politicians on the defensive and forced the resignation of Jiri Hodac, the controversial director of Czech state TV.

In the south of Spain, meanwhile, Vladimir Gusinsky sits under house arrest amid the opulence of his holiday villa, a victim of a Kremlin-inspired hounding, while his vast Russian media empire, including the country's best and biggest private TV channel, NTV, comes under pressure to toe the Kremlin line.

Gusinsky's Media-Most offices in Moscow were raided for the umpteenth time last week, his Moscow house was seized, and the Kremlin gave the thumbs down to overtures from the billionaire CNN founder, Ted Turner, to buy a quarter of NTV.

A decade after the great democratic upheavals that banished communism and dictatorship, television has become the big battleground in the new democracies."All across eastern and central Europe the political parties are trying to control national television. Then there are the transnational corporations moving into the media looking for profits," says Dusan Reljic, a Serbian media researcher at the European Institute for the Media in Berlin. "The victims in this contest are the viewers."

Hodac, a former head of the BBC's Czech service, is closely identified with Vaclav Klaus, the rightwing former prime minister who hopes to succeed Vaclav Havel as president next year. His appointment - outrageously political, say the critics - sparked a mutiny within state TV and the protests swiftly and surprisingly spread to the streets of Prague and other Czech cities.

But in Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia, too, the powerful are nervously following the drama in Prague and wondering if they are next.

President Rudolf Schuster in Slovakia, for example, has been complaining that state television pays insufficient attention to his activities and affords him less airtime than is his due. He is now likely to muffle his complaints for the time being.

In Poland, too, where in last year's presidential elections state TV was widely seen to have favoured the victorious incumbent, Alexander Kwasniewski, there are growing calls for changes to the way political appointments to television boards are made.

And in Belgrade, where tight control of national television was a key to the longevity of the Milosevic regime, it is not surprising that the state TV building was among the prime targets in last October's democratic insurrection in Serbia. Storming television headquarters in Belgrade was at least as important as capturing the parliament.

Since October, Serbian state TV has simply switched sides, indulging in hagiography of the new rulers and exasperating Belgrade's independent journalists.

Across the region, the political elites see control of TV as the big prize. TV executives, meanwhile, curry favour with governments to ensure access to scarce resources and subsidies in an industry where insufficient advertising revenue is generated to stay afloat.

"The television people are smarter than the politicians," says Alexei Pankin, a Moscow media analyst. "And they have been very successful in selling themselves as indispensable to the politicians."

In Russia, TV can make or break presidents and Putin's spin doctors know that. The two big channels, ORT controlled by Berezovsky and Gusinsky's NTV, joined forces in 1996 to win Boris Yeltsin a second term against the odds.

This blatant violation of the rules of fair play and political neutrality was justified by claims of the urgent necessity of heading off a return to communism in Russia. In 1999, ORT helped hugely in Putin's ascent to power, denouncing his rivals as gays, murderers or crooks.

Since securing the presidency in March last year, Putin has made it a priority to control all national TV. ORT is the first public channel and Berezovsky has just conceded defeat in his ostensible attempt to keep it free and independent. Gusinsky faces embezzlement charges if he is extradited back to Russia.

The Kremlin now appears to be trying to sabotage efforts to sell a quarter of NTV, the second channel in terms of range and viewers, to Ted Turner. The second state channel, RTR, is already a mouthpiece for Putin. "National television in Russia is always a political project," says Pankin. "And what we're now getting is presidential TV."

There is no debate in Moscow - in contrast to Prague, Warsaw or Budapest - about the values and practices of public service broadcasting. If and when Putin gets his people in control at ORT and NTV, Red Square will not witness the events that have been seen in Wenceslas Square.

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: Yes, even we journalists are bored by the dot.com doom and gloom. The solution? Dust the mothballs off dot.com femme fatale Martha Lane Fox, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
 Yes, even we journalists are now bored senseless by all the dot.com doom and gloom. The solution? Dust the mothballs off dot.com femme fatale Martha Lane Fox. The Independent started the ball rolling by a spurious story about MLF buying back shares from friends and family - furiously denied by Martha of course, who for all her faults isn't quite daft enough to lose £3 per share bought back. Next, a Business365 survey stunned the nation by touting MLF as Britain's most overrated businessperson. Surely not. But top marks for MLF story of the week goes to Silicon.com for its astute stalkers, sorry reporters, supposedly spotting her buying a long-haul flight from Trailfinders. Does her loyalty to her own company know no bounds?

 It's official. The days of First Tuesday are over. After more media hype than Billie Piper's phantom baby, venture capitalists all over the world must be breathing sighs of relief, knowing that they no longer have to schlep along to over-crowded rooms and spend the evenings being stalked by obsequious internet liggers. Problems at parent company Yazam and a lack of interest in VC matchmaking (wonder why) were the final deathknell of First Tuesday. Yazam must be kicking itself for not anticipating the big crash and shelling out £2m to buy the firm in the summer, especially since its founders sensed it was reaching burn-out and quickly scarpered after pocketing the cash.

 Internet people work too hard. Fact. Catch some of them out of work though and you'd be forgiven for finding them a little bit quirky with perhaps some unusual interests. Take Julie Meyer, erstwhile golden girl of First Tuesday, for example. A few months back Ms Meyer admitted in our My New Media column that she hasn't watched TV since she was 12 and spends 15 hours a day on the web. If that's not bizarre enough, she is now gunning for a reputation as an oddball. Diligent scanners of the latest version of Who's Who will already have seen Meyer's debut in lights, but for those that haven't here are the recreations she lists: "Pastis and Amaretto, taking weekend trips and sleeping late, genealogy, carrying on family traditions, finding John Galt." Good luck Julie - he's been dead for 162 years.

 By the time this diary is printed, Letsbuyit.com's fate will have been decided. The ill-fated group-buying website, always an accident waiting to happen, has kept everyone amused during the subdued start to the year. It's the curse of the Swedish dot.coms - far too much blond over-ambition and folly. Letsbuyit.com tried to protect itself, threw in the towel, then came back with the rather bizarre statement that it still had hope. Although trading has been suspended for weeks, the website still bizarrely says there are 142 active co-buys. As if.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com amy.vickers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: United Media to ditch remaining consumer interests
fields.trailText: 8.30am: United Business Media is on the verge of selling off its last consumer operations, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The City is gearing up for a wave of disposals from United Business Media, as Lord Hollick's group turns its back on the consumer market.

United is set for a final shake-out of its consumer businesses, which include Exchange & Mart and a 35% stake in Channel 5, in order to focus on becoming a business information company.

Analysts said United had started to market the assets for a sale that would boost the group's coffers ahead of next month's mammoth £1.25bn share buyback.

The shareholder windfall is financed by Granada Media's £1.75bn acquisition of United's ITV franchises last summer.

"Before Christmas, United said it had not actively marketed the consumer assets. But United admitted it was getting the process under way, and the disposals should start happening now," said one analyst.

The £4.2bn group has drastically altered its portfolio over the past year, with the sale of the Express newspapers to Richard Desmond and the Miller Freeman titles to VNU.

In December, it dumped its old name United News & Media.

"There is definitely a clearing of the decks in its consumer operations. United does not want be a mile wide and an inch deep," said Paul Richards, media analyst at West LB Panmure.

United is also under pressure to sell its consumer operations in order to fend off potential predators over the next few months.

"United has shrunk and, if the hi-tech market falls through the floor and stocks are hit, it could look like a target," said Nicola Stewart, head media analyst at Commerzbank.

The assets are expected to fetch between £500m and £750m for the group, although sources close to United say its 35% stake in Channel 5 is safe for the time being.

"United is not close to selling its stake. It has no desire to do so and is under no pressure," said one source.

However, a recent courtroom clash between United and RTL, Channel 5's owner, over a £10m film deal is being widely interpreted as a prelude to a drawn-out haggling process.

It is thought United will sit tight until RTL makes a sizeable offer for the stake.

United intended to sell its 20% holding in the ITN news service through a flotation, although plans for a share issue have now been put on hold.

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Turpin
fields.trailText: By Jonathan Turpin, CEO of Fish4.co.uk.
fields.body:
Favourite sites?

bbr.com (Berry Brothers & Rudd). It's a friendly and sophisticated site which allows you to build and maintain an online wine cellar. I can update my stock and organise a delivery whenever I want. It's a very secure way to collect and store wine.

Last online purchase?

A weekend skiing break. Being able to put together a holiday package from the net was great.

Most recent technological faux pas?

My Wap phone has been the most disappointing piece of technology. It's very big, people stare at it, and it's not very useful.

Main news source on the web?

BBC Online and CNN, but I only check the web for breaking news.

Most persistent spam emailer?

I've somehow managed to avoid being on any spam lists.

Time spent on the web?

I spent 12 hours over two days looking for a holiday, but otherwise it's about half an hour a day at work.

Next boo.com?

Customer service is the biggest factor in deciding who remains. My bete noire at the moment is iglu.com. I tried to book a skiing trip with them but I couldn't do it online. I phoned, had to leave a message and they never called me back. If you don't get an instant response, you'll click off and go somewhere else.

Least useful site on the web?

waitallday.com It's a wonderful misuse of a server. People sit there all day waiting to be connected to something and don't realise it's a spoof.

Most useful site?

Probably Railtrack. It's the only efficient part of it. It's easy to find out travel information and is a huge timesaver.

Which screensaver do you use?

I don't use one and it's struck me that our company should have one for security.

Most irritating thing about the web?

The lack of good advice. In other media there's a lot more guidance and judgment. You're on your own with the web and sometimes you need expert advice. For example, when I wanted to book a skiing holiday, I could have saved so much time if the information I needed about hotels and flights was compiled on one "best of" page. It would have saved so much time rather than checking out individual sites.

Do you bother with old media?

Yes, particularly for news. I like snuggling up on the sofa with a newspaper. It's important to have something tangible, especially if you're working online.

 Jonathan Turpin is the CEO of Fish4.co.uk

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Paul Tonkinson
fields.trailText: By Paul Tonkinson, who takes over today as presenter of Channel 4's Big Breakfast.
fields.body:
Newspapers:
I've always bought the Guardian and I get the Mirror in the week for the sport. I'm on the cusp between the Observer and the Sunday Times, but the Observer has better writers, and the Sunday Times has too many supplements.

Magazines:
I have to read Heat every week. I love American magazines such as Talk, Vanity Fair, GQ and Esquire. The writing is superb and the celebrity profiles are great.

Television:
I've been left a bit bereft of choice now that The Sopranos, The Royle Family and Cold Feet have all gone. I watch Paramount comedy channel and Nick Jr with my kids. I'm enjoying Peter Kay's new series.

Books:
I'm interested in eastern spirituality and am reading Heart of Tibetan Buddhism by a modern Buddhist master (Osho). I also like American fiction writers like Don DeLillo. I loved Will Self's The Sweet Smell of Psychosis and always read him if I want to learn new words.

Adverts:
I like the Bacardi Breezer advert with the dancing ladies and a dancing cat. I'm interested when comics do adverts: Alan Davies stayed on the right side with Abbey National but Neil Morrissey doing Homebase was a bit grim. I once did a radio voiceover for Blockbusters. That was OK because I was disguised.

Radio:
Paul Ross on London Live does a nice wake-up-and-smell-the-coffee morning show. Sara Cox has real warmth and I like Chris Moyles. I sometimes tune into Classic FM's Smooth Classics At Seven on the way to a gig, but on the way home, Freak FM is better for my adrenaline.

Films:
I saw The Perfect Storm four times. I'm a big Michael Douglas fan and really enjoyed Wonderboys. I liked Billy Elliot, but it wasn't the classic everyone wanted it to be.
New Media:
I bought a computer three years ago and have just taken it out of the box. I'm going to get an email address and have resolved to confront my technophobia.

 Paul Tonkinson takes over today as presenter of Channel 4's Big Breakfast.
