webTitle: The BBC view of the ITV return to News At Ten

fields.headline: Clash at Ten
fields.standfirst: As ITV bids farewell to its shortlived Nightly News and returns to its old 10pm news slot, newscasters Dermot Murnaghan of ITV and Peter Sissons of BBC1 give their views.
fields.trailText: As ITV bids farewell to its shortlived Nightly News and returns to its old 10pm news slot, newscasters Dermot Murnaghan of ITV and Peter Sissons of BBC1 give their views.
fields.body:
Dermot Murnaghan

In its final days before it headed off to the big newsroom in the sky, it is ironic that the ITV Nightly News performed the very role the politicians who so hated it expected. Namely we carried details of some very important parliamentary proceedings that no other bulletin last Wednesday was able to cover - the result of the bitter and contentious hunting debate in the House of Commons.

And the reason we were able to carry the outcome was not due to the failings of our rivals, but simply because we were on at 11pm and the vote didn't finish until 10.45pm. Nearly 3.5m people (25.7% of the available audience) were kept informed about the functioning of our democracy. The BBC's News at Ten O'Clock was only able to report some of the earlier debate.

And that more or less sums up the frustration I feel about the whole Nightly News saga. In the time that I've presented the programme, there seems to have been more column inches dedicated to who's watching and who isn't - even the prime minister admitted to being tucked up in bed before the Nightly News.

The press interest was so intense that I actually found myself on the front page of the Mirror as part of its campaign to have News at Ten reinstated. This led to one of the most surreal events of my career, when I had to feature the article as part of the programme's nightly newspaper review. But despite an obsessive press campaign, the programme was not a failure - either in its journalism or ratings.

In the short 22-month life of the Nightly we were able to break several stories at 11 o'clock, including Michael Portillo's admission of homosexual experiences, developments from the Kosovo conflict and Bill Clinton's impeachment. And it achieved a high water mark of more than 6m viewers (admittedly with a following wind from Who Wants to be a Millionaire?), but it also broke 5m on half a dozen occasions. It's overall average was 3.5m. And bear in mind that the BBC's News at Ten O'Clock got 3.4m last Monday.

Now I can't say, personally, that I'm not delighted to be moving to tea-time news and rediscovering my family and social life. And at 30 minutes long, The Evening News will still be ITV's biggest primetime news bulletin. I'm also looking forward to another change - a two- presenter format with Mary Nightingale.

But I loved presenting the Nightly News (it earned me the Newscaster of the Year award for 2000) and I won't see it die without it being given its due.

Perhaps the oddest element of the whole saga was that I genuinely knew that it would happen this way.

The extreme case of deja vu that I'm suffering from is all down to a conversation I had at the end of 1998. Shortly after the decision had been taken to kill off News at Ten, a senior television executive described to me the axeing of a country's flagship ten o'clock news show. After being pulled from the primetime slot, the programme was exiled to the outer reaches of the schedule at 11pm. This was followed fairly rapidly by a decline in news audiences, outcry from politicians of all persuasions - and soon after that the reinstatement of the programme, with much trumpeting about "heritage" and "brands". The country in question? Canada.

But it's at this point that the parallels between our experience and Canada's begin to unwind.

Because in homes with only four or five terrestrial channels - the majority - there will now be two news programmes at 10 o'clock.

Which is surely not the outcome the politicians who lambasted ITV, and its regulator who ordered News At Ten's reinstatement, had in mind.

As far as I can see, the ball is back in the BBC's court - if it, too, wants the biggest shop window for its journalistic efforts, what is it doing squatting at 10 o'clock which the majority of the nation feel belongs to Trevor McDonald and News at Ten?

Oh, and one footnote - some other losers in this whole affair. Those 3.5m viewers who regularly tuned in to the 11pm Nightly News. Somebody was watching, somebody liked it, some may even miss it. Watch this space for the "Bring Back News at 11 lobby". But I would say that wouldn't I?

Peter Sissons

In the next few weeks, you will get a lot of spin from ITV about the return of its news to 10pm. But let's get one thing straight: it's not the return of News at Ten. That once-great programme was killed off for commercial reasons - an act described by my first editor at ITN, Sir Geoffrey Cox, as a "betrayal of the public interest by the people appointed to safeguard that interest".

ITV made a lot of money from the move, but it still had a political problem. Politicians liked News at Ten, and liked seeing themselves on it. Most of the public were opposed to the change. And the regulator, the ITC, was unhappy at charges that it had betrayed its obligation to insist on a substantial news programme on ITV in prime viewing time.

The relatively small audiences for the 11pm Nightly News - sometimes a third of those for the old News at Ten - added to the embarrassment. And claims by the ITC that audiences for news on ITV would improve overall were shown to be misjudged. When they reviewed the changes, something had to be done. The result was the birth of the compromise already dubbed "News at When?"

In effect, ITV can now cherrypick the 10pm slot with a moveable news bulletin, tailored in timing and length to the requirements, not of the viewer, but the advertisers. That's not surprising. In ITV, the level of investment in all programmes is a factor of advertising revenue. But it cannot be described as a cast-iron commitment to quality news in prime time.

One of the strange things is ITV's apparent resentment of the BBC grabbing the 10pm slot. On the News at Ten O'Clock, we've found ourselves at the centre of the ratings war, with ITV throwing everything at us. We've taken some big hits, but not many. And despite the onslaught from some of ITV's biggest ratings-pullers, we've increased the news audience.

Since the launch of the Ten on October 16, the average audience is 5.2m viewers, compared with 5.1m for the old Nine O'Clock News. When you consider that everything has been thrown at us, it's an excellent start. On the big stories - for example, 7.2m during November's floods - the nation turns to the BBC, as ever, in droves.

Make no mistake; the BBC is in this for the long haul. As a former ITN man, I always believed 10pm was a better time for news, and that view is now generally accepted at the BBC. Ten o'clock is also now seen as a better news time for BBC1 as a whole. The channel is investing heavily in new drama and comedy, which can be launched more effectively at 9pm than at 9.30pm.

As for the team that produces the BBC's 10 O'Clock news, we want to be judged, above all, on the quality of the programme. Judge us on the ratings, by all means, but over two years, not two weeks. However snazzy the presentation, news programmes stand or fall on the reporting team, and their production back-up. At BBC News, with more correspondents in more bureaux around the world than any other broadcasting organisation, we draw on an award-winning team of the most experienced TV journalists. It is a cutting edge that cannot be matched.

BBC News has always welcomed competition, and has no fear of going head-to-head with ITN. We don't believe the clash will necessarily be in the interests of viewers, but it's ITV that has created the situation - and which has muddied the waters by its bizarre "now you see it, now you don't" attitude to its own flagship news programme. But the BBC News at Ten O'Clock will be there, six nights a week, on the button. And that's something you can rely on.

And the winning channel is...
Maggie Brown

Who will win most viewers? In the short term, the answer is ITV. That's down to "inheritance" - about 80% of news viewers have watched the preceding programme on the same channel, and ITV's schedule is stuffed with hits. Since the BBC moved its news last October, BBC1 has only won nine 9-10pm slots.

And ITV has opened 2001 very confidently, with a new Touch of Frost two-parter and Caroline Quentin in The Innocent destroying the BBC's offerings. Even the normally critical Zenith Media concedes its line-up is "looking pretty good" - although the jury is out on Popstars. To reduce zapping, the network is revolutionising presentation by rolling programmes together. Last week it staged a presentation to tell advertisers that it will target BBC1 this year, aiming to improve on the 7% leadin peak-time it already enjoys.

The balance of power may start changing in the autumn as Greg Dyke's millions flow into BBC1 programming, funding a fourth episode of EastEnders and reviving other popular drama and comedy. But senior BBC executives admit this spring will be difficult.

Averaging 5.2m, audiences for BBC's 10pm news were initially close to those for the old 9pm bulletin. But ratings have deteriorated this month in the face of a fired-up ITV: for nine nights in a row, they have been below 5m.

Interestingly, ITV network centre sources now concede that viewers missed News at Ten and that factual series such as World War Two in Colour will do even better later, as viewers who might be tempted to switch to the BBC for a 10pm news fix will stay with ITV. Remember, ITV news is shorter, running only until 10.20pm, and has no central ad break.

As for Chris Smith's warning to the BBC about a significant reduction in audiences for news as a result of the simultaneous bulletins, the 10pm head-to-head certainly creates an opportunity for Channel 4, Channel 5 and satellite stations to lure viewers with entertainment and movies. But calculating how much any loss is down to the clash - rather than a general decline in news audiences, and/or what Greg Dyke calls the current lack of "real news" - may be hard to calculate.

At 10pm there are 23m people watching TV on average, according to Zenith Media, falling to 19.3m by 10.30pm, while by 11pm that is cut to 12m. The BBC News at Ten O'Clock and ITV's Nightly News pulled around 8m viewers during the autumn. This compares to the 10-11m who watched the BBC Nine and former News at Ten two years ago. No one knows how viewers will behave when forced to choose between news and news on the main networks.

The BBC news machine is vaster than ITN's. But the ITV news provider will compete ferociously. It is desperate to succeed against the BBC: even the bongs are coming back, alongside Sir Trevor McDonald, signed for another four years. Underlying ITN's determination is the fact that ITV is set to renegotiate its news supply contract early (Sky News is hovering once again as a potential replacement), while ITV bosses feel deep unease over the costs and distractions of ITN 24 hour News, which is trailing far behind Sky News and News 24.

One final point: the outburst of public disapproval over the axeing of the original News at Ten - including a campaign in The Mirror - was not matched by similar lamentations about the abolition of the BBC's Nine O'Clock News. That shows which side engaged hearts and minds.

To reduce zapping, the network is revolutionising presentation by rolling programmes together. Last week it staged a presentation to tell advertisers that it will target BBC1 this year, aiming to improve on the 7% leadin peak-time it already enjoys. The balance of power may start changing in the autumn as Greg Dyke's millions flow into BBC1 programming, funding a fourth episode of EastEnders and reviving other popular drama and comedy. But senior BBC executives admit this spring will be difficult. Averaging 5.2m, audiences for BBC's 10pm news were initially close to those for the old 9pm bulletin. But ratings have deteriorated this month in the face of a fired-up ITV: for nine nights in a row, they have been below 5m. Interestingly, ITV network centre sources now concede that viewers missed News at Ten and that factual series such as World War Two in Colour will do even better later, as viewers who might be tempted to switch to the BBC for a 10pm news fix will stay with ITV. Remember, ITV news is shorter, running only until 10.20pm, and has no central ad break. As for Chris Smith's warning to the BBC about a significant reduction in audiences for news as a result of the simultaneous bulletins, the 10pm head-to-head certainly creates an opportunity for Channel 4, Channel 5 and satellite stations to lure viewers with entertainment and movies. But calculating how much any loss is down to the clash - rather than a general decline in news audiences, and/or what Greg Dyke calls the current lack of "real news" - may be hard to calculate. At 10pm there are 23m people watching TV on average, according to Zenith Media, falling to 19.3m by 10.30pm, while by 11pm that is cut to 12m. The BBC News at Ten O'Clock and ITV's Nightly News pulled around 8m viewers during the autumn. This compares to the 10-11m who watched the BBC Nine and former News at Ten two years ago. No one knows how viewers will behave when forced to choose between news and news on the main networks. The BBC news machine is vaster than ITN's. But the ITV news provider will compete ferociously. It is desperate to succeed against the BBC: even the bongs are coming back, alongside Sir Trevor McDonald, signed for another four years. Underlying ITN's determination is the fact that ITV is set to renegotiate its news supply contract early (Sky News is hovering once again as a potential replacement), while ITV bosses feel deep unease over the costs and distractions of ITN 24 hour News, which is trailing far behind Sky News and News 24. One final point: the outburst of public disapproval over the axeing of the original News at Ten - including a campaign in The Mirror - was not matched by similar lamentations about the abolition of the BBC's Nine O'Clock News. That shows which side engaged hearts and minds.

fields.headline: Media monkey
fields.trailText: TalkSport boss Kelvin MacKenzie has some strange habits, but this one is new to Monkey. Last week, he arrived at the office dressed as Gladiator Maximus.
fields.body:
 TalkSport boss Kelvin MacKenzie has some strange habits, but this one is new to Monkey. Last week, he arrived at the office dressed as Gladiator Maximus, vowing vengeance on all his enemies, both in this life and the next. Photographic evidence of this bizarre behaviour will appear alongside a profile in one of our downmarket rivals this week. You wouldn't catch us stooping so low.

 When legal eagle Joshua Rozenberg left the BBC for the dizzy heights of the Daily Telegraph law page, unkind corporation insiders were none too sad to see the back of him, claiming he was not programme editors' first choice when a complicated court case had to be unpicked in a 30-second two-way. So, guess who the BBC booked for News 24 to pontificate on the Grobbelaar libel appeal verdict? No, you couldn't make it up.

 More dismay north of the border where the Scotsman is selling each Monday's issue at 15p per copy, in a move which will cost the Scottish newsagent trade £300,000. Desmond Barr, a Paisley newsagent, is horrified and says, "We're sitting ducks. We've got to sell, we've no alternative and this cut in cover price margins is a cut to our livelihoods." Scotsman editor-in-chief Andrew Neil, who hails from Paisley, might want to be careful on his next visit to his old stomping ground.

 Could Nigel Lythgoe - new star of Popstars and last week's cover story - be letting fame go to his head? Not only is his voice mail now clogged with wannabes massacring Angels (as indeed is a Sun phone line set up for friends of the Popstars to out them) but Lythgoe decided to sing it himself on Kiss FM last week. Where will it end? Nasty Nigel is apparently next week's guest reviewer of the Top 10 singles in Top of the Pops magazine. Enough already.

 Lis Murdoch's fledgling media company has made its first high-profile signing. Monkey hears that Kenton Allen, producer of The Royle Family, has passed up an opportunity within the BBC's increasingly deserted entertainment department to take the Murdoch shilling. She's back.

 Ex-literary editor of the Sunday Times, Harry Ritchie, has penned the latest based-on-experience novel to cause excitement in the media world. Ritchie's book, The Friday Night Club, tells the story of the Sunday Chronicle and its not-very-bright editor Jonathan Witherington. So not at all about John Witherow then.

 New Panorama editor Mike Robinson was so underwhelmed by the film-making skills of staff on the troubled BBC current affairs show that he sent them all off to a workshop with respected BBC documentaries chief Olivia Lichtenstein. The suggestion, as you can imagine, didn't go down too well with the more seasoned members of the team, and a three-line whip had to be imposed on Tom Mangold, Jane Corbin and John Ware. While Ms Corbin is the model of decorum, the gruff words of Mangold and Ware cannot be reprinted in a family diary.

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: There are two ways of minimising the impact of a difficult piece of news - put it out when no-one's looking or when there are lots of other stories around, writes John Kampfner.
fields.body:
It's an old trick that predates New Labour. There are two ways of trying to minimise the impact of a difficult piece of news - put it out either when no one's looking, or when a lot of other stories are around. The former normally applies to government announcements. They're sneaked out late on Thursday evenings, or Fridays, when few MPs and lobby journalists are around. The latter applies to everything else, and last Wednesday provided a perfect example.

It was a busy news day. The Commons was debating hunting, and Tony Blair was condemning internet adoption. Those were the two main issues on the minds of hacks as they traipsed up the stairs to the turret of the Palace of Westminster for the lobby briefing from Alastair Campbell at 3.30pm.

Instead, the main line was that Tony Blair was, after all, rejecting broadcasters' plans for election television debates with William Hague and Charles Kennedy. This was all the more surprising as it was Campbell who had first mooted the idea at a press gallery lunch.

A few minutes later, three doyens of what's known as "the white Commonwealth" - David Hughes of the Mail, Trevor Kavanagh of the Sun and George Jones of the Telegraph - were spotted walking off to Conservative Central Office. There they were briefed about the £5m donation by betting magnate Stuart Wheeler. This was the story the Tories wanted out as soon as possible - even if it drowned out the others.

So did the Campbell strategy work? Apart from the Independent, the TV debates story didn't figure on page one. (The Times had it on the front for the first edition, but later knocked it inside.) Others included it in their hunting and Wheeler stories. In most of the tabloids, it was pushed way back. Yet, just when the government's spinners might have been chuckling over another clever call, the Mail went in both feet first.

Declaring "Blair goes to ground", it devoted the whole of its front to a story linking the prime minister's decision to duck the hunting vote and the debates. By Friday, the Guardian and FT had leader articles and the Independent had a column accusing Blair of a lack of courage. The word "chicken" was on everyone's lips.

fields.headline: Gregory's goals
fields.standfirst: It's a year since Greg Dyke took the top job at the BBC. It's also showdown time between his revamped corporation and ITV as their news bulletins go head to head for the first time at 10pm.  Andrew Harvey  finds out why, for the director-general, the two events are inextricably linked
fields.trailText: It's a year since Greg Dyke took the helm at the BBC. It's also showdown time as the BBC's news bulletins go head to head with ITV's at 10pm. Andrew Harvey finds out why, for the director-general, the two events are inextricably linked.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke reckons that moving the BBC television news from nine o'clock to 10 is one of the best things he's done in his first year as director-general. He's an action man, a risk taker by instinct, and although he speaks with consummate diplomacy about life within the constraining culture of the corporation, he saw his opportunity and seized it. He played the game rather like a football striker shackled by a tight defence. A patient build-up, a moment of individual magic, the ball's in the net and the crowd are jubilant. The build-up involved weeks of preparation before the proposal was taken to the board of governors. Last August there was unanimous agreement that the time had come to confront the taboos by moving the news to the 10pm slot left vacant by ITV.

If that was dramatic in principle, the real maverick touch came in the autumn when the ITC told the commercial companies to return ITN news to its old niche, at least for part of the week. Dyke instantly cut short the planning and gave BBC news a two-week deadline to occupy the open ground at 10pm while at the same time doubling the length of the regional news bulletin to seven minutes. "We decided to move fast, something unusual at the BBC," recalls Dyke. "It was one of the best things I have done in terms of the effect on the morale of the staff. They realised that we really could move quickly. I've discovered, just wandering around, the number of people who have found the change quite exhilarating. It's unbelievable.

"We got a lot of flak from politicians and journalists," he adds without concern. "But any change at the BBC brings you flak, it always has done." Tonight, barely three months later and with viewing figures unimproved, Dyke and his news team face their toughest challenge when the trusty Trevor McDonald will once again front News at Ten. The nation will have to make its choice as BBC (average 5.2m at 10pm) and ITV (3.2m at 11pm) go head to head on three or four days a week.

Dyke is scornful of the competition's scheduling, doubting that companies such as Carlton and Granada wanted to give back prime drama and comedy time to news.

"They're not even promising to show the News at Ten on the same nights each week," Dyke scoffs. "It's a ridiculous idea, there's not a broadcaster in the world that does that." He puts it down to a "fudge" to please politicians and doubts it will satisfy the viewers.

Cue Chris Smith, the culture secretary and the man whose ministry includes the broadcasting brief. He is thought to favour a return to the status quo of BBC at 9pm and ITN an hour later and has let it be known that he is "worried" that the clash of the bulletins may result in fewer people watching the news.

There has been speculation that Smith may try to pressure the BBC to vacate 10pm if aggregate news ratings fall. He has no statutory power to interfere in BBC scheduling and Dyke is in no mood to give back what he has taken with such panache.He says that it's his hunch that the total audience for news is likely to go up: "Since Christmas the figures have been poor because there has been no real news, but this is a long-term project which may take one or two years to assess. If we eventually make a change it will be a decision taken by the governors and the executive committee of the BBC.

"What really matters is the quality of programmes that you put out before the news. You hope you will retain most of your viewers to watch the bulletin."

This brings him to the parallel plank in his strategy and the other main area of reform where he has applied himself in his first year: saving money to spend on programmes.

"What matters at the BBC is output," he declares. "The only role of management it seems to me is to make sure you have a good product and the means to make good programmes - and that's it."

Most conspicuously he has "flattened" the management structure which in more brutal language means the first 350 staff have either fled or been been fired in a reorganisation of middle tiers that will see 1,000 departures by 2003. He was shocked early on to discover that 26% of the BBC's £2.2bn annual income was going on what he calls "running the institution that is the BBC". His target is to slash costs to 15% of a higher income over three years.

Some economies have already made headlines, such as the squeeze on taxi travel, entertaining and first-class tickets. Chauffeurs are down from 19 to eight and the internal market developed by John Birt, Dyke's predecessor, no longer charges local radio stations more to access a CD than it would cost to go to HMV and buy it. "There's nothing wrong with an internal market, we've just removed the absurdities." He saw that saving money was a vital end in itself in a publicly-funded organisation and says it is another factor which has helped improve staff morale.

In commercial television, where Dyke spent years as everything from a programme maker to a chief executive - not to mention arch-rival of the BBC - he was used to the discipline of the profit and loss account, a concept that is alien in a public corporation. He was also used to taking a gamble. "You can't always be sure you'll win, but to succeed you have to take risks," he says. "But taking risks in the public sector is without doubt harder than taking them in private organisations because you are much more publicly accountable. It's a risk-averse culture and I'm not sure there is much you can do about it."

Dyke calculates that by 2003 he will be spending an extra £500m on output, with the money coming from the inflation-linked licence fee, savings on salaries and admin plus the growing revenues from the BBC's commercial enterprises.

He recognises the argument that it's the corporation's duty to maintain a level of quality before chasing ratings but dismisses the notion that one naturally excludes the other. "There's a belief that if a programme gets an audience it can't be quality, and that's complete bullshit," he snorts. "We are looking for great programmes. They don't necessarily have to be popular, but they do have to be special."

Moving Panorama to Sunday night was a consequence of the rescheduling of the main news. It drew the predictable laments from bilious columnists but Dyke is unfazed. Although the audience is down by half a million, he cites research by his former station LWT that showed a higher percentage of ABC1 viewers tune in on Sunday night than at any other time of the week. "It will take time to settle," he says. "Ultimately, the justification for Panorama is in the quality of the investigations you can do, and the best take a lot of money." He's putting an extra £500,000 into the next 30-programme series and would like to see any newspaper that accuses him of dumbing down put half as much into investigations of its own.

Investigations of worthwhile subjects, that is. His old enemies at the Times, the Daily Mail and the Sunday Times have spent time and money this past year scurrying round trying to nail him for financial irregularities or other misdemeanours. Some staked out his ex-wife in an attempt to tap into a rich seam of revelation. Nothing doing. "It's all crap," says Dyke adding that "a lot of newspapers in pursuit of what they call journalism do a real disservice to themselves." He feels vindicated - Peter Stothard's Times campaign against him left the editor looking foolish, he reckons - but still smarts at the power of a few senior journalists to indulge in such hostility.

Of course, a man like Dyke isn't out of the news for long. He's rich, colourful and carries opinions that are as challenging as they are often refreshing. A year in charge at the BBC has not dimmed these characteristics although he navigates his way through an on-the-record encounter with care. It's rare to find him shooting from the hip in public and even his "hideously white" comments about the staff numbers within his organisation and the Metropolitan police turned out to be based on reasoning he has put forward several times about the need to integrate more people from ethnic minorities in the senior management of Britain's public bodies.

He is braced for the coming election when he expects more fuss will be made over his perceived Labour leanings. He is ready for his record to be examined while insisting that he has very little day-to-day influence on the news output of the BBC. "There was this great myth that I would act like some sort of Svengali forcing my politics on the news department. In fact the editorial power is quite a long way down because the set-up is so large and diverse. The idea that I can ring up a show and say 'I insist that you do this or that' is just not real.

"Part of the problem is that newspaper editors can and do do that and they believe that because they can, then the BBC is like that. It's not.

"An awful lot of bullying goes on at election time, so it's very important that we remain robust in the face of attempts to bully us from either side. We have to be fair, but the parties themselves don't play fair."

During the last campaign, the BBC extended the Nine O'Clock News to 45 minutes in order to accommodate election reports each day. The tactic was a turn-off. This time Dyke intends to let the campaign take place with no more than 10 minutes tacked on to the standard 25 minutes. Besides, the new 10pm news leaves precious little room between bulletin and bedtime.

It is still too early to judge whether the extra investment will work in the BBC's favour. But Dyke is in this for the long haul - at 53 he has a potential maximum term of seven years. The new money and the programmes it will fund will not begin to show in the schedules until September. "From what I've seen there's some pretty good stuff coming up," he says with the casual candour that his competitors will recognise as less of a boast and more of a challenge.

webTitle: New Labour widens the dossiers on journalists

fields.headline: Hack watch
fields.standfirst: The security services and Whitehall have long kept dossiers on certain journalists but, characteristically, New Labour has widened the focus - as an internal cabinet memo obtained by the Guardian shows.
fields.trailText: The security services and Whitehall have long kept dossiers on journalists but New Labour has widened the focus. By Seumas Milne and Kevin Maguire.
fields.body:
'The worst thing you can ever do in politics is get hooked on reading your press," Tony Blair told Vanity Fair magazine last summer, straining to distance himself from new Labour's now immovable reputation as a media-fixated coven of spinmeisters and image-weavers. "I can't think I spend more than five minutes a day reading it - I read the Financial Times and I flick through the rest."

Even allowing for a touch of understandable hyperbole, there seems little reason to doubt his word. Fortunately for the prime minister, he now has a small army of little helpers to do the job for him. The days are long gone when Blair, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson ran the most effective media operation in British politics by themselves from a couple of mobile phones in a House of Commons corridor.

Under the command of the short-tempered Alastair Campbell, an impressive three-pronged structure - based in Downing Street, the cabinet office and Labour's Millbank headquarters - has been grafted on to the traditional government information service to monitor and respond to the ever-growing out pourings of broadcast, print and internet journalists.

Now an internal cabinet office memo about the supposed connections and quirks of a hotch-potch of political journalists, leaked to the Guardian, has cast a new light on the thoroughness with which this enterprise is prosecuted - and highlighted the increasingly incestuous, inward-looking process of modern politics, as politicians report on journalists reporting on politicians.

It is not as if governments have never been fixated with their media coverage in the past. Both Harold Wilson and John Major were famously obsessed, masochistically consuming everything written about them, while cabinet papers of both Labour and Tory post-war governments reveal regular acerbic asides about this or that reporter or commentator and their possible motivations or weaknesses.

The security services and individual Whitehall departments have long kept dossiers on the more awkward journalists, but with characteristic rigour, new Labour - which likes to think of itself as more spinned against than spinning - appears to have widened the focus.

This cabinet office briefing on print journalists is understood to have been drafted in the autumn by Carl Shoben with Chris McShane, the two special advisers who effectively guide the government's media monitoring unit on Campbell's behalf and previously did the same job at Millbank.

Not to be confused with the more proactive strategic communications unit at Number 10, the media monitoring unit works on the Millbank model, providing round-the-clock summaries and analysis of the press and broadcast media to ministers and civil servants across Whitehall, including Blair himself.

Its briefings form the agenda for the daily 9am news planning meeting in Campbell's office. But it also provides customised reports for particular ministers and, courtesy of the intelligence services' electronic eavesdropping facilities, is able to monitor hard-to-reach broadcast networks.

Shoben and McShane's memo was drawn up as a thumbnail guide to the perceived influence, reliability and political leanings of daily newspaper reporters and commentators for the civil servants preparing the daily briefings, as well as the monitoring unit's other customers.

Their assessments vary from the unexceptionable to the questionable - reflecting the authors' own prejudices as much as the journalists' - while comments on the state of the reporters' careers pepper the briefing.

Andrew Grice of the Independent is thought to be "perhaps a little on the wane now" while at the same time it is said that "almost anything he does is significant", while Benedict Brogan of the Telegraph is regarded as being in a "proving himself situation at the moment".

Political designations include Thatcherite, rightwing, centre-right, liberal, old Labour right, centre-left and leftwing, but the authors understandably tread gingerly round the Blairite/Brownite camp affiliations that have provided so much lobby gossip fodder in recent years.

The Guardian's David Hencke and Hugo Young are both described as "obsessed" with freedom of information, while others are (tacitly) praised for relying more on "officially placed stories rather than leaks". The Mail's Simon Heffer, Anatole Kaletksy and Peter Riddell of the Times and the Guardian's Hugo Young and Polly Toynbee are all singled out for being influential, respected or widely read.

Of the 28 daily journalists listed in the memo, nine work for the Times, seven are on the Guardian, three are with the Telegraph, three the Independent, two are on the Mail, two the Financial Times and one each on the Mirror and the Express.

Surprisingly, no one is included from the Sun, not even its political editor Trevor Kavanagh, regarded by some as the most influential political journalist in the country. One explanation for the omission is that ministers and officials need no guidance as to where Rupert Murdoch's tabloid and its staff are coming from.

The memo has none of the contemptuous tone Campbell routinely deploys against recalcitrant journalists in his efforts to encourage more posi tive coverage of the government. But while some named on the list will be embarrassed by the official praise and others will wear criticism as a badge of honour, several of the authors' judgments will inevitably be questioned inside and outside the Westminster loop. Among those criticised, the Express's Patrick O'Flynn was recently promoted to be political editor, while the Guardian's Patrick Wintour, on any objective basis, is widely acknowledged as a story-getter and admired for his range of contacts and grasp of policy.

Most journalists are in any case well aware that different branches of government may be keeping a track of their activities. Departments will, for example, provide potted biographies of lunch guests for ministers to read in the back of the car on their way to meet political correspondents.

Details of a journalist's interests are usually included, along with relevant press cuttings, to prepare the minister for discussion on any pet issues.

One old hand from the lobby still cherishes the dossier that a friendly Labour minister passed over as a memento of their lunch.

"I was quite amused and the minster was too," says the former reporter. "The details were fairly innocuous, such as my areas of interest and subjects I'd been recently interested in, if not entirely accurate."

But even if the language used by the authors of the leaked cabinet office memo is restrained compared with that of the prime minister's spokesman, it is doubtful that most career civil servants would have wanted to sign off such a politically explicit briefing.

New Labour's importation of modern US political campaigning and media management techniques into Whitehall - and the clean-out of press officers throughout the government - has sometimes strained relations with sections of the officially non-partisan civil service.

In the case of the ex-Millbank apparatchiks Shoben and McShane (the latter used to work for Scottish minister Brian Wilson), their role as special advisers means they will have to resign on the day the election is called. But the media monitoring unit will carry on.

John O'Sullivan, the civil servant who acts as the unit's director, explains that Shoben and McShane are in charge of the explicitly political side of the 10-strong unit's work. Once the election is called, he says, it will "continue to provide a media monitoring service to ministers and Whitehall press officers... with integrity, impartiality and honesty".

 The (unedited) cabinet office briefing

Note on Print Journalists

Bruce Anderson (Mail) - Thought to be the authentic voice of the Thatcherite/pro-Unionist wing of Conservative party. Distant from Hague bit [but?] is probably more of a generational thing.

Tom Baldwin (Times) - Gets good unofficial leaks. Generally has new angles to political stories.

Benedict Brogan (Telegraph) - New to watch. Has come from Herald, so is in a proving himself situation at moment.

Brian Groom (FT) - New to the job as political editor. Has special interests in regional politics, Europe, devolution.

Michael Gove (Times) - Right of centre commentator. Wrote Portillo's biography and is widely believed to be one of Michael Portillo's strongest supporters in the media.

Andrew Grice (Independent) - One of Westminster's most influential political reporters though perhaps a little on the wane now. The master of the leak, especially from Millbank. Nick Jones in his books on spin doctors believes Grice to be close to Mandelson. Never appears on TV, paper reviews etc. Assume almost anything he does is significant.

Simon Heffer (Mail) - Always put his comment in brief. Rightwing commentator, taken more seriously than likes of Peter Hitchens.

Anatole Kaletsky (Times) - Free marketeer, anti-European. Views taken seriously.

George Jones (Telegraph) - Political editor, tends to take a backseat in terms of exclusives, concentrating more on the political comment. Has more of an insight into Conservative politics.

James Landale (Times) - Straight political reporter. Good links inside CCO. [Conservative Central Office]

Magnus Linklater (Times) - An ardent critic of government's devolution programme - conservative commentator.

Don Macintyre (Indy) - Liberal inclinations. Tends to defend govt against [attacks?] from left and right. Traditionally famous in Westminster for being a close friend of Mandelson.

Kevin Maguire (Guardian) - Former Mirror political editor. Now working as a roving news reporter, with emphasis on "scoops". Enjoys close relationship to treasury team. Left of centre.

Seumas Milne (Guardian) - Veteran industrial and political correspondent. Leftwing, thought to be close to both Peter Mandelson and Ken Livingstone.

Patrick O'Flynn (Express) - Political reporter. Gets good exclusives for paper, though often turn out not to be true.

Matthew Parris (Times) - Views respected. Seen as a good reflection of Tory leftwing. Thought not to like Hague.

Peter Riddell (Times) - Political commentator. Never controversial. Seen as fair. Is widely read in Whitehall.

Paul Routledge (Mirror) - Influential in the sense that his columns appear in prominent placing in the Mirror each day. Formally [formerly?] close to Scargill, but now on traditional Old Lab right. Close to Charlie Whelan. Famously an enemy of Mandelson and "New Labour".

Robert Shrimsley (FT) - Well connected political reporter. Especially strong links within Conservative party.

Rachel Sylvester (Telegraph) - Once seen as a rising star, but her links with mainly people like Derek Draper, so star a little in decline. Her stories tend to be from around the cabinet office working groups, so dressing pieces on issues like genetics with some machinery of government news.

Paul Waugh (Independent) - Cut his teeth on mayoral campaign. A political machinery fanatic. Little policy.

Roland Watson (Times) - Straight political reporter. Tends to get good new leads on running political stories.

Philip Webster (Times) - Very well respected political editor. Rarely puts his own spin on stories. Gets many exclusives. Usually officially placed stories rather than leaks.

Michael White (Guardian) - Labour supporting political editor. Veering to "Old Labour" - he's keen to point out how leftwing govt really is.

Patrick Wintour (Guardian) - Quite well connected to Lab but his exclusives are rarely as good as they initially seem. Recently moved from Observer, so his unattributive Sunday journalism not as appropriate for a daily.

Hugo Young (Guardian) - Obsessed with Europe and freedom of information, but considered very influential among Lab-voting "chattering classes".

Polly Toynbee (Guardian) - Very well respected writer on the centre left, writes widely on social issues.

fields.headline: FilmFour set for radical revamp
fields.trailText: 9.30am: FilmFour is to overhaul its website, paving the way for pay-per-view films on the internet. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
FilmFour is to radically overhaul its website in March, paving the way for pay-per-view films on the internet.

Plans in discussion include expanding FilmFour.com into a generic film site that will build on Channel 4's reputation for good films.

"We want to make FilmFour.com the authoritative UK film site. The plan is to create a website that builds on the strong brand we already have but stands out from the crowd," said a spokesman for FilmFour.

The surge in new media activity coincides with a planned expansion of the FilmFour schedule, possibly involving the shift of the peak film slot to 9pm, rather than 8pm and 10pm. Details of this "expansion" are still under wraps.

Other plans for FilmFour.com include more interactive elements, mobile services, behind-the-scenes footage and building up a database of short films.

The mobile services will be based around information such as cinema listings, TV listings, ticketing, competitions and games.

"It will also feature intelligent recommendations based on individual profiles, hopefully using Fingertips [a soon-to-launch entertainment portal in which Channel 4 has taken a stake]," said Andy Anson, head of strategy and interactive at Channel 4, who is spearheading the new developments.

He, along with Stevan Keane, head of interactive commissioning at Channel 4, will negotiates internet rights during negotiations for TV film rights.

"Rights issues are more relaxed after the ridiculous frenzy of last year when broadcasters from all walks of life thought they could sell internet rights for millions of pounds," said Mr Anson.

webTitle: Families of vCJD victims to get interim payout

fields.headline: Families of vCJD victims to get interim payout
fields.trailText: Families of victims of the human form of BSE are expected to be awarded interim compensation payments that may run up to £25,000 each.
fields.body:
Families of victims of the human form of BSE are expected to be awarded interim compensation payments that may run up to £25,000 each.

The government will announce stop-gap payments within a few days, while negotiations continue over longer term arrangements with the families' lawyers.

Sources yesterday could not confirm exact sums but the government is known to be anxious to show it is moving on the politically sensitive issue. Eighty-three people in Britain have died from variant CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). Five, identified as probable victims, are still alive and another six cases are under investigation.

Ministers have accepted the need for "no-fault" compensation to avoid courtroom battles, and as a possible model their advisers point to a trust that compensates people with Aids or HIV - a fund that since 1987 has paid out nearly £100m.

A fund of £1m, to improve coordination of care for CJD patients, exists. But the Treasury, increasingly nervous over the sharp acceleration in cases, will be reluctant to sign any open-ended commitment.

An announcement on interim compensation is expected as part of the preliminary government response to the BSE inquiry report, published in October, which calls for sweeping changes in the way Whitehall responds to such human health threats.

David Body, a lawyer for the families, said: "If there is to be an interim payment it will be most welcome. There are people who would benefit, and this would come on top of good work that has resulted from setting up the care package."

He added that talks were still a long way from establishing compensation arrangements robust enough to last for years.

Malcolm Tibbert, chairman of the Human BSE Foundation, whose wife, Margaret, was an early victim, said: "We are all desperate to find out what is going to happen. No amount of money can replace those who have died, but we have to be realistic, and there are a lot of people out there who have children to bring up and their future has to be secured.

"The sooner the government comes up with a formal offer, and we can see if it is acceptable, the better."

Many victims' families are frustrated at the time the government has taken to respond to their formal lodging of the court action, although Whitehall has always said it had to wait for the inquiry report, which was published nearly three years after it began taking evidence.

But families point out that farmers have been paid huge compensation sums for BSE.

webTitle: Will rebranding the Post Office work?

fields.headline: Brand new
fields.standfirst: As the Post Office renames its overseas operation Consignia,  Claire Cozens asks whether rebranding works
fields.trailText: As the Post Office renames its overseas operation Consignia, Claire Cozens asks whether rebranding works.
fields.body:
The Post Office is the latest household name to fall victim to the brand consultants, but it is in good company. Syntegra, Sonera and Accenture may sound like the offspring of an over-imaginative rock star, but they are, in fact, the latest new names to hit the stock market.

The Post Office's new brand name, Consignia, won't be used in the UK at all. It is intended to help the Post Office expand abroad, where its existing name would be even more meaningless than the new one it has chosen. But as the trend for meaningless and frankly rather silly company names gathers pace, even the brand consultants - who get paid to come up with new names for old - are becoming cynical.

"It does seem to be open season on name changes at the moment," says Piers Schmidt, strategy director for branding consultancy The Fourth Room. "If your reputation is suffering a bit, changing your name is seen as the answer and at the moment the trend is to go for something vaguely Latin or Greek. But the public's not that stupid. If your reputation is suffering what you need to change is your products or your service levels, the things that actually matter."

A recent survey by the brand consultants Enterprise IG showed that a whopping 250 British companies changed their names in 2000, giving us the dubious honour of being the biggest name changers in Europe.

Of the companies that adopted new names, just over half did so because of a merger or acquisition. But that leaves 47% which changed their names with no clear reason for doing so.

Terry Tyrrell, chairman of Enterprise IG, predicts a return to more traditional company names over the next year, particularly in the financial sector. After bombarding customers with wacky-sounding new brands from Egg and Smile to IF and Cahoot, the banks have woken up to the fact that it makes more sense to trade on your existing brand.

"I think we are beginning an era of brand consolidation with a lot of the new dot.coms returning to their mother brands," Tyrrell says. "Companies are realising that it doesn't make sense to spend money marketing five or six brands and are rationalising their brand architecture."

Of course, no one is saying a name doesn't matter. It does - as General Motors found out when they tried to launch the Nova in Spain, only to find that "no va" means "doesn't go" in Spanish.

But plenty of companies hang onto their old names when they do new things - take De Beers, which is branching out into retailing in a joint venture with French luxury goods brand LVMH. "If you're well known it makes far more sense to keep your name, even if you do want to change your image," says Schmidt of The Fourth Room. "There aren't very many names left that haven't been patented and the trouble with made-up names is that the public finds them very difficult to relate to. And the idea that Accenture is supposed to make you think of an accent on the future is frankly bullshit."

"If your reputation is suffering a bit, changing your name is seen as the answer and at the moment the trend is to go for something vaguely Latin or Greek. But the public's not that stupid. If your reputation is suffering what you need to change is your products or your service levels, the things that actually matter." A recent survey by the brand consultants Enterprise IG showed that a whopping 250 British companies changed their names in 2000, giving us the dubious honour of being the biggest name changers in Europe. Of the companies that adopted new names, just over half did so because of a merger or acquisition. But that leaves 47% which changed their names with no clear reason for doing so. Terry Tyrrell, chairman of Enterprise IG, predicts a return to more traditional company names over the next year, particularly in the financial sector. After bombarding customers with wacky-sounding new brands from Egg and Smile to IF and Cahoot, the banks have woken up to the fact that it makes more sense to trade on your existing brand. "I think we are beginning an era of brand consolidation with a lot of the new dot.coms returning to their mother brands," Tyrrell says. "Companies are realising that it doesn't make sense to spend money marketing five or six brands and are rationalising their brand architecture." Of course, no one is saying a name doesn't matter. It does - as General Motors found out when they tried to launch the Nova in Spain, only to find that "no va" means "doesn't go" in Spanish. But plenty of companies hang onto their old names when they do new things - take De Beers, which is branching out into retailing in a joint venture with French luxury goods brand LVMH. "If you're well known it makes far more sense to keep your name, even if you do want to change your image," says Schmidt of The Fourth Room. "There aren't very many names left that haven't been patented and the trouble with made-up names is that the public finds them very difficult to relate to. And the idea that Accenture is supposed to make you think of an accent on the future is frankly bullshit."

webTitle: New claims of vaccine danger rebutted

fields.headline: New claims of vaccine danger rebutted
fields.trailText: New salvoes were fired yesterday in the war between a scientist who believes there is a link between the MMR vaccination and autism and the medical establishment, which has consistently rebutted the hypothesis. Sarah Boseley reports
fields.body:
New salvoes were fired yesterday in the war between a scientist who believes there is a link between the MMR vaccination and autism and the medical establishment, which has consistently rebutted the hypothesis.

Andrew Wakefield, a consultant gastroenterologist at the Royal Free hospital in London, is now alleging that the combined measles, mumps and rubella vaccination was not tested thoroughly enough for safety before it was introduced in Britain in 1988. In a paper shortly to be published in the medical journal Adverse Drug Reactions, he claims that children given the combined jab were not followed up for long enough to be sure that there were no side-effects.

The renewed battle over the MMR will dismay public health officials, who have warned that there is the danger of a potentially fatal measles outbreak if parents do not take their children for vaccination. Only 88% of children are now being vaccinated because of public uncertainty. In Ireland and the Netherlands, low vaccination coverage last year led to deaths from measles. The World Health Organisation says 95% coverage is advisable to prevent an outbreak.

Yesterday the Department of Health produced a long and detailed rebuttal of Mr Wakefield's latest allegations, based on reviews of his work carried out by independent scientists on the joint committee on vaccination and immunisation and the committee on the safety of medicines.

The paper by Mr Wakefield claims that children given the MMR jab in the pre-licensing trials were not followed up for longer than 28 days and therefore long-term side effects of the vaccinations would not have been picked up.

The Department of Health said yesterday that this was "factually incorrect". Most of the trials followed children for four to six weeks, one particular trial monitored them for six to nine weeks and a minority of children in the trials were followed up for a year. The department accused Mr Wakefield of biased reporting. "Studies that fail to support the author's views are not mentioned," it said.

Mr Wakefield's thesis, which caused a furore when published in the Lancet in 1998, is that the MMR jab can trigger Crohn's disease, a bowel disease, in certain susceptible children, which in turn can lead to autism. He claims in the new paper that some small trials in the US showed that significant numbers of chil dren developed stomach bugs, but that in spite of this, the follow-up period was reduced to 21 days from 28 days.

His original work was on just 12 children whose parents said they showed no signs of autism until after their MMR jab. Mr Wakefield's opponents point out that the vaccination takes place at around 18 months, the same time that autism is usually noticed. A study of all the autistic children in part of north London was commis sioned by the Department of Health, which concluded that there was the same rate of autism in children who had been vaccinated with the MMR and those who had not.

Mr Wakefield and colleagues claimed to have found signs of the measles virus in the gut of autistic children. But nobody has been able to replicate this finding. A panel of top scientists, convened by the medical research council at the request of the Department of Health, reviewed Mr Wakefield's data and found no evidence to substantiate his claim of the link between MMR and either bowel disease or autism.

But many parents of autistic children, searching to understand and explain what has happened to them, are convinced the MMR vaccination must be to blame. Mr Wakefield said yesterday that he now has 170 children on his books, instead of the original 12, and that in most cases the parents could show the autism appeared after the MMR.

Professor Brian Duerden, medical director of the public health laboratory service, said yesterday that he could find "no hard scientific basis at all" for Mr Wakefield's claims. "He is a fervent believer in his views on this," said Prof Duerden. "One person's idiosyncrasy and interpretation puts the vaccination programme and the need to protect children at risk."

webTitle: Angry parents undermine children's hospital care

fields.headline: Angry parents undermine children's hospital care
fields.trailText: Aggressive parents are undermining their children's hospital care by behaving in threatening and sometimes violent ways towards doctors, a survey has revealed. James Meikle reports
fields.body:
Aggressive parents are undermining their children's hospital care by behaving in threatening and sometimes violent ways towards doctors, a survey has revealed.

Two in three paediatricians are subjected to severe verbal or physical abuse each year, and far more can recall at least one violent incident, the study suggests. It is based on responses from hospital doctors in the south Thames and north-west NHS regions and Northern Ireland.

It was found that one doctor had had a death threat and another had been warned that a paramilitary organisation might be called in to settle a dispute over a child's care.

Gerry Mackin, a doctor at the Little Acorns paediatric unit, Derry, who did the research, warns in an article in the journal Archives of Disease in Childhood that doctors' decision-making can be seriously affected by such behaviour.

"Verbal abuse and threats are often overlooked and are not usually reported to either hospital authorities or the police. Such events are often perceived to be part of the job... paediatricians, and junior paediatricians in particular, are at significant risk."

Dr Mackin interviewed 75 doctors, more than half of them women. He concludes that more training in how to manage aggressive patients and relatives is needed.

webTitle: Sects may soon own TV licences

fields.headline: Sects may soon own TV licences
fields.standfirst:
Ministers to consider lifting broadcast ban

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The government is considering relaxing the ban preventing religious organisations from owning television broadcast licences. Ministers have indicated they are open to suggestions on how the restrictions could be eased.
fields.body:
The government is considering relaxing the ban preventing religious organisations from owning television broadcast licences. Ministers have indicated they are open to suggestions on how the restrictions could be eased.

Cult-watchers, such as the Cult Information Network, oppose any move that would allow evangelical sects to extend their influence among vulnerable people.

The proposal is contained in a little-noticed section of the communications reform white paper, published late last year. The white paper noted that the rules had been strict until now because of the relatively small number of television licences available. But with the proliferation of satellite and digital channels extending viewers' choice, the rules could be changed.

It conceded that such a move would be controversial. "There is a strong demand by some for religious content. But religious content has a particular capacity to offend those with different views and opinions, or, sometimes, to exploit the susceptibilities of the vulnerable. Religious issues may also shade into matters of political controversy."

But it says there may be a case for reform: "We nevertheless welcome views on whether we could relax the prohibition when choice increases in the digital future, or whether it will remain a necessary safeguard."

At present religious organisations may not run TV channels but can hold local radio licences. There are strict rules on what religious content can be broadcast. It is forbidden, for example, to try to convert listeners or solicit donations.

The largest religious broadcaster is Premier, which holds a radio licence in London and the south-east and broadcasts on the internet.

Organisations such as the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God have extensive media interests abroad. The church, to which the eight-year-old Anna Climbie was taken just before she died after suffering horrific abuse at the hands of her guardians, owns about 20 television and 50 radio stations in Brazil.

There are also concerns about exploitation. In the US the TV evangelist Jim Bakker publicly admitted using $265,000 from his Praise the Lord group in an unsuccessful bid to buy the silence of a church secretary who claimed he had sex with her.

Ian Howarth, spokesman for the Cult Information Network, said he did not object to mainstream churches starting digital TV stations, but cults should be firmly banned.

"Cults, by definition, remove personal freedom," he said. "The definitions in any new legislation would have to be very tight.

"It is interesting that in the UK we allow cults to register as charitable institutions in the same way as religious or therapeutic organisations."

webTitle: GPs fail young mental health patients

fields.headline: GPs fail young mental health patients
fields.trailText: Young people with mental health problems are not getting the help they need because GPs do not tell them about support services, according to a charity survey. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Young people with mental health problems are not getting the help they need because GPs do not tell them about support services, according to a charity survey.

The report claims GPs lack empathy, knowledge, understanding or interest in mental health problems. This hinders young people's access to community and hospital care, as GPs are the gatekeepers to these services.

Turned Upside Down by the Mental Health Foundation (MHF) reveals that each year thousands of vulnerable young people fail to receive adequate treatment as they slip through the gaps between child and adult services.

It calls on the government to establish a national service framework (NSF) specifically for 16 to 25-year-olds to ensure they get the help they need, particularly as this is the age when the first signs of schizophrenia are most likely to occur.

Fifty-four per cent of the young people interviewed by the MHF went to their GP for help but few found them helpful.

One of those youngsters, Lucy, said she ended up addicted to valium at the age of 16 after going to her GP for help when she became depressed. Although her mother had recently died, she says the doctor asked her no questions nor offered her any counselling and just prescribed a series of sedatives and anti-depressants.

"I was getting more and more desperate. Even after I cut myself with razor blades, he didn't ask me what was the matter, just bandaged me up and sent me away. I don't think he took it seriously," she said.

When Lucy started a business studies course at a college in Bromley, London, she did find a GP sensitive to her problems.

"I'd reached crisis point. I broke down in class and a friend took me to my new surgery. Fortunately my new GP was great - he addressed the root of my problems rather than just the physical symptoms. He referred me to a psychiatrist for counselling and within a week I was in a psychiatric hospital where they helped me to come off the medication."

Lucy, now 25 and an administrator for a mental health charity, believes GPs hold the key to tackling mental health problems.

"Without my current GP, I'd never have received counselling. But my original GP's surgery had no information about mental health. If he'd been clued up, I might have recovered by now."

Lesley Warner, spokeswoman for the MHF, called for GPs to develop a greater awareness of mental health issues.

She said: "If a GP doesn't have an interest in or experience of dealing with mental health then this is the first problem for young people trying to get help."

But Streatham GP Dr Alan Cohen, head of primary care at the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health, said the problem was that young people were the patient group least likely to consult their GP.

Dr Cohen said: "It may be that they think GPs are not interested, so don't come to our attention until they're in crisis. But nearly 30% of consultations are concerned with some aspect of mental health, so all GPs have an interest in it. Indeed, about 50% of practices now offer counselling services on site."

fields.headline: Baker to edit mortgage website
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Martin Baker, former launch editor of TheStreet.co.uk, is to edit a new website for endowment policy-holders, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Martin Baker, former Sunday Business associate editor and launch editor of TheStreet.co.uk, is to edit a new website for endowment policy-holders.

Myendowment.com, which launches this weekend, has been designed to help holders of endowment mortgage policies with red or amber warning letters.

The site is backed by the publishing division of mortgage broker Chase de Vere Mortgage Management.

Mr Baker, a well-known financial journalist who has written a book of satirical essays about financial markets A Fool and His Money, left thestreet.co.uk suddenly early last year.

webTitle: Kennedy and Hague may agree to two-way TV debate

fields.headline: Kennedy and Hague may agree to two-way TV debate
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A TV debate between Charles Kennedy and William Hague may be staged as early as February 11 in a concerted attempt to embarrass Tony Blair over his decision not to join a three way challenge during the general election campaign.
fields.body:
A TV debate between Charles Kennedy and William Hague may be staged as early as February 11 in a concerted attempt to embarrass Tony Blair over his decision not to join a three way challenge during the general election campaign.

London Weekend Television has put the proposal to the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives.

The two party leaders are already due to be interviewed on a LWT special presented by Jonathan Dimbleby on February 13. LWT agreed to the programme under pressure from the Independent Television Commission and after the two parties complained about the hour-long Ask the Prime Minister special the broadcaster screened a month ago.

Late last week LWT privately proposed a debate between the two men, which Mr Kennedy's staff have said he was keen to join. The programme would not be subject to the rigorous rules on balance in the Representation of the People Act, which apply during the election.

The one-hour LWT special was first conceived as two separate 30-minute interviews.

It also emerged yesterday that, in an unprecedented form of cooperation between Tories and Lib Dems, Mr Kennedy and Mr Hague had considered holding a joint press conference to try to force Mr Blair to take part in TV debates. The proposal was put to Mr Kennedy by Conservative Central Office a week ago.

The press conference would have been held today, but the idea was shelved after Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, announced last Wednesday that the prime minister would not join a TV debate.The Lib Dems had not finally agreed to the press conference idea, and had also been considering a joint letter or article. Some of Mr Kennedy's staff were uncertain about a joint press conference, fearing public pressure might make it more difficult for Mr Blair to concede.

On BBC1's Breakfast with Frost programme yesterday, Mr Kennedy said: "I am quite happy to debate with William. If such a debate during an election caused legal problems for the broadcasters, then why don't we get a body like the Hansard Society and put the two of us on a platform and let people listen to what we have got to say? If Tony Blair does not want to be there, that's entirely a matter for him."

Linking Mr Blair's refusal to debate to fears he would back away from a referendum on the euro, Mr Kennedy said: "If you shy away from people, if you're not willing to go in front of the TV cameras and put your case and try and persaude, then that does not augur well for the election - but also for a referendum campaign thereafter." Some Blairities are privately urging the prime minister to "clarify" his policy on the euro by saying that he would not stage a referendum until at least a year after the election.

Mr Kennedy responded warmly to an assurance from the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, that he expected the Labour manifesto to contain a commitment to a referendum on electoral reform for the Commons.

Mr Cook told GMTV: "I have no reason to doubt that the very clear policy of the party will be included in the manifesto, including a commitment to a referendum." However, electoral reformers expect the manifesto to say the referendum will not be held until after other voting changes in Scotland and Wales have bedded down.

webTitle: BBC suspends Blood on the Carpet

fields.headline: BBC suspends Blood on the Carpet
fields.trailText:
8.30am:BBC2's Blood on the Carpet, which exposes corporate bust-ups, has been suspended from the schedules, writes Jason Deans.
Blood on the Carpet watched by 2.6m
fields.body:
The hit BBC2 show Blood on the Carpet, which lifts the lid on senior corporate bust-ups, has been suspended from the schedules.

Nick Mirsky, who has produced both series of the critically acclaimed documentary, said "there probably won't be another run".

"We've trawled the last decade for the best stories and I think the ground needs to be left fallow for a while.

"It's also quite hard to gain access for these shows," Mr Mirsky added.

It took eight months to persuade ex-BBC chief Matthew Bannister to take part in Walking with Disc Jockeys.

And it took 18 months to get Rocco Forte in front of camera for the show about his takeover battle with Granada, Mr Mirsky revealed.

Last week's instalment focused on Mr Bannister's stormy stewardship of BBC Radio 1, from his ousting of DJs such as Simon Bates and DLT to the hiring and firing of Chris Evans.

In the past, Blood on the Carpet has tackled Gerry Robinson's hostile Granada takeover of Mr Forte's hotel business and the short and unhappy alliance between royal-wedding-dress designer Elizabeth Emanuel and Joe Bloggs founder Shami Ahmed.

The four shows still to run focus on British Biotech, the battle between two rival darts organisations, the 1999 Woodstock music festival and the gourmet sausage industry.

"We want to go out on a high but the strand will probably be rested for a while," Mr Mirsky said.

The first series went out in summer 1998 and was repeated early the following year.

In some cases, Mr Mirsky has spent more than two years working on individual programmes, while keeping costs down by having a small production team.

Blood on the Carpet is produced by BBC creative director Robert Thirkell's business unit.

It is also responsible for Trouble at the Top and Back to the Floor.

Mr Mirsky said he would probably move on from the business unit when the current series of Blood on the Carpet is completed.

However, he added that if good stories about business fall-outs arose, Mr Thirkell's outfit would cover them.

A BBC spokeswoman said: "There are no plans to go immediately back into production with Blood on the Carpet. But that does not mean there won't be any more."

fields.headline: Election ad millions is 'wasted money'
fields.trailText: 8.30am The millions Labour and the Tories will spend on election ads is wasted money, says Labour's former ad supremo. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The millions of pounds Labour and the Tories are planning to spend on pre-election advertising is wasted money, according to Labour's former ad supremo, Chris Powell.

In an interview with MediaGuardian.co.uk, Mr Powell, who headed Labour's advertising in the 1992 and 1997 elections, said a Labour victory was such a foregone conclusion that the political parties would be well advised to scrap their campaigns.

Such a move would not be entirely unprecedented - in the 1983 general election Margaret Thatcher was so confident of victory that she cancelled her advertising budget.

Opposition leader William Hague is understood to have come under pressure from some members of the cabinet to do the same, to prevent his cash-strapped party from wasting millions on a lost cause.

But Mr Powell believes this is unlikely to happen:

"This is probably Hague's only chance - of course he's going to throw everything he's got at it," he said, adding, "it might be more of an argument for Blair, though".

But even if they are not scrapping their ad campaigns altogether both political parties are saving the bulk of their firepower for the final few weeks before the election, with Labour having booked up more than 3,000 poster sites ahead of a major advertising blitz in April.

Advertising already released by both parties has been pretty tame, but the gloves are likely to come off as the election approaches.

According to newspaper reports, both Labour and the Tories are planning aggressive campaigns that will involve personal attacks on each other's leaders.

The Tory party's ad agency, Yellow M, is likely to describe Mr Blair as "the great pretender", a reference to his perceived slick style and broken promises.

And TBWA, the Labour party's ad agency, is planning a bitter attack on William Hague, presenting him as "a joke and a danger".

But getting personal can be a dangerous strategy. The Tories famously had their fingers burned in the run-up to the 1997 election when they portrayed Tony Blair as the devil in their "demon eyes" ads.

The public outcry over the ads contributed to the party's split from its long-time ad agency, M&C Saatchi.

"Comparing Blair to the devil was always going to backfire," says Mr Powell.

"Calling him the great pretender might have a little more resonance, but knocking your opponent personally is a very dangerous strategy. And the British don't like to see someone kicked when they're down, so a personal attack on Hague could also backfire."

Another reason for the political parties leaving their campaigns to the last minute this year is voter apathy.

The widespread predictions of a Labour landslide are expected to result in a poor turnout at the polls and both parties are keen to leave their election campaigns until as late as possible to avoid boring the electorate.

webTitle: BP to close 5,000 petrol stations worldwide

fields.headline: BP to close 5,000 petrol stations worldwide
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is to save an estimated £1bn by closing down or ending supply contracts with 5,000 petrol stations worldwide. The company is implementing a global rebranding programme.
fields.body:
BP Amoco is to save an estimated £1bn by closing down or ending supply contracts with 5,000 petrol stations worldwide. The company is implementing a global rebranding programme.

Most of the stations are in the US where two recent acquisitions - Amoco and Arco - are being integrated into the oil group. BP yesterday said about 12 stations in Britain would be affected by the cuts.

BP would not indicate how many of the company-owned stations it intended to close during the four-year rebranding programme, but it has previously been estimated that 3,000 jobs are likely to be lost as the group consolidates.

The company owns about a third of the 28,000 stations which it supplies around the world. The cutbacks were widely expected in the wake of BP's £79bn spending spree over recent years, bringing Amoco, Arco and Burmah Castrol within the group.

In an interview with the Sunday Times BP chief executive Sir John Browne said of the stations affected: "Some will be sold to other oil companies and others sold as property to be redeveloped. Five thousand is not a huge amount - it's called adjusting the portfolio." Those stations which are not BP-owned will be free to negotiate supply contracts with other oil companies.

It is understood that all of the US Arco stations, mainly found on the west coast of America, will escape closure. BP's rebranding programme includes spending £136m to bring a new green, yellow and white sun logo to its fore courts, in place of the 70-year-old shield insignia.

New BP Connect convenience stores alongside the busiest forecourts are being introduced in an effort to boost retail sales by more than 10% per year. The stores include internet links through which motorists can check weather and traffic conditions and plan their route.

In July last year, Sir John described the company's new logo - dubbed "the Helios symbol" after the Greek sun god - as signifying dynamic energy in all its forms, from oil to gas and solar. He added that as BP moved towards a single brand, the company name should stand for "beyond petroleum" rather than British Petroleum.

In a separate development, a spokesman for BP yesterday confirmed that drilling at its Crazy Horse field in the Gulf of Mexico was producing better than expected results. Analysts had been anticipating that the site would yield 1bn barrels of oil, but is now likely to exceed that figure by 25%.
