webTitle: Tory donor says party must stay anti-euro

fields.headline: Tory donor says party must stay anti-euro
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The betting tycoon who pledged £5m to the Tories without policy strings yesterday announced he would not back the party if Kenneth Clarke, or any supporter of the European single currency, became Conservative leader.
fields.body:
The betting tycoon who pledged £5m to the Tories without policy strings yesterday announced he would not back the party if Kenneth Clarke, or any supporter of the European single currency, became Conservative leader.

Stuart Wheeler, chairman of the spread betting company IG Index, had insisted at the time of the gift he was not seeking to influence party policy, or receive anything in return. He denied his latest remarks qualified his pledge of a gift with no policy strings attached. He said: "I'm very confident that William Hague will remain leader whether he wins or not.

"But if Kenneth Clarke was to become leader after the election, I do not see myself supporting the Conservatives or any other party led by somebody who is so keen to go into the euro."

He played down reports that he might double his donation to Mr Hague's election campaign, saying it was "very unlikely". He might have to take out a loan to raise the full £5m.

Mr Wheeler said his opposition to Mr Clarke was not such that he would stop giving money if the former chancellor were made a member of the shadow cabinet.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats seized on his rejection of Mr Clarke, and the euro, to claim Mr Wheeler was influencing Tory policy and strategy. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said it was "entirely wrong that any large donor should say to a party who it is prepared to see as spokespersons for that party".

Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, asked: "Should it be for wealthy tycoons to start deciding who becomes the democratically elected leaders of our parties? I don't think so."

Mr Wheeler's firm is also lobbying the Treasury and the government's review of gaming legislation to protect the spread betting industry. The review on legislation, including gaming hours, is being conducted by the economist Sir Alan Budd.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is expected to use the budget to replace the current 9% tax on individual bets with a post-profits tax on betting firms. The reform is designed to prevent the rapidly evolving betting industry going offshore to avoid tax.

Paul Austin, a spokesman for IG Index, has said he would welcome a switch to gross profits tax only if spread betting firms were subject to a lower rate than their fixed odds competitors. He claimed the cost base for companies such as IG was greater.

The Conservative election coordinator, Andrew Lansley, dismissed the controversy over Mr Wheeler's remarks on the euro. "He's not asking for any policy commitments, he's expressing a view about Conservative party policy and he's expressing a view about the leadership of the Conservative party," he said. "The position is the same if Mr Wheeler were giving us £10 or £5m."

It is now likely that Mr Hague - who plans to campaign largely away from London - will be able to use a helicopter, as well as the latest communications technology.

Mr Lansley also revealed that his party will publish in days the details of how it will cut £8bn from the government's spending plans. So far the Conservatives have identified £5.3bn. At the weekend, the Conservatives said they would privatise Channel 4 and reduce £1bn from the national lottery fund reserve, so raising £2bn for art galleries and museums.

fields.headline: Suddenly everyone loves the euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Nothing illustrates the fickleness of the foreign exchange market more than its treatment of the euro. For two years, Europe's single currency was the butt of dealers' jokes.
fields.body:
Nothing illustrates the fickleness of the foreign exchange market more than its treatment of the euro. For two years, Europe's single currency was the butt of dealers' jokes. One memorably called it a "toilet currency". Now, all of a sudden, it is the only one of the big three (the other two being the dollar and the yen) that isn't going down the pan.

Since its nadir of 82 cents in October, the euro has climbed 15% against the dollar, finishing trading in London on Friday at just below 94 cents. Meanwhile, the yen is plummeting. Just why the markets should so suddenly have promoted the euro to top dog remains a subject of intense debate among economists.

Some attribute it to real economic factors, such as the staunching of capital flows from the eurozone. Others point to interest rate differentials between the US and the euro-12. But, in reality, it probably reflects no more than a change in market psychology.

At a discussion in London last week organised by the Centre for Economic Policy Research, Richard Portes went through the conventional explanations offered by City analysts for the euro's decline during 1999 and 2000 and showed that none of them stood up to scrutiny.

Net capital outflows from the eurozone, one of the most popular explanations, actually declined between 1998 and 1999, for example. Interest rate differentials, as measured by long-term interest rates, have shown no substantial change since 1996, although there has been some fall (in favour of the euro) since mid-1999. The short-term rate differential of 2% since mid-1999 should have corresponded to a 2% appreciation, not substantial depreciation, of the euro against the dollar.

Professor Portes, president of CEPR, says the only convincing story is that the currency's value has been determined by the psychology of the market, a nebulous confluence of factors, including mistrust of euro-area stability, inconsistency on the part of the European Central Bank and misplaced concern about the fiscal positions of countries such as Italy. Now that sentiment has changed, after signs that the US may be going into recession, the question is: where does the euro go next?

The euro-dollar exchange rate has been marking time in the past few weeks and has yet to break through 96 cents, but no foreign exchange market rally ever occurs in a straight line. With the outlook for economic growth in the US darkening and growing correspondingly brighter in the EU, most analysts expect the euro to reach parity with the dollar before long, but several believe it could fall later in the year if it becomes clear that the US has achieved a soft landing.

Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, believes that the euro is likely to appreciate by much more than many think, however.

Based on the assumption that, in the long run, exchange rates are determined by the size of a country's sustainable current account deficit, he calculates that the euro's fair value against the dollar is 1.25. That is the rate needed to bring down the huge, and still growing, US current account deficit, which is on course for a record $500bn (£347bn), equivalent to 5% of GDP, far bigger than it got in the 1980s when concern about the size of the deficit triggered a 50% fall of the dollar.

By Bergsten's calculation, the dollar still has some 20-25% to fall against the euro. The only question is how it gets to its equilibrium level. The big danger, he argues, is that it will happen suddenly, precipitating the hard landing which Alan Greenspan is working so hard to avoid.

A crash in the value of the dollar would push up inflation and interest rates and bring the fragile stock market to its knees.

Dr Bergsten's best guess is that the underlying strength of the US economy, manifested in higher productivity growth, will keep GDP expanding by about 2-3%. At half the rate of the peak of the boom, it will feel like a recession, especially when unemployment starts rising, even if it does not meet the technical criteria for one - two successive quarters of falling output.

As the story of the euro has shown, market psychology can always take over as the driver of currency valuations in the short term and there will be plenty of opportunities for sentiment towards the dollar to take a turn for the worse.

Not least the trade tensions which are likely to break out as unemployment in the US starts to rise. Under the surface, the EU and US are at each other's throats on a variety of issues, from hormones in beef to the labelling of GM food, and it will not take much for those disagreements to burst out into a bloody trade war. If that happens, the dollar could go into freefall.

Larry Summers probably won't see it this way, but there are some compensations for handing over the reins of the world's biggest economy to Paul O'Neill, the new US treasury secretary. With almost no experience of international finance, he will need all the luck he can get to stay on the right side of the forex market.

That is the rate needed to bring down the huge, and still growing, US current account deficit, which is on course for a record $500bn (£347bn), equivalent to 5% of GDP, far bigger than it got in the 1980s when concern about the size of the deficit triggered a 50% fall of the dollar. By Bergsten's calculation, the dollar still has some 20-25% to fall against the euro. The only question is how it gets to its equilibrium level. The big danger, he argues, is that it will happen suddenly, precipitating the hard landing which Alan Greenspan is working so hard to avoid. A crash in the value of the dollar would push up inflation and interest rates and bring the fragile stock market to its knees. Dr Bergsten's best guess is that the underlying strength of the US economy, manifested in higher productivity growth, will keep GDP expanding by about 2-3%. At half the rate of the peak of the boom, it will feel like a recession, especially when unemployment starts rising, even if it does not meet the technical criteria for one - two successive quarters of falling output. As the story of the euro has shown, market psychology can always take over as the driver of currency valuations in the short term and there will be plenty of opportunities for sentiment towards the dollar to take a turn for the worse. Not least the trade tensions which are likely to break out as unemployment in the US starts to rise. Under the surface, the EU and US are at each other's throats on a variety of issues, from hormones in beef to the labelling of GM food, and it will not take much for those disagreements to burst out into a bloody trade war. If that happens, the dollar could go into freefall. Larry Summers probably won't see it this way, but there are some compensations for handing over the reins of the world's biggest economy to Paul O'Neill, the new US treasury secretary. With almost no experience of international finance, he will need all the luck he can get to stay on the right side of the forex market.

webTitle: Rally driver loses son and daughter as family helicopter crashes

fields.headline: Rally driver loses son and daughter as family helicopter crashes
fields.trailText: Leading Northern Ireland rally driver Bertie Fisher and his wife were critically ill in hospital today after a helicopter crash in which their son and daughter were killed.
fields.body:
Leading Northern Ireland rally driver Bertie Fisher and his wife were critically ill in hospital today after a helicopter crash in which their son and daughter were killed.

Mr Fisher's private helicopter went down a short distance from his home a few miles outside Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh.

Air accident investigators were at the scene carrying out an investigation to try and discover what went wrong.

The helicopter crashed in a small copse of trees beside a country lane, causing extensive damage to the cockpit.

RUC Superintendent Eddie Graham said: "Mr Fisher was an accomplished pilot and at this stage we don't know why the aircraft went down. It is a tragedy that two of his children were killed."

Mr Fisher and his wife Gladys, together with another son, were taken to the Erne Hospital in Enniskillen for treatment.

An army helicopter based in the town was scrambled to collect a medical team from the hospital and take them to the scene of the crash at Monea, five miles from Enniskillen on the road to Derrygonnelly.

It then made two trips to ferry the injured to hospital where Mr and Mrs Fisher were later reported to be in critical conditions and their other son stable.

A local GP pronounced the Mr Fisher's son, Mark, 27 and daughter, Emma, 25, dead at the scene.

The Northern Ireland environment minister and Fermanagh man Sam Foster, who knows the Fisher family, expressed his sadness.

"The community is in deep shock," he said. "This was a well known family in the Fermanagh area and further afield. "They are a highly respected, decent, responsible family. This is a devastating blow."

Police investigators said they want to hear from anyone who may have seen or heard a helicopter in the Monea or Derrygonnelly area during the afternoon to contact them.

webTitle: Daniel Libeskind, the man behind Berlin's Jewish Museum

fields.headline: Star man
fields.standfirst: Daniel Libeskind is the man behind Berlin's Jewish Museum - built like a broken star of David - and the V&A's Spiral.  Jonathan Glancey  tracks his work from drawing board to cityscape
fields.trailText: Daniel Libeskind is the man behind Berlin's Jewish Museum - built like a broken star of David - and the V&A's Spiral. Jonathan Glancey tracks his work from drawing board to cityscape
fields.body:
To see a world in a grain of sand

And a heaven in a wild flower

Hold infinity in the palm

of your hand

And eternity in an hour

These haunting lines of William Blake wove through my mind as I peered into the initially baffling drawings by Daniel Libeskind in the tiny jewel of an exhibition at Sir John Soane's Museum in London. Libeskind, one of the most intelligent architects at work in the world today and famous for the extraordinary Jewish Museum in Berlin, began his architectural investigations long before he built, drawing complex ideas for structures that might never, could probably never, exist. These "micromegas" - vast, labyrinthine ideas compressed into small sheets of paper - were first exhibited in 1979.

Who, looking at these iconoclastic drawings with their clashes of right angles and fractal geometry, could have seen the kernel of the Jewish Museum, or the outpost of the Imperial War Museum now being built in Manchester, or the planned Spiral extension of the Victoria & Albert Museum? Some may have seen references to the work of the revolutionary Russian Constructivists - maybe Libeskind's drawings were a homage to El Lissitsky or Kasimir Malevich. Or maybe, switching countries, to the Dutch graphic artist MC Escher, whose drawings abound in contrary perspectives.

Libeskind's early drawings are clues to his highly personal approach to architecture. Difficult to interpret at first, second and third attempts, they represent a search for that which ultimately cannot be spoken about, cannot be described. This is neither as odd nor as negative as it might sound; rather it relates to the prophetic strain of Jewish mysticism that informs Libeskind's work, according to Charles Jencks, writing in the exhibition catalogue: "Especially the notion of the unutterable or unspeakable."

The search for the unutterable has driven many artists, musicians and poets. But it might seem an impossible task for an architect, given that any idea must ultimately be forged in three all too solid and knowable dimensions. Equally, a philosopher might not make the best architect, although Wittgenstein (best known for his much-quoted dictum "What we cannot speak about, we must pass over in silence") had a go with a house for his sister in Vienna. And yet the Jewish Museum has proved that architecture can represent the idea of the unutterable or unspeakable.

There are two spaces in the building that capture this mood: the concrete void that runs through the museum, and the Holocaust Tower, which, seen from inside, vanishes into a trick of light. Both spaces have that quality shared by the innermost sanctum of Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem (razed by the Romans in 70AD): an absence. At the core of the temple God was represented by an empty space.

But let's come back to earth, or at least the Breakfast Room of the Soane Museum. Here, on a mirror-topped table in one of the most beautiful rooms in any house anywhere in the world, sits a collection of exquisite models of Libeskind's buildings. This is a lovely conceit. The models - including the Jewish Museum, the Imperial War Museum and the Spiral - are micromegas, just like the drawings on show elsewhere in the Soane. Here the originals' complexity is reduced into miniatures that appear to be realised in gold and silver, bronze and lead. Big buildings sit happily inside a small breakfast parlour. "The magic of the Breakfast Room," says Libeskind, "makes me think of Alice in Wonderland, which boldly proposed that every day before coming to breakfast, one should have constructed seven unprecedented ideas."

This breakfast room is, you may have guessed, the perfect setting for an exhibition of Libeskind's work. This domed and mirrored interior is one special part of the labyrinthine house-as-museum designed and built by the brilliant, if tortured, Soane, one of Britain's most inventive architects. The museum, with its phantasmagorical collection of architectural models and plaster casts, is, on one level, a kind of cross-section or representation of Soane's poetic mind. It contains multitudes, a play of spaces that inspire as well as deceive. In this house (well, three houses knocked together), Soane compressed his novel ideas concerning space and architecture, his quest for the poetry of architecture.

Libeskind's architecture is similarly complex, and the visitors' book at the Soane suggests that those encountering his ideas, his drawings, his models, are either uncritical enthusiasts or baffled sceptics. Of course, Libeskind has been influenced by many of the great architects of the 20th century. Yet his is a brave attempt to reinvent architecture - and one that has succeeded beyond all expectations. "What is new in his architecture and drawing," says Charles Jencks, "is the intensity and density of contradiction and the tilting of the ground plane . . . But within this disorder there is in-between space or liminal space." What does he mean by liminal space? "In architecture," Jencks explains, "it is that of the labyrinth, while in society it is that of the theatre and ritual." It relates to the moments that change your life, such as funerals or weddings, when "space-time loses visual coordinates and becomes liminal or endless". It is a blurring into infinity or God.

If Blake approached this liminal space through a web of complex engraved poetry, Libeskind's route was his matrix of drawings, models and writing. He reminds us, in an age of so much slick, fashion-driven, soulless architecture, that one of architecture's goals has been to connect heaven to earth, humankind to God. This is a very Biblical view of architecture, but then Libeskind is steeped in the Bible.

God only knows how much faith Libeskind ever had that his micromegas would one day become the "megamicros" that have been built in Berlin and Osnabrück (the Felix Nussbaum Haus) and are either being constructed or planned for Manchester (Imperial War Museum North), Denver (an extension to Denver Art Museum) and London (the Spiral). The last of these has been awaiting the appointment of a new director at the V&A. Should this be Timothy Clifford, it is likely to remain a "micromega"; if one of the three other candidates, its destiny is as a building to intrigue and delight.

The show at Sir John Soane's Museum is one way of getting into Libeskind's fecund mind. If you still can't make sense of it, try walking around the museum itself, and then booking a ticket to Berlin.

fields.headline: Things get worse for 'bizarre' Kilshaws
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: If Judith and Alan Kilshaw thought the worst was over, they were wrong. Not only have their adopted babies been removed by social services, but every day brings fresh revelations about their unconventional lives from former colleagues, neighbours and relatives.
fields.body:
If Judith and Alan Kilshaw thought the worst was over, they were wrong. Not only have their adopted babies been removed by social services, but every day brings fresh revelations about their unconventional lives from former colleagues, neighbours and relatives.

Bizarre allegations of magic rituals and amateur artificial insemination in their front room were splashed across yesterday's papers, fuelling concern about their appropriateness as parents - to their sons Rupert and James, as well as the twin sisters.

The couple are preparing to fight social services in court on Tuesday for custody of the twins, Kimberley and Belinda, who they adopted over the internet from an American single mother. Keith McDonogh, director of education and children's services at Flintshire council, said: "We are aware of reports which are beginning to focus on the situation of the boys... we are monitoring the well being of all the children."

Tabloids yesterday claimed that Mrs Kilshaw, 47, had threatened to use magic to get the twins back, although she denied the claim. Former business partners and tenants said she had issued death threats following rows.

Her daughter Louisa from her first marriage, claimed the couple had begged her to act as a surrogate mother. When Louisa said she was already pregnant, her mother apparently told her to get an abortion and charged her £50 a week to live in an unheated caravan. Mrs Kilshaw said yesterday that she would never speak to her daughter again.

With her instinct for making a bad situation worse, she told a reporter that she had had argued with her husband. "We nearly came to blows. I was saying to Alan that he hadn't defended me enough."

In another statement likely to invoke the local authority's wrath, she said: "I will not be sending my two sons to school tomorrow because I'm afraid they'll be bullied."

Yesterday's stories would seem incredible if any other family were involved. But the new claims seem run-of-the-mill for the couple. Alan Kilshaw, a 45-year-old solicitor, is as eccentric as his wife. He was the home affairs spokesman for the hard-right Democratic party. He happily confirmed that he was encouraging Hollywood to turn their story into a film and is allegedly trying to recoup some of the £24,000 spent getting the girls out of the US.

The couple's former childminder said their farmhouse in Buckley, north Wales, was "covered with dog muck", but the couple said the only problem was that it was haunted. They allegedly called in paranormal investigators.

Their self-belief seems to have blinded them to the impression they are creating. Mrs Kilshaw herself told a paper that she had impregnated a female friend using Mr Kilshaw's sperm. Little wonder that, as she complained this weekend, she says, "I am going to have to live with this for the rest of my life".

fields.headline: Believe it or not
fields.standfirst: Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: Why juries for libel? Originally it was felt that the loss of a person's reputation was something that could best be understood by "ordinary" people from the same community as the defamed person. Only they could appreciate whether or not certain words affected a victim's standing, and by how much - a judge was too remote from the people to understand the nuances of their reputations. But it's a long time since those suing came from the same groups as those sitting in judgment.
fields.body:
Why juries for libel? Originally it was felt that the loss of a person's reputation was something that could best be understood by "ordinary" people from the same community as the defamed person. Only they could appreciate whether or not certain words affected a victim's standing, and by how much - a judge was too remote from the people to understand the nuances of their reputations. But it's a long time since those suing came from the same groups as those sitting in judgment.

When libel became a plaything of the rich and famous the gulf between juries and plaintiffs became huge. Juries often seemed to have no idea of how to assess whether there had been defamation in the first place, let alone the amount of compensation. That's why, up to a decade ago, such ludicrous damages awards were dished out by juries who didn't know what they were doing.

Now that the appeal court can reduce excessive compensation and the trial judge can firmly guide juries as to the sums to be awarded, their influence on the financial side has greatly waned. That leaves them the job of deciding whether or not there has been a libel, which is often reduced to a question of whom we believe: Bruce Grobbelaar, Neil Hamilton, Gillian Taylforth, Jeffrey Archer - or their opponents? That's a decision that juries are fully capable of taking (they do so all the time in criminal cases). But so are judges.

I don't think there's anything to choose between them on gullibility; I'm sure judges are just as capable of being taken in as juries, and of getting it wildly wrong on occasion. Should libel juries be abolished? Probably, but not because one jury went wrong in the Grobbelaar case. The valid reason is because they no longer serve their purpose.

I 'm pleased that the lord chancellor won his appeal against a tribunal ruling that he'd been guilty of sex discrimination by appointing his friend Garry Hart as a special adviser. True, the post wasn't advertised and wasn't opened to competition. No women applied because there was no application process. On the surface, every rule in the do-it-right book was smashed. Hart, a solicitor was appointed because Lord Irvine knew him, trusted him and would listen to him.

Those criteria did not apply to any potential woman adviser, nor indeed to any other man. Hart got the job because he was Hart. Had there been a job advertisement, it would have said: "No one who isn't Garry Hart need apply."

Of course, in general, jobs of influence in government ought not to be dished out privately, and I'm sure that too many ministerial advisers benefit from patronage. But it should also be allowed - in limited circumstances - for a senior minister to appoint someone not on qualifications and CV, but on personal grounds.

We saw a lot of a Boston courtroom when Louise Woodward's trial for murder was televised. The city's on our screens again in Boston Law (BBC1). I hoped it would be like LA Law, full of randy lawyers who compulsorily slept with their clients and impossibly good- looking advocates litigating unbelievable cases. But Boston Law, in contrast, is a fly-on-the-wall documentary on the criminal trial system. Judges, prosecution and defence lawyers, witnesses, the accused, and various others involved are filmed and talked to. They're remarkably open and honest in telling the camera what they're doing and feeling. The result is riveting. This isn't, though, a plea that the cameras should have similar open access here. What makes gripping programmes isn't necessarily good for justice.

I 'm often surprised by how few English barristers use their insider knowledge to write courtroom thrillers. Dexter Dias keeps up a good standard, but a couple more in whom I had hopes seem no longer to be writing. There's a reason for the paucity - lawyers find it difficult to express themselves on the page in ordinary English. I've read scores of book manuscripts and articles sent to me by lawyers who want to write; they have real difficulties in translating their expertise into readable language. So I was delighted to read a thriller that doesn't just portray the legal system accurately, but is sparklingly written, with believable dialogue and a lively plot. Elizabeth Woodcraft, the author of Good Bad Woman (HarperCollins), is a member of Michael Mansfield's chambers, so she knows her stuff. The story's about a lesbian barrister who, after representing a friend on a minor charge, finds herself, as one does, suspected of murdering a complete stranger, who'd been sitting in the courtroom. I hope Woodcraft writes more.

fields.headline: Website prosecutions 'would not work'
fields.standfirst:
Despite concern over baby-trading on the net, service providers say full regulation or court action could not be enforced

More net news
fields.trailText: The government's intention may be good, but the news that the Department of Health has told internet providers they could be prosecuted for relaying information that breaks British adoption rules was last night greeted with scepticism and cynicism.
fields.body:
The government's intention may be good, but the news that the Department of Health has told internet providers they could be prosecuted for relaying information that breaks British adoption rules was last night greeted with scepticism and cynicism.

Leading industry figures and experts believe that the nature and scale of the internet, as well as the status of those who provide access to the web, will make it impossible to enforce the rule.

They also point to a European directive, expected to come into force in Britain in the next two years, which defines internet service providers (ISPs) merely as conduits for information who cannot be responsible for content. This rule would seem to contradict the warning.

The Department of Health also came under fire for failing to consult the industry properly before sounding its warning and it is bound to be heavily criticised by civil liberties campaigners who will see the development as another attack on free speech.

ISPs have three main functions. They provide access to the web, so theoretically they could stop particular sites being reached. But they say that would not be feasible as it would require almost unlimited resources. And banning a site would give it notoriety prompting many more people to look at it. The British government also cannot try to shut down a foreign website at source because it would have no jurisdiction to do so.

The second main function of the ISPs is to provide "hosted web space" for websites. ISPs do have more control here, but even a small website may have 20 pages. So if an ISP hosted just 100 websites, it would have 2,000 pages to monitor.

Third, the ISPs provide news groups, or bulletin boards where articles can be posted. An article posted with an ISP's news group - for example, on adoption - will be picked up by linked news groups run by other ISPs worldwide. Checking everything on the news groups would be impossible.

What will particularly annoy the ISPs about the government's warning is that they are considered world leaders in self-regulation. ISPs are not licensed and do not have to register anywhere. But about 130 internet firms in the UK are members of the Internet Services Providers Association, which has been at great pains to provide a code of practice aimed at addressing the problem of illegal material. Formed in 1996, the Internet Watch Foundation (IWF) also works with the internet companies, the police and government, to tackle problems such as child pornography sites.

There appears to have been little consultation between the Department of Health and the industry. The IWF heard about what was afoot only when officials from other government departments began ringing it late last week.

Both the IWF and ISPA believe that the Department of Health's approach is flawed.

David Kerr, IWF's chief executive, said: "I think it's been generally accepted by ministers and the police that internet service providers don't and can't be expected to know what's on their servers. The department seems to be ignoring this basic point. This tactic is very unlikely to work and will put the department in conflict with the industry in the UK and in the rest of the world."

Mr Kerr said the industry had tried to stop material appearing on the web which would be illegal to publish in other forms in the UK - for example, child and extreme adult pornography. Although ISPs cannot monitor all the material passing through, once they are told about such material, they can remove it.

But another huge complication is the status of the ISPs. Many argue that they are not publishers but facilitators. The possible counter-argument, that they are indeed publishers because they own the servers carrying the material, has not been explored in the courts.

There are few precedents. Last year a New York lawyer sued the net firm Prodigy after an impostor sent obscene messages purporting to come from his 15-year-old son. The state's highest court threw out the claim, arguing that "an ISP, like a telephone company, is merely a conduit", and was backed by the supreme court.

Here, however, Mr Justice Morland decided in the high court that the internet company Demon Internet was liable for defamatory comments published about the physicist Laurence Godfrey - whose argument was that the ISP had become a publisher when it did not remove the comments.

Campaigners for free speech point out that some British ISPs now remove a comment, however fair and legitimate, as soon as they get a complaint rather than risk being sued.

Speaking after the Godfrey case, Mark Stephens, a media lawyer and vice-chair of the IWF, anticipated a flurry of litigation unless the laws were clarified. "In America ISPs have immunity over the content they provide access to and that must be the situation here. Otherwise, you'll have a legal free-for-all with libel writs flying left, right and centre."

He was right. A radical gay magazine's website, an anti-censorship site and one which highlighted miscarriages of justice, have all fallen victim to the uncertainty. Some have moved sites to the US rather than risk prosecution here.

One leading industry figure said: "It sounds as if the Department of Health has leapt into this without thinking the thing through. A lot of people in the industry are going to be puzzled and angry."

webTitle: Families of vCJD victims to get interim payout

fields.headline: Families of vCJD victims to get interim payout
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Families of victims of the human form of BSE are expected to be awarded interim compensation payments that may run up to £25,000 each.
fields.body:
Families of victims of the human form of BSE are expected to be awarded interim compensation payments that may run up to £25,000 each.

The government will announce stop-gap payments within a few days, while negotiations continue over longer term arrangements with the families' lawyers.

Sources yesterday could not confirm exact sums but the government is known to be anxious to show it is moving on the politically sensitive issue. Eighty-three people in Britain have died from variant CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). Five, identified as probable victims, are still alive and another six cases are under investigation.

Ministers have accepted the need for "no-fault" compensation to avoid courtroom battles, and as a possible model their advisers point to a trust that compensates people with Aids or HIV - a fund that since 1987 has paid out nearly £100m.

A fund of £1m, to improve coordination of care for CJD patients, exists. But the Treasury, increasingly nervous over the sharp acceleration in cases, will be reluctant to sign any open-ended commitment.

An announcement on interim compensation is expected as part of the preliminary government response to the BSE inquiry report, published in October, which calls for sweeping changes in the way Whitehall responds to such human health threats.

David Body, a lawyer for the families, said: "If there is to be an interim payment it will be most welcome. There are people who would benefit, and this would come on top of good work that has resulted from setting up the care package."

He added that talks were still a long way from establishing compensation arrangements robust enough to last for years.

Malcolm Tibbert, chairman of the Human BSE Foundation, whose wife, Margaret, was an early victim, said: "We are all desperate to find out what is going to happen. No amount of money can replace those who have died, but we have to be realistic, and there are a lot of people out there who have children to bring up and their future has to be secured.

"The sooner the government comes up with a formal offer, and we can see if it is acceptable, the better."

Many victims' families are frustrated at the time the government has taken to respond to their formal lodging of the court action, although Whitehall has always said it had to wait for the inquiry report, which was published nearly three years after it began taking evidence.

But families point out that farmers have been paid huge compensation sums for BSE.

webTitle: Testing at animal lab may grow under US backers

fields.headline: Testing at animal lab may grow under US backers
fields.standfirst: Drug firms pledge contracts after ministers broker rescue deal for Huntingdon Life Sciences
fields.trailText: Drug firms pledge contracts after ministers broker rescue deal for Huntingdon Life Sciences.
fields.body:
Even more experiments could be carried out on animals at Huntingdon Life Sciences as a result of the government-brokered deal for US backers to guarantee the company's future, it was revealed yesterday.

British drugs companies have pledged to channel multi-million pound contracts to the laboratories in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, and Occold, Suffolk, and there was speculation last night that some contracts may come from government-funded schemes.

The pledges by pharmaceutical companies are understood to be the result of the government's role, particularly that of the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, in the HLS saga. The future of the company was even discussed during cabinet meetings last week as the extent of its financial woes became apparent.

Lord Sainsbury is thought to have played a central role in brokering a rescue package for the laboratory, which faced closure after a £22m loan fell due for repayment on Friday.

Royal Bank of Scotland - owed half of the £22m, for which it accepted £1 - is now no longer connected to the loss-making company after new backers were found in the US. Their identity is being kept secret to deter animal rights activists from the intimidation that has led a stream of financial backers to turn their backs on the firm. Yesterday the activists, who were again out in force, insisted it would take them only a few weeks to discover their identities.

While finding new financial backing for HLS, which has not made money in three years, was important, securing commitments from the pharmaceutical industry for new contracts to test drugs under development on animals is also thought to have been essential for HLS's future.

A spokesman for the Association of British Pharmaceutical Industry said: "Pharmaceutical companies will continue to provide work through the granting of future contracts, and support HLS in the development of new medicines."

While Brian Cass, managing director of HLS, insisted that orders had risen 38% in the past two years, he admitted that the recent uncertainty about its future had led to slump in business.

The identity of the firms preparing to push business HLS's way was unclear last night, although in the past it has claimed that 75% of the top pharmaceutical companies have provided it with work. Glaxo SmithKline is known to be one of them.

Lord Sainsbury said: "The UK has a well-justified reputation for medical research. This in some cases requires the use of animals. HLS is one of only a few organisations in the UK able to carry out high-quality and well-regulated work on animals. If HLS had closed, many jobs, including those of 400 scientists, would certainly have gone abroad, and some pharmaceutical companies may subsequently have taken the decision not to do their medical research here."

The government made clear at the weekend that tests on animals should take place only where "absolutely necessary for medical research" and said it had stopped cosmetics testing on animals.

Yesterday more than 200 protesters demonstrated outside the Occold laboratory. They said they were trying to identify the companies that agreed to extend a £22m loan made by the Royal Bank of Scotland subsidiary NatWest, along with Allfirst, an American subsidiary of the Dublin-based Allied Irish Banks, and Comerica, based in Detroit.

Andrew Tyler, director of the charity Animal Aid, added: "The protesters will not go away. The money HLS has received this week has simply resuscitated them temporarily. The animal rights movement is very determined once it has a clear set of objectives which are just. I have no doubt that these American backers will be identified, and it is in the public interest that they are."

The new investors have granted a loan until June 30 2006, and injected cash into the business to keep it going. Their identity is described only as HLSF LLC.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two die in heliopter crash
fields.body:
Two die in heliopter crash

A son and daughter of Ireland's best known rally drivers, Bertie Fisher, 50, died when a helicopter he was piloting came down a few miles from Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh, yesterday.

Mark, 27, also a rally driver, and Emma, 25, a chiropodist, were killed, while Fisher, his wife Gladys, and another son, Roy, 23, were badly hurt. A military helicopter airlifted them to Erne hospital.

Ulster booby trap defused

The army yesterday defused a trip wire bomb at the police station in the Co Derry village of Claudy, allowing more than 60 people to return home. It came after police and army found 1,100lbs of explosive on the border outside Armagh; both are believed the work of republican dissidents.

March opposes offender hostel

Around 2,500 joined a march in Balham, south London, yesterday to oppose a hostel for former offenders, including paedophiles, proposed by a voluntary agency, the Langley House Trust, and the Inner London probation authority.

Police look into Shipman deaths

West Yorkshire police are investigating the deaths of three patients who died on the same day in Todmorden, where Harold Shipman worked as a GP in 1975. He was jailed for life last year for murdering 15 patients in Hyde, and Greater Manchester police are inquiring into 62 newly identified victims following the Baker report.

11-year-old will not stand trial

An 11-year-old boy charged with murder following the stabbing of a nine-year-old girl in Edinburgh last year will not face a court trial. The case will be dealt with by the children's panel, after he was found to have a mental age below criminal responsibility.

webTitle: Scots pound worth less in US

fields.headline: Scots pound worth less in US
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: An independent Scotland seemed closer yesterday on news that Scottish pound notes were changing hands at different rates to the English ones at a number of overseas bureaux de change.
fields.body:
An independent Scotland seemed closer yesterday on news that Scottish pound notes were changing hands at different rates to the English ones at a number of overseas bureaux de change.

The pound is being traded at Thomas Cook bureaux across North America at the different rates, depending on whether the notes are issued by the Bank of England or by one of the three Scottish banks authorised to do so, it was claimed.

A spokeswoman for Thomas Cook yesterday confirmed reports from baffled tourists that its North American money-changing centres regularly posted different rates for what they referred to as a "Scottish pound". At one point last Friday, its bureaux were offering travellers an exchange rate of 1.5949 US dollars to the English pound, and one of 1.5941 to the Scottish pound.

Thomas Cook's financial services HQ in Peterborough explained the discrepancy: Scottish notes cost more to ship to many parts of the world - including the US and Canada - than their English counterparts, because demand was much lower.

"If our American customers travelling to Britain insist on Scottish pounds - and some of them do - we will get them shipped over," the spokeswoman said. "But the rate purely reflects the fact that the costs involved are larger. It has nothing to do with the break-up of the pound."

However, a different explanation came from one confused employee of Thomas Cook North America this month when a Scottish tourist, curious about the differing rates, inquired as to the reason. He was reportedly told: "The English pound and the Scottish pound are different currencies, with different exchange rates."

In fact, tourist rates depend on global wholesale currency shipping rates and can often be considerably higher than the rates on the open market.

The Bank of Scotland was the first bank in Europe to successfully issue paper currency after beginning service in 1696.

There have been various threats to its right to issue notes, including an attempt by parliament in 1826 to prevent the issue of notes under £5. This was successfully opposed by Sir Walter Scott, whose portrait appears on Bank of Scotland notes.

webTitle: Angry parents undermine children's hospital care

fields.headline: Angry parents undermine children's hospital care
fields.trailText: Aggressive parents are undermining their children's hospital care by behaving in threatening and sometimes violent ways towards doctors, a survey has revealed.
fields.body:
Aggressive parents are undermining their children's hospital care by behaving in threatening and sometimes violent ways towards doctors, a survey has revealed.

Two in three paediatricians are subjected to severe verbal or physical abuse each year, and far more can recall at least one violent incident, the study suggests. It is based on responses from hospital doctors in the south Thames and north-west NHS regions and Northern Ireland.

It was found that one doctor had had a death threat and another had been warned that a paramilitary organisation might be called in to settle a dispute over a child's care.

Gerry Mackin, a doctor at the Little Acorns paediatric unit, Derry, who did the research, warns in an article in the journal Archives of Disease in Childhood that doctors' decision-making can be seriously affected by such behaviour.

"Verbal abuse and threats are often overlooked and are not usually reported to either hospital authorities or the police. Such events are often perceived to be part of the job... paediatricians, and junior paediatricians in particular, are at significant risk."

Dr Mackin interviewed 75 doctors, more than half of them women. He concludes that more training in how to manage aggressive patients and relatives is needed.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 300m-year-old forest found
fields.body:
300m-year-old forest found

Scientists are working to preserve a petrified tropical forest found at an open cast coalmine, they revealed yesterday. Fragments of more than 40 trees and bushes, dating from the Carboniferous period 300m years ago, when Wales was on the equator, were uncovered a month ago by diggers at the Darrell opencast site in the Dulais valley, Nant-y-Cefn, south Wales.

Clinton naming plan for M-way

Two Co Louth councillors have called for a 10 mile (17km) section of motorway between Belfast and Dublin, which opens officially on Friday, to be named the Bill Clinton highway in honour of the last US president's contribution to peace in Northern Ireland. His car was the first to use the stretch of road, between Dunleer and Dundalk.


Family home firebombed

A family of six were forced to leave their home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, when a petrol bomb was thrown through a window yesterday. No one was hurt but the house received smoke damage.


Scouts adopt new image

The Scout Movement has changed its 25-year-old logo and adopted a design (above) incorporating the phrase "Be prepared", it was announced yesterday. The new design boasts a "swoosh" with "Scouts" written inside. More than 46,000 people responded to a questionnaire on the design of new scout uniforms, which will be revealed next month and phased in over two years, as the modernisation programme continues.


MoD looks at sweaty feet

fields.headline: End of an idyll
fields.standfirst: Causeway blamed for island robberies
fields.trailText: The remote Hebridean island of Berneray, above, has always been the kind of place where doors are not locked, car keys can be left in the ignition, and there has never been a need for a burglar alarm. Until now.
fields.body:
The remote Hebridean island of Berneray, above, has always been the kind of place where doors are not locked, car keys can be left in the ignition, and there has never been a need for a burglar alarm. Until now.

A raid last week on the local store was the island's second recorded crime in its history, and islanders say a causeway built to link them to civilisation is to blame.

The causeway joining Berneray with nearby North Uist was opened in April 1999 by Prince Charles, who was said to be very taken with the island's community and the quiet rural lifestyle they enjoyed.

Last week thieves used the 200-yard long causeway to stage a raid on Ardmaree Stores and make off with £1,000 worth of alcohol and cigarettes. Nine months ago a small quantity of goods was taken from the same shop.

Police believe the recent culprits used a pick-up stolen from the nearby island of Benbecula.

"People on the island are very shocked at what's happened," said Inspector Ian Bryce of Western Isles police.

"They are not used to crime. One of the problems we have here is to persuade people to lock their doors or remove their keys from their cars. There is not even a burglar alarm on the island. There's never been a need for one."

Inspector Bryce said that locals believed the benefits of the causeway still outweighed the drawbacks. "However, it does show that crime can reach anywhere now, even Berneray."

webTitle: Efforts to block MI6 book look doomed

fields.headline: Efforts to block MI6 book look doomed
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Efforts by government lawyers to prevent British newspapers from disclosing the contents of The Big Breach, by the MI6 renegade officer Richard Tomlinson, are expected to collapse this week with the book's publication in Moscow.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor and  Ian Traynor  in Moscow
fields.body:
Efforts by government lawyers to prevent British newspapers from disclosing the contents of The Big Breach, by the MI6 renegade officer Richard Tomlinson, are expected to collapse this week with the book's publication in Moscow.

Further passages were posted on the internet yesterday, after publication at the weekend of an extract in Komsomolskaya Pravda, Russia's biggest-selling newspaper.

The website of Narodny Variant, a publishing house set up by Sergei Korovin, continued to maintain that the book would be launched in Moscow today. However, in machinations almost as intriguing as the contents of the book, Mr Korovin was not responding last night to phone calls or emails, coyly refusing to say when or where the launch would take place.

Internet orders are being taken for the book on Amazon and Narodny Variant websites.

Yesterday's extract on the internet described an undercover mission by Mr Tomlinson to Moscow in 1992, when he was allegedly told to "exfiltrate" unidentified "notebooks" at an international conference on doing business in Russia.

Komsomolskaya Pravda described MI6 training exercises at Fort Monckton, Portsmouth, including, Mr Tomlinson alleged, recruits being dropped off in the city centre and told to obtain the passport number of a member of the public.

The book is believed to contain accounts of operations already published, including allegations of how MI6 officers posed as journalists in the Bosnian civil war, had an agent in the German Bundesbank, and tried to infiltrate a suspected Iranian attempt to procure material for a chemical weapons plant.

What is new are accounts of MI6 operations which the agency says are damaging, though names of officers and agents have been changed.

In a court affidavit designed to prevent the Sunday Times from publishing further extracts from The Big Breach yesterday, an MI6 officer, identifed only as AH, said Mr Korovin also used the name Kirill Chashkin and used professional counter-surveillance techniques.

AH claimed that the publisher was "acting on behalf of Russian intelligence". Mr Tomlinson, who works in a bar in Rimini in Italy, last night described the claim as "pure MI6 fantasy".

He said he had been given a £28,000 advance for the book. His main motive in publishing it was "to get MI6 off my back... I've put all my cards on the table. They can come and get me or leave me alone."

Though Mr Justice Eady told the high court on Friday that it would be ridiculous to prevent the Sunday Times from publishing extracts of The Big Breach if it was widely accessible, he stayed his ruling pending an appeal, likely to be heard this week. On Friday night three appeal court judges declined to hear the case as there was no evidence the book was widely available.

Mr Korovin said he would distribute 10,000 copies in Russia, the US and Germany.

Russian media, holding the country up as the home of glasnost in contrast with the closed conditions in Britain, speculated that Mr Tomlinson, while operating as a secret agent in Russia in the early 1990s, may have been one of the couriers ferrying out KGB documents that formed the Mitrokhin archive, published in Britain 16 months ago.

If Russian foreign intelligence, the SVR, was behind Mr Korovin, Narodny Variant and The Big Breach, Russian media postulated, they could be seeking revenge on MI6 for the Mitrokhin revelations.

Whitehall sources denied that Mr Tomlinson had any role in the defection of Vasili Mitrokhin, the former KGB officer who gave MI6 details of Soviet penetration of the west.

webTitle: MI5 and MI6 win gagging order in Shayler trial

fields.headline: MI5 and MI6 win gagging order in Shayler trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Jack Straw and Robin Cook have signed public interest immunity certificates - court gagging orders - to prevent the activities of the security agencies being disclosed during the trial of the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.
fields.body:
Jack Straw and Robin Cook have signed public interest immunity certificates - court gagging orders - to prevent the activities of the security agencies being disclosed during the trial of the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

The home secretary and the foreign secretary warn that the damage they are trying to avoid could occur if the documents are opened to scrutiny. Mr Straw also insists the identity of all MI5 officers giving evidence be protected.

Lawyers yesterday warned that the trial might be abandoned if the judge objected to Mr Straw's demands.

The attempt by Mr Straw and Mr Cook to suppress the information on MI5 and MI6 will be strongly opposed by Mr Shayler's lawyers in pre-trial hearings due to start soon. The lawyers are expected to argue that MI5 officers will have to reveal the information, otherwise the jury will not be able properly to assess the damage to national security the prosecution claims has been done by Mr Shayler.

Mr Shayler is charged with breaking the Official Secrets Act by passing information to the Mail on Sunday in 1997. He is also charged with taking away MI5 documents. He says he exposed wrongdoing and that the secrets act is anyway incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

His trial is due to start at the old Bailey on April 23.

fields.headline: Target practice
fields.standfirst: President Bush is unlikely to let foreign objections get in the way of Republican plans for a new national missile defence system
fields.trailText: Now that he is inaugurated, how does President Bush intend to sell to a hostile world the new administration's plan to deploy a ground-based national missile defence (NMD) system that initially comprises 100 space interceptor rockets?
fields.body:
Now that he is inaugurated, how does President Bush intend to sell to a hostile world the new administration's plan to deploy a ground-based national missile defence (NMD) system that initially comprises 100 space interceptor rockets?

The answer given by Republican hawks is that he does not have to. American security interests are paramount. The US faces threats posed by the proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons of mass destruction and offensive missiles. Its government has a duty to defend itself against "states of concern" (the politer term that has replaced "rogue states") such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq and international terrorists. NMD is going to happen, say the hawks. Like it or lump it.

Secretary of state designate, General Colin Powell, former chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, will be NMD's top salesman. But in his new role as the chief US diplomat, he will also have to face the opposition. An effort will be made to persuade; selling NMD is likely to involve carrots as well as sticks.

Take Russia. President Vladimir Putin has been saying that NMD will create insecurity, breach the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty, disrupt strategic arms reduction talks (Start III) and provoke a new arms race. The US will reply that even if Start III were agreed, Russia would retain 1,500 to 2,000 deployed nuclear warheads and a non-operational stockpile of about 25,000. Russia has more than 1,100 operational intercontinental and submarine-launched ballistic missiles. It is also deploying the advanced SS-27 (Topol-M) intercontinental missile. This arsenal guarantees Russia's security and, in extremis, would easily overwhelm an NMD shield.

The argument continues: Russia cannot afford to maintain its current strategic forces, let alone augment them in response to NMD; thus a Start III agreement is greatly in Russia's interest. The ABM treaty, meanwhile, need not be scrapped, merely updated. Russia's immediate security concerns, for instance in dissuading Nato from expanding into the Baltic republics, could be adversely affected if it tried to block NMD. The country depends on IMF, World Bank and commercial bank lending. The US could pull the plug; indeed, Bush threatened last weekend to do just that.

The Chinese case is that NMD is yet another manifestation of America's threatening, "hegemonistic" tendencies. The US may reply that China has over 100 nuclear warheads and is making more. China already has at least 20 CSS-4 intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs) capable of hitting the US and is developing new ICBMs, such as the DF-31, and more sea-launch platforms. These forces could break through any NMD shield, so the principle of mutual assured destruction is maintained.

China is already engaged in a big arms build-up with a rising annual military budget now estimated at $60bn. Spending even more on defence will hinder economic development. (Hawks who view China as the next big threat to US global dominance actually hope this will happen). Chinese obduracy over NMD could strengthen pressure in Congress to sell new theatre missile defences to Taiwan.

China's successful entry into the World Trade Organisation, its large export trade with the US and its lucrative international arms business depend on smooth relations. It will be intimated that there is a threat of tougher scrutiny of its human rights record in, for example, Tibet.

Here in Europe Labour is divided on the NMD requirement of an upgrade to the American tracking station at Fylingdales, North Yorkshire. But the emerging line is that the UK will acquiesce if Russia and others agree. The Tories have given their unreserved support. Despite the threat of Greenham Common-style protests, the US probably expects to have little trouble getting the British on side. The UK is too dependent on intelligence and military hardware, as well as in broad political and economic terms, to defy Washington's will.

France, the other European nuclear power, is stridently critical of NMD. But Paris may be reminded that its pet project, the EU rapid reaction force, could face stiffening American and Nato opposition. French intransigence might also be linked by the US to continued American support for Balkan peacekeeping. As for Germany, Spain and the others, their opinion will make no difference, although Mr Powell will no doubt listen politely.

European allies may be assured that a phase-two NMD with 250 interceptors will protect their territories. At this point perhaps, for public-relations purposes, the chauvinist national missile defence tag may be swapped for something more "inclusive", such as "international" or "allied" missile defence.

In tandem with NMD development, the US will back the strengthening of international containment mechanisms such as the non-proliferation treaty, the missile technology control regime, the Wassenaar arrangement (on dual-use technology export controls), the chemical weapons convention and the biological and toxin weapons convention.

Some believe NMD's cost - $30bn rising to more than $60bn in phase two - and its unresolved technical problems will stop the US going ahead. They misunderstand what an overriding priority it has become in Republican-controlled Washington. President Bush and his generals are determined to get what they want.

 Simon Tisdall is the Guardian's foreign leader writer

webTitle: Liverpool goes green as cemeteries fill up

fields.headline: Liverpool goes green as cemeteries fill up
fields.trailText: Liverpool is to become the biggest council in the country to join the green burial movement as its conventional cemeteries face a lack of space.
fields.body:
Liverpool is to become the biggest council in the country to join the green burial movement as its conventional cemeteries face a lack of space.

The city has earmarked woods in the suburbs as an alternative to graveyards, after an audit showed that one of its six municipal cemeteries was full and two more would have to turn away burials within a few months.

Reflecting a national problem, only one cemetery in the city can accommodate a substantial number of new graves. With 30% of the population still opting for burial instead of cremation, room has to be found annually for 160,000 new burials - the equivalent of interring the population of Bournemouth.

The Liverpool project has been approved by the Liberal Democrat-controlled council, which has stipulated bio-degradable coffins and a minimum of disruption to the countryside. Saplings and tree-stumps will take the place of headstones and formal signings to the green graveyards will be modest.

A council spokesman said: "People are much more environmentally conscious nowadays, and there is a real interest in green burials, quite apart from our potential problems with space."

The scheme will start next month in woodland at Woolton, where ashes of cremated bodies will be buried. It will then expand to Allerton, where woods will be designated as green burial grounds.

Enthusiasm for "natural" burials grew last year when the novelist Barbara Cartland opted for a biodegradable coffin. There are now 130 green graveyards across the country and most are privately run.

The diocese of Ely in Cambridgeshire has introduced green burial services, the first official sign of approval by the church. Growth has also been helped by the low cost of green funerals with cardboard coffins costing an average £50 compared to £300 for traditional wood caskets.

webTitle: Police ask why mother should have killed herself and young sons

fields.headline: Police ask why mother should have killed herself and young sons
fields.trailText: A mother of two asphyxiated her young children and then apparently hanged herself in the garage, police said last night.
fields.body:
A mother of two asphyxiated her young children and then apparently hanged herself in the garage, police said last night.

The bodies of Laurance Gregory, 35, and her sons Arnaud, seven, and Antoine, 18 months, were found by her husband, Mark, when he returned to their home in St Austell, Cornwall, on Saturday evening.

Detective Chief Inspector Dave Dunne of Devon and Cornwall police said postmortem examinations yesterday had found that both boys died from asphyxiation. Their mother appeared to have taken her life by hanging.

Police inquiries would continue to ascertain what had happened to make Mrs Gregory "go down such a road as it would appear she has done," he said.

A single bouquet of flowers lay on the doorstep of the yellow semi-detached house where the family had lived for five years.

Mr Dunne said: "The husband arrived home. He was confronted with this scene which was terribly difficult for him to comprehend. He is devastated by what he has found."

Ms Gregory, who was French, worked as a lecturer at St Austell college. Neighbours described the couple as a "lovely family" whose children were often playing outside with their friends.

Catherine Barratt, who had to break the news to her four-year-old daughter, Charlotte, said: "They were very friendly. Arnaud was a really bright spark and bilingual. A lovely, polite kid. She (Mrs Gregory) must have been so sad for some reason."

Neighbours Tony and Margaret Greathead reacted with "disbelief". Mr Greathead said that days earlier Arnaud had put a handwritten letter through his letter box thanking them for Christmas presents.

"They were a very together family," he said. "We are very sad. They were a lovely, normal family who did things together."

Christine Spinney, a coordinator at the college where Mrs Gregory worked, said: "She taught my daughter A-level French a few years ago. It was a hard syllabus but somehow she managed to make it fun for them. She got on very well with the students and was very positive with them. She was a lovely person, very calm and friendly."

She (Mrs Gregory) must have been so sad for some reason." Neighbours Tony and Margaret Greathead reacted with "disbelief". Mr Greathead said that days earlier Arnaud had put a handwritten letter through his letter box thanking them for Christmas presents. "They were a very together family," he said. "We are very sad. They were a lovely, normal family who did things together." Christine Spinney, a coordinator at the college where Mrs Gregory worked, said: "She taught my daughter A-level French a few years ago. It was a hard syllabus but somehow she managed to make it fun for them. She got on very well with the students and was very positive with them. She was a lovely person, very calm and friendly."

fields.headline: Juries in jeopardy
fields.standfirst: Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: The court of appeal's unprecedented judgment in the Grobbelaar libel case is yet another signal that trial by jury no longer occupies a hallowed role within our system of justice.
fields.body:
The court of appeal's unprecedented judgment in the Grobbelaar libel case is yet another signal that trial by jury no longer occupies a hallowed role within our system of justice.

A careful analysis of the court's decision shows that these judges are substituting their view of the facts for the deliberations of three previous juries, two of whom could not agree (leading to Grobbelaar's acquittal) and one of whom found in Grobbelaar's favour on the civil burden of proof. Quite simply, the judges found Grobbelaar guilty, claiming that the jury were confused or hoodwinked by slick legal footwork.

This argument has been at the root of much opposition to trial by jury. It is predicated on the belief that ordinary jurors don't understand the niceties of the law and it should be left to the professionals. This was the thinking behind the Roskill Committee Report 1983-86, which recommended that fraud trials should be heard by a special three-man tribunal.

Alongside this has to be set the repeated attempts to end the right to choose trial by jury for hybrid offences affecting more than 18,500 defendants a year. So far, this proposal has been successfully blocked by the House of Lords. Despite this, the home secretary has committed the government to this policy, knowing that waiting in the wings is Lord Justice Auld's review of the criminal courts. All the signs are that this will result in yet more erosion of the jury by recommending that even more offences are tried by magistrates (recently renamed district judges). Well over 90% of crime is already tried in magistrates courts.

At the same time, this government wishes to accord the police and the state increased powers in the latest criminal justice and police bill published on Friday, without any concomitant transparency or accountability under official secrets legislation. If such measures are thought desirable then the greatest protection against abuse and the arbitrary exercise of power is a healthy input by ordinary citizens.

This has been strongly supported by notable jurists and commentators: "What makes juries worthwhile is that they see things differently from the judges, that they can water the law, and the function which they filled two centuries ago as a corrective to the corruption and partiality of the judges requires essentially the same qualities as the function they perform today as an organ of the disestablishment" - Blackstone lecture given by Lord Devlin (the Times, November 20 1978).

EP Thompson evoked a similar line in New Society in 1978: "The English common law rests upon a bargain between the law and the people. The jury box is where the people come into the court: the judge watches them and the jury watches back. A jury is the place where the bargain is struck. The jury attend in judgment, not only upon the accused but also upon the justice and humanity of the law."

While in opposition these were the views of Shadow Home Secretary Jack Straw, the shadow attorney general and the current attorney general. "Where the issue of dishonesty is involved the right to jury trial must be kept. It is cardinal." The argument now that they are in power is one of economy and efficiency.

Famous jury trials going back over the centuries have provided our system with a glowing example for the rest of the world. Whenever reference is made to fairness and justice it is the role of the jury which is put forward.

Although the Grobbelaar judgment is in the civil courts and there may be a separate debate to be had about the appropriateness of a jury for libel, the burden of proof in libel and the nature of libel laws, what this case demonstrates is the willingness of the judiciary to usurp the jury's role when it disagrees or when it finds a verdict perverse.

Does this mean that when juries acquit in a criminal case the prosecution will be able to argue that this was perverse and request the court of appeal to overturn it (currently prohibited)? This may seem far-fetched, but the government is already toying with the possibility of prosecution appeals and with the ending of the double-jeopardy rule.

The time has come to be clear. Either we want a democratic element maintained in our system or we don't. Either we trust the judgment of 12 ordinary citizens or we don't. Whenever individuals or the community are asked the response is overwhelming - citizens prefer trial of significant issues by their peers. What we have to ensure is that the material and protections for a jury trial are provided so that the 12 can make an informed and fair assessment of the facts. Proper resources, proper disclosure and an equality of aim are essential, not an approach which removes judgment and verdict to those who think they know better.

 Michael Mansfield QC is president of the National Civil Rights Movement

webTitle: Gary Younge: Lifting as you climb

fields.headline: Lifting as you climb
fields.standfirst: The success of a few black Americans, notably in Bush's cabinet, does not mean progress for the many
fields.trailText: There can be few better times to examine the legacy of Martin Luther King than the inauguration of the 43rd president of the United States. For the mixture of ethnic diversity and political conservatism in Bush's administration brings into sharp focus so much of what King said but which was rarely heard.
fields.body:
There can be few better times to examine the legacy of Martin Luther King than the inauguration of the 43rd president of the United States. For the mixture of ethnic diversity and political conservatism in Bush's administration brings into sharp focus so much of what King said but which was rarely heard.

For the most part, King's fight for equality is seen as beginning and ending with civil rights. You would think that his political relevance was over in 1963 with his "I have a dream" speech and that his dream ended with "sons of former slaves and sons of former slave-owners sitting down together at the table of brotherhood". True, King wanted a seat at the table. But he wanted to see the menu. Having led the battle to ensure that black people could eat in a restaurant of their choice, he knew that this important victory would remain academic if they didn't have the money to pay for the meal.

"In the past in the civil rights movement, we have been dealing with segregation and all of its humiliation; we've been dealing with the political problem of the denial of the right to vote," he said just a week before he died. "I think it is absolutely necessary now to deal massively and militantly with the economic problem."

His targets were moving from race to class, which is how it came to be that he was killed while in Memphis supporting a strike by dustmen over pay, conditions and union recognition.

The 60s were a heady and, at first sight, apparently contradictory time for African-Americans. On the one hand, in 1967, there were riots in Boston, Cincinnati, Tampa, Buffalo, Newark, Memphis, Detroit and Milwaukee. But a year later there were major breakthroughs. In Cleveland, Ohio, Carl Stokes was elected the first black mayor of a major American city. In Washington DC, Thurgood Marshall became the first black member of the US supreme court. But King stuck to the local dispute in Memphis because he knew that so long as progress remained with a few judges and mayors, then the sacrifices of the many would have enabled the success of just a few.

In the last speech he made he said: "Nothing would be more tragic than to stop at this point in Memphis. We've got to see it through. And when we have our march, you need to be there. Be concerned about your brother. You may not be on strike. But either we go up together or we go down together."

Which brings us neatly on to Bush's incoming administration. For while we can see, more than 30 years later, that black Americans did not go up together, it is also clear that they did not stay down together either. Illegally employed nannies and cleaners notwithstanding, Bush will have the most ethnically diverse cabinet in the history of America. Its secretary of state will be General Colin Powell, (Jamaican-American); the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice (African-American); the transport secretary, Norman Mineta (Japanese-American) and the energy secretary Spencer Abraham (Arab-American). Bush's conclusion on this is the following. "It shows that anyone who works hard in America can get on." Now, given the levels of incarceration, execution, unemployment, infant mortality and so on among African-Americans we know that is not true.

But that doesn't mean that the diversity in his cabinet is not a good thing. It is no good arguing for years that more black people are needed in positions of authority and then complaining when it happens. It does count that Bush has a diverse administration. If diversity is to be generally regarded as a good thing then diversity at the highest level of politics must be a good thing. It just doesn't count for much - yet.

Colin Powell provides an excellent illustration of why our expectations must be tempered. It's not because he's a Republican. Someone's got to be a Republican. African-Americans have spent years complaining about how the Democratic party takes their support for granted. Maybe this will force the Democrats to work that bit harder to woo their most loyal bloc of voters.

I have a problem with Republicans but I don't have a problem with Colin Powell being a Republican. He has as much right to be wrong-headed in his politics as anybody else. He should neither be spared criticism meted out to other Republicans or attract special criticism just because he's black.

But his professional and political rise does tell a story that is illustrative of a pattern in black America which we could easily see here.

First there is how he got there professionally. He got there through the army. And how did black people get to get ahead in the American army? Well of course they had to be good. That goes without saying. Regardless of the attempt that is made to link affirmative action with lowering standards, the truth is that more often than not black people still need to be twice as good as white people to get half as far. That is what racism is all about.

But being able never used to be enough. It took a threat by Philip A Randolph, the head of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, a black union for those who worked the railroads. In 1948, Randolph threatened to stage a march on Washington and a nationwide campaign of civil disobedience unless President Truman agreed to desegregate the armed forces. Truman reluctantly obliged. That's how America got to let black and white people mix while carrying guns before they would ever let them mix carrying schoolbooks or hamburgers.

Were it not for the unions and the civil rights movement, there would be no Colin Powell rising through the army. So I think we're going to need to see what he and his colleagues do about union rights and civil rights before we talk about whether his appointment is a real step forward for African-Americans.

The second story is how he got there politically. He owes his position to a man who won an election in which black people were systematically denied the right to vote. One-third of black men in Florida were not even able to register because they were convicted felons. Many others were simply turned away at the polls in Florida. About 90% of those who would have voted, if they could, would have voted for Gore. It is because they couldn't that George Bush won and could then nominate Colin Powell.

So Colin Powell got where he is professionally, thanks to the political struggles of those who went before him which won black people their civil rights. And he got where he is politically thanks to the loss of the civil rights of those who might come after him. The success of a few, does not always signify advancement for the many.

 This was extracted from the Martin Luther King lecture, sponsored by the Guardian, delivered on January 20.
