webTitle: Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs

fields.headline: Britain 'in crisis' on skills and filling jobs
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The industry minister Kim Howells conceded yesterday that Britain has a skills and recruitment crisis, partly due to a collective failure to train a modern workforce.
fields.body:
The industry minister Kim Howells conceded yesterday that Britain has a skills and recruitment crisis, partly due to a collective failure to train a modern workforce.

He also challenged the relevance to industry of much sixth form and university education. "I am worried by the skills gap," he said. "It is a real constraint on growth." He urged companies to become "much more involved in what is taught in education".

Mr Howells is preparing for a tour next month to promote greater corporate social responsibility, including a bigger commitment from companies to train and retrain their workforce. The prime minister asked him last year to take on the job.

The Cabinet Office is publishing a paper today on the scale of the skills gap and the role immigrants could play in meeting the shortages.

The report follows a call by the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, for a debate on whether immigration laws need to be relaxed in specific areas to plug the skills gap. The largely factual report from the performance and innovation unit shows that other countries are increasingly recruiting internationally.

Mr Howells said: "Even blue chip companies are finding the labour market so tight they are suffering serious recruitment difficulties. The Germans, French, Australians, Canadians and Americans are out in Bangalore trying to recruit IT specialists, especially software programmers, of which we are all very short. Everyone is trying to get hold of Java programmers and paying phenomenal wages for them".

For Britain simply to import foreign labour would be "a symbol of defeat" meaning that "we have not convinced enough of our people there are viable careers here and they should retrain for them.

"We should be looking at the way we educate our kids and the way we train and retrain our workforces so we don't experience these shortages. I don't think we are doing that properly. We have a lot more people staying on at sixth form and going to university, but what the hell are they studying?

"I am a believer in education of all sorts, but we have to focus much more sharply on where there are weaknesses in the economy and in the skills feeding those areas."

He said the government had only scratched the surface in urging greater social responsibility on companies. Such displays of commitment to the community would help them win in the recruitment war.

Claiming that Britain was close to becoming a full employment society, as defined by the economist John Maynard Keynes, he said there needed to be much more private sector involvement in formulating the best way to get young people to go into IT, and later on in retraining people.

"No matter what a company does, if it is associated with doing good, and the company is made stronger by motivating its employees, it becomes much easier to recruit people.

"The glamour and reputation that attach to companies that do beneficial work for the community help recruitment".

Mr Howells said he did not just want to encourage firms to do more to train their workforce, he wanted them to do more to help their communities - for instance, by sponsoring schools for expelled pupils.

He plans to identify the five most socially responsible companies in each region and publish examples of best practice.

Research showed that companies with a commitment to their workforce and community tended to attract greater consumer loyalty, he said.

fields.headline: Public day for Victoria's mausoleum
fields.standfirst: Rare opening to mark centenary of royal interment
fields.trailText: One of the most extravagantly decorated but least accessible of Victorian buildings, the Royal Mausoleum at Frogmore, near Windsor, is to have a rare opening early next month on the 100th anniversary of the interment of Queen Victoria.
fields.body:
One of the most extravagantly decorated but least accessible of Victorian buildings, the Royal Mausoleum at Frogmore, near Windsor, is to have a rare opening early next month on the 100th anniversary of the interment of Queen Victoria.

The building, a lofty domed edifice, lined with marble and granite and sumptuously coloured in reds and golds, houses the sarcophagus containing the bodies of the queen - who died 100 years ago today - and her beloved husband Albert, who departed nearly 40 years before her.

They lie together under their enormous marble effigies, the queen frozen in time as she appeared at the date of Prince Albert's death, rather than the small, plump, black-clad figure of her old age.

A platform is being erected so that the several thousand visitors expected on Sunday February 4 can get a clear view of the carvings, which are too high to be seen properly from ground level. Admission will be free.

"I suppose it is not everybody's idea of a day out, but it is a gem of a building and strangely moving in its way," said Hugh Roberts, director of the royal collection.

The scene of the queen's death, Osborne House on the Isle of Wight, will not be open today - although the grounds will be - because of renovations. As a mark of respect, English Heritage has asked the builders to lay off work that day.

The serenity of both places contrasts with the behind-the-scenes chaos that surrounded the old queen's death and funeral arrangements, belying any reputation Britain might have had for imperturbability in its imperial heyday.

A new book - The Victorian Celebration of Death, by James Stevens Curl - details the feuds, rivalries and sheer lack of readiness of the court for the 81-year-old queen's death.

Almost immediately the problems started. The honour guard did not know how to drill with reversed arms and started fainting, overcome by the scent of lilies around the coffin.

Then there was an unseemly row over responsibility for the funeral between the lord chamberlain, the earl marshal and the royal heralds, all of whom claimed the right, though none knew how a state funeral should be organised. The queen's equerry, Sir Frederick Ponsonby, was eventually put in charge.

When the cortege arrived at Windsor railway station some of the Royal Artillery horses due to pull the gun carriage bearing the coffin broke their traces, threatening to send the dead queen hurtling backwards down the hill, scything through half the crowned heads of Europe. Disaster was averted only when the escort party of naval ratings was ordered to take over the harness and haul the gun carriage into the castle - a tradition which has continued ever since - much to the fury of the Royal Artillery.

Even the interment was ac companied by family rows over who had received invitations, leading to Ponsonby - who had arranged the coffin's transport from Osborne without so much as a telephone - being furiously dressed down by the new king.

By all accounts of her sense of humour, Queen Victoria would have been amused.

Then there was an unseemly row over responsibility for the funeral between the lord chamberlain, the earl marshal and the royal heralds, all of whom claimed the right, though none knew how a state funeral should be organised. The queen's equerry, Sir Frederick Ponsonby, was eventually put in charge. When the cortege arrived at Windsor railway station some of the Royal Artillery horses due to pull the gun carriage bearing the coffin broke their traces, threatening to send the dead queen hurtling backwards down the hill, scything through half the crowned heads of Europe. Disaster was averted only when the escort party of naval ratings was ordered to take over the harness and haul the gun carriage into the castle - a tradition which has continued ever since - much to the fury of the Royal Artillery. Even the interment was ac companied by family rows over who had received invitations, leading to Ponsonby - who had arranged the coffin's transport from Osborne without so much as a telephone - being furiously dressed down by the new king. By all accounts of her sense of humour, Queen Victoria would have been amused.

fields.headline: Corporate killings
fields.standfirst:
Rail crash spurs a new prosecution bid

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Rail crash spurs a new prosecution bid
fields.body:
A second report, due tomorrow, by the health and safety executive into the Hatfield rail crash will make grim reading. The investigators found the unsafe line shattered into 300 pieces after the crash. The HSE is to urge the crown prosecution service to pursue manslaughter charges against a number of senior officials. Four passengers were killed in the crash. Earlier precedents suggest it will be difficult to achieve a conviction, but the HSE is right to push the CPS into proceeding. Corporate Britain has to be made more accountable for safety. Prosecution - with possible prison terms - is a far more effective way of making directors pay attention to safety than corporate fines that just get deducted from profits.

Of the 124 cases involving deaths which the HSE has referred to the CPS since 1992 for manslaughter charges, prosecutions were only initiated in 34, and guilty verdicts secured in only nine, all involving small companies. Responsibility in big companies has been ruled too diffused. The 1997 Southall train crash, in which seven people died and 150 were injured, was rightly referred by the HSE to the CPS, but manslaughter charges were subsequently dropped. Under the current law, companies can only be found guilty if the prosecution can show single individuals, or a "controlling mind" of the firm, was directly to blame. Corporate manslaughter has fallen between two stools: unable to prosecute the company because individual accountability has to be shown; unable to prosecute the individual because of a defused responsibility. Yet a recent high court ruling suggested the CPS had been applying too narrow a test on the existing manslaughter laws in relation to workplace deaths. The same narrowness could apply to rail crashes too. Ministers announced last May plans for a new offence of corporate killing, allowing companies to be prosecuted for collective management failure. But it has run into trouble with industry by requiring directors to be in the dock as well. The old law should not be over-looked.

Meanwhile, Hatfield survivors will be disappointed by a decision not to hold a public inquiry. They should hold their fire and see what happens to the prosecution - and to the Cullen inquiry into Paddington, which after Hatfield widened its safety brief. It will still be open to minister to hold an inquiry, if the two other avenues prove unsatisfactory.

fields.headline: Cancer blinds Kosovo veterans
fields.standfirst: Serb soldiers fear after-effects of exposure to Nato's depleted uranium shells
fields.trailText: Serb soldiers fear after-effects of exposure to Nato's depleted uranium shells.
fields.body:
Serbian doctors have found cancerous tumours in the eyes of two ex-soldiers who served with the Yugoslav army in areas of Kosovo where Nato fired shells containing depleted uranium last year.

"I have always had perfect eyesight and there is no history of cancer in my family," a diconsolate Milan Bisercic told the Guardian yesterday in the Belgrade hospital where he sat with a bandage round his head, covering the socket where his right eye used to be.

"A surgeon took it out on Thursday, the day after I was rushed here. I noticed my sight was going funny in December. It got steadily worse and in 25 days the right eye was virtually blind," he explained.

Still stunned by his sudden disability, he declined to be photographed.

In a neighbouring ward is Stanisa Zivkovic, another veteran of the Kosovo war whose sight has been struck by an unexplained cancer. Both men served in Urosevac in central Kosovo, one of 112 sites that Nato confirmed recently had been targeted by American planes using DU munitions.

The two men are the first confirmed cases of cancer among Kosovo veterans from the Yugoslav army, although there is no proof that their illnesses were caused by radiation from DU. Like Nato governments, the Yugoslav army has been trying to play down the effect of DU exposure on its soldiers.

The Milosevic regime, which was ousted last autumn, made a great propaganda play about Nato's use of DU, describing it as a war crime. But it never admitted that any civilian or soldier had been found with suspected radiation-caused illnesses.

The army checked 1,100 of the more than 100,000 soldiers who served in Kosovo, according to a senior medical source at Belgrade's military academy hospital, and says it found no problems.

"But the question is what kind of examination did they perform and what specialised equipment did they use," the Yugoslav army doctor said yesterday. He was not part of the team which checked the men.

A Belgrade weekly tabloid, Nedeljni Telegraf, reported last week that three officers from the Pristina Corps died of leukaemia in recent months and 10 other soldiers are ill with the disease; four of them terminally.

They were all stationed near Prizren, in areas of western Kosovo where Nato dropped many DU weapons because of a large concentration of tanks and armoured vehicles. They were deployed to prevent the Kosovo Liberation Army moving men in from Albania.

One man who died earlier this month was a member of the personal escort team for General Nebojsa Pavkovic, who commanded Yugoslav land forces in Kosovo throughout the war, according to the newspaper. The general is currently Yugoslav chief of staff.

The newspaper did not name any of the sick or dead veterans, and the Yugoslav army has denied the report.

While refusing so far to confirm any link between DU and sickness among soldiers and civilians since the Kosovo war, the authorities were quicker than Nato in ordering measures to protect people.

After reports in Italy and Portugal at the beginning of this month exposed unex plained cancer deaths among Nato soldiers, international peacekeepers only began last week to use warning tape to seal off sites in Kosovo where DU struck.

"We were asked to go down to southern Serbia long ago," Snezhana Pavlovic, the head of the radiation and environmental protection department at Yugoslavia's Vinca Institute of Nuclear Science, said. "Of course we have no access to Kosovo where most of the DU was used. But seven sites were struck in southern Serbia. We checked them for radiation and ruled out three. The other four contaminated areas have been sealed off."

Her team retrieved parts of DU-tipped shells from fields and hillsides. "Nato says it fired up to 3,000 DU rounds in southern Serbia. So far we've only found fragments from 100 shells," she said. "We are still trying to check the area more precisely."

Back in his hospital ward in Belgrade, Mr Bisercic recalls seeing the repeated Nato attacks on the barracks at Urosevac during his two months in Kosovo last year. He and other members of his scout unit were living in Albanian houses whose owners had fled or been expelled.

"I was never closer than 500 metres to the explosions, so I don't know why I should have got radiated more than anyone else, if that was what gave me cancer," he said.

"The surgeon said he could not prove the cause was DU. Until I read about it in the papers last week, I had never heard of DU."

A 36-year-old reserve officer from Brus, Mr Bisercic was called up and sent to Kosovo about a month after Nato started its bombing campaign.

The father of two used to work in a tractor factory in Krusevac. "My job involved using an oxyacetylene cutter on metal. I asked the surgeon if that could have caused the tumour," he said helplessly. "He thought it was impossible. So now I just don't know why I've lost my eye."

The head of the Greek Orthodox church, Archbishop Christodoulos, yesterday accused Nato of creating "ruins and catastrophes" in Kosovo. During a sermon after a one-day trip to visit Greek peacekeepers, the archbishop, an outspoken critic of the war, claimed the Nato attacks had destroyed life for Christian Orthodox Serbs in the province.

webTitle: Labour to play on the feel-good factor

fields.headline: Labour to play on the feel-good factor
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Violent crime is going up. Bodies are left in a hospital's chapel of rest. The railways are a shambles. Anyone watching the news could be forgiven for thinking that Tony Blair is counting down the days to electoral oblivion.
fields.body:
Violent crime is going up. Bodies are left in a hospital's chapel of rest. The railways are a shambles. Anyone watching the news could be forgiven for thinking that Tony Blair is counting down the days to electoral oblivion.

Yet if the polls are anything like right, Labour is on course for another landslide victory. May 3 is pencilled in for polling day, and the Westminster gossip is of which cabinet ministers will be culled to make way for the new blood coming up from the ministerial ranks. Barring an absolute catastrophe, Mr Blair will get his cherished second term and the reason is simple: voters may be unhappy about health, education and crime, but the real meat of an election campaign - the economy - is doing well enough to convince the electorate to give Labour another term.

William Hague has to be like Basil Fawlty in the sketch about the Germans. Talk about bodies in makeshift morgues, talk about police numbers - but don't mention the economy. It may work. After a while economic success becomes boring, barely worthy of mention and after eight years of growth news about jobs and prices gets pushed from the headlines.

But in political terms, this probably doesn't matter, with the most significant recent pointer to the election the finding that four out of five people believe that their personal and working lives are improving. Polls show that the feel-good factor in Britain is stronger than almost anywhere else in Europe.

As far as Labour is concerned, this is virgin territory. Although the economy continues to have many defects, there is not much for the Tory spin doctors to play with in the coming months. Labour as the party of runaway inflation? Forget it. Last year the government's preferred measure of the cost of living - which excludes mortgages interest payments - averaged 2.1%, the lowest since records began in the mid-70s. Labour as the live-now-pay-later party? Take a look at public finances, which will be in the black by about £15bn this year. Labour isn't working? Last week's figures showed the number of people out of work and claiming benefit falling to its lowest for 25 years, and with no sign that lower unemployment was leading to inflation-busting pay claims.

Golden inheritance

To be fair, not all the credit for this belongs to Labour. John Major handed over an economy in 1997 that was growing with unemployment falling and interest rates low. There was a healthier balance between manufacturing and services under Kenneth Clarke than under Gordon Brown. Labour has been lucky.

The international environment has been benign, with the world economy entering a period of stability after the inflation shocks of the previous 25 years. Previous Labour administrations were not so fortunate, although it is true that they then tended to compound their inherited problems through a combination of overambition and error. This time it has been different. One reason for the almost preternatural caution shown by the government in its first two years was the fear of screwing things up.

If it is a truism that good economies win elections, then it is an even bigger truism that economic crises lose elections, as Harold Wilson, Jim Callaghan and John Major all found out to their cost. Devaluations, runs on the pound, spending cuts, Black Wednesdays: these are things that lead to a changing of the political guard. The Blair administration has jealously guarded its golden inheritance.

Labour's safety-first approach would be more problematical were the Tories able to mount a realistic economic challenge. But none of the four shadow chancellors since 1997 have yet to lay a glove on Gordon Brown, and the 2001 election will be a rerun of 1987, where a government that was respected rather than loved was presiding over a strong economy and faced an opposition with a credibility problem. There is not a shred of evidence that voters trust the Tories to do a better job than Labour.

Flaunt it strategy

Politics being politics, the government may yet have a fight on its hands. Firstly, there is the risk that voters have become so used to the economy doing well that they decline to give the government any of the credit. The chance of this happening would be increased if Labour repeated the mistake made by Al Gore and refused to use the economy as the centrepiece of the campaign. Gore was reluctant to hang on to Bill Clinton's coat-tails: the argument is that Tony Blair will be reluctant to give Gordon Brown the credit for his re-election. Frankly, this seems highly improbable. The message from Labour's strategists will be that if you've got it, flaunt it.

Secondly, it is undoubtedly the case that the strength of the economy has been less evident in Labour's heartlands than in the more prosperous south of England. The number of people working in manufacturing has fallen by 100,000 over the past year as the strength of the pound has affected exports.

In 1970 there were three times as many people working in manufacturing as in financial services, but since then the steady haemorrhaging of jobs has meant that there are 20% more people employed selling financial products than in making things. Could Labour have reversed this secular trend? Probably not. Could it have done more? Its supporters in the regions think so. Looked at in cynical political terms, Labour's core constituency has only two choices: to vote for the government or stay at home. The idea that the election will be a walkover is not that helpful for the government, which needs the prospect of a Hague victory to put the frighteners on its supporters and hence ensure a reasonably high turnout.

Finally, Labour's re-election prospects could be affected by a serious downturn in the economy. Despite the recent good figures, clouds are gathering. Globally, the US is heading for a recession which will last for at least the first half of 2001 and perhaps beyond. Japan is poised to nose dive back into recession. Retrenchment in the world's biggest economies would have an impact on Britain even if there were no domestic problems looming. But the unemployment data suggests that there could be tougher times ahead. The number of people employed fell by 25,000 in the latest quarter, and using the internationally agreed measure of unemployment - which counts the number of people looking for work rather than those eligible for benefit - the jobless total has risen for the past two quarters.

The message for the government is straightforward. The economy is still the key to the election and it is looking good. But unemployment may start to rise on all measures during 2001 as growth slows. So, it should strike while the iron is hot and go to the country as soon as possible. Any delay could cost seats.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Suharto's son linked to bombs
fields.body:
Suharto's son linked to bombs

A woman suspected of planting bombs around Jakarta last week has accused the fugitive son of Indonesia's former dictator Suharto of ordering her to do so, police said yesterday.

Elize Maria Tuwahatu, 33, and other suspects, said Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Putra supplied the explosives, the police spokesman, Brigadier General Saleh Saaf, said. AP, Jakarta

Khatami aide faces charges

An Iranian hardline court yesterday charged a key ally of the reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, with slander for his alleged role in riots last August.

Mostafa Tajzadeh, a deputy interior minister, said that the court for civil servants had charged him with "slander and provoking people to disturb public security and order" during the riots in Khorramabad.

Mr Tajzadeh has come under fire from hardliners since his appointment in November to supervise this June's presidential elections. Reuters, Tehran

Rabbi calls for Papon's release

A noted Paris rabbi was quoted yesterday as saying that 90-year-old Maurice Papon, a former Vichy official convicted for deporting Jews during the second world war, should be released from jail because of his age and ill health.

Gilles Bernheim told the regional newspaper L'Alsace that Papon's trial and jailing were enough to have opened France's eyes to the role played by some Vichy officials in helping the occupying Nazis during the war. Reuters, Paris

China executes bus driver

Authorities in the western Chinese province of Xianjiang have executed a bus driver who hit and killed two pedestrians while driving at night with his lights off, the Xinjiang Daily said yesterday. AP, Beijing

fields.headline: New team halts Clinton agenda
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush has signalled a swift change from the Bill Clinton years by quashing executive orders issued by his predecessor and by getting to bed before midnight, even on inauguration day, a feat that would have been inconceivable for the hedonistic Mr Clinton.
fields.body:
George Bush has signalled a swift change from the Bill Clinton years by quashing executive orders issued by his predecessor and by getting to bed before midnight, even on inauguration day, a feat that would have been inconceivable for the hedonistic Mr Clinton.

Within hours of swearing the oath of office, Mr Bush authorised the new White House chief of staff, Andrew Card, to place an immediate moratorium on the implementation of as many of Mr Clinton's last executive orders as possible. The orders include health insurance guidelines, meat safety standards, environmental protection for wetlands and the designation of historical monuments.

On his first full day as president yesterday, Mr Bush was up early to attend a morning service at the Washington National Cathedral, before settling down to a series of briefings at the White House.

After a weekend of partying and praying to mark his inauguration, Mr Bush will quickly face the reality of the presidency in his first working day; a series of domestic and international issues, not all of them under his direct control, demand his attention.

In the Middle East, a new round of negotiations between the Israelis and the Palestinians are to take place in Egypt today, two weeks before an Israeli general election which could transform a region largely unfamiliar to the new president.

At the Pentagon, Mr Bush faces immediate pressure from service chiefs for extra spending on new weapons programmes, including the F-22 fighter. The Ballistic Missile Defence Organisation has also set out a schedule on national missile defence that requires Mr Bush to decide within weeks whether he will go ahead with the initial stages of a building programme in Alaska, which Russia regards as a breach of the anti-ballistic missile treaty.

In California, the nation's most heavily populated state, more than 20m Americans face a power shortage crisis with immense practical and political implications, not least for Mr Bush, who supports precisely the kind of public utility deregulation which caused the blackouts.

webTitle: Congolese mourn Kabila as his allies consider next move

fields.headline: Congolese mourn Kabila as his allies consider next move
fields.trailText: More than 1m people lined the streets of the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo yesterday to welcome home the body of President Laurent Kabila, who was assasinated last week, allegedly by a lone bodyguard.
fields.byline: James Astill in Kinshasa and  Chris McGreal, Africa correspondent
fields.body:
More than 1m people lined the streets of the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo yesterday to welcome home the body of President Laurent Kabila, who was assasinated last week, allegedly by a lone bodyguard.

Carefully planned scenes of public grief in Kinshasa turned into a mass demonstration of patriotic fervour, releasing the tension of an anxious four-day wait for the army's response to the killing.

In the Angolan capital, Luanda, the presidents of Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia - Kabila's military allies - met to decide a united approach to his killing and the war against rebels.

Diplomatic sources said southern African leaders were considering a full summit in Mozambique on Wednesday.

Angola has been keen to pull out of the conflict, and Namibia is drifting that way. But Zimbabwe is the main player in the war against foreign-backed insurgents, and it is President Robert Mugabe who will have the greatest say in Congo's immediate future.

Zimbabwean soldiers, the main force among foreign troops in Kinshasa, are in a position to put a stop to any challenge to the new regime or remove it themselves if they choose.

As a gun carriage bore Kabila's coffin from the outlying airport into Kinshasa yesterday, thousands of spectators fell into a jog behind.

"Mobutu died and now Kabila is dead too," they chanted, referring to the dictator overthrown by Kabila in 1997. "But we, the people, will run behind."

The interim president, Joseph Kabila, the dead leader's son, led the cortege from within a phalanx of soldiers as helicopter gunships buzzed overhead.

If the proclamations of grief seemed improbable, that impression was reinforced by a group of women at the airport gates, who were apparently receiving instructions on how to lament. When Kabila's body eventually emerged, a ripple of wailing tracked the cortege's progress. Women threw themselves into the road screaming and tearing at their hair.

"It's always sad when someone dies," said one of them, dusting herself off with the handkerchief she appeared to be using to mop up tears only moments before.

The city's central boulevard was strewn with palm fronds, a traditional sign of welcome, and most Kinshasans had decorated their cars and themselves with palms and leaves.

"Everybody is really happy that Kabila is dead. There could be no peace under him," said a businessman, referring to the 30-month war which has split the country, sucking in half a dozen neighbouring powers. "But you'd better get some leaves or you'll be in trouble."

After days wondering which way the Congolese army would go, yesterday's presence on the streets of Kinshasa suggested its approval of the new government. One of Joseph Kabila's first acts last Friday was to order the payment of salaries to the army and civil service.

Meanwhile in Luanda, the presidents of Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia pledged to keep their troops in Congo to defend the government but only Angola gave public backing to the new president.

In a joint statement they urged all factions in the conflict to "contain offensive military measures".

Portugal's Lusa news agency quoted President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola as blaming the "enemies of the Congolese people" for Kabila's death, saying they had taken advantage of a lapse in security to try to sow chaos in Kinshasa and pave the way for a takeover of power.

The Zimbabweans may not be popular with Kinshasa's citizens but they are not altogether unwelcome. They offer a degree of control and stability that prevents the Congolese army from rampaging through the streets, looting whatever it can lay its hands on.

The Zimbabweans are also likely to stave off any rebel attempt to exploit Kabila's death with an assault on the capital. The Rwandan and Ugandan-backed insurgents are more feared than the foreign troops.

In the longer term, Mr Mugabe may bring an end to the war which almost no one in Congo wants - except the foreigners and profiteers.

He was the most effusive of all African leaders in his condolences over Kabila's death, but he arguably had the greatest interest in removing him from office.

Mr Mugabe's finance minister, Simba Makoni, has been pressing for Zimbabwe to pull its troops out of Congo because the financial and political cost is now too high. Mr Makoni has admitted that Harare has spent £130m fighting the war in Congo over the past two years.

Mr Mugabe also needs to protect his position ahead of a presidential election next year. Zimbabwe's economy is diving and the despatch of its troops to die in Congo is extremely unpopular with the public.

fields.headline: Doubts about Mr Bush
fields.standfirst:
He has already tilted too far to the right

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: He has already tilted too far to the right
fields.body:
Like all political leaders, George Bush will be judged by his actions in office. Fine sentiments such as those on offer at his weekend inauguration as 43rd US president, like those expressed in the campaign, are mere words.

Mr Bush now swaps aspiration and positioning for raw power and real problems. Despite 18 months of the closest scrutiny, quite how this untested, untried man will respond to the harsh challenges of incumbency remains unclear. What was true when he was nominated at the Republican convention in Philadelphia last August still holds: Dubya has an awful lot to prove.

If it is any guide, his progress so far during his transition to the Oval office has been littered with misjudgments. In tacit recognition perhaps of his own inexperience, he has surrounded himself with old hands who date back to the Ford administration. But these appointments do not sit well with his Philadelphia commitment to a "new era". He has recruited heavy-hitting soloists like Colin Powell at the state department and Donald Rumsfeld at defence. But these two powerful personalities may prove hard to control and will test his unquantified leadership skills.

The political complexion of the Bush cabinet also suggests a lack of understanding, or else a deliberate decision to ignore what happened last November. Mr Bush has no clear popular mandate; the very legitimacy of his victory remains in question. Yet in selecting a largely rightwing team including the likes of John Ashcroft as attorney general, he has tilted away, sharply and unwisely, from the centre ground where most Americans live. So much for those other fine words about "compassionate conservatism", "healing the nation", and "bipartisanship". More worrying is the thought that he may actually be unaware of the contradiction. Perhaps he simply did what that savvy old hawk and new White House godfather, Vice-President Dick Cheney, told him to - and then took a break for his favourite videogame.

When it comes to the sort of actions Mr Bush may take in future, now he has his uncertain finger on the button, there are three main areas to watch. How he handles any one of them could make or break his presidency. At home, it is the economy and the possibility that the current slowdown could turn into a full-blown recession. If the bubble definitively bursts on Mr Bush's watch, voters who enjoyed unprecedented, unbroken prosperity during the Clinton years will know who to blame. Tax cuts may not be much help in such circumstances. Nor will the Democrats, who are looking for an early revenge in the 2002 congressional elections. All that could leave Dubya facing an identical fate to that of his one-term father back in 1992.

Unfamiliar though he is with the concept of abroad, Mr Bush's plans for a military build-up, especially national missile defence, and the expected focus on East Asia and the Middle East, will have big international repercussions, not least on the Atlantic alliance and relations with Russia, Europe and Britain. Taiwan and Iraq have the potential to explode in his face; nobody in the US voted for more foreign wars. On the other hand, neglect or passivity elsewhere could raise damaging prospective questions such as who lost Russia? Or, indeed, who lost Nato?

The other basic test of the Bush presidency will be his own personal conduct. Many are the pitfalls and temptations of power, many the snares for the vain, the arrogant and the greedy. Bill Clinton got away with his shenanigans; but Americans will expect better from Mr Bush. Woe betide him if he lets them down.

webTitle: Orange expected to float at a discount

fields.headline: Orange expected to float at a discount
fields.trailText: A big test of investors' appetite for technology shares comes this morning after mobile phone company Orange claims it will be worth at least €60bn (£38bn) when it returns to the stock market next month.
fields.body:
A big test of investors' appetite for technology shares comes this morning after mobile phone company Orange claims it will be worth at least €60bn (£38bn) when it returns to the stock market next month.

Once one of the most popular sectors on the stock market, telecoms shares were among the first to feel the brunt of investors' caution at the end of last year.

It emerged yesterday that more than 500,000 British private investors have registered to buy shares in Orange, which launches its flotation prospectus today.

A fanfare of publicity will surround simultaneous press conferences in Paris and London as the French-owned firm reveals the details of float, which is likely to include special terms for retail investors. They are expected to be able to buy at a 5% discount to institutional investors.

The prospectus will reveal that Orange, owned by France Telecom, will be holding back about 1% of shares to be spread among it 14,000-strong work force as option bonuses. It is understood about 300 senior management, including incoming chief executive Jean-François Pontal, will receive the lion's share of the options payouts, many of which they will not be allowed to exercise for some time.

Hans Snook, who supervised the first flotation of the company before it was ultimately bought by France Telecom, will leave after it goes public.

The price at which the shares will be offered to investors will try to incorporate the downturn in sentiment across the telecoms sector in recent months. One industry source said he expected the company to be floated with a value of between €60bn and €68bn. This is well short of the figure France Telecom originally hoped for, and is a discount of about 15% on what its advisers claim is the true value of the business.

The offer price may be cut even further at the last minute to ensure that the float, which is being watched eagerly by other telecoms and technology companies hoping to float this year, is met with enthusiasm in the City.

It has been suggested by some analysts that the market has lost its appetite for initial public offerings in recent years. This is why the Orange flotation, one of the biggest anticipated this year, will be seen as providing a litmus test for other firms.

"There's a lot of telecom paper around, so unless there's a significant discount there's not much incentive to switch out of the one stock and into Orange," said François-Xavier Legendre, a fund manager at Rothschild.

"They need to offer a discount of 20% to Vodafone to tempt people."

An independent study by Nomura advised investors to buy Orange shares if the company was valued at between €50bn and €60bn.

A spokesman for Orange said that the company was confident it would get the price right and attract a roaring reception on February 12.

webTitle: Leader: Internet scandal drives adoption reforms

fields.headline: Adoption advances
fields.standfirst:
Internet scandal drives new reforms

More net news
Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: Internet scandal drives new reforms.
fields.body:
Scandals have always been more effective in driving forward social reform in Britain than research and active pressure group campaigns. In less than a week since the international adoption battle over the "internet twins" broke, ministers have committed themselves to accelerating the reform of UK regulation of overseas adoptions - and will seek to end internet adoption sales.

Health officials confirmed yesterday that by April, new regulations which will protect overseas babies from being adopted by an inappropriate British couples will be in place. All UK couples hoping to adopt overseas babies will be required to undergo an assessment by accredited adoption workers.

About time too. Overseas children deserve the same safeguards that British children already enjoy. Bringing in adopted children before assessment will be made a criminal offence subject to a £600 fine and three months in prison. The fine sounds too low, particularly given the thousands of pounds that couples are ready to spend on overseas adoptions, while the prison sentence is unnecessary. Quashing the adoption should be punishment enough. Controlling internet sales will be much more difficult but should be explored.

As control of overseas adoptions is tightened, delays to the equally important reform of our domestic adoption laws continue. Even the involvement of the prime minister seems to have failed to push through a change over which Tory and Labour ministers have dithered for far too long.

The extra baby adoptions, which the reform will achieve, have been exaggerated, but it should speed up the main bulk of adoptions, 96% of which are with over-fives. The public has been shocked by the news that the internet twins have had four separate lots of carers in six months. About 15% of all adopted children currently have had six separate placements. This indecent, long-drawn-out and harmful cycle should have been ended long ago.

webTitle: Claws out as Calvin Klein goes to court

fields.headline: Claws out as Calvin Klein goes to court
fields.standfirst: Fashion industry's top names sue and counter-sue over 'sub-standard' designer jeans
fields.trailText: Even for an industry not known for its camaraderie, the court case which pitches Calvin Klein against Linda Wachner in New York today promises to be particularly nasty.
fields.body:
Even for an industry not known for its camaraderie, the court case which pitches Calvin Klein against Linda Wachner in New York today promises to be particularly nasty.

At stake is not only a multi-million dollar licensing agreement to produce and sell Calvin Klein jeans but the personal and professional reputations of two of the fashion industry's best known names.

Mr Klein, the softly spoken designer with the rags-to-riches story, fired the first shot when he filed a lawsuit against Ms Wachner and her company, Warnaco, for breach of contract and trademark infringement.

In the lawsuit, filed last May, Mr Klein accused the company that manufactured his jeans and underwear of making sub-standard products and selling them in huge discount stores such as Costco. In so doing, the designer claimed, Warnaco was in contravention of a 25-year licensing contract signed in 1994.

The tone of the lawsuit was both tough and personal. "Warnaco and Wachner herself have become a cancer on the value and integrity of the [trade]marks," it thundered.

Mr Klein then used his appearance on a late-night talk show to criticise his former partner even further. Linda Wachner, known by all who have crossed her path as a tough and aggressive businesswoman, instantly counter-sued. Warnaco accused the ever-tanned designer of defamation and of bringing its business into disrepute. Mr Klein was further accused of failing to turn up with designs on time and of bringing his own brand into disrepute by using childlike models to sell underwear.

The situation worsened last week when Calvin Klein's lawyers asked for the licence to be terminated because of Warnaco's financial woes. Shares in Warnaco have fallen to below $3 from $14 a year ago as investors worried about its increasing debt load and disappointing earnings. Calvin Klein says that Warnaco has subsequently breached a contract which requires it keep a debt-equity ratio of five to one.

Ms Wachner and Warnaco have denied that they are in such dire financial straits. Few analysts doubt the importance of Calvin Klein to the company. CK jeans are estimated to contribute about one third to Warnaco's annual sales.

The financial stakes for Mr Klein are just as high. Not only does he derive a significant proportion of an estimated $5bn (£3.6bn) in annual revenues from the Warnaco contract, but people familiar with the company suggest that his disagreements with Ms Wachner only rose to the surface after the designer tried and failed to sell his company last year.

One person familiar with the company explicitly links the legal action to the problems of selling Calvin Klein. "He was trying to offload his company but he had this baggage of her with it," he said.

The company argues that it took legal action once the extent of Warnaco's discount selling came to light. This could have happened when Warnaco was one of the handful of potential suitors for the entire business.

With the stakes so high, each side has hired some of the best known lawyers in America.

In court today, David Boies, who successfully defeated Microsoft in an anti-competition trial last year and also acted for Al Gore in Florida, will argue for Calvin Klein while Brendan Sullivan, whose clients have included Iran-Contra figure Oliver North, has been hired by Ms Wachner.

Few trademark lawyers believe that Mr Klein has an easy fight on his hands, though the allegations that Ms Wachner used thin or cheap denim and then kept the warehouse sales a secret may have already harmed her.

In so doing, the designer claimed, Warnaco was in contravention of a 25-year licensing contract signed in 1994. The tone of the lawsuit was both tough and personal. "Warnaco and Wachner herself have become a cancer on the value and integrity of the [trade]marks," it thundered. Mr Klein then used his appearance on a late-night talk show to criticise his former partner even further. Linda Wachner, known by all who have crossed her path as a tough and aggressive businesswoman, instantly counter-sued. Warnaco accused the ever-tanned designer of defamation and of bringing its business into disrepute. Mr Klein was further accused of failing to turn up with designs on time and of bringing his own brand into disrepute by using childlike models to sell underwear. The situation worsened last week when Calvin Klein's lawyers asked for the licence to be terminated because of Warnaco's financial woes. Shares in Warnaco have fallen to below $3 from $14 a year ago as investors worried about its increasing debt load and disappointing earnings. Calvin Klein says that Warnaco has subsequently breached a contract which requires it keep a debt-equity ratio of five to one. Ms Wachner and Warnaco have denied that they are in such dire financial straits. Few analysts doubt the importance of Calvin Klein to the company. CK jeans are estimated to contribute about one third to Warnaco's annual sales. The financial stakes for Mr Klein are just as high. Not only does he derive a significant proportion of an estimated $5bn (£3.6bn) in annual revenues from the Warnaco contract, but people familiar with the company suggest that his disagreements with Ms Wachner only rose to the surface after the designer tried and failed to sell his company last year. One person familiar with the company explicitly links the legal action to the problems of selling Calvin Klein. "He was trying to offload his company but he had this baggage of her with it," he said. The company argues that it took legal action once the extent of Warnaco's discount selling came to light. This could have happened when Warnaco was one of the handful of potential suitors for the entire business. With the stakes so high, each side has hired some of the best known lawyers in America. In court today, David Boies, who successfully defeated Microsoft in an anti-competition trial last year and also acted for Al Gore in Florida, will argue for Calvin Klein while Brendan Sullivan, whose clients have included Iran-Contra figure Oliver North, has been hired by Ms Wachner. Few trademark lawyers believe that Mr Klein has an easy fight on his hands, though the allegations that Ms Wachner used thin or cheap denim and then kept the warehouse sales a secret may have already harmed her.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley: Masters of bile, but not much else

fields.headline: Masters of bile, but not much else
fields.standfirst:
The Tories have little election strategy except to pick fights

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague leads the most incompetent opposition in modern British history - a judgment I make with the authority which comes from membership of a narrowly defeated contender for that title.
fields.body:
William Hague leads the most incompetent opposition in modern British history - a judgment I make with the authority which comes from membership of a narrowly defeated contender for that title.

Hague and Co win the palm because, even in 1983, the Labour party rarely made the elementary error which shadow cabinet members now repeat day after day. We lost because we supported bizarre policies, appeared incompetent and were conspicuously disunited. This year Tory prospects are prejudiced, indeed extinguished, by all those liabilities. But the Conservatives add to their unpopularity by reducing every issue to the lowest common denominator of party politics. Has nobody told them that British voters hate "slanging matches"?

If that piece of elementary information has been circulated among the Conservative leadership, no member of the high command has taken the advice to heart. Michael Ancram (once a rational human being) explained on television that the chaos on the railways was all John Prescott's fault - conjuring up pictures of the deputy prime minister sabotaging the line at Hatfield and tampering with the obsolete signalling system.

Perhaps Mr Ancram can be excused his moment of absurdity. There is something in the air at Conservative Central Office which (pace Chris Patten) causes once reasonable men to say anything that seems convenient in the interest of their party. Ancram was only embarrassingly silly. Liam Fox, responding to Alan Milburn's statement on the Bedford mortuary scandal, performed the difficult trick of being simultaneously ridiculous and repellent.

Initially Dr Fox - the opposition health spokesman - confused Bedford with Bradford. Scotland's "12th most eligible bachelor" is, no doubt, too preoccupied with social engagements north of the border to make himself an expert on Sassenach geography. But why did he think that his party had anything to gain by raving on about the government massaging the waiting list statistics? It was a moment for compassion, not confrontation.

Politicians do well to avoid piety. But they ought to cultivate common sense. Fox should have expressed his sympathy with the relatives and his willingness to wait for the report Milburn promised. Instead, he tried to turn the occasion into a party political broadcast. It is easy enough to guess how the television audience reacted. Even the least fastidious must have felt nauseating disbelief that he could so misjudge the mood of the moment.

Last week on Newsnight Ann Widdecombe fell, with an even more resounding thud, into the same trap. Jeremy Paxman - as always, determined to be centre stage - began his crime-figures interview with a statement rather than a question. "You had better make the most of these figures; violent crime is going to fall next year." There was only one possible response for an even moderately competent politician to make - "I hope you are right Mr Paxman. I certainly hope you are right."

Assuming that she was allowed to continue (admittedly an unlikely hypothesis), Ms Widdecombe should then have explained that a reduction in the number of assaults would be something about which we all should rejoice. She might even have added that she resented the implication that she would make political capital out of human suffering. Instead she held Jack Straw responsible for every mugging committed in England since Jack the Ripper terrorised London.

The Tories are sufficiently foolish, or destabilised, to continue campaigning in the same mindless way right up to polling day - constantly accusing Tony Blair of cowardice because he refuses to take part in a television debate. His decision was undoubtedly right. It would be absurd for the prime minister to encourage a trivialisation of the campaign. The TV channels want a confrontation because it would be showbiz lightly disguised as serious politics. They know that the tabloid publicity which it would attract would have little or nothing to do with the campaign's real issues.

All we remember about the world's first television debate is that Richard Nixon looked as if he had not shaved. And the obsession with Blair's sweat-soaked shirt, after his party conference speech, confirms that this year's headlines would not concern the more obscure aspects of fiscal policy.

In the weeks before polling day I shall feel not the slightest interest in whether Hague's bald head shines under the television lights. Nor will most voters. Indeed they will not care a tinker's cuss about the prime minister's reluctance to take part in a glorified panel game. But the Tories will bore the nation to death with complaints about the "denial of democratic debate". That may be because they have nothing much more to say. But picking the wrong sort of fight will only increase the size of their defeat. Out of touch means out of office.

webTitle: The kid who nicks a mobile phone will bring Blair down

fields.headline: The kid who nicks a mobile phone will bring Blair down
fields.standfirst:
Peter Preston Labour's manifesto sets so many targets it's a recipe for self-destruction

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Here is a haunting question. How, in 2005 or 2009, will New Labour fall at last to earth, out of office and out of favour? A legacy rejected, a memory reviled. Put away your crystal balls, for you have no need of them. The future, as usual, is the small print of the present extrapolated.
fields.body:
Here is a haunting question. How, in 2005 or 2009, will New Labour fall at last to earth, out of office and out of favour? A legacy rejected, a memory reviled. Put away your crystal balls, for you have no need of them. The future, as usual, is the small print of the present extrapolated.

An NHS magnificently restored? But somewhere, on a hospital floor, bodies will lie in shrouds. An education system to stun the world? But somewhere, perhaps a stone's throw from Westminster, there will be classes without teachers and too few books. Crime cracked, two bobbies on every beat? Some vile kid killing in urban sinkdom will do for that dream. Public transport to delight? This government's 10-year plan won't have got there yet. A signals failure at Watford.

And it will all, in its crude condemnation, be pretty unfair. The health service - in the broad - will be better, not worse. School results, too, will leave 1997 for dead. Labour will have tried mightily to tackle the causes of crime and have poured millions into thickening the thin blue line. More buses and trains will run on time. Blood, sweat, tears and billions invested: but the devil of self-destruction is in the targets.

Watch, for first confirmation, this spring's manifesto: on current indications it is the longest suicide note in history - because it doesn't understand the nature of politics. After the three (out of five) solemn pledges offered, come hundreds of challenges - or targets, diligently assembled for Guardian readers last week by Patrick Wintour. Robbery in West Yorkshire down 21.4% by 2004; 10% fewer building fires by March 2004 (against a 1998-99 baseline); 6m museum and gallery visits by children (against 4.59m last year).

Such targets, great and small, flow inexhaustibly - beadily superintended by Geoff Mulgan, director of the Cabinet Office's performance and innovation unit. Geoff believes that "practical implementation has been undervalued in British government and society in the past". He wants things done, specifically achieved, not windy promises or elegant minutes. He, like his master, has become a delivery man.

What's wrong with that? Who defends costly policies which don't work on the ground? If Whitehall stands at the centre of British governance, then Whitehall should be a operated like a proper business - with detailed budgets, performance monitoring, achievement incentives and, of course, management consultants. Geoff fits that final bill neatly: he's run thinktanks and pop concerts and written interesting books. He (like William Hague from McKinsey's) must surely know how to run a country.

Yet politics, as we see all around us, is Great (or Lukewarm) Britannia plc. The chief executive isn't thanked, at some thinly attended AGM, for bringing overall crime levels down: he is kicked on the knee because teenagers keep nicking each other's mobile phones. He can open a new hospital every three days, but it's the one without a decent morgue that brings him down. And so it must be in this new, cold world of incessant targetting.

Where does it come from? The answer, inevitably, is that it comes (along with so much else) from Bill Clinton's two terms and his partial reinvigoration of federal government. Bill showed the way. But Bill is gone this morning, and his usurper arrives promising to change this federal inheritance utterly, to break it down and scatter the pieces across 50 states. Many of Clinton's ideas may, in detail, have been good: but they float on a political tide which goes in and out, carrying its flotsam with it.

And Clinton, at least, had an advantage that New Labour lacks. He could inspire affection - or the other side of its coin, loathing. He could engage emotions (from a girl in a stained dress to a black chapel filled with chanting adulation). There is something curiously chilly about his touring company's British version. It is, already, tolerated rather than loved. It will be re-elected soon enough, but with no more joy than a board of suits at a shareholders' meeting.

Why this crucial lack of affection? Well, some people (old Labour, old Thatcher-lovers) are never happy. But the rest of us, in the middle, need something warm to identify with. Tony Blair could do warmth at the start, but the constant, frustrated recitation of statistics and complex initiatives has drained that from him. Worse, the beginnings of an election campaign - with its crude, argy-bargy statistics - undermines him further. He's effective CEO, he seems to say, of the NHS, of Railtrack, of the dome, of the Metropolitan police. An impossible spin.

Of course, in reality, New Labour isn't a business at all. How could it be? Would any successful business temporise so long and so feebly about Europe? Would any business set up a tug of war between its chief executive and finance director which, over the years, it did nothing to resolve? Would it give that finance director, no matter how callow his underlings, a licence to veto the work of other, more expert departments? Would any ambitious business duck out of debates or get its marketing in such a twist?

Governments are not giant corporations. They are, at best, the reconciler of hopes and reality. They can set a direction and, through prudent distancing, leave others to follow through. (That's the point about the American way: so much, for good or ill, is left to the states, so much can be mired in Congress). But New Labour, long out of power and thus short of experience, saw only detail, not strategy. Tony Blair became visibly enraged by the sluggard pace of Whitehall. Ministers became ciphers as he kicked the dozy machine. Targets showered from on high; and the essence of real achievement drained away, lost in a forest of benchmarks as frail as the first voter (or Daily Mail reporter) to stub his toe on one.

In this dismal arena, one publicised failure equals a dozen successes. The more targets you set, the more certain you are to fail in individual perception. The more voluminous your target list, the less time you have to talk direction. Time will always betray you, because that is the nature of time in politics. One step forward will always be one step back when the next lot get in.

If I were Mr Blair, I'd write a two-sentence manifesto. "We've done a lot, as you can see, and we aim to do a lot more. Give us the chance to drive on while our energy lasts." And I'd make Geoff Mulgan visiting professor in governmental theory at Bath and Harvard. If there are no big ideas in an unideological world, let there at least be honest endeavour and constant dialogue - the tools of affection. Why limp into the sunset because West Yorkshire robberies have dropped by only 19.3%?

fields.headline: Porn again
fields.trailText: I must correct the impression in your report (Channel 5 owners at war, January 18) that my departure from Channel 5 was somehow connected to its alleged reliance on "cheap imports and late-night soft porn". All channels find imports more cost effective than origination. Compared with other terrestrial channels, both originations and imports are relatively cheap on Channel 5. This will remain the case for the indefinite future. As for "late-night soft porn", the policy of including a small amount of erotic drama in the Channel 5 schedule was taken long before I joined, was reconfirmed unanimously by the board in response to a proposal from my successor when she was director of programmes and continues to this day.
fields.body:
I must correct the impression in your report (Channel 5 owners at war, January 18) that my departure from Channel 5 was somehow connected to its alleged reliance on "cheap imports and late-night soft porn". All channels find imports more cost effective than origination. Compared with other terrestrial channels, both originations and imports are relatively cheap on Channel 5. This will remain the case for the indefinite future. As for "late-night soft porn", the policy of including a small amount of erotic drama in the Channel 5 schedule was taken long before I joined, was reconfirmed unanimously by the board in response to a proposal from my successor when she was director of programmes and continues to this day.

While supporting that policy, my own view of the need for erotic material in the schedule can be gauged from my application for the franchise, which made no reference to such material.

David Elstein
London Elsteindavid@cs.com

webTitle: Letters: More suggestions for Labour's next manifesto

fields.headline: More suggestions for Labour's next manifesto
fields.trailText: The government seems to have got itself in a bit of a pickle about its pledges (Labour admits failures on policy targets, January 19).
fields.body:
The government seems to have got itself in a bit of a pickle about its pledges (Labour admits failures on policy targets, January 19). These things can be complicated. A simpler list of actions and timescales might look like this:

End the voucher system for asylum-seekers - today.

Restore the pensions and benefits link with pay and prices - today.

Repeal section 28 (Local Government Act, England and Wales) - today.

Increase public services employment, eg by improving pay for nurses and teachers - today.

Scrap nuclear missiles (the courts find them immoral) and depleted uranium - today. And so on.

Measures like these begin to tackle discrimination and disadvantage, and help to give us - all - the fairer and healthier society which ministers want. As would "joining up" the railways (and likewise removing health and education from the clutches of private finance initiative). Public health is not safe in private hands.
John Nicholson
Chief executive, UK Public Health Association john@ukpha.org.uk

 The interesting thing about the government's vision for the UK in 2005 (Hidden manifesto, January 19) is not what they include, but what they choose to leave out.

There is no mention of the maintenance of the basic state pension as the foundation on which the majority of income in retirement will be built.

Instead, there is talk of insecure funded stakeholder pensions for those at work and the massive extension of mean-testing for those who have already retired.

In short, the government's existing pensions policy just does not add up. And furthermore, there is absolutely no guarantee that tomorrow's pensioners will be any better off than today's.

That is why existing pensioners, and those that follow, should support the maintenance of the basic state pension as of right, the restoration of the link with average earnings and the strengthening of the National Insurance system. That would give a much better vision for 2005.
Jack Thain
General secretary, National Pensioners Convention

 No mention, then, of the universities in Labour's "hidden manifesto". Will they have ceased to exist by 2005? Or is it that they will be safely in the hands of the private sector by then?
James Harris
University of Glasgow j.harris@philosophy.arts.gla.ac.uk

 Most of the public service targets you list for Britain 2005 for education, welfare, children and poverty, and virtually all those for the environment and transport will have to be delivered by local government, but there are no signs in the Treasury's expenditure plans that local government will be given the funds needed to meet them.
Cllr John Garrett
Norwich
fields.bodyText: The government seems to have got itself in a bit of a pickle about its pledges (Labour admits failures on policy targets, January 19). These things can be complicated. A simpler list of actions and timescales might look like this: End the voucher system for asylum-seekers - today. Restore the pensions and benefits link with pay and prices - today. Repeal section 28 (Local Government Act, England and Wales) - today. Increase public services employment, eg by improving pay for nurses and teachers - today. Scrap nuclear missiles (the courts find them immoral) and depleted uranium - today. And so on. Measures like these begin to tackle discrimination and disadvantage, and help to give us - all - the fairer and healthier society which ministers want. As would "joining up" the railways (and likewise removing health and education from the clutches of private finance initiative). Public health is not safe in private hands. John Nicholson Chief executive, UK Public Health Association john@ukpha.org.uk  The interesting thing about the government's vision for the UK in 2005 (Hidden manifesto, January 19) is not what they include, but what they choose to leave out. There is no mention of the maintenance of the basic state pension as the foundation on which the majority of income in retirement will be built. Instead, there is talk of insecure funded stakeholder pensions for those at work and the massive extension of mean-testing for those who have already retired. In short, the government's existing pensions policy just does not add up. And furthermore, there is absolutely no guarantee that tomorrow's pensioners will be any better off than today's. That is why existing pensioners, and those that follow, should support the maintenance of the basic state pension as of right, the restoration of the link with average earnings and the strengthening of the National Insurance system. That would give a much better vision for 2005. Jack Thain General secretary, National Pensioners Convention  No mention, then, of the universities in Labour's "hidden manifesto". Will they have ceased to exist by 2005? Or is it that they will be safely in the hands of the private sector by then? James Harris University of Glasgow j.harris@philosophy.arts.gla.ac.uk  Most of the public service targets you list for Britain 2005 for education, welfare, children and poverty, and virtually all those for the environment and transport will have to be delivered by local government, but there are no signs in the Treasury's expenditure plans that local government will be given the funds needed to meet them. Cllr John Garrett Norwich

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: BCCI creditors attack fees
fields.body:
BCCI creditors attack fees

Deloitte & Touche, the international accountancy firm, is under attack for still charging fees of £7m a year for its role in liquidating BCCI, the bank which went bust more than a decade ago.

According to the English Creditors' Committee, one of the groups fighting for creditors' rights, Deloitte had charged £166m for professional services until October last year. Deloitte is now drawing £150,000 a week from the liquidation to cover its fees. The creditors' committee calculated that Lovells, the liquidators' solicitors, has received more than £85m in fees.

Deloitte & Touche was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Asda takes on Boots

Asda yesterday announced plans to take on chemists chain Boots by expanding the number of its in-store pharmacies, photo centres and opticians.

The move will create 870 new jobs over the next 12 months. Asda will increase the number of its photo centres from six to 50, open 50 vision centres offering a full optician service and increase its pharmacies from 36 to 94.

Boots has 1,300 chemist outlets and 300 optician stores.

Bugles, the latest snack

Golden Wonder, the crisp maker which sells Wotsits and Nik Naks, is to launch another strangely named snack on the unsuspecting public. Cone-shaped and made of corn, Bugles are to be advertised on television and sold initially in Scotland, Northern Ireland and the Tyne Tees region in cheese, salt & vinegar and BBQ flavours.

Business fails to prepare

British businesses have no contingency plans for disasters such as floods, fuel shortages and rail problems despite last year's experiences.

According to research published today by the Institute of Management as many as 84% of businesses have not taken measures to reduce the impact of future rail disruption. Fewer than a quarter, have thought about preparing for flooding and fewer than half have taken measures to reduce the impact of another fuel crisis.

Entrepreneurs back Voxpilot

Scottish entrepreneurs Tom Hunter, who sold his retail chain Sports Division for £290m, and Chris Gorman, who helped to build up mobile phone chain DX Communications, are helping to back Dublin voice technology company Voxpilot. The two, alongside GUS subsidiary Reality Ventures, are putting about $1m into the company. Voxpilot is headed by e-commerce businessman Kevin Lynch.

fields.headline: Bryant falls to Taylor Woodrow
fields.trailText: Housebuilder Bryant is expected to announce this morning that it has accepted an increased £630m bid from construction group Taylor Woodrow, derailing once and for all Bryant's planned merger with rival Beazer. The deal will create one of Britain's biggest housebuilders with a market capitalisation of more than £1bn, and is likely to bring to an end a brief but complicated four-way takeover tussle.
fields.body:
Housebuilder Bryant is expected to announce this morning that it has accepted an increased £630m bid from construction group Taylor Woodrow, derailing once and for all Bryant's planned merger with rival Beazer. The deal will create one of Britain's biggest housebuilders with a market capitalisation of more than £1bn, and is likely to bring to an end a brief but complicated four-way takeover tussle.

Taylor is believed to be offering about 210p a share in cash and shares, compared with its original bid of about 194p a share, rejected last week, and Bryant's closing price on Friday of 192p. The new proposal includes 85p-90p a share in cash and values Bryant at about £535m, with Taylor taking on £95m of debt.

The companies' advisers were locked in meetings last night putting the finishing touches to a statement due to be issued to the Stock Exchange today.

Rejecting Taylor's earlier approaches, Bryant had insisted that it preferred to go ahead with its tie-up with Beazer. The new terms from Taylor, which were made over the weekend, have changed the board's mind. It is believed leading shareholders indicated to Bryant they favoured the Taylor deal if the price could be improved.

Bryant's proposed merger with Beazer to create a company called Domus was announced in December and set off a flurry of activity among Britain's housebuilders. As well as prompting Taylor Woodrow to announce its interest in Bryant, builder Persimmon also stepped in.

Persimmon has targeted Beazer, and on Friday announced it was considering a £528m bid for the company. Today's expected announcement of the deal between Taylor Woodrow and Bryant will leave the way clear for the Persimmon bid.

Persimmon has claimed it would have the largest land bank in Britain if it succeeded in acquiring Beazer, and forecast annual savings of £20m through reducing staff numbers and other cutbacks.

Taylor Woodrow's keenness to strike a deal with Bryant is part of chief executive Keith Egerton's strategy to move Taylor from a broad-based construction group into one focused on housebuilding.

Analysts believe further moves in the sector are inevitable, with housebuilders seeking mergers where they can cut costs and boost profits. Berkeley Homes is said to be on the lookout for acquisitions, as are Wimpey and Barratt Developments.

fields.headline: Bush's new ballpark
fields.trailText: John O'Farrell (The misunderestimated president, January 20) rightly points out that the ballpark at Arlington was indeed one of George Bush's murkier financial dealings for the Texas Rangers baseball team.
fields.body:
John O'Farrell (The misunderestimated president, January 20) rightly points out that the ballpark at Arlington was indeed one of George Bush's murkier financial dealings for the Texas Rangers baseball team.

Murkier still is the Arlington Sports Facility Development Authority, which oversaw the stadium's construction. This nongovernmental organisation was also vested with the power of eminent domain - a cunning detail of the bill establishing that authority, which Bush helped push through the Texas legislature.

Thus, when the Rangers failed to secure land next to the stadium site for well below market value, the ASFDA used its powers of eminent domain to condemn the land, later turning it over, at no cost, to the Rangers for development.

Although one may question the new president's intelligence and political experience, his cunning should certainly not be "misunder-estimated".

Eric Flesher
Berlin, Germany

 During the inauguration ceremony, George Bush spoke of creating an inclusive society and bringing all Americans together. It seems strange then, that the ceremony began and ended with exclusively and overtly Christian prayers. Are the many non-believers, Jews, Hindus and Muslims not considered to be citizens of the US?

Adrian Barnett
Morecambe, Lancs.
adrian@abarnett.demon.co.uk



 How sadly apt that BBC2's coverage of Bush's inauguration should have been preceded by a John Wayne movie.

Robin Carmody
Portland, Dorset
robin@elidor.freeserve.co.uk
