fields.headline: Gavin Young
fields.standfirst: Renowned foreign correspondent who turned his wanderings into bestsellers
fields.trailText: Gavin Young, who has died aged 72, was an intrepid foreign correspondent who, after 20 years and 14 wars, started writing travel books. He wrote 10 in all; two of them, Slow Boats To China (1981) and Slow Boats Home (1985) became bestsellers - and classics of their kind.
fields.body:
Gavin Young, who has died aged 72, was an intrepid foreign correspondent who, after 20 years and 14 wars, started writing travel books. He wrote 10 in all; two of them, Slow Boats To China (1981) and Slow Boats Home (1985) became bestsellers - and classics of their kind.

He looked the part: tall, with what used to be called finely-chiselled features, which eventually became hawklike. His normal manner was amused, even in the most unpromising circumstances. In western capitals, he wore a good suit and good shoes, with a silk handkerchief in his top pocket. In his prime, he looked like a young brigadier in mufti.

This was appropriate. His father was a Welsh Guards colonel who died, aged 80, with a copy of Conrad's Mirror Of The Sea at his bedside. His mother, after a divorce, lived off Sloane Square. Young was conceived at the Semiramis Hotel in Cairo, brought up in his grandmother's house next to the sea at Bude, Cornwall, and educated at Rugby and Trinity College, Oxford.

Conrad was his hero and, as a war correspondent, he always carried a Conrad novel as a sort of talisman. He maintained that his love of Conrad came at Rugby when he was 15; the headmaster read out the passage from Youth, in which Conrad regrets the lost years of youth. The words struck Young "with the force of strong drink", telling him to wake up and start living.

In 1950, at 22, after military service with the Welsh Guards, mostly in Palestine, he took a £5-a-week job as a clerk with the traders Ralli Brothers in Basra, and learnt rough-and-ready Arabic. He planned to investigate the desert but, over lunch at the British consulate, the great Arabian explorer, Wilfred Thesiger, urged him to take up with the Marsh Arabs.

The next two years provided Young's formative adventure. Only two other Europeans, Thesiger and Gavin Maxwell, really knew the marshes and spoke the language, a derivation of Iraqi Arabic. The marshes, Young thought, were a watery, natural paradise, inhabited by the inheritors of all the virtues of the pure-blooded Arabs of the Arabian desert; thrift, hard work, courage, simplicity, generosity and reverence.

Like other Englishmen, Young found that his idealism and emotions were only released outside the structures of his own country. He loved the Marsh Arabs and learned that he had a natural ability to get on with simple people. Thereafter, his sympathy for victimised minorities - for the Marsh Arabs themelves, for Nagas, Kurds, Vietnamese, Cambodians - informed, and to some extent inspired, all his work.

Then came a slightly mysterious period, when Young lived in a tent and worked in the wilds of south western Arabia with an outfit called Desert Locust Control. Suspicious friends accused him of being a spy; he denied it. However, the Suez crisis put an end to freelance British adventurers in Arabia, and he drifted off to work half-time for Radio Morocco.

There, Ian Fleming, then the Sunday Times foreign manager, gave him his card and said that if he ever thought of journalism to give him a ring. Young did think of journalism, but also recalled that the Sunday Times had been pro-Suez while the Observer, its rival, had been opposed. In the event, he was taken on as a stringer for the Observer to report the Algerian war, then the Congo and Katanga.

In an episode straight out of Evelyn Waugh's Scoop, the Observer editor, David Astor, wrote to ask if Young fancied a trip to report the war in Nagaland. Young cabled his agreement back, not having the faintest idea where Nagaland was. A hazardous 10-day journey followed, up the Chindwin river, through Burma to the jungle-covered mountains of eastern Assam, with Young pretending to be a missionary. Needless to say, he had the story of the Nagas' oppression by India to himself.

Now fully established as a foreign correspondent, he travelled the world. In 1965, came the first of many visits to Vietnam. Soon after he arrived, he met an ordinary Vietnamese family, through whose eyes he ever afterwards saw the dangers, horrors and politics of the war. He helped them as best he could for the rest of his life.

In the late 1970s, after Cambodia, Young began to think he had had enough of death, destruction and refugees, and that his luck might be running out. He gradually gave up journalism and started writing books. There was the short Return To The Marshes (1977), Iraq: Land Of Two Rivers (1979) and his big success, Slow Boats To China (1981). His passion for Conrad produced In Search Of Conrad (1991).

A Wavering Grace (1997), about the Vietnamese family, was probably his most moving and personal book. His last was Eye On The World (1998), a collection of his photographs with his own commentary.

Young's life as a war correspondent and traveller contrasted with his London life or, when he was there for a couple of years, New York. In London, he rarely strayed far from the Travellers Club and must have been one of the last people to live in "rooms"; in his case in South Audley Street, Mayfair. In New York, he drank bullshots at the Ritz Carlton and martinis at PJ Clark's. He wrote almost nothing in London, and filed little from New York. The Observer eventually realised that the way to get him writing was to send him far from the fleshpots, preferably towards the sound of gunfire.

He contrived encounters or interviews with the best people. In Paris, he became friends with Mary McCarthy, in New York with Gore Vidal, in London with Graham Greene. Between tours of Vietnam duty, he met Mae West in Los Angeles. Long ago, she told him, she had met Ho Chi Minh in London, when she was in a play in the Strand, and he was working at the Savoy Hotel.

Young never settled down. His plan to end his life in the east, preferably in a favourite riverside hotel in northern Thailand, did not work out. He died of a slow degenerative disease in a rented London flat. When friends visited, he liked to hear Conrad read aloud.

 Gavin David Young, writer and traveller, born April 24 1928; died January 18 2001

webTitle: Row over crackdown on adoption websites

fields.headline: Row over crackdown on adoption websites
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The government is to clamp down on adoption over the internet by warning British-based service providers that they face criminal prosecution for relaying material which infringes British adoption law, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: John Carvel, Steven Morris and Tania Branigan
fields.body:
The government is to clamp down on adoption over the internet by warning British-based service providers that they face criminal prosecution for relaying material which infringes British adoption law, it emerged yesterday.

The extraordinary move by the Department of Health, which came as the controversy concerning the case of the couple who adopted twins on the net continued to gather pace, was immediately attacked as unworkable.

Industry leaders argued that the nature and scale of the internet meant that it was impossible for ISPs to check all material being accessed by their customers. There was also concern that the warning from the health minister John Hutton seemed to go against the spirit of a European directive on e-commerce. Moreover, it would put a great strain on the authorities who would have to try to police the ISPs.

The government, however, is keen to be seen acting strongly following the case of Alan and Judith Kilshaw, who bought baby twins Beverley and Kim berley from a Californian adoption broker they found on the internet. Even before Mr Hutton's initiative emerged, the government had announced that parents who adopted from abroad without undergoing the proper checks would face up to three months in prison and a fine of £600.

Regulations on inter-country adoptions had already been under discussion following a private member's bill passed in 1999 but it understood that they were not going to come into force until January next year. They will now be introduced in April.

The developments coincide with increasingly lurid allegations about the Kilshaws. One newspaper alleged yesterday that Mrs Kilshaw had said she would use witchcraft to regain the twins, who were taken into care on Thursday, though she denied making such a threat.

Mr Hutton, the minister responsible for child protection, believes his move against the ISPs could provide a lead for the EU and G8 to crack down on child-broker websites.

Government lawyers have advised that the adoption internet sites are a clear in fringement of the 1976 Adoption Act. Although they are powerless to close down sites based outside British jurisdiction, they have advised ministers that ISPs offering a route for the material to be accessed by people in Britain are open to prosecution.

The 1976 act makes it an offence for any advertisement to be published indicating that a parent or guardian wants their child to be adopted, or that a person wants to adopt a child, or that any person other than a local social services authority or voluntary adoption agency approved by the secretary of state is willing to make arrangements for the adoption of a child.

fields.headline: Corus faces £400m shutdown bill
fields.standfirst: Ministers may force steel company to pay clean-up costs as deterrent to closure of south Wales plant
fields.trailText: Ministers are considering threatening Corus with the environmental cost of cleaning up the Llanwern steel works if the company decides to cut as many as 6,000 steel jobs in Britain. Corus is due to announce the outcome of a countrywide review of its business within days.
fields.body:
Ministers are considering threatening Corus with the environmental cost of cleaning up the Llanwern steel works if the company decides to cut as many as 6,000 steel jobs in Britain. Corus is due to announce the outcome of a countrywide review of its business within days.

The brunt of the cuts are expected at the steel works in Newport, south Wales. Some ministers, including the local Labour MP Alan Howarth, believe the threat to put some closure costs onto the company might force the Anglo-Dutch group to rethink.

One minister said: "It would work on the principle of the polluter pays. If Corus were landed with a £400m cost, their figures might change. It would stop the argument that relative costs of closing a company are lower in Britain than elsewhere."

Ministers fear that Corus, formed through the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens of the Netherlands, has been looking at the relative cost of closure in Europe and Britain, where the Lackenby works on Teesside is also thought to be on the critical list.

Closing the plants will raise associated bills of clearing the heavy metal, clinker and toxic waste which would normally be borne by the state. The legal propriety of trying to force a company to pay for the clean-up costs of an abandoned site is uncertain. But it is a measure of the desperation of the Labour government over the closure threat.

The Welsh Labour Party fears that a big closure programme, with its knock-on effect in the rest of the south Wales economy, might have a devastating political impact. Plaid Cymru has made unexpected political inroads into traditional Labour bastions in south Wales. A retraining package is already being prepared by government.

Corus shed 4,500 jobs last year reducing its total workforce to 33,000, citing the strong pound and tough trading conditions in the industry and is widely expected to cut at least as many posts this year. Corus has repeatedly described as speculation reports that Llanwern will close. Company officials have been briefing analysts and union leaders about the state of the industry in this country in the run-up to the announcement which could come by the end of the week. Some industry sources claimed that the announcement might be delayed for another fortnight.

Michael Leahy, general secretary of the biggest steel workers' union, the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, said yesterday: "Corus is going to make its most important decision ever. We hope the company has heeded our words and will tough it out until we are through the present difficult trading conditions.

"To make further redundancies or even to close a factory would be the worst decision not only for the company but also for the country."

Bob Shannon, national officer of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "There is enormous speculation but we are waiting for the official announcement and we just hope that Corus will hold its nerve."

In another landmark decision for British industry Japanese car firm Nissan is expected to announce this week whether it will build a new car at its plant in Sunderland or at a factory near Paris.

The chances of Sunderland winning the work have been boosted after the European commission approved a £40m government grant if the Micra is produced in this country. The Sunderland Nissan plant is one of the most productive in Europe and a decision to shut it would be blamed firmly on the high pound and Britain's failure to join the euro.

webTitle: FSA rule may cut risk capital

fields.headline: FSA rule may cut risk capital
fields.trailText: Venture capitalists are threatening to move their business off-shore in response to new regulations which they claim are preventing them seeking financial backing overseas.
fields.body:
Venture capitalists are threatening to move their business off-shore in response to new regulations which they claim are preventing them seeking financial backing overseas.

At a time when the government is trying to encourage investment in venture capital, the industry is infuriated by financial services authority rules that it claims are hampering its efforts to attract rich American individuals to support investments.

The row which has erupted between the British Venture Capital Association and the FSA and the Treasury comes as Paul Myners, the chairman of the Gartmore fund management group, puts the finishing touches to his report for the chancellor, Gordon Brown, on boosting the venture capital industry. Its final recommendations are expected to be published about the time of the Budget in March.

Mr Myners, who is chairman of Guardian Media Group which publishes the Guardian, was commissioned by the chancellor to establish why the rate of investment in venture capital is lower in Britain than in the US.

Edmund Truell, vice chairman of the BVCA, said that an important stream of potential investment was now under threat.

He blamed a decision by the Treasury to require venture capitalists to comply with British as well as American rules when doing business in the United States. As a result, venture capitalists were unable to approach rich individuals to invest in their projects - a practice which is prohibited in Britain but permitted in America.

Mr Truell, who is the chief executive of venture capital group Duke Street Capital, said: "Our ultimate threat is 'why should we practise in the UK?' We're fairly transportable."

Legislation is expected shortly. The Treasury said it was "taking account" of the views received during the consultation period.

It is understood that many of the comments were sympathetic towards the introduction of the "home state" regulations - which means that British rules must be adhered to by British regulated companies when doing business outside the country.

webTitle: Starting up: the frustrations of domain name registering

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst:
It can be surprisingly murky in the world of domain names

More net news
fields.trailText: Starting up a business has its frustrations. This week's pain is the surprisingly murky world of domain name registration and hosting.
fields.body:
Starting up a business has its frustrations. This week's pain is the surprisingly murky world of domain name registration and hosting.

Electronic business is supposed to be ushering in an era of efficiency. If so, no one seems to have mentioned it to the organisations responsible for determining how businesses can protect their key intellectual e-properties such as domain names.

As a new business our domain name requirements are relatively modest. And although we do not have to protect an existing portfolio of offline brands, we do need to plan for the future.

In fact, right at the start, our lawyers recommended we register over 10 different domain derivatives of rools alongside the basic rools.com and rools.co.uk.

Buying domain names is increasingly cheap - ".co.uk" domain names are being advertised for £5 in some internet magazines. These resellers often use these cheap headline rates to entice customers to spend on other services. And unfortunately they tend to be less robust than other businesses.

One of our early domain names was registered at one of these companies. We think it has gone bust. "Think" because no one has informed us. But when we first tried to move the domain name two months ago, they told us they were having technical difficulties. Since then the company's website has been withdrawn and there is no response to our emails. We are left to pick up the pieces and deal directly with the UK's registry, Nominet.

Buying the domain names is easy. Problems start if you want to change anything with the domains you have registered. We have needed to do this on several occasions, mainly to reflect changes in ownership - from personal to company, from one company to the next - or hosting arrangements.

The trickiest process appears to be in transferring ownership of ".com" domain names, if you are based in Britain at least. These names are administered from the United States. It took us six weeks, a visit by a member of the rools team to the American Embassy in London to obtain the vice-consul's signature, and countless emails and phone calls (mostly unanswered) to the original registrars, to complete the simple transfer of ownership of a domain from one of the directors to the company itself.

There are documented cases of domains being inappropriately transferred away from their rightful owners, which is a more pernicious version of cybersquatting, but, surely, it should not be this difficult for legitimate businesses to manage their intellectual property.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the founders of rools, an online payments service for teenagers

fields.headline: Compete with the forecasters
fields.trailText: Time is running out to win £500 worth of books in our annual economics forecasting competition. All you have to do is guess what will happen to the UK economy this year. Will it be a year of sustained growth and low inflation? Will a recession in the US have any effect here? What will happen if there is a change of government?
fields.body:
Time is running out to win £500 worth of books in our annual economics forecasting competition. All you have to do is guess what will happen to the UK economy this year. Will it be a year of sustained growth and low inflation? Will a recession in the US have any effect here? What will happen if there is a change of government?

What we are looking for is the most accurate forecast in six areas of the economy: growth, interest rates, underlying inflation, unemployment, the current account and the exchange rate. You should say what you think the increase in gross domestic product will be in 2001; what the bank base lending rate will be on December 31; the level of inflation excluding mortgage interest payments in December 2001; the unemployment total in December on the seasonally adjusted claimant count; the UK current account in 2001 (in pounds not as a percentage of GDP) and sterling's value against the euro on December 31 (ie how much €1 will buy).

Entries are welcome from all those who fancy themselves as an economics pundit. Previous years have shown that a sixth former is as likely a winner as a City analyst. You could win £500 worth of book tokens from leading publisher Palgrave. Answers on a postcard to: Guardian Economics Competition, Economics Desk, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

You can also enter on the web at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/economy. Online entries will also be in the running to win a Palgrave economics dictionary. Guardian competition rules apply. Entry deadline is February 1.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The British and European economies have converged to the point where the government can prepare for euro entry, according to the influential think tank the National Institute for Economic and Social Research.
fields.body:
Observer

The British and European economies have converged to the point where the government can prepare for euro entry, according to the influential think tank the National Institute for Economic and Social Research. The think tank says if Britain joined in the next parliament, the government would have to raise income tax by 2p or cut public investment by £12bn.

Sunday Times

BG, the gas exploration arm of the old British Gas, is being stalked by an unknown American predator. Industry experts say Phillips Petroleum is the most likely candidate. Together BG and Phillips would form a company worth £20bn. Phillips has a strong gas division and would fit well with BG, which is primarily an exploration business. The American company is expected to decide by the end of the month whether to bid.

Nissan is close to awarding its Sunderland plant the deal to produce the new Micra after vigorous lobbying by the government.

ISL, the sports marketing company, is said to be facing a financial crisis and is carrying out a review which could lead to deals being renegotiated or terminated.

Mark Dixon, billionaire founder of serviced office company Regus, plans to hand over operational control to two new chief executives.

Sunday Telegraph

Serco, the engineering and services group, is favourite to win the controversial partial privatisation of national air traffic control services after submitting an indicative bid of about 800m. This is said to be between £100m and £200m higher than rival offers. Other bidders include Novares, a joint venture between Lockheed Martin and New Zealand's Airways International. Another consortium includes British Airways, British Midland and Virgin.

CGNU, Britain's largest insurance group, is said to be considering scrapping its alliance with French banking group Société Générale. The move could include CGNU selling part of its 7% stake in the French group.

John Menzies is putting up for sale its 220-store strong chain Early Learning Centre. Analysts say the business, which sells educational toys, could fetch about 40m.

Entrepreneur Robert Breare is expected to announce a £472m bid for Midlands pub and brewing group Wolverhampton & Dudley, backed by venture capital group Botts & Co. He has been working on the bid since August.

Mail on Sunday

Belgian beer group Interbrew is drawing up plans to break up Bass to appease competition watchdogs. It is looking at selling Bass's main operations in England and Wales, and hopes to persuade the government that it should be allowed to keep Bass's operations in Northern Ireland and Scotland.

Sunday Express

Ed Wallis, the boss of electricity generator Powergen, is in line for a payoff worth almost £4m if a proposed takeover by Germany's E.ON goes ahead. Analysts said E.ON would have to pay around 800p a share or £5.2bn to secure Powergen.

Clifford Chance, Britain's biggest law firm, is being sued for up to £1bn by a Canadian construction magnate over alleged negligence, improper conduct and conflict of interest. The claim, by Joseph Zappia and Zappia Middle East Construction, relates to military and civil construction projects in Abu Dhabi in the mid-1980s.

Sunday Business

Former Barings deputy chairman Andrew Tuckey has been barred from the Institute of Chartered Accountants for four years for failing to control rogue trader Nick Leeson, who brought down the bank in 1995.

EasyJet, the budget airline, is considering bidding for rival Go, owned by British Airways, if the asking price continues to fall.

British email encryption specialist 5GM has rebuffed takeover approaches from Baltimore Technologies and Nasdaq-listed Entrust.

IoS

A plan to put former chief executive Greg Hutchings back in charge of troubled conglomerate Tomkins is being hatched with the support of the Gates family, the Denver-based industrialists who own 20 % of the company. Mr Hutchings resigned in October after allegations about his corporate excesses.

Satellite broadcaster BSkyB is preparing to write off as much as £250m of its £301m investment. Sports Internet Group , bought last year at the height of the internet boom.

Pierre Bonelli, chief executive of technology services group Sema, is expected to announce his retirement later this month. He has been under pressure since the company issued a profits warning in November.

fields.headline: Sir Reginald Bennett
fields.trailText: Sir Reginald Bennett, the former Tory MP for Gosport and Fareham, and then Fareham, for 29 years, who has died aged 89, lived a life of missed opportunities.
fields.body:
Sir Reginald Bennett, the former Tory MP for Gosport and Fareham, and then Fareham, for 29 years, who has died aged 89, lived a life of missed opportunities.

With the brains of a Winchester and New College, Oxford, scholar, the training as a doctor at St George's and a psychiatrist at the Maudsley - and skills as a flyer and champion yachtsman - his highest parliamentary achievement was as chairman of the Commons catering committee and parliamentary private secretary to Sir David Maxwell-Fyfe and then Iain Macleod.

His own great claim was that he warned a disbelieving Macleod that Alec Douglas-Home was likely to succeed Harold Macmillan as prime minister in 1963. Along the way, he also became commodore of the Commons yachting club and his own convivial Imperial Poona Yacht Club.

Although he entered parliament in 1950 with Edward Heath, Reginald Maudling, Macleod and Enoch Powell, Bennett lacked their driving ambition. He preferred to be seen as a jovial yachtsman who sailed with Prince Philip, an eager free-tripper and a willing accepter of consultancies and directorships.

Then the only Tory psychiatrist in the Commons, he might have attributed his relaxed style to too much uncritical affection from his parents. He was born in Yorkshire, the son of a civil servant. At Oxford, he joined the university air squadron and won a blue for sailing each year from 1931 to 1934, when he also won the Hamburg Cup, competing against the Germans. He was helmsman on the Shamrock V, which competed against the United States in 1934-35.

He served as a surgeon lieutenant commander during the second world war, initially in the western approaches and on the northern patrol, surviving being torpedoed twice. After he won his wings with the Fleet Air Arm in 1941, he became a flying medical officer in East Africa and Ceylon.

Having fought the hopeless seat of East Woolwich in 1937 and 1945, Bennett won Gosport and Fareham in 1950. When his party won the 1951 election, he became PPS to Maxwell-Fyfe, Churchill's first postwar home secretary. But he showed himself better as a drinking or yachting companion than as a political eager-beaver.

His occasional articles for the doctors' magazine, the Practitioner, included one which sought to prove that mothers-in-law willed the failures of their children's marriages, wanting their sons to reject "the silly, feather-brained little minx who has infatuated her boy". In a debate on homosexuality, he welcomed the fact that their then fear of imprisonment helped their treatment.

His political activity tended to concentrate on improving the quality of the water through which yachts had to sail. The Solent was full of untreated sewage, enabling him to coin the phrase, "You get your own back."

After falling ill with salmonella poisoning, Bennett complained about Commons hygiene, and was promptly elected chairman of the Commons kitchen committee, a post which enabled him to replenish its depleted wine cellar. He was knighted when he announced he would retire.

He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Henrietta, their son and three daughters.

 Reginald Frederick Brittain Bennett, psychiatrist and politician, born July 22 1911; died December 19 2000

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 17. Relocation
fields.trailText: 17. Relocation
fields.body:
Your boss has been posted to the Sydney office for two years and, despite all your laboured hints, you haven't been invited. It's no use gnashing your teeth; you've got to make the best of it - for you and your boss. And if you think moving house in the UK is stressful, try moving yourself and your family halfway around the world! Your boss will need all the help he can get.

* First, does your firm have a good relocation policy? If so, it needs to be communicated clearly so that employees who are relocating know exactly what to expect. Preparation is vital. If there is no policy, get one started.

*Next, get reliable advice from experts. Find a good information site and gather as much material on the relocation destination as possible. The person who is going to live there can never know too much about the place, from the culture to the climate, and from the work habits to the social niceties. This will help the employee to settle in more quickly. In particular, find out what sort of budget he or she will need once out there.

*Companies should be aware of any obstacles employees might face, such as visa restrictions, requirements for importing certain items into the country, or immunisations they need before travelling.

*Schools are a major issue for families relocating, so firms must ensure there are suitable ones close by. It's also important to consider the family set-up. Where career-minded spouses are involved, firms would be well-advised to ensure there are work possibilities for them, too. Nothing will jeopardise a successful relocation more than an unhappy spouse.

*Make sure employees have somewhere to live on a long-term basis as soon as possible. Arrangements for healthcare provision need to be made before the relocation takes place. Employees can change these once they've arrived, but the service must be accessible immediately.

*Encourage the relocating member of staff to learn the lingo - or at least make a start - and do some "culture orientation" before they go. Serious culture shock is no joke, and can leave people unable to function properly for days.

*And cheer up! You may not be jetting off to work in Sydney, but maybe you can swing a cheap holiday while your boss is out there.

By Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: Seeing eye to eye
fields.standfirst: How one duo manage it
fields.trailText: How one duo manage it
fields.body:
The Assistant: Helen Sears Marketing and new business co-ordinator Biss Lancaster (PR agency)

"It was partly because of my degree in French that I was employed by Graham, and it was used from the moment I started as his PA five years ago. My potential in other areas was also noticed, and I was soon given the opportunity and training to get involved in areas like international marketing and setting up the corporate video and website.

"I guess it was this recognition that led me to adore my job and have a constant thirst for more responsibility which, in turn, has led to a series of promotions. I'm even getting my own assistant next week.

"Unlike many people whose work involves large amounts of administration, I honestly believe my boss recognises my value. That's why I have such loyalty towards this company."

The Boss: Graham Lancaster Chairman

"Years ago, I worked as a PA at the CBI. My job title wasn't PA largely because I was a bloke, but nevertheless that's what the job was. That's when I learned that it's an extremely demanding role and have respected it ever since.

"My ethos here is 'If you can't measure it, you can't manage it.' That's why I make sure we monitor employees' hours through timesheets; we measure their morale through regular chats; and we measure the development they require through providing each of them with a personal development manager.

"I'm particularly keen on the development part, as I feel that employees are often pigeonholed when they join a company. They begin as, say, a junior secretary and continue to be defined as that. I believe in defining people's role not as what it was when they joined the company, but what it has developed into."

fields.trailText: * A big boo-hiss goes out to all those beastly bosses giving the Weakest Link treatment to their poor, bedraggled employees. fields.body:
* A big boo-hiss goes out to all those beastly bosses giving the Weakest Link treatment to their poor, bedraggled employees. A survey by website business365 quizzed more than 1,000 staff to find which famous personality they most likened to their superiors. The results, in this mad, bad, TV-led world showed a quarter likening their bosses to that old stickler of a role model Anne Robinson.

The second most popular choice (named by 17%) was Mr Burns, the tight-fisted yellow nuclear power chief from The Simpsons; and the third (chosen by 15%) was that wideboy Del Boy Trotter in Only Fools and Horses. Other "boss-alikes" included Eastenders' Ian Beale and Coronation Street's Mike Baldwin.

Disregarding the fact that our nation's bosses are largely dishonest demons, WPM thinks you lot should get out more. The term "personality" isn't just confined toTV. It's a big ol' world beyond the sofa, you know.

*Yes, we know it's childish and we know it's silly, but we'd still like to send a little anonymous note to a handful of colleagues - just to let them know the real reason we've been shamelessly avoiding them for the past couple of years. The preliminary draft reads . . .

Dear co-worker,

You stink.

Love anon.

The thing is, WPM doesn't want to take responsibility for the letter in case she is in any way seen as insensitive (and in case she gets found out).

So, hail the arrival of CoWorkerHints.com - unquestionably our website of the week for its campaign to rid the office of unsavoury sights and smells. Founded by Carole Shepard in the USA (where else?) the website writes anonymously to fellow office workers, tactfully telling them they may need to improve their hygiene or habits.

Personal hygiene problems covered on the website include nose-picking and body odour, while other letters broach the subjects of dressing provocatively, always being late and having bad dandruff.

Shepard got the idea for the website after experiencing for herself the trauma of pungent colleagues. Initial responses have been positive and more than 70 anonymous letters are sent out by Shepard each week on behalf of workers at their wits' end.

"TN" is one of the happy customers whose $9.95 was well spent. (S)he enthuses on the website ". . .Your letter surpassed my expectations. We had tried everything we could think of to get our coworker to use deodorant . . . Now we can breathe again . . ." Don't you just love a happy, sweet-smelling ending?

*Many thanks to Cathy Mowat of PricewaterhouseCoopers for her email responding to our report last week on the devaluation of work by bad spelling and poor grammar in the work place.

A good example of said sloppiness, writes the impressively perceptive Pricewaterhouse-Coopers employee, is the advertisement placed in the Guardian by the General Teaching Council for England, the first line of which talks about "it's own professional standards . . ."

A truly appalling mistake, as our reader points out. But at the same time Miss Cathy fails herself. She writes: "If one cannot rely on an institution like that to get it right, who can we reply (sic) on !" Sigh. For a moment then, WPM felt she had met her match. But disappointment reigns. She is once again left with the impression that there truly is no one as perfect and perceptive as she.

*The way to the office staff's heart is through their stomachs. That's the message of Nimble, the UK's popular low-calorie bread, following a survey of office workers' early eating habits. The Nimble study shows that 10% of employees arrive at their workplace early in order to eat breakfast. And a further one in ten combine their morning munch with a breakfast meeting two or three times every week. Since almost four in 10 workers are eating breakfast at their desks every day, the Nimblers reckon that understanding bosses are catering for the trend by providing kettles, microwaves, toasters and even ovens for a lucky one in ten of the UK workforce. Following the results of the survey, WPM is thinking of asking for a fully fitted Andrew Macintosh kitchen at her desk area. All in the name of brain food, you understand.

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: New Buckenham, Norfolk
fields.trailText: New Buckenham, Norfolk
fields.body:
At a distance in the gathering dusk it looked like a huge black tarpaulin smothering the field. But at our approach the sheet suddenly rose in a single continuous wave then twisted vertically and spiralled skywards. They were rooks and jackdaws, a pre-roost gathering of thousands of birds, which filled the air with a musical, conversational chatter. Small wonder that the collective noun for a rook flock is a parliament. Similar in appearance to the carrion crow and raven, the rook was never blighted with the other bird's evil reputation. Their presence was usually taken as a good omen and their behaviour treated as a reliable weather report. A flock flying up and down or moving very slowly was taken as a sign of rain and wind, but if they flew high to roost then a fine day was in store.

While generally considered the farmer's friend for eating many insect pests, they are still treated as a nuisance in arable areas. The misnamed scarecrow was, in truth, always aimed at the rook, not its more solitary cousin. If birds couldn't be frightened away, then their numbers were controlled - one benefit was the rook's renown as a good foodstuff, a reputation dating back even to the ancient Greeks. In the 18th century, rook livers sold in Norwich market as a cure for rickets, and until recently rook pie was a standard in the country kitchen (is it still?). Landowners prized them so highly as food that they regularly protected their rookeries from poachers, and until the mid-19th century a large rookery like the one in old limes at Hampton Court Park yielded a seasonal harvest of 1,200 birds.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Collector | Who Am I? | Rita, Sue And Bob Too | L'Argent
fields.body:
The Collector

(William Wyler, 1965)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Terence Stamp stars as a butterfly collector who pins down art student Samantha Eggar, kidnapping and imprisoning her in a farmhouse cellar. This is a chilling portrait of sexual obsession from Stamp, and Eggar is impressively restrained; the veteran Wyler retains much of the creepiness of John Fowles' first novel.

Who Am I?

(Bennie and Jackie Chan, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax A minor adventure from the master of martial arts comedy, but for sheer Chan chutzpah it exceeds the more illustrious Rush Hour. The creaky plot has Chan's crack commando Whoami pursued by killers. He doesn't know why - he's suffering from amnesia - but, with the hugely entertaining fight scenes, it really doesn't matter.

Rita, Sue And Bob Too

(Alan Clarke, 1987)

11.50pm, FilmFour

Here's a comic slice of life in the raw on Bradford's Buttershaw estate. Schoolgirls Rita and Sue (Siobhan Finneran, Michelle Holmes) are shagged, in quite a dreary sort of way, by snazzy Bob (George Costigan) in his flash car. It gets grimmer, though. There's his furious wife (Lesley Sharp), a miscarriage and parental ire. But a bubbly humour remains - down-to-earth, just like Mike Leigh's, but more credible. And the film throws up some great, salt-of-the-earth performances that hardly look like acting.

L'Argent

(Robert Bresson, 1983)

4am, FilmFour

A schoolboy (Christian Patey) unloads a forged 500 franc note, thereby launching a chain of events that lead to madness, murder and prison. Based on Leo Tolstoy's short story The Counterfeit Note, Robert Bresson's final film is an extraordinary parable on greed, conscience and redemption. Employing a non-professional cast (Bresson famously had no time for actors) and a typically sparse, unadorned visual style, he creates a bleakly moving vision of humanity.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Steve Buscemi in Bloodhounds Of Broadway (Howard Brookner, 1989)

Who? Professionally skinny Peter Lorre-lookalike Buscemi has made a career out of playing weaselly types, most famously as the weaselly Mr Pink in Reservoir Dogs (1992). He's been weaselly in indie movies (Fargo, Living In Oblivion) and weaselly in blockbusters (Con Air, Armageddon). After appearing as a weaselly wannabe rock star in Airheads (1994) with Adam Sandler, the two became friends, and Buscemi has had uncredited weaselly cameo roles in all Sandler's comedies. He also turned director for the Cassavetes-inspired Trees Lounge (1996), and his second film behind the camera, Animal Factory, is out later this year.

The role: Whining (and decidedly weaselly) Willie, a no-good low-life who plays poker with Regret (Matt Dillon), Feet Samuels (Randy Quaid) and the extremely intimidating Big Sheley (Herschel Sparber).

Best line: After betting with (and losing) an engagement ring in the poker game, he whines "She said she wouldn't schtup me until we were engaged. So I went out and borrowed the thing from my mother. But she expects it back tomorrow... and they're both going to kill me!"

Cringe factor: He's slightly more weaselly than usual, but not much more.

Other wannabes: Madonna in almost good film shock! She starred as Hortense Hathaway alongside a post-Dirty Dancing, pre-nose job Jennifer Grey (cast as Lovey Lou).

Critical judgement: "The cast is game," said Leonard Maltin, "and there are some funny bits - but it's mostly a snooze."

Also not starring in: A 1986 episode of LA Law and Kiss Daddy Goodnight (1997).

Bloodhounds Of Broadway, 11pm, Thursday 25 January, Carlton Cinema

After appearing as a weaselly wannabe rock star in Airheads (1994) with Adam Sandler, the two became friends, and Buscemi has had uncredited weaselly cameo roles in all Sandler's comedies. He also turned director for the Cassavetes-inspired Trees Lounge (1996), and his second film behind the camera, Animal Factory, is out later this year. The role: Whining (and decidedly weaselly) Willie, a no-good low-life who plays poker with Regret (Matt Dillon), Feet Samuels (Randy Quaid) and the extremely intimidating Big Sheley (Herschel Sparber). Best line: After betting with (and losing) an engagement ring in the poker game, he whines "She said she wouldn't schtup me until we were engaged. So I went out and borrowed the thing from my mother. But she expects it back tomorrow... and they're both going to kill me!" Cringe factor: He's slightly more weaselly than usual, but not much more. Other wannabes: Madonna in almost good film shock! She starred as Hortense Hathaway alongside a post-Dirty Dancing, pre-nose job Jennifer Grey (cast as Lovey Lou). Critical judgement: "The cast is game," said Leonard Maltin, "and there are some funny bits - but it's mostly a snooze." Also not starring in: A 1986 episode of LA Law and Kiss Daddy Goodnight (1997). Bloodhounds Of Broadway, 11pm, Thursday 25 January, Carlton Cinema

webTitle: Mark Lawson on the police drama Second Sight

fields.headline: The chosen ones
fields.standfirst: Trying out a potential drama series as a one-off pilot may seem a logical way of assessing audience appeal. But, as the police drama Second Sight shows, it has its pitfalls, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: Trying out a potential drama series as a one-off pilot may seem a logical way of assessing audience appeal. But, as the police drama Second Sight shows, it has its pitfalls, says Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
One of the biggest changes in television in the last three decades has been the attitude to try-out episodes. In the 60s and 70s - when budgets were much greater, rival channels scarce and the opinions of viewers were thought largely irrelevant - a "pilot" show was usually for internal consumption only. If admired by the programme-makers, it would be screened as the first of the eventual series, shown in the summer slump as what was euphemistically called a "special", or simply shelved in the basement: there have been entire documentaries constructed from unseen sample shows.

These days, as this column frequently points out, the power is with the consumer. The schedules contain more pilots than the cabin-crew rest-rooms at Kennedy Airport. Most potential series are now asked to screen a taster, rather in the way that supermarkets lay out paper plates with small pieces of new delicacies for shoppers to try, with the hope of tempting them to purchase.

One of last year's in-store promotions by the BBC was a Paula Milne two-parter about DCI Ross Tanner (Clive Owen), a detective diagnosed with a degenerative condition of the retina which produces blurred vision and hallucinations. He confides in DI Catherine Tully (Claire Skinner), whose big, bright eyes became his own when they were at work. When they were at home, he gazed in to them with romantic intent.

Second Sight now returns for a second viewing as a series, and offers a fascinating case-study in the difficulties of turning a successful one-off into a long-runner.

The first difficulty is personnel. One of the attractions of the first Second Sight was that it was written by Paula Milne, one of the best television dramatists. But the level of demand for her words has made her unavailable for the series and so she becomes, in the closest the TV scriptwriter gets to being god, an absentee creator, her characters handed over to the lesser-known Antonia Hallem.

It's true that many television shows are multi-authored - all the soaps, most American comedies - but there's a problem when a piece of writing begins bespoke and then goes off-the-peg. Editions of ITV's London's Burning were fine as long as you hadn't seen the single crafted drama by Jack Rosenthal, the spark from which it spread. Watching that - and now Second Sight - you begin to contemplate a literary equivalent of the Child Support Agency, bringing writers to account for the conceptions they've left others to raise.

Executives would argue that only very picky viewers spot a change of dramatist. But an overhaul of the performers is harder to disguise.

In the pilot episode, viewers presumably responded to the central couple and the secret they were keeping. Yet, having carefully established this intriguing dependency in the tempter episode, the series opener is devoted to dismantling it. Skinner is missing from most of the second part, assumed working on other projects. She returns briefly near to the end to play what has the feel of an exit scene, patting her lover's dog and asking him to look after his master. The strong Hollywood precedent is that actresses who say goodbye to Fido have got another offer.

Lacking both the initial writer and the original co-star, Second Sight is in even worse than usual condition to face the traditional complication of the series-pleader which gets accepted: how much recapping should there be? Think of that moment at a dinner-party when a late entrant or loo-user arrives at the end of a joke or anecdote. The demanded repetition is not only irritating for those who know the punchline, but the narrator may get self-conscious in the re-telling.

The making of a series from a drama previously previewed is a multi-million pound extension of the same dilemma. With the establishing episodes recently repeated to build interest in the series, a large percentage of viewers have already lived through Tanner's terrifying realisation that his vision is slipping. The solution in what might be called the second Second Sight is to run elegant variations on his difficulties: a hand-shake with a stranger becomes like finding the light-switch at night, he trails his fingers along the nearest wall in a mannerism which looks idle but is vital. There is, though, no speech for new viewers explaining what his condition is.

It increasingly seems to me that the most crucial question in making television programmes is: how much does the audience know? In news and documentary, the answer to this question sets the intellectual level of the product. In drama and comedy, the response decides whether the script can be allusive and subtle or filled with characters telling each other things they already know. Most British dramas follow the American tradition of the re-cap ("Previously on this series..."), but the test is most severe in the shift from pilot to series.

My fear is that the second Second Sight is too repetitive if you saw the original, not echoey enough if you didn't. The system of piloting shows is designed to be more sensitive to the viewer but, in some cases, it works against the audience.

 Second Sight, tonight, 9.10pm, BBC1

fields.headline: You had to be there
fields.trailText: I Love 1981 | Phoenix Nights | It's Your Funeral | London's Burning
fields.body:
I once went to a fancy dress party as Adam Ant. I think I was seven. It was the first time I had ever won the best costume prize. (The second (and last) time came some years later when I went to another fancy dress party dressed as Herr Flick from 'Allo 'Allo). I mention this only because I Love 1981 (BBC2, Saturday) was rather like an acid flashback. And being six in 1981, I had never taken acid. Come to think of it, I still haven't. Considering how scary I Love 1981 was without drugs - particularly seeing how terribly Adam himself has aged - I think I'll continue to avoid LSD.

Mind-altering substances might make Phoenix Nights (Channel 4, Sunday) slightly more amusing. It would be unfair to call Peter Kay's creation a sitcom. But it's not a drama-comedy - a "dramady" - either. That only leaves the label of comedy- drama which, I suppose, is a fair assessment of its strengths and weaknesses. Phoenix Nights is a "coma".

While not flatlining yet, it is rather insipid, with not nearly enough variety of character or detail in the plot to encourage regular viewing. There were some nice touches - Ray Vaughan, the mullet-sporting DJ, a Das Boot gambling machine - and elements of truth to the goings-on at the northern club run by the wheelchair-using Brian. Overall though, it seemed too nastily patronising towards its subjects, without an archness or streak of comic genius, the presence of which would make its nastiness almost forgivable. As it is, we have a rather second-rate northern comic taking the mickey out of northern plebs. Hilarious.

Slumming it somewhat, Kaye Adams presents It's Your Funeral (Channel 5, Sunday) in which each week a celebrity guest discusses what kind of burial they'd prefer and how they'd like their friends to remember their last big day. "It's not about death," Kaye - looking smashing in leather trousers - told us. "It's a celebration of life."

The series has 13 parts. This is unlucky for some, namely Kaye and any viewer tuning in by accident. For the first in the series, they obviously couldn't get any celebrities - or else Sylvestra Le Touzel cancelled at the last minute - so Lesley Joseph was parachuted in as a replacement. Kaye was right after all. It's not about death. It's about torture.

After dropping into the conversation that she had been on This Is Your Life, Lesley mused on how awful it would be to be gone and forgotten. Clearly she didn't realise that being gone and forgotten is slightly better than being around and forgotten, a feeling she may be more familiar with. (Unless you count those supermarket adverts she did which, frankly, we don't).

Lesley's choice of funeral rites and privileges was actually quite interesting. She wanted Sunrise, Sunset from Fiddler On The Roof played, she wanted Jewish prayers, she wanted photographs of her family and her granny's little shoe in her coffin with her (don't fret - her grandma didn't need it).

For a moment, you could actually feel a little human warmth for her. And then she showed the dress she wanted to be buried in. It looked like an unravelled pan scourer. "I'll look like mutton dressed as lamb," she said firmly. Where a less experienced presenter might have blurted out "No change there, then", Kaye maintained a diplomatic silence. The woman is a professional. Next week, Kaye Adams talks to Carmen Silvera about how she wants to be remembered.

London's Burning (ITV, Sunday) returned for a 13th series and again, it was unlucky for some. Despite killing off a couple of regulars, flagging up the presence of a couple of sexual deviants (a gay bloke and a virginal lad) and getting the man who throws all the money away in that insurance advert to run the station, there was hardly a spark of excitement. The dialogue was clunky, the pace leaden and the acting so wooden, it was a wonder the firefighters of Blue Watch didn't spontaneously combust when they braved burning buildings. The special effects, meanwhile, made Casualty look like Independence Day.

There was a pregnant lady trapped in a car, a strange plotline about a cheap handbag and an expensive necklace, and Kira from This Life plunging to her death from a great height. And the theme tune is so 80s. Not, it has to be said, in a good way.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: A Revolution In Five Acts | Nature: The Albatross
fields.body:
A two-week season recalling Queen Victoria's 63 years on the throne begins today, the 100th anniversary of her death. There are, naturally, acres about the royals but the more compelling programmes deal with issues in which they played little or no part. In daily episodes this week Ian Hislop traces A Revolution In Five Acts (11.0am, Radio 4), the legislation which underpinned the century's industrial and social changes. He opens with the 1844 Railway Act, a startling Parliamentary curb on unrestricted capitalist enterprise.

The ways of evolution can sometimes be quite impenetrable, as Mark Carwardine discovers in Nature: The Albatross (9.0pm, Radio 4). Though its nesting area has an apparently adequate supply, the bird still chooses to fly hundreds of miles in search of food. This habit is proving ever more costly with the spread of long-line tuna fishing. Cruising albatrosses spot the bait, dive for it, and are mortally impaled on the hooks holding it.

webTitle: BBC News goes head to head with News at Ten

fields.headline: Head to head
fields.trailText: Tonight, for the first time ever, the BBC News (10pm, BBC1) and ITV News At Ten (10pm, ITV), will run against each other.
fields.body:
Tonight, for the first time ever, the BBC News (10pm, BBC1) and ITV News At Ten (10pm, ITV), will run against each other.

Critics' reviews of the year 2000 all made the point that the developing trend in TV last year was the broadcasting of elimination and humiliation: Big Brother, The Weakest Link and Survivor all employed head-to-head competition leaving only one person to take the prize.

This game-show culture has now come to current affairs. It seems unlikely that both the BBC and ITV bulletins can remain at 10pm. In the next few months, executives and newsreaders at either organisation may be able to empathise with the contestants voted out of the Big Brother house.

Looking at the schedules for tonight's first 10pm stand-off, there are two key factors to consider in assessing the likely ratings: inheritance and alternative.

The rough science of scheduling depends heavily on the idea of inheritance: that a successful programme, like a tycoon writing his will, can change the fortunes of those which follow. The BBC1 is relying on The Weakest Link (8.30pm) and Second Sight (reviewed left). ITV is banking on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? (9pm). Most money will be on ITV to win, although the BBC might hope that the opposition is now over-exploiting a declining brand.

The question of alternative is also intriguing. The one possible advantage of the two News at 10pm is that the terrestrial viewer now has only three excuses for not watching the bulletin rather than four. BBC2 has treated its sister gently, scheduling only the latest Room 101, but there is some evidence that Channel 4 is mischievously seeking to spoil two launch parties by screening one of the finest films of the 90s, the Coen brothers' Fargo. Most worryingly, we now face another few months of the news being in the News.

fields.headline: Perverting the course of justice?
fields.standfirst:
They admitted it. The judge said they had no defence. But last week, two people who attempted to trash a nuclear submarine were acquitted. Marcel Berlins and Clare Dyer on why more and more juries are returning 'perverse' verdicts

Special report: trial by jury
fields.trailText: They admitted it. The judge said they had no defence. But last week, two people who attempted to trash a nuclear submarine were acquitted.  Marcel Berlins  and  Clare Dyer  on why more and more juries are returning 'perverse' verdicts.
fields.body:
On the very day that the appeal court described the jury's verdict in the Bruce Grobbelaar libel trial in the most damning terms that judges can muster, virtually calling the jurors mad, another 12 men and women, in Manchester, were doing their bit to be added to the roll-call of juries for whom "perverse" is an honourable label. They brought in a verdict of not guilty on two anti-nuclear protesters charged with conspiracy to cause criminal damage to a Trident submarine in a Barrow-in-Furness shipyard. The two happily admitted their intention to trash the sub but said they were doing so because nuclear weapons were immoral and illegal. The judge told the jury that such ideals formed no defence against the charge. He was ignored. Not guilty, said the jury.

It was not the first time that juries have, apparently contrary to the evidence, acquitted defendants charged with sabotage of defence equipment. But that strand of acquittals is itself part of a greater English tradition, going back to the trial of William Mead and William Penn, nonconformists charged in 1670 with unlawful preaching and conducting a seditious assembly. The jury was threatened by the judge and locked up for two nights "without meat, drink, fire or tobacco" after it refused to convict them but still stubbornly stuck to its verdict. The jurors were then fined and imprisoned till they paid, but were ultimately released by the Chief Justice, upholding "the right of juries to give their verdict by their conscience".

A perverse verdict could just mean - as in the Grobbelaar case - a totally unreasonable conclusion from the evidence presented. But the more distinguished form of jury perversity arises when jurors in a criminal trial, following their consciences and their moral beliefs, acquit a defendant even where the evidence and the law clearly point to conviction. Lord Devlin, one of the great law lords, regarded the jury's right to bring in a perverse acquittal as one of the glories of our jury system. "It gives protection against laws which the ordinary man regards as harsh and oppressive . . . an insurance that the criminal law will conform to the ordinary man's ideas of what is fair and just. If it does not, the jury will not be a party to its enforcement."

In 1985, Clive Ponting, a senior Ministry of Defence official, was tried under the Official Secrets Act for revealing to an MP that government ministers had misled Parliament over the sinking of the Argentine warship General Belgrano during the Falklands War. There was no doubt that he had done so and that he had no legal defence to the charge, as the trial judge made clear to the jury. Nevertheless the jury acquitted him. Jurors may not be asked why they reached a particular verdict, but it emerged that some of them resented the patronising and over-emphatic way in which the trial judge, in effect, ordered them to convict. Another factor was the feeling that the "catch-all" section of the Official Secrets Act under which Ponting was charged and which allowed no public interest defence was unfair and oppressive.

Even more striking was the acquittal at the Old Bailey in 1990 of Pat Pottle and Michael Randle, on a charge of helping the Soviet spy George Blake escape from Wormwood Scrubs in 1963, enabling him to flee to Russia. This was not just a case of a jury disregarding the judge's clear - and legally correct - instruction that the two men had no defence. The jury knew for a fact that they were guilty - not least because they had published a book entitled The Blake Escape - How We Freed George Blake and Why. As if that wasn't enough, Pottle and Randle, defending themselves, confirmed their responsibility for the crime and made impassioned speeches from the dock. They argued that bringing them to court 26 years after the crime was an abuse of the legal process and showed a political motive behind their prosecution. The jury was clearly impressed and acquitted, knowing that it was delivering a perverse verdict, showing two fingers to a system that would behave in this way. Nor is it just in highly publicised cases raising quasi-political or social issues that juries have shown their bolshie independence. Away from the headlines, juries often acquit guilty defendants simply because they feel strongly that no prosecution should have been brought. Forgetful elderly shoplifters are frequent beneficiaries of jury anger at their being in the dock at all.

In the 19th century, juries used to find defendants not guilty of crimes they had clearly committed because the penalties - a death sentence or long imprisonment - were so disproportionate to the crime (stealing a sheep, for instance). The modern equivalent is the jury that refuses to convict a mercy killer of murder, even when all the ingredients of the crime are present, because a murder conviction means an automatic life sentence. The result is that mercy killers often escape with a conviction for manslaughter, and a lighter sentence, on the often spurious grounds of diminished responsibility.

Peace protestors have a long record of successful appeals to the jury's conscience. In the 1970s a group led by the well-known campaigner Pat Arrowsmith were charged under the 1934 Disaffection Act for leafleting troops at Aldershot and acquitted after a 51-day trial, despite overwhelming evidence against them. The trial took place before the Contempt of Court Act 1981 put a firm lid on jury revelations, and some jurors revealed afterwards that they had made up their minds to clear the defendants after just five days.

In recent years lawyers have put forward ingenious defences to con vince juries to acquit their clients. A string of anti-nuclear protesters including Sylvia Boyes and Keith Wright, the anti-Trident activists acquitted last week, have pleaded that their actions were necessary to prevent a greater evil. The pair, members of Trident Ploughshares, were caught in wet suits near the Trident submarine Vengeance, docked in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, in November 1999. They were carrying hammers, an axe and six cans of aerosol polish and admitted they intended to damage the sub, which was equipped to carry one-quarter of Britain's nuclear arsenal. They were acquitted of conspiracy to cause criminal damage by a Manchester jury after arguing that their actions were justified because nuclear weapons were immoral and in breach of international law. Politicians could not be trusted to act, so they had to step in to prevent disaster. In 1996 a Liverpool jury similarly acquitted two women charged with causing £1.5m damage to a Hawk fighter jet to prevent its use in the bombing of East Timor by Indonesia, contravening international law.

In another series of prosecutions, people with multiple sclerosis or other painful illnesses charged with using, growing or supplying cannabis have pleaded that the drug was the only means of relieving their pain. Juries have acquitted almost all those accused. Last September, Lord Melchett, executive director of Greenpeace, and 27 other environmental activists who trashed a field of genetically modified maize in Norfolk in July 1999 successfully pleaded that their action was justified to prevent the contamination of nearby organic crops. Under the Criminal Damage Act 1971, an accused has a defence if he acted to protect other property that he believed was in imminent danger, using means that he believed reasonable in the circumstances. Or maybe, like many of their fellow citizens, they just didn't like the idea of GM foods. Scimac, the industry body representing the company that developed the GM maize, said after the trial that the verdict raised "fundamental questions about the ability of our legal system to cope with the gradual erosion of respect for public rights and authority".

It offends them to have to convict an MS sufferer who takes a few illegal puffs to alleviate pain. They're also reluctant to make criminals out of defendants who think like them and have the same world view. And jurors don't want to risk sending to prison those who act out of genuine public interest or moral concern, even if they break the letter of the law. Most juries heed the judge's warnings and convict on the evidence, not on their feelings. But more and more jurors, it seems, are following their consciences. Perverse verdicts are on the rise.
fields.bodyText: On the very day that the appeal court described the jury's verdict in the Bruce Grobbelaar libel trial in the most damning terms that judges can muster, virtually calling the jurors mad, another 12 men and women, in Manchester, were doing their bit to be added to the roll-call of juries for whom "perverse" is an honourable label. They brought in a verdict of not guilty on two anti-nuclear protesters charged with conspiracy to cause criminal damage to a Trident submarine in a Barrow-in-Furness shipyard. The two happily admitted their intention to trash the sub but said they were doing so because nuclear weapons were immoral and illegal. The judge told the jury that such ideals formed no defence against the charge. He was ignored. Not guilty, said the jury. It was not the first time that juries have, apparently contrary to the evidence, acquitted defendants charged with sabotage of defence equipment. But that strand of acquittals is itself part of a greater English tradition, going back to the trial of William Mead and William Penn, nonconformists charged in 1670 with unlawful preaching and conducting a seditious assembly. The jury was threatened by the judge and locked up for two nights "without meat, drink, fire or tobacco" after it refused to convict them but still stubbornly stuck to its verdict. The jurors were then fined and imprisoned till they paid, but were ultimately released by the Chief Justice, upholding "the right of juries to give their verdict by their conscience". A perverse verdict could just mean - as in the Grobbelaar case - a totally unreasonable conclusion from the evidence presented. But the more distinguished form of jury perversity arises when jurors in a criminal trial, following their consciences and their moral beliefs, acquit a defendant even where the evidence and the law clearly point to conviction. Lord Devlin, one of the great law lords, regarded the jury's right to bring in a perverse acquittal as one of the glories of our jury system. "It gives protection against laws which the ordinary man regards as harsh and oppressive . . . an insurance that the criminal law will conform to the ordinary man's ideas of what is fair and just. webTitle: Four women tell  Diane Taylor their dress codes

fields.headline: Four women tell  Diane Taylor their dress codes
fields.standfirst: Suits you
fields.trailText: There are lots of practical considerations when you are a teacher. It's not the same as having an office job - schools can be fairly dirty.
fields.body:
Amanda Haehner
is 40 and a teacher at a south London comprehensive. There are lots of practical considerations when you are a teacher. It's not the same as having an office job - schools can be fairly dirty. Many a teacher has leaned against a radiator and ended up covered in old chewing gum.

I spend a lot of my time climbing up to get things from high shelves or delving into cupboards, and as the furniture is very old, you can end up spending a fortune on snagged tights. The heating system is often dysfunctional, too, so at the moment warm clothes are a priority. In the summer I dress to stay cool because there's no air-conditioning.

I know at some schools teachers are expected to wear suits but at mine the dress code is informal. I tend to wear jumpers and skirts or a comfortable suit, and I do wear make-up - but not too much. Some female teachers can manage high heels but I think it's difficult. I wouldn't wear anything expensive, either, because it would get ruined.

My pupils are very quick to pick up on my outfits. They think anyone over the age of 21 can't possibly be fashionable. The girls will make a comment if I've had my hair done or say something like: "New shoes, Miss?" or "I like your jacket". Fortunately their comments tend to be favourable - I have heard of kids being very cruel about what their teachers wear. I had one pupil who insisted I must be married - which I'm not - because I looked "respectable". She wasn't terribly clear on what not looking respectable might mean.

Amanda Jordan
is in her mid-40s and director of corporate strategists The Smart Company. She lives with her partner and their three children, aged 16, 11 and five.
Alot of our clients are in the city and the dress code there is much easier for men because they can just adopt the uniform of suits. I tend to do the same - my aim is not to cause a stir because I want to be recognised for my work, not my appearance.

The concept of power dressing - the padded shoulders, bright colours and heavy jewellery from TV shows like Dynasty - is very dated now. Senior female executives today go for a much more neutral look.

I do wear make-up but I think that's more because I'm getting older than because I want to impress. And I wear shoes with heels because I'm fairly small rather than because of any power dressing issue - I can't remember seeing any women in stilettos when I worked in the city.

Wearing fewer clothes to work in the summer isn't really an issue for women in the city because so many go to work early, finish late and sit in air-conditioned offices all day, so the suits can stay. When dressing down was introduced, I had to stop and think what the new uniform was.

I stick to my suits because I don't have time in my life to plan a new wardrobe. The trend for city women over the past five years has been to replace skirt suits with trouser suits. If I particularly wanted to impress at a meeting, I'd take extra care but that wouldn't necessarily mean putting a skirt on. The whole issue of dress codes is easier for men because men still dictate the roles and culture in big organisations.

Dr Kate Nobes
is 36 and a research scientist and lecturer at University College London. She lives with her husband and four-year-old daughter.

In a typical day I might conduct an experiment on nerve cell movement in the laboratory, give a lecture, then rush off to collect my daughter from nursery. I wear flat shoes because they're practical - you rarely see female scientists in heels - and smart but comfortable trousers and tops. I generally don't wear a skirt because I'm worried I won't be taken quite so seriously as an academic, but I do like to have a token feminine look because I think female lecturers are role models to students and I don't just want to dress like a man. I want to look attractive but not glamorous. I wear make-up but always use a neutral lipstick and only a bit of mascara.

Most senior scientists are male and that does influence how I dress - if I wore anything too glamorous, I know they'd view it as frivolous. I don't do the power dressing thing but if I'm giving a lecture, I spend a bit of time planning what to wear. If the audience is male and academic, I tie my hair back and wear black. I feel if I look like that, my science will be taken more seriously.

As a student and post-doc, I always wore jeans but I'm far more conscious of what I wear now. I'm aware of dressing slightly "up" to make a distinction between me and the students - I don't think men have to do that in the same way.

Last summer I wore a short T-shirt and hipster trousers which left my belly button on show. Nothing was said but I know it was noticed. Perhaps you can't be a good scientist and show your belly button.

Marina Pirotta
is 34, married and director of communications for Brent Council in north London.

PR is all about image and dealing with people's innate prejudices, and you can turn that to your advantage. I could either make a stand by not conforming or I could join the grey suits brigade and I chose to do the latter.

I remember in a previous job a male manager commented on how young I looked to be doing the job I was doing. I knew he wouldn't have said that to a man, so I made a conscious decision about how I was going to present myself. I deliberately look sober and not fashionable, and I never wear a skirt because I don't want to show off my legs.

I am more confident about my clothes now I'm older because I know I'm good at what I do. But first impressions do count - part of my job is media training and we teach women to avoid short skirts, dangly earrings and crossing their legs if they want to make a good impression.

Make-up is something I think about, too. I wear enough to look professional but I wouldn't put on lipstick or nail varnish for work because it might reinforce prejudices about my field being a fluffy, soft option full of dumb Sloane Rangers.

What I like about wearing a suit is that it's a uniform. I don't have to think about it - I know exactly which shirts go with which suits. What I don't like is the term power dressing because it's not a comment anyone would make to a man in asuit.

At weekends, I wear combats, a T-shirt and a denim jacket. If everyone dressed down at work, that's probably what I'd wear.

 Michele Hanson returns next week.
