fields.headline: Hack watch
fields.standfirst: The security services and Whitehall have long kept            dossiers on certain journalists but, characteristically, New Labour has            widened the focus - as an internal cabinet memo obtained by the Guardian            shows
fields.trailText: January 22 2001: The security services and Whitehall have long kept dossiers on certain journalists but, characteristically, New Labour has widened the focus - as an internal cabinet memo obtained by the Guardian shows.
fields.body:
"The worst thing you can ever do in politics is get hooked on reading your press," Tony Blair told Vanity Fair magazine last summer, straining to distance himself from new Labour's now immovable reputation as a media-fixated coven of spinmeisters and image-weavers. "I can't think I spend more than five minutes a day reading it - I read the Financial Times and I flick through the rest."

Even allowing for a touch of understandable hyperbole, there seems little reason to doubt his word. Fortunately for the prime minister, he now has a small army of little helpers to do the job for him. The days are long gone when Blair, Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson ran the most effective media operation in British politics by themselves from a couple of mobile phones in a House of Commons corridor.

Under the command of the short-tempered Alastair Campbell, an impressive three-pronged structure - based in Downing Street, the cabinet office and Labour's Millbank headquarters - has been grafted on to the traditional government information service to monitor and respond to the ever-growing out pourings of broadcast, print and internet journalists.

Now an internal cabinet office memo about the supposed connections and quirks of a hotch-potch of political journalists, leaked to the Guardian, has cast a new light on the thoroughness with which this enterprise is prosecuted - and highlighted the increasingly incestuous, inward-looking process of modern politics, as politicians report on journalists reporting on politicians.

It is not as if governments have never been fixated with their media coverage in the past. Both Harold Wilson and John Major were famously obsessed, masochistically consuming everything written about them, while cabinet papers of both Labour and Tory post-war governments reveal regular acerbic asides about this or that reporter or commentator and their possible motivations or weaknesses.

The security services and individual Whitehall departments have long kept dossiers on the more awkward journalists, but with characteristic rigour, new Labour - which likes to think of itself as more spinned against than spinning - appears to have widened the focus.

This cabinet office briefing on print journalists (see box) is understood to have been drafted in the autumn by Carl Shoben with Chris McShane, the two special advisers who effectively guide the government's media monitoring unit on Campbell's behalf and previously did the same job at Millbank.

Not to be confused with the more proactive strategic communications unit at Number 10, the media monitoring unit works on the Millbank model, providing round-the-clock summaries and analysis of the press and broadcast media to ministers and civil servants across Whitehall, including Blair himself.

Its briefings form the agenda for the daily 9am news planning meeting in Campbell's office. But it also provides customised reports for particular ministers and, courtesy of the intelligence services' electronic eavesdropping facilities, is able to monitor hard-to-reach broadcast networks.

Shoben and McShane's memo was drawn up as a thumbnail guide to the perceived influence, reliability and political leanings of daily newspaper reporters and commentators for the civil servants preparing the daily briefings, as well as the monitoring unit's other customers.

Their assessments vary from the unexceptionable to the questionable - reflecting the authors' own prejudices as much as the journalists' - while comments on the state of the reporters' careers pepper the briefing.

Andrew Grice of the Independent is thought to be "perhaps a little on the wane now" while at the same time it is said that "almost anything he does is significant", while Benedict Brogan of the Telegraph is regarded as being in a "proving himself situation at the moment".

Political designations include Thatcherite, rightwing, centre-right, liberal, old Labour right, centre-left and leftwing, but the authors understandably tread gingerly round the Blairite/Brownite camp affiliations that have provided so much lobby gossip fodder in recent years.

The Guardian's David Hencke and Hugo Young are both described as "obsessed" with freedom of information, while others are (tacitly) praised for relying more on "officially placed stories rather than leaks". The Mail's Simon Heffer, Anatole Kaletksy and Peter Riddell of the Times and the Guardian's Hugo Young and Polly Toynbee are all singled out for being influential, respected or widely read.

Of the 28 daily journalists listed in the memo, nine work for the Times, seven are on the Guardian, three are with the Telegraph, three the Independent, two are on the Mail, two the Financial Times and one each on the Mirror and the Express.

Surprisingly, no one is included from the Sun, not even its political editor Trevor Kavanagh, regarded by some as the most influential political journalist in the country. One explanation for the omission is that ministers and officials need no guidance as to where Rupert Murdoch's tabloid and its staff are coming from.

The memo has none of the contemptuous tone Campbell routinely deploys against recalcitrant journalists in his efforts to encourage more posi tive coverage of the government. But while some named on the list will be embarrassed by the official praise and others will wear criticism as a badge of honour, several of the authors' judgments will inevitably be questioned inside and outside the Westminster loop. Among those criticised, the Express's Patrick O'Flynn was recently promoted to be political editor, while the Guardian's Patrick Wintour, on any objective basis, is widely acknowledged as a story-getter and admired for his range of contacts and grasp of policy.

Most journalists are in any case well aware that different branches of government may be keeping a track of their activities. Departments will, for example, provide potted biographies of lunch guests for ministers to read in the back of the car on their way to meet political correspondents.

Details of a journalist's interests are usually included, along with relevant press cuttings, to prepare the minister for discussion on any pet issues.

One old hand from the lobby still cherishes the dossier that a friendly Labour minister passed over as a memento of their lunch.

"I was quite amused and the minster was too," says the former reporter. "The details were fairly innocuous, such as my areas of inter est and subjects I'd been recently interested in, if not entirely accurate."

But even if the language used by the authors of the leaked cabinet office memo is restrained compared with that of the prime minister's spokesman, it is doubtful that most career civil servants would have wanted to sign off such a politically explicit briefing.

New Labour's importation of modern US political campaigning and media management techniques into Whitehall - and the clean-out of press officers throughout the government - has sometimes strained relations with sections of the officially non-partisan civil service .

webTitle: Adams no more unto the breach

fields.headline: Adams no more unto the breach
fields.standfirst:
England stalwart calls time on international career
Leicester 0 - 0 Arsenal
fields.trailText: Tony Adams's decision to end his England career now rather than later is a case of a message being received and understood.
fields.body:
Tony Adams's decision to end his England career now rather than later is a case of a message being received and understood. In other words he has responded logically to what his body has been telling him for some time.

Adams would never have given up international football because he feared being dropped or merely because the new England coach, Sven-Goran Eriksson, has intimated in a vague sort of way that David Beckham might keep the captaincy. Recurring injuries, in particular a back problem, have persuaded Adams that, at 34 and in order to prolong his career with his club, Arsenal, he must give up playing for his country. Eriksson said he was "sorry" to hear of Adam's international retirement, having long admired his leadership qualities, but that he respected his decision.

In some ways his departure was inevitable. Last summer he led Kevin Keegan's team into the 2000 European Championship reading Henry V and ready to shore up English pride with English dead. But injuries restricted his participation to the opening game against Portugal.

Back to the squad he came for the start of the 2002 World Cup qualifiers, only to be forced out by injury for the Finland game four days after England's defeat by Germany at Wembley had hastened Keegan's departure and, with the help of Lazio's slump, Eriksson's arrival. Perhaps Adams should have been studying Hamlet - where practically everyone of note ends up dead except Fortinbras.

Eriksson would have been Adams's sixth England coach. Bobby Robson gave him his first cap in a friendly against Spain in Madrid in 1987, a match England won 4-2, and the following summer he played in the 1988 European Championship in West Germany, when Robson's side lost all three group games and came home early.

Adams missed the 1990 World Cup, although right up to the squad deadline he was waiting on reports of Mark Wright's fitness. Two years later, when Wright pulled out of Graham Taylor's squad for the 1992 European Championship after the deadline, England failed to get Uefa's permission to bring in Adams and he had to wait until Euro 96 to lead his country in a major tournament.

This Adams did with distinction, finally dispelling the image of Düsseldorf in 1988 when Marco van Basten turned him inside out in scoring the first of his three goals in Holland's 3-1 victory. In 1996 England avenged themselves on the Dutch with an exhilarating 4-1 win but in the quarter-finals they struggled against Spain and owed much to Adams in taking the game to penalties, where David Seaman took over.

In the 1998 World Cup Adams again provided the leadership qualities England needed and surpassed himself in St Etienne when, following the dismissal of Beckham, Hoddle's 10 men forced Argentina to extra-time and, fatefully as it turned out this time, penalties.

As far as the England captaincy goes Adams will be a bigger loss than Alan Shearer, who retired from internationals after Euro 2000. The strength of Adams was that, whether or not he was wearing the captain's armband, he effectively led the team when the going became difficult. International football coaches rarely see captaincy in the same light as their equivalents in cricket or rugby.

It would be surprising if Eriksson regards the question of who will lead his England teams as a matter of high priority and Beckham may well get the armband simply because he had it when the Swede took over.

The strongest alternative to Beckham as England captain is Tottenham's Sol Campbell. But Eriksson will be more concerned with getting the blend of experience and youth he needs after the team's stumbling start to the World Cup qualifiers, with youngsters like Liverpool's Steven Gerrard and Manchester United's Wes Brown high on his list.

With England in a state of transition but still needing to take at least seven points from World Cup matches against Finland, Albania and Greece if they are to retain a chance of reaching next year's tournament in Japan and South Korea, it is a pity that Adams has felt it necessary to stand down now. His experience would have been invaluable in helping the newer caps settle in.

Yet Adams clearly feels he still has something to give Arsenal and, had he continued his international career he might have ended up having to retire altogether. As it is, the example Adams has set in fighting alcoholism to lead his country with such distinction says everything about the strength of character England have now lost and will be fortunate to find elsewhere.

Just one thought: when Adams goes, can Seaman be far behind?

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Captain issues orders but Gunners misfire

fields.headline: Captain issues orders but Gunners misfire
fields.standfirst: David Lacey pay tribute to Tony Adams
fields.trailText: Captain issues orders but Gunners misfire.
fields.body:
Arsenal have scored one goal in their last four away games, at Carlisle in the FA Cup, which is hardly the stuff of European qualification let alone the Championship. Here Arsène Wenger's side had 21 efforts, a formidable total for a travelling team, and still could not take all the points.

It would send many a manager into a dark rage but not Wenger, because he witnesses this kind of waste week in, week out. Afterwards he issued an unusual SOS as he reflected on his team's distress. It was, he said, "the same old story".

Given the glittering reputations of Thierry Henry, Sylvain Wiltord, supported here for the last half-hour by Dennis Bergkamp, perhaps the act of simply putting the ball in the net is too mundane. There is, as Wenger conceded, too much straining for perfection. "We seem to need to score a perfect goal from a perfect pass," he said. "At the moment I would be very happy to score some scrappy goals."

If that was beneath Arsenal, it was well beyond Leicester who, despite the touch of Roberto Mancini and speed of Dean Sturridge, could not really expect the debutant strikers to score, given their severely limited service.

Peter Taylor's team lost two midfielders: Matthew Jones sent off for his second booking shortly before the interval, and Muzzy Izzet carried off, with a neck brace attached, just past the hour. Izzet was taken to hospital for precautionary x-rays and encouragingly that his injury does not appear serious.

Taylor offered little sympathy to Jones, his lunge from behind on Fredrik Ljungberg meriting a red card in itself rather than a second yellow. But Leicester's manager was justified in asking, amid so many incidents, "who's reffing the game?"

Barry Knight was almost as busy delegating his powers as making his own decisions. The referee issued Jones's second caution after strong urging by Tony Adams and on the advice of his linesman Philip Sharp, who then seemingly had the casting vote over a bizarre incident in which Knight first consulted the other linesman, John Holbrook, and then Sharp before booking Martin Keown for an alleged foul on Robbie Savage which only Holbrook could have seen.

When Knight made a critical unilateral decision, he could not be faulted. Despite the baying for a red card, even Taylor conceded the referee was correct in issuing Silvinho with yellow after hauling back Sturridge because Lee Dixon was covering as the last man. Given all this, and the seven-minute stoppage for Izzet's injury, the game should have drifted on until almost 5pm. Yet, absurdly, only six minutes were added on.

By this time Wenger had seen the long-delayed debut of his £5m Brazilian Edu last only 16 stylish minutes. The substitute went off with hamstring trouble; Highbury must wait at least another three weeks to see him.

Wenger also witnessed Wiltord hit a post, Henry do the same as well as redirecting a shot from Robert Pires only for the valiant Simon Royce to block with an outstretched foot. But the vast bulk of their finishing was woefully inaccurate.

Given their handicaps, Leicester's players greeted the stalemate as a victory, even if they did not once trouble David Seaman. So, too, did Taylor. "They showed today that they deserve the tag of The Grinders - they grind out results."

But how do the more sensitive skills of the 36-year-old Mancini fit? No problem, says Taylor. "He's a correct man and a proud professional. He hasn't come here for a jolly, he's come here to do well."

 Arsenal face a Home Office inquiry into their £1m signing of the Lithuania striker Tomas Danilevicius last month. He holds a Greek passport and is classed as an EU player. But it is claimed this document is false and, if that is proved, Arsenal could be severely disciplined.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Abbey 'deal would hit poor'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB would be able to discriminate more easily between its richest and poorest customers in the services it offers them if it takes over Abbey National, the Consumers' Association says in its submission to competition authorities.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB would be able to discriminate more easily between its richest and poorest customers in the services it offers them if it takes over Abbey National, the Consumers' Association says in its submission to competition authorities.

The CA argues in its report to the office of fair trading that any bid by Lloyds TSB for Abbey National should be referred to the competition commission for a full-scale inquiry.

The submission, obtained by the Guardian, makes clear that its concerns are based on the 29% share of current accounts Lloyds TSB would enjoy if its bid were successful. The CA concludes that competition concerns do not arise from any boost in its share of mortgages.

Despite the entrance of new players into the current account market, the CA argues that the merger would "enhance incumbent power and reduce effectiveness of smaller rivals from whom most competitive pressure has come over the last decade".

The CA dismisses the idea that undertakings from Lloyds to assuage its concerns about using current accounts as a platform from which to sell more products to customers or the difficulty customers face in moving their account to another bank would be effective.

The CA argues that the current account market is being segmented according to customers' incomes. The more attractive terms offered to better educated and more affluent internet customers are not having much "spillover" to non-internet based customers.

"In such a market increasing the market power of the largest player would further insulate that player from the effects of competition," the CA's principal policy adviser Phil Evans writes in his submission to the OFT's case officer Graham Winton. "The merger would also have the effect of affording Lloyds TSB the opportunity to more effectively segment its market and price discriminate with its customer base, as the addition of the Abbey National customers would include Cahoot, its internet-only bank."

Referring to competition theory, the CA points out that the concentration of current accounts between the big four - Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Barclays and HSBC - would rise from 74.02% to 79.27%, making it "highly concentrated".

fields.headline: The Offspring: more pop than punk
fields.standfirst:
The Offspring
NYNEX, Manchester
**
fields.trailText:
The Offspring
NYNEX, Manchester
**
fields.body:
Who wants to be a millionaire? All of The Offspring do. For years, they were just one of many underground US punk bands who barely earned enough to pay the bills for their hair dye. Then along came Nirvana, interest in punk revived and Offspring hits such as 1994's Come Out and Play carried the band to multinational independent success. Almost uniquely among punk bands, The Offspring showed no willingness to bite the hand that fed them. They signed to a major label, dumbed down, and now proffer punk-lite to one of the youngest audiences in pop, who presumably think a Sex Pistol is some form of older person's medical attachment.

The Offspring's offerings are these days dunderheaded anthems reminiscent of football songs with signature spoken sections, topped off with videos of enforced goofiness that look great on MTV.

Oddly enough, they still seem to think that they are a punk band. At their Manchester gig, there are none of the video screens associated with large arenas and, more incongruously, the stage set mocks up a garage. The Offspring still a garage band? Yeah right. They play in venues big enough to house an entire motor industry.

Borrowing mostly from US cartoon punks the Dickies, the Offspring are more pop than punk nowadays. Only daft-haired guitarist Noodles (who looks like he fell off a surfboard and woke up on the Anarchy tour) looks remotely punk rock, and the music evokes baseball stadiums rather than basements full of mohicans. Then again, some of their stupid chants are undeniably rousing, and they do provoke a triumphant explosion of the pogo - although this is actually because their massed, jumping teeny audience catapults innocent bystanders into the air.

However, years of playing fast riffs and lifting their wallets seem to be taking their toll on the band. The Offspring seem to be going through the motions. Singer Dexter mutters some appalling schmaltz about Manchester being "the best gig we've ever played" and, unforgivably, encourages the audience to laugh at a virtually naked, massively overweight roadie. After 65 minutes, they stop pretending to be a garage band and head for their hotel.

They signed to a major label, dumbed down, and now proffer punk-lite to one of the youngest audiences in pop, who presumably think a Sex Pistol is some form of older person's medical attachment. The Offspring's offerings are these days dunderheaded anthems reminiscent of football songs with signature spoken sections, topped off with videos of enforced goofiness that look great on MTV. Oddly enough, they still seem to think that they are a punk band. At their Manchester gig, there are none of the video screens associated with large arenas and, more incongruously, the stage set mocks up a garage. The Offspring still a garage band? Yeah right. They play in venues big enough to house an entire motor industry. Borrowing mostly from US cartoon punks the Dickies, the Offspring are more pop than punk nowadays. Only daft-haired guitarist Noodles (who looks like he fell off a surfboard and woke up on the Anarchy tour) looks remotely punk rock, and the music evokes baseball stadiums rather than basements full of mohicans. Then again, some of their stupid chants are undeniably rousing, and they do provoke a triumphant explosion of the pogo - although this is actually because their massed, jumping teeny audience catapults innocent bystanders into the air. However, years of playing fast riffs and lifting their wallets seem to be taking their toll on the band. The Offspring seem to be going through the motions. Singer Dexter mutters some appalling schmaltz about Manchester being "the best gig we've ever played" and, unforgivably, encourages the audience to laugh at a virtually naked, massively overweight roadie. After 65 minutes, they stop pretending to be a garage band and head for their hotel.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: How to use a scarf to prevent any unwelcome romantic attention, a gag-friendly look at the difficulties of writing a script, a love triangle with a bitter twist and Jonni Nitro, the female assassin
fields.trailText: How to use a scarf to prevent any unwelcome romantic attention, a gag-friendly look at the difficulties of writing a script, a love triangle with a bitter twist and Jonni Nitro, the female assassin
fields.body:
Romanov: Scarf Mania
(www.sundanceonlinefilmfestival.org)
Webfilm finally gets the Sundance imprimatur this week, with the world's favourite indie festival debuting an online festival alongside the Park City shenanigans. Laudably, the programmers have chosen to celebrate mostly web-specific work, injecting hefty doses of animation (including the wonderful Fishbar) and documentaries like Jennifer Arnold's The Mullet Chronicles, for a diverse mix. Dodging the grant-aided film art for once, we hit on stylish and stylised animation Romanov: Scarf Mania, which unfolds silent-film-style, with elegant off-beat intertitles, and found out what happens to the muffler-free in a city where bare necks are considered an erotic spectacle. Which whetted our appetite for Chris Lanier's weekly Romanov webcartoons on www.wildbrain.com. But will it stand a chance in the Sundance Online Audience Award stakes, we wonder? "Vote early, vote often," as they say in Dade County, Florida. (KS)
 View the film

Script Doctor
(www.atomfilms.com)

Nurse 1: "Pagecount is rising, doctor"
Nurse 2: "We're losing the adolescent audience"
Doctor: "I'm going to flashbacks - CLEAR!"

Of course it's a one-trick pony, but Adam Field's ER-inflected take on script doctoring manages to pad out the gag nicely with a stream of anxious screenwriters whose problems are diagnosed as everything from infertile writing partnerships ("Your ideas are sterile - have you considered adapting?") to a bad case of cliché. Wickedly funny for cinephiles is the final emergency in which Batman 5 goes Code Blue and the team throw everything short of Elaine May at it. Delicious stuff and not just for industry insiders and wannabes. (KS)
 View the film

Gramaglia
(Fuck Gramaglia Up)
John, a roommate of Andrea, writes her a love letter asking her to cheat on her friend and fellow roommate, Floy. The two girls share the secret and plot a humiliating revenge. All is not as it seems, as John finds out and plans an even more humiliating counter-revenge. Think of Richard Linklater's 1991 film, Slacker, add a Machiavellian twist, and you've got one of the smartest and sassiest films on the web. (SD)
 View the film

Jonni Nitro
(www.eruptor.com)
Jonni Nitro is a professional assassin, government agent and also a girl. She is the star of this superb flash animation that features real actors rendered in a menacing black and white duotone. Noirish, a bit light on plot but it looks ace. Like the Avengers only colder. (SD)
 View the film

fields.headline: Soho Theatre serves up a rich brew
fields.standfirst:
A Wedding Story
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
A Wedding Story
Soho Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
Memory is one of the key themes of modern drama. And Bryony Lavery's lyrical and tender new play, jointly presented by Sphinx Theatre Company and Birmingham Rep, tackles it on multiple levels - literally in that it deals with a mother afflicted by Alzheimer's, and metaphorically in that it suggests that our whole life is a fusion of past and present and is shaped by the virtual reality of cinema.

Set in a fog-enveloped wedding marquee, Lavery's 90-minute play presents parallel but intertwined actions. In part, it is the story of free-spirited lesbian Sally who meets the amazing Grace at a wedding and who, after an ecstatic fling, finds herself torn between independent solitude and lifelong commitment. But it is equally about the devastating impact of Alzheimer's on Sally's mother, Evelyn, and on her father, vainly trying to cope with a wife who scarcely recognises him. To add to a rich brew, Sally's brother is a California-based movie buff and the action is suffused with memories of Evelyn's favourite film, Casablanca.

What strikes one most of all is Lavery's compassionate understanding of life's erratic mixture of farce and sadness. There's a great scene where the whole family pursues the runaway Evelyn, who has just wet herself, in order to dress her in a nappy and the blue dress that symbolises her youth. Without moralising, Lavery shows the awful absurdity of life and the way age reduces us to childlike dependency. She also suggests that the tragedy of Alzheimer's is its unpredictability. One moment Evelyn treats her husband as an intrusive stranger, the next she seems to be reliving some past dinner party forever fixed in her memory.

If I have any reservation, it is that Lavery never fully establishes the causal connection between Sally's filial caring and final commitment to Grace; it seems to hinge on the idea that love has to be given "unconditionally" - but a word is a slender thread on which to hang a total change of heart. One's doubts, however, are overcome by the limpid beauty of Annie Castledine's production and Ruari Murchison's wedding-tent design - and by the quality of the acting. Jackie Clune's impish mischief as Sally is offset by the fixed intensity of Aicha Kossoko as Grace. Kika Markham's remarkable Evelyn, oscillating between vacant serenity and fury, is balanced by Andrew Hawkins's impotent concern as her husband. Even the evocation of Casablanca adds to the play's pervasive mood-music and sense of life's comic sadness.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-7478 0100.

fields.headline: Voluntary action
fields.standfirst:
The Variety Club children's charity is the spice of life for Tony Alexander. He tells Dolly Dhingra why working as a full-time volunteer keeps him sane

Work Unlimited
The inside track: Volunteering
fields.trailText: The Variety Club children's charity is the spice of life for Tony Alexander. He tells Dolly Dhingra why working as a full-time volunteer keeps him sane.
fields.body:
The shade of Tony Alexander's suntan alone shows that the 68-year-old ex-dancer and actor enjoys a good life. He admits as much. Blessed with a fabulous family and good fortune, he considers it necessary to help those less fortunate than himself.

This year may have been labelled "the year of the volunteer", but Alexander is an old hand at it. For five years he's been offering his services two days a week to the Variety Club children's charity (VCCC), which helps sick, disabled and disadvantaged kids throughout the UK.

"I have to be honest - although I'm retired, I couldn't stop at home seven days a week. I couldn't just cook, shop and clean. I'd go berserk. This gets me out of the house," he says.

Volunteering is a two-way process - in exchange for his services, Alexander not only reaps the reward of putting good karma into the world, but the work provides him with a function as well as an extended social life. "I love the people I work with. I have a great time, but at the back of my mind I know that I don't have to do it so I have a completely different attitude than I would to paid work," he says.

He refers to his job as a "glorified office boy", but admits to never using a computer. "I'm useless with mechanical things, I really am. If I try to photocopy stuff, the thing breaks down." Instead, the self-confessed technophobe "works the phones, does all the ringing around and writes letters. Actually, I do use the photocopier sometimes," he says. Over the years Alexander has had little experience of working in an office. "If office work was my life's work I think I would be doing something else. I'm far better with people than I am with a piece of paper."

It was the charity's link to showbusiness that initially drew Alexander to its doors. One of the VCCC's founding members was theatre owner John Harris, and the charity has always had close links with the arts world.

Alexander attended drama school and starred on stage and screen. He made more than 40 films during his career (including Sixty Glorious Years), and was in the first British stage version of The Wizard of Oz. Despite many a good year in fine, thespian form, he finally waved goodbye to the theatre in order to prevent himself becoming "London's oldest chorus boy".

Though the actor's life was hard work, he says his work for VCCC is harder still. He has been part of the sales team for the gold heart badges - currently being sold nationwide to raise funds. Gold Heart Day is on Valentine's Day, and because it's February, it's always cold. "Standing outside Covent Garden station selling gold hearts and freezing to death isn't funny," says Alexander. "The annoying thing is, you can sell them, but you can't ask anyone to buy them. Rattling the can is against the law, so all you can do is stand there looking like a waxwork dummy," he explains.

But for all the glamour and opportunity his own life has afforded him, one of the most magical experiences is simply getting smiles from children when they are provided with a gift or experience that they might never otherwise have had. "I know it sounds a pious thing to say, but without the work we do, these children wouldn't get to see some things. We had this big party at the seaside and I couldn't believe it - some of those children had never seen the sea and you think, 'but for the grace of god that could have been me'."

 Donations to The Variety Club: 020 7428 8100.

fields.headline: All hail the emperor of easy
fields.standfirst:
Andy Williams
Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Andy Williams
Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
It seems the world has forgiven Andy Williams for giving The Osmonds their first big break on his TV show, and has embraced him as the latest postmodern icon to be salvaged from a previous generation. Williams is no longer the crooner cast into the shade by Sinatra or Tony Bennett, he is the emperor of easy, grooved to by hipsters slurping banana daiquiris in Islington lofts.

If you judged this performance objectively, you'd have to point out that the pitch of his voice was unstable, often flailing around alarmingly in search of the right key. You might add that Andy's habit of clipping some of his best-known songs short, not least the majestic Can't Get Used To Losing You, is no way for an easy-listening icon to treat a revered back catalogue. And the dance routine by James and Cathy Taylor, while Andy went off for a breather, was like a hideous flashback to Atlantic City in 1960.

But the man has a sense of occasion. It's not often that you see a bloke accompanied by an 11-piece band dressed in matching black-and-red outfits, like staff at a garish Las Vegas casino. Dinky Andy bounces around the stage as though in search of a vaulting-horse to leap over, though at the age of 73 this wouldn't be wise. There was even a comedy interlude, where Andy showed us clips of himself in his movie I'd Rather Be Rich, with old Andy electronically inserted alongside the young Andy of 1964.

He waltzed through Our Love Is Here To Stay, and looked chipper in Call Me Irresponsible. Days of Wine and Roses and Moon River were heard fleetingly, and if Williams has no more chance than anybody else of making sense of Jimmy Webb's lyrics to MacArthur Park, he managed to hit some impressive high notes. Advancing boldly into the late 20th century, he made a decent stab at Every Breath You Take, and managed a moderately majestic Desperado. We will never see his like again, or so the publicity says.

 At Southend Cliffs Pavilion (01702 351135), tonight; Fairfield Hall, Croydon (020-8688 9291), tomorrow; Anvil, Basingstoke, Wednesday (01256 844244); then tours.

fields.headline: Head to head
fields.standfirst:
Ask a PA about what her job entails and her hours. Then ask her boss. Their answers will be poles apart, says a new survey. Kate Hilpern reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ask a PA about what her job entails and her hours. Then ask her boss. Their answers will be poles apart, says a new survey. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
Suppose you knocked on the door of your manager's office right now and said, "Look, I'm sorry to interrupt, but I was just wondering how much overtime you reckon I do a week? And while we're at it, how satisfied do you think I am with my job and, for that matter, the training I get here? And do you know how qualified I am?" Think the answers would be anywhere near the truth? Not likely. At least, that's the message from a major survey published today by recruitment consultancy Gordon Yates in association with the Guardian.

"We asked secretaries these very questions about themselves. We then asked their bosses for their view. We got vastly different replies. Employers, we discovered, underestimate the workload and educational level of their secretaries while overestimating how contented they are," explains Jo Tomazou, managing director of Gordon Yates.

Against today's background of high demand for secretaries, the implications are immense, she believes. "A staggering 37% of companies admit it's becoming harder to recruit and retain skilled support staff. This study may provide the reasons why."

Least surprising to support staff will be the result that almost half work more than 40 hours a week. "The average UK employee works seven hours a week for nothing," confirms another new survey by the TUC. But bosses estimate the proportion at just a quarter. "I knew subconsciously that my PA was working until 7pm most evenings because I'd say goodbye to her when she left," admits Luke, a manager of an insurance firm. "But because I worked those hours as a matter of course, I hadn't really taken it in consciously that, for her, that constituted overtime."

Secretaries work far harder than their bosses realise, concludes the study, which reveals even more worrying discrepancies when it comes to job satisfaction.

"Fifteen per cent of bosses believe their secretaries are more satisfied with their job than they were last year. Secretaries disagree. Eleven per cent say they find their role less fulfilling," it reports. This, found Tomazou, is generally down to lack of recognition, increased responsibility and the stress of constant change - whether it's constituted by new technology or a company takeover.

Likewise, support staff are revealed to be far less enthusiastic about the level of training and development they get than their employ ers. "I get sent on an annual two-day course to update my IT skills. Yet my employers consider themselves 'committed to the development of our staff'. It's a joke," laments Kate, a PA at a small City firm. Kate doubts her manager even knows she's a graduate, a claim that the study also shows is not uncommon, with employers estimating that a quarter of their secretaries hold a degree whereas the actual figure is closer to half.

"It is reasonable to assume that the higher qualified and trained the secretary, the more likelihood of a salary rise or promotion," says careers adviser Jane Scott. "So it is reasonable to assume from this report that secretaries are missing out on deserved rewards. Coupled with the resentment and frustration they must feel as a result of being overlooked in other areas, I'm not a bit surprised companies are experiencing a higher turnover rate of support staff than ever."

Carmel Steiner, divisional director for recruitment consultancy Angela Mortimer, has found that disparity between the views of bosses and their secretaries is most likely to occur in companies where "secretary" is still perceived in the traditional sense. "Some sectors - particularly those dominated by 'old-school' men - still consider secretaries in that old-fash ioned letter-taking kind of way. In other words, that they don't do much else," she explains.

Paul Jacobs, communications director at recruitment agency Office Angels, believes one solution lies is changing the term "secretary". "Fifty per cent of today's secretaries manage their own projects and 71% have sole control for budgets averaging £30,000," he says. "This massive increase in responsibility is the very reason that we now call top secretaries 'executaries'. It's a term that reflects this increase and encourages bosses to recognise it."

Indeed, one recent survey from Office Angels found that whether people are called secretaries or executaries, the roles are very often identical. The difference is that the latter are more likely to have bosses who appreciate their worth.

Steiner agrees that recruitment agencies have a role to play in educating bosses. "We make a point of visiting them to explain that they'll have to change old-fashioned mentalities if they want to keep good staff," she says.

But secretaries seeking recognition must also help themselves, insists Jacobs. "If there's an appraisal system in place, it's worth taking advantage of the annual review to make your boss aware of your main areas of responsibility and achievements over the previous year, requesting training, promotion and a salary increase where appropriate. It's a good idea to find out what you're worth in the marketplace by looking at advertisements for similar positions so that you can provide evidence of what you could be earning. It's also a good idea to be able to justify the reasons you want training or promotion, spelling out the added value you feel you'll be able to give your boss and company."

If there isn't an appraisal system in place, call a meeting anyway, advises Jacobs. " Bosses rarely just wake up one morning and think, 'Wow, my secretary really does work hard and I'm going to reward that.' You need to help them see it."

In other words, that they don't do much else," she explains. Paul Jacobs, communications director at recruitment agency Office Angels, believes one solution lies is changing the term "secretary". "Fifty per cent of today's secretaries manage their own projects and 71% have sole control for budgets averaging £30,000," he says. "This massive increase in responsibility is the very reason that we now call top secretaries 'executaries'. It's a term that reflects this increase and encourages bosses to recognise it." Indeed, one recent survey from Office Angels found that whether people are called secretaries or executaries, the roles are very often identical. The difference is that the latter are more likely to have bosses who appreciate their worth. Steiner agrees that recruitment agencies have a role to play in educating bosses. "We make a point of visiting them to explain that they'll have to change old-fashioned mentalities if they want to keep good staff," she says. But secretaries seeking recognition must also help themselves, insists Jacobs. "If there's an appraisal system in place, it's worth taking advantage of the annual review to make your boss aware of your main areas of responsibility and achievements over the previous year, requesting training, promotion and a salary increase where appropriate. It's a good idea to find out what you're worth in the marketplace by looking at advertisements for similar positions so that you can provide evidence of what you could be earning. It's also a good idea to be able to justify the reasons you want training or promotion, spelling out the added value you feel you'll be able to give your boss and company." If there isn't an appraisal system in place, call a meeting anyway, advises Jacobs. " Bosses rarely just wake up one morning and think, 'Wow, my secretary really does work hard and I'm going to reward that.' You need to help them see it."

fields.headline: Memos and masterpieces
fields.standfirst:
What could an artist or playwright do for your workplace? Ian Boughton finds out

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: What could an artist or playwright do for your workplace? Ian Boughton finds out.
fields.body:
At the building society, customers are puzzled to find themselves the subject of attention from an artist with an easel in the corner. At a council office, staff are intrigued to be offered the help of a multimedia artist to "express themselves artistically, emotionally, psychologically and stylistically, within the confines of their screensaver".

It sounds like a stunt the Tate Modern might pull, but in fact it is part of a £5m campaign, funded by the lottery, in which a thousand creative types, working in media from painting and sculpture to film, drama and "digital art", are seconded to British offices and factories. Any number of office workers may now find themselves looking into the lens of a video camera, or being questioned by a scriptwriter or poet about their motivation for going to the coffee-machine.

The artist in the workplace is with us to show us a fresh perspective on how we all work. "The image of the artist isolated in a studio is the view of the average person who hasn't thought of the artist's role in society," explains Tamara Krikorian of Cywaith Cymru, the organisation that is sending artists into Welsh workplaces.

"Artists encourage creativity in other people - the idea of the artist in the workplace is to trigger new ideas and unleash creative energies," adds Krikorian.

Elaine Pantling is working in a tights factory in Blaby, collecting material for Gusset, a play to be performed on the shopfloor, which will "show how the relationship between the artist and the hosiery worker is cut, divided, and sewn together".

In Colchester, where the council staff's restaurant was once a library, artist Bob Jaroc is "taking people's impressions of the link between food and books, and turning it into a video".

Meanwhile, at the Newcastle Building Society, manager John McCabe has become used to seeing Lionel Playford setting up his easel in the middle of business. "People wondered what on earth an artist could bring to an office - but we're glad we did it," says Playford.

McCabe agrees. "The tangible benefit is already there, in his work on the walls brightening up the offices, but the intangible benefit has been in morale. Most people have never known the enjoyment of being painted," he says.

At the pharmaceutical company Pfizer, in Kent, human resources director Martin Ferber is demonstrating the work-life balance by bringing drama into his research division, with actors in the workplace to write a play on subjects suggested by the staff.

"It's an act of faith in bringing together artists and scientists - two kinds who would never normally meet. Although our researchers are creative, they are also constrained by science. This will show that the daily stress can be countered by other stimulation, and remind us that anything which stimulates creativity can be important to us," says Ferber.

At Essex county council, manager Steve Downey is offering staff psychological screensavers from digital artist Gail Pearce. "The idea is to personalise inanimate computers in a way that says something about the person - they relate their interests, or hobbies, and she helps them put it on the screen. One of our people, a strong family person interested in horticulture, now has pictures of her family growing like flowers in slow motion," says Downey.

The result, he continues, is a rede finition of our perception of art and the artist. "People have strange ideas about artists - they think of Van Gogh, madmen, and dead sheep. All these projects around the country will touch millions of people who have never met an artist before - this will combat the stereotypes of the artist's place in society."

But there is a more down-to-earth benefit, says David Smallridge, whose Chasestead staff bash metal into prototypes for car designers. "We're an old-fashioned skills factory, not used to messing about with art. But we're under tremendous pressure from competitors all over the world, to the point where we've only got our creativity left to stand out with.

"When I deliberately left space for a sculpture park in the middle of our factory, and the artist came in, the workforce thought I'd gone bananas. But we made sculptures out of scrap metal and won the Art at Work award for Hertfordshire," says Smallridge. "The big benefit was getting employees to think laterally, and showing that we have imagination is what now stands us apart from our competitors."

And if that tack fails, art at work may provide his commercial alternative. "For the Academy of Chief Executives, I made the annual awards out of scrap - and now everyone's coming to us asking for them. If I didn't have to concentrate on cars, I'd be happy to go down that road!"

fields.headline: Medeski Martin & Wood
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
"Mixing" can mean all manner of things: the final mix of a CD; the deliberate transformation of sound in dub; simply cross-fading discs on a turntable. Yet in performed music the mix is made by the musicians, who listen and instinctively adjust their dynamics to each other. Medeski Martin & Wood have this down to a fine art. They are a "power trio" whose power doesn't rely on volume. So it was unfortunate that MMW were lumbered with a huge and wholly inappropriate PA system that obscured rather than reinforced what they produce so naturally - a subtle ensemble sound honed over years of playing small clubs and colleges.

This is a band who could rock your house party without waking the neighbours, something they proved on the encore number Swamp Road, which ended as a purely acoustic jam: Chris Wood on unamplified double bass, Medeski blowing a Melodica (through a long white hosepipe inserted in the mouthpiece) and Billy Martin on hand-held percussion. It was a great end to a concert that featured most aspects of MMW's collective genius: the sneaky, New Orleans-style grooves of Chubb Sub and Big Time (from their latest album, The Dropper), and the disciplined and abandoned "new thing" of Hermeto's Daydream.

Cover versions included a wonderful Duke Ellington blues and Third Stone From The Sun (by Jimi Hendrix). There was plenty of solo and collective improvisation to join everything together. They don't announce numbers or make any movements other than those necessary to play the music, but they are the most communicative and enthralling band to watch and hear.

Martin's grooves are the magic ingredient. When he kicks into a familiar drum pattern the hardcore fans - hairy guys in their 20s who know all the songs - leap to their feet to dance. A slim girl, dancing in silhouette by the door light, unwittingly re-created Maurice Binder's famous titles for Dr No. And yes, there is a touch of 1960s nostalgia in MMW's commercial appeal. Comforting memories of Booker T and the MGs are invoked by the way they top a soulful rhythm section with a Hammond organ lead: Medeski's Note Bleu is a clever reinvention of this style. But at least they have chosen some good bits to recycle - Mingus, free jazz and funk beat the "hippies, drugs and Radio 1" version of the 60s any day.

Theirs is vital and inspiring music - it's a tribute to the musicians that we were still able to enjoy most of what they were doing, despite that bass-heavy PA system. It would be great to hear MMW do residencies at some British clubs where they can get the sound right and preach to more than the converted. A five-star gig, with one star deducted for the sound.

fields.headline: Orfeo ed Euridice
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
*****
fields.trailText:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
*****
fields.body:
Haydn is held up as the father of the symphony and of the string quartet. He also fathered at least 25 operas, but popular histories hardly ever mention them - as though they were wild oats, best not discussed in polite company. Received opinion rarely goes further than remarking that Haydn wasn't as good an opera composer as his younger contemporary Mozart. But that's rather like saying that someone isn't as good a poet as Shakespeare.

Haydn's last opera, Orfeo ed Eurydice, or L'anima del filosofo (the spirit of philosophy) had a rare outing in a concert performance with the Academy of Ancient Music, conducted by Christopher Hogwood, on Saturday - the only UK stop on its current European tour. Received opinion survived the trial - but only just.

On the evidence of this performance, Haydn certainly had his limitations as an opera composer. Pace flags; the libretto rambles. And yet Orfeo is full of sharply memorable things - vivid choral writing and at least one great aria - the Sibyl's brilliant Al tuo seno fortunato in act three. No less astonishing is the ending. It isn't simply that Haydn defies convention and ends the opera quietly: the Bacchantes' chilling cries of terror simply evaporate into a low drum-roll and a few muted gasps of D minor. Even Mozart would have been proud of that.

Christopher Hogwood's enthusiasm for Haydn was obvious. In places where the pace might have sagged fatally, Hogwood kept up the momentum. The playing of the Academy of Ancient Music was alert, clear, muscular and supple. An advantage of period instruments is that the players don't have to rein themselves in: 18th-century trumpets, trombones and drums can blare and pound to their hearts' delight without fear of swamping the voices.

The voices were well worth hearing. Albert Schagidullin created a noble, impassioned human being out of Euridice's father, King Creonte - his aria of vengeance, Alla vendetta!, with its surging strings and scintillating brass fanfares, made a thrilling finale for act two. As Orfeo, Raul Giminez was elegant and sweet-toned. But the star of the evening was - as it had to be - Cecilia Bartoli in the dual role as Euridice and the Sybil. In itself, Bartoli's voice isn't especially powerful: it was her agility, searing expression and strikingly natural musicality that made this a great performance. The rapturous applause at the end of Al tuo seno fortunato was thoroughly deserved.

fields.headline: The inside track
fields.standfirst:
Volunteering

Work Unlimited
Voluntary action
fields.trailText: Volunteering
fields.body:
'People tend to associate volunteer with the word amateur," says a spokesman for Community Service Volunteers (CSV), one of the UK's largest agencies for linking up voluntary workers with good causes. But volunteering is about donating skills as well as time. Admin skills are universally in demand, according to the CSV, "because many organisations cannot afford to pay for them". And the voluntary sector is an excellent place to acquire skills as well as donate them.

Volunteering is also commonly association with retiring. But voluntary work is creeping into the workplace as employers are given opportunities to do community service through their employer.

As well as benefiting the local community, there is something in it for the employer, too. Voluntary schemes are a recognised means of developing "soft skills", such as communication and team-working. A community project can give people the opportunity to stretch themselves which may not be afforded by their current job.

And it's fun too. A survey by the National Council for Volunteering found that volunteer work was the second biggest source of public enjoyment after dancing. And it is widespread - the council estimates there are 22m active volunteers.

If you don't have the opportunity to volunteer at work, a government sponsored website, Do-It, runs a search engine that matches individuals with organisations which need volunteers. There are more than 200,000 jobs going, matched according to your interests, skills, location and the time you have available. For those who can't make a regular commitment, the CSV runs one-off community projects, known as GO weekends, in London and Manchester.

The National Council for Volunteering estimates that the value of work performed by volunteers is about £40m. So it's big business - or it would be if anyone earned money out of it.

fields.headline: Studs
fields.standfirst:
Hull Truck Theatre
***
fields.trailText:
Hull Truck Theatre
***
fields.body:
Sport on stage, broad humour, fortified language - must be John Godber, right? Wrong. The main man at Hull Truck seems to have shifted away from these themes of late; but before drifting off into a haze of almost Chekhovian mellowness he has taken the precaution of cloning a version of his former self.

Gordon Steel, whose previous two plays, Dead Fish and Like a Virgin, also successfully premiered at Hull Truck, is to John Godber what football is to rugby - they play to slightly different codes, but both are essentially about big blokes fired up by their balls.

Studs is the association rules version of Up and Under, Steel being an ex-Sunday morning player as opposed to Godber, who has a background in rugby league. Sunday league has a mud-encrusted, gladiatorial aspect to it, but Steel recalls the changing-room atmosphere of stale breath, lineament and shin-guards with wistful fondness.

Strong in language, weak in plot, Studs is a play of two halves. The first is a bit of a scramble to boot as many belly-laughs into the audience as possible; the second a slower, more tactical attempt to engage their emotions. The result, I'd say, is a draw.

Like Godber, Steel gathers a group of stereotypes and revels in the comic business of bashing their egos together until everyone comes out bruised or injured. What Steel doesn't really offer is a wider context for the slapstick. Up and Under was a investigation of male aggression in a climate of limited opportunity. Studs is about a bunch of blokes in a lean- to, belching and discussing their poo. Perhaps this signifies the Beckettian futility of Sunday league football, but in truth the action never digs far beneath the playing surface.

Steel, who also directs, brings out some terrific performances, however. Outstanding is Trevor Fox as Mac, a great, steaming tank of testosterone whose transformation from hard as nails to soft as putty occurs at the moment he recognises his girlfriend (a vulnerable Caroline Wardell) as a person rather than a sex object, by which time it is too late. Joe Caffrey matches him well as the terminally indecisive Tommo. Michael Hodges is excellent as the acerbic team manager, sour as a half-time lemon, while Jill Halfpenny does well with the thankless business of a life spent on the touchline. The beautiful game? Pele ought to see this and think again.

 Until February 3. Box office: 01482 323638.
